HEADLINE: Map of All Chromosomes To Guide Genetic Hunters

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER

 BODY:
Scientists have roughed out the first comprehensive map of all human chromosomes, a feat considered one of the high hurdles of the ambitious and expensive international effort to parse the complete genetic blueprint for a human being.
The map should sharply accelerate scientists' efforts to isolate the 100,000 genes that make up human DNA, to track down mutations that result in disease, to trace the evolution of humanity as recorded by subtle runes inscribed in the genes and to solve other grand puzzles of biology. Those efforts are all part of the Human Genome Project, a 15-year program now under way at dozens of laboratories in the United States and abroad.
 
Flaws Are Conceded
 The new map, called a physical map, is still preliminary, and the researchers who generated it concede that it has many flaws. Nevertheless, the effort is considered a significant stride forward. Although scientists have been analyzing the chromosomes in piecemeal fashion for years, the map is the first effort to give an overview of the 23 pairs of chromosomes.
 
Yeast Cells and Lists
 "It's not perfect, and I don't want anybody to think I'm saying it's perfect," said Dr. Daniel Cohen, a molecular biologist at the Centre d'Etude du Polymorphisme Humain in Paris who helped devise the map. "As with all maps, it needs to be refined. "But best is an enemy of good, and good things, even if they're imperfect, are very useful." 
 Dr. Cohen, who called the physical map "an important milestone," headed a team of French scientists reporting on their generation of the map today in the journal Nature.
"I think it's kind of great," said Dr. Kathleen Gardiner, a molecular biologist at the Eleanor Roosevelt Institute in Denver who has worked on mapping several human chromosomes. "There are a lot of resources here that will be useful to a large number of investigators."
The new compilation does not resemble a standard map. It consists of two elements: large collections of yeast cells growing on laboratory dishes, each cell enfolding a particular segment of a human chromosome, and lists of 2,000 genetic markers, precise descriptions of biochemical patterns found on the different chromosomal chunks.
The markers serve as road signs, giving sense and direction to the otherwise inscrutable monotony of human DNA. They indicate how the segments would be aligned in the heart of the human cell, and they spell out the distance between road signs.
Dr. Cohen said he would give out information about the markers over electronic mail to any interested scientist. Researchers can also call one of 10 central laboratories in the United States, or others overseas, to request any of the 33,000 chromosomal segments, or clones, which will be sent in test tubes and kept fresh on dry ice.
"You can call and say, 'I need this and this clone,' and you'll get it in two days," he said. Each clone harbors about a million bases, or chemical subunits of DNA, a stretch that may represent hundreds of individual genes.
With clones and markers in hand, researchers can cut their search for individual genes by months or years, Dr. Cohen said.
Confirming the utility of the map, Dr. Gardiner said after reading the new report that she was planning to contact Dr. Cohen immediately to get marker information about a particular region of chromosome 3, where a gene linked to leukemia is thought to lie.
 
Making Life Easier
 Dr. Francis S. Collins, director of the National Center for Human Genome Research in Bethesda, Md., who leads the American part of the genome effort, said of the map, "If it's as good as it appears to be, it will certainly make the life of the gene hunter easier than it used to be."
But, lest anybody on Congressional budget committees or elsewhere think the mapping effort of the genome project is done, he added, "This is not the end, but the beginning, or maybe the middle point."
Comparing the struggle to make a complete physical map of the chromosomes to the effort to build a national highway system, Dr. Collins said: "What we have now is the road system of about 1850. You can get from one place to another but you may find it pretty hard slogging sometimes, and on occasion you may have to get out of your wagon and walk."
Dr. Maynard V. Olson, a professor of molecular biotechnology at the University of Washington in Seattle who helped invent the yeast-based technology that the French team relied on for their mapping, said: "One thing I like about Daniel's go-for-broke attitude is that it will encourage more of the same. I think this sort of attitude will be required to move on to more detailed maps."
 
Mapping a Slippery Target
 Scientists emphasize that the new map by no means guarantees that every quest for human genes will be smooth. Indeed, some argued that having a physical map is only a small part of the difficulty of isolating genes. They said that for years scientists had an excellent physical map of the region of chromosome 17 thought to harbor an important breast cancer gene, but that six major laboratories were still struggling to home in on the gene itself.
However, the breast cancer gene is thought to be an unusually slippery target. For the capture of most genes, Dr. Olson predicted, the map will prove very useful. He also said small and less amply endowed laboratories would probably benefit more from the new report than would large scientific groups able to whip up their own cloned segments within a matter of weeks.
Using the same highway analogy that Dr. Collins used, he said: "An interstate highway stimulates economic activity tremendously by making it possible for small businesses to move goods without having to own a railroad at the same time. Having a biological infrastructure like a physical map makes it possible for smaller and more diverse labs to tackle the isolation of important genes."
Beyond creating maps and identifying genes, scientists in the genome business hope soon to begin spelling out, or sequencing, all three billion chemical letters that make up human DNA. That task, the most daunting element of the genome project, is not likely to be completed before the turn of the century.

HEADLINE: Rebuking Aide, U.S. Says Haiti Policy Stands

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Rebuking its top human rights official, the Clinton Administration said today that it had no intention of changing its policy of returning Haitian boat people without granting them a chance to seek political asylum.
"There is no change in Administration policy on that question," Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, said today. 
 State Department and White House officials reportedly were incensed by the comments by John Shattuck, Assistant Secretary for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, who suggested on Tuesday that the Administration's policy on Haitian boat people should be re-evaluated. The policy has drawn sharp criticism from human rights groups, which say it violates international treaties on the handling of refugees.
On a visit to Haiti, Mr. Shattuck told reporters that he was returning to Washington "with a view that a policy review is necessary."
But White House and State Department officials were quick to say that Mr. Shattuck's comments did not reflect Administration thinking, and that Mr. Shattuck was given a stern dressing down this morning by Peter Tarnoff, the Under Secretary for Political Affairs and the second highest ranking official in the State Department.
"It was completely wrong and outrageous and there is enormous anger in the White House and the State Department about his alleged statement," said one State Department official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. "That is not the policy. There will be no review. It was a completely rogue statement."
Mr. Shattuck has told State Department officials that the article misquoted him, but according to several State Department officials who asked not to be quoted by name, "nobody believes that." In private conversations with friends, Mr. Shattuck and other Administration officials have expressed disquiet over the policy, which has remained in place for nearly a year even though there has been no discernable progress in restoring democracy to Haiti.
Mr. Shattuck did not return telephone calls seeking his comments today.
The confusion over American policy toward Haitian boat people comes at a time when the number of people trying to flee the beleaguered country is rising sharply. Since the country's military leaders refused to allow the return of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, as scheduled on Oct. 30 and since the imposition of an economic blockade by the United Nations, the number of Haitians applying for asylum at the three American processing centers in Haiti has risen sharply.
The Coast Guard reported today that it had so far picked up 220 Haitians trying to flee the island in boats in December. That is a large jump from the 60 caught at sea in November. But it remains a long way from the 1,363 Haitians who were picked up last January, before Mr. Clinton reversed a campaign pledge and directed the Coast Guard to pick up and forcibly return Haitians trying to escape the political repression and economic chaos in their country.
The reiteration of the President's policy regarding Haitian refugees came as Robert Malval, the Prime Minister appointed by Father Aristide, said that because of a lack of support he was canceling a new round of talks among representatives of a cross section of Haitian society aimed at resolving the country's political crisis.
Administration officials said that at a meeting in Paris on Monday, Mr. Malval told envoys from the United States, France, Canada and Venezuela that Father Aristide had withdrawn his support for the talks. Representatives of the four countries are scheduled to meet next week with Father Aristide in an attempt to persuade him to back the Malval-initiated talks, one official said.
Mr. Malval's resignation as Prime Minister technically becomes effective today. But he has said he will remain in office until a successor is named and ratified by the Haitian Parliament.

HEADLINE: Makers of Anti-Personnel Mines Are Urged by U.S. to Ban Exports

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has asked more than 40 countries that produce land mines to ban exports of anti-personnel mines for three to five years, senior American officials said today.
The Administration, which wrote to the governments on Dec. 7, has also told them that it wants a new agreement to stop the spread of mines. The accord would be based on an existing agreement, the Missile Technology Control Regime, intended to limit the spread of missile technology. 
 Congress has agreed to extend a one-year ban on United States mine exports for three years, and the United Nations General Assembly is expected to give unanimous support to a nonbinding resolution calling for a global moratorium on such exports.
There are already 80 million to 100 million land mines sown around the world.
 
The Main Sources
 The General Assembly has already adopted a European-sponsored resolution calling on all aid and development agencies to include mine-clearing in their work and asking the Secretary General to consider a fund to finance such work.
The countries the Administration is pressing for a moratorium include China, Italy and the former Soviet republics, which some officials say are probably the biggest mine exporters, as well as Brazil, Argentina, North and South Korea and the East European countries.
United States officials have set an initial goal of ending trade in anti-personnel mines rather than anti-tank and ship mines in order to ease resistance from some defense ministries and arms makers.
But they also argue that the inexpensive devices, which are hard to detect, are often scattered indiscriminately in areas where they become a major threat to civilians, complicating the task of furnishing aid to war victims and hindering the return of refugees.
 
A Dangerous Randomness
 According to a State Department report last summer, the use of mines has changed in recent decades in ways that make them a major threat to civilians.
In contrast with World War II, when both sides laid "rigorously mapped minfields," the report said: "Mines are now generally laid without maps in areas designed to protect economic targets or to instill fear in opposition soldiers and civilians. Unfortunately, in this terror style of mine warfare, it is the civilians who suffer the most."
Afghanistan remains the most heavily mined country, with 9 million to 10 million mines -- and possibly as many as 35 million -- unaccounted for. Between 5 million and 10 million mines are thought to be planted in Angola, a similar number in Iraq, and four million to seven million in Cambodia, or one for every two inhabitants.
Cambodia's 12-year-old civil war is thought to be the first in which more people have been killed by mines than by any other weapon. This has left Cambodia with the world's highest percentage of disabled people: one Cambodian out of every 236 has lost a limb.
Mozambique, Somalia, Western Sahara and Bosnia and Herzegovina are each thought to have one million to two million mines, the report said.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD TRADE AGREEMENT: The Negotiators;
Odd Couple Bring a World Trade Accord Home

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 15

 BODY:
One is portly, one is slim. One is subtle, the other blunt. One is a committed free trader and a one-time protege of Margaret Thatcher; the other is a Los Angeles lawyer, willing to argue almost any position, who started in politics as an advocate of the dispossessed.
But to an extraordinary extent, today's global trade pact is the product of the unusual friendship between Sir Leon Brittan, the Englishman who represented the European Community, and Mickey Kantor, who represented the United States.
 
Frosty at First
 When they met 10 months ago, their relationship was frosty. That is not surprising, since one is the product of Cambridge University and Britain's traditionally aristocratic Tory Party and the other, folksier in style, started life in America's country-music capital, Nashville, and made his name as a wheeling-and-dealing entertainment lawyer. 
 Sir Leon delights in the rituals and perquisites of international negotiations. Mr. Kantor often travels tieless across the Atlantic in tourist class, lugging a bag over his shoulder.
Months of close work, however, have turned suspicion to trust, they and their aides say. The two men abandoned the usual practice of holding meetings with legions of assistants. Instead, they would meet with one another for hours at a time, relying heavily on their memories instead of their aides. Their confidence in each other grew and in time, they began to compare notes about the political and lobbying pressures they faced at home, finding they had more in common than they realized.
In the end, they could seal with handshakes a succession of trillion-dollar trade deals.
"I found we could do a lot just one-on-one -- there were things said in private, just to each other, that really helped, particularly in difficult moments," Mr. Kantor said here today.
For his part, Sir Leon learned to face Mr. Kantor's table-thumping negotiating style with equanimity.
"I would just quietly say, 'Look, where is this going to get us,' and he changed," Sir Leon said in a telephone interview tonight from his home in Brussels. "I know various American styles," Sir Leon, who also studied at Yale University, said. "It doesn't faze me."
Aides say the friendship between Sir Leon and Mr. Kantor eased the tension of negotiating sessions that ran as long as 22 hours, and made a real difference in enabling compromises on several occasions.
Early Tuesday morning, for instance, Sir Leon had to decide whether to yield to American insistence that the issue of greater access to Europe for American films and TV programs should be dropped from the agreement. Such a step would preserve the United States' ability to impose trade penalties against Europe, particularly the French.
Sir Leon pondered the issue as he stared out of his limousine after leaving the American trade mission's conference room. Finally, according to an aide in the car, Sir Leon slapped his thighs with both hands and said "Yes" aloud to himself, realizing that he knew Mr. Kantor well enough to recognize that further discussion would be hopeless.
"He knew he had reached the American bottom line," the aide said.
 
Ardent Free Trader
 Sir Leon, who is 54, was a protege of former Prime Minister Thatcher of Britain until his free-trade instincts led him to support a politically unpopular plan for the British Government to buy helicopters from an American, not British, manufacturer. As the European Community's commissioner for industrial competition policies in the late 1980's, he enraged the French by challenging their subsidies to state-run industries as unprincipled meddling with market forces.
By contrast, Mr. Kantor, who is also 54, is contemptuous of economic ideologies, and has less worldly interests. He has preferred to vacation in Hawaii and had never even been to Asia before taking the trade job.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The World Trade Agreement
Seven years of world trade negotiations were completed under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. [Page D1.] Hollywood executives expressed disappointment that a clause ending export restrictions to Europe was not included. [D1.]
The trade pact is the product of an unusual friendship between the chief European and U.S. negotiators. [D8.] President Clinton immediately began pushing for Congressional approval. [D8.] 
 A phone call from President Clinton to U.S. trade representative Mickey Kantor was the turning point in the talks. [D9.]
 
Companies
United Airlines and its pilots and machinists unions agreed on a proposal valued at more than $5 billion for the unions to buy at least 53 percent of the airline. The plan to create the largest employee-owned airline will be presented to United's board today. [D1.]
Kodak's new chairman said 1994 earnings would be well below expectations. The news sent the company's stock down 11 percent and depressed the Dow Jones industrial average. [D1.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Proposes to Divert Fresh Water To Restore Damaged California Delta

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15

 BODY:
In a concerted action without parallel, four Federal agencies moved today to reverse the long-term environmental destruction of San Francisco Bay and the Sacramento Delta, the vast estuary that is the lifeblood of California.
The agencies, which rarely cooperate, entered one of the most politically charged issues in California by proposing new water quality standards for the estuary. If adopted, they would require that substantial amounts of fresh water be diverted away from cities and farms, particularly in dry years. 
 By stepping in under the authority of the Federal Clean Water Act and the Endangered Species Act, the agencies are trying to resolve what had become an intractable environmental problem. Fifteen years of political paralysis have brought several fish species to the brink of extinction in the Sacramento Delta and have threatened the quality of drinking water as increasingly larger amounts of water have been siphoned off to slake the thirst of farms and fast-growing cities.
 
Vital Agricultural Area
 The delta harbors more than 120 species of fish and is the source of drinking water for 20 million people. It also irrigates 200 different crops, including 45 percent of the nation's fruits and vegetables.
The environmental damage is caused by saline water from the Pacific Ocean that backs up through the 1,600-square-mile estuary, which extends east from San Francisco Bay nearly to Sacramento.
Fresh water that would hold back the salt water is carried by aqueducts hundreds of miles south to Los Angeles and other cities, and to farms in the Central Valley, the state's main agricultural area that extends for more than 400 miles between the Sierra Nevada and Coast Ranges. The delta provides two-thirds of all the water used in California.
The big question now is whether the state will cooperate and help shape and carry out the new rules, or continue to fight and let the Federal agencies and courts impose a solution.
While Federal action has been pending for years, Clinton Administration officials compelled the disparate agencies to cooperate to minimize the economic impact of the action, saying they could reduce the amount of water needed in the delta by using it to meet several different environmental objectives at the same time.
And the officials extended a conciliatory hand to Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a Republican who last April scuttled years of state efforts to rescue the delta on the ground that planning was impossible because of the threat of fragmented Federal action under different laws.
"This is an unprecedented proposal by four Federal agencies to work with the state to end the gridlock in water policy in California," said Felicia Marcus, the regional administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, adding that the Government was open to modifying today's proposal.
The proposal, which goes into effect after a 90-day period for public comment, would set minimum salinity standards for Suisun Bay, a crucial fish hatchery area northeast of San Francisco, and reduce salinity elsewhere to protect migrating Chinook salmon and the spawning areas of striped bass.
As part of the plan, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service proposed to designate the Sacramento splittail, a 12-inch fish of the minnow family, as threatened and changed the status of the winter-run Chinook salmon on the Sacramento River from threatened to endangered, a more serious designation. It also reaffirmed its designation of the Delta smelt as threatened.
 
Additional Fresh Water
 The Government estimated that the rules would require an average of 500,000 acre feet of additional fresh water in the delta a year, and as much as 1.1 million during extended droughts. On average, this is about 7 percent of the water drawn from the delta. An acre foot is about 326,000 gallons, or enough water for two typical households for a year.
Farm interests were dubious, saying the plan would require considerably more water.
Pressure on the delta has eased in the last year with the end of a six-year drought in the Far West. Even so, only 40 percent of the delta's historic water flow remains, and the salinity has threatened not only fish and the commercial fishing industry, but also local drinking water supplies.
San Francisco gets its water from the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir in Yosemite National Park, and is not directly dependent on water from the delta, but most of its suburbs gets its water from the delta.
After the state killed its plan last April, 16 environmental groups sued the E.P.A. for failing to enforce the Clean Water Act. Under a settlement negotiated by the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund, the Government agreed to issue proposed rules by today.
 
Reaction Is MixedOther Agencies Listed
 The other Federal agencies are the Fish and Wildlife Service, the National Marine Fisheries Service and the Bureau of Reclamation, which operates the Central Valley Project, the largest irrigation project in the state.
Reaction to the action was predictably mixed.
Environmentalists hailed it as a milestone. "The Federal Government said today that the environment can no longer be ignored," said David Behar, executive director of the Bay Institute of San Francisco, an advocacy group. "The key question is will the state now get off the dime and work toward a solution that meets both environmental and water supply needs."
In a statement, Governor Wilson criticized the standards but also offered to negotiate with the Administration. He said the standards would "thoughtlessly cost California jobs," and accused the Federal agencies of grossly underestimating how much water would be needed to meet the standards. But he said he hoped to reach an agreement that would reconcile "the economic and environmental dependencies on the bay-delta."
For many farmers, the action today was viewed as yet another blow after years of water cutbacks. This year, 90,000 acres remained fallow because of water diverted for environmental reasons.
 
Delta Issue Unites Cities
 "There have been several foreclosures this year, and they are primarily tied to water issues," said Don Upton, a spokesman for the Westlands Water District in the Central Valley.
Urban interests were more equivocal. The delta issue has, for the first time, united cities in Northern and Southern California, long divided over water. The state's largest district is the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, which depends on the delta for 30 percent of the water that is supplied to 16 million people.
Duane L. Georgeson, assistant general manager of the district, said the proposal was a source of "serious concern" over the amount of water that might be lost. But he said he had been given assurances by Elizabeth Rieke, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, that the Clinton Administration was open to compromises to reduce the economic impact.
The Federal action came two days after another major milestone in California's water wars. After years of controversy and litigation, the City of Los Angeles agreed to reduce the amount of water it takes from streams feeding Mono Lake, which provides an important habitat for migrating birds and which has suffered extreme environmental damage after eight decades of pumping by Los Angeles, 400 miles to the south.

HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SPLIT OVER BUDGET CUTS

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Working against a Christmas eve deadline, members of President Clinton's Cabinet have begun lobbying in earnest for relief from the tight spending ceilings that are forcing many to slash their 1995 budget requests.
Most Cabinet secretaries are keeping their complaints relatively quiet to maintain an illusion of solidarity within the President's top ranks. But the fissures are widening as senior Administration officials find themselves feuding with each over policy and politics while the White House prepares its budget proposal for the 1995 fiscal year, which begins next October. The plan will be submitted to Congress in February. 
 Defense Secretary Les Aspin, who announced today that he was resigning after a year on the job, broke ranks last week when he made public his displeasure over the White House plan to leave the Pentagon $40 billion to $50 billion short of what the military contends is needed to sustain the forces Mr. Clinton wants.
And Secretary of State Warren Christopher has sounded similar alarms, signaling frantically that the State Department cannot hope to meet its post-cold war peacekeeping responsibilities while complying with the Office of Management and Budget's recommendation that its budget be sliced significantly.
 
Little Hope of Help
 The pressure is at least as intense on the domestic side of the budget equation, where the bulk of Mr. Clinton's new policy initiatives fall. The President has been meeting with his agency heads almost every day since Thanksgiving to listen to their pleadings. But with the aid of the fierce and unyielding front supplied by his economic advisers, he has offered little hope of additional help.
The President's budget recommendations will not be made public until next month, and Mr. Clinton is expected to consider recommendations from his advisers over the Christmas holiday break.
"He's not there to evenly divide his priorities among 14 children," an adviser said. "He's there to lead the country."
The fights that have erupted over the budget within the Administration arise from the passage of last year's budget plan, which freezes discretionary spending at about $550 billion and does not even allow increases in inflation.
Discretionary spending is the money allocated to all programs for which the money must be approved each year by Congress. Many benefits programs, such as welfare and Medicare are financed over multiple years.
"There's tons of wrestling going on," said one adviser to the President.
 
Meetings With Secretaries
 Mr. Clinton has made a point to meet with each of his Cabinet secretaries personally to hold what one White House aide called "real earnest discussions." The President often finds himself confronting old friends like Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, Education Secretary Richard W. Riley and Health Secretary Donna E. Shalala.
As each Cabinet secretary has trooped into the West Wing Cabinet Room, he or she has been greeted not only by the generally cordial President, but also by the unsmiling aides whose job it is to prevent Mr. Clinton from yielding to his natural tendency to compromise.
These advisers include the budget director, Leon E. Panetta, and Robert E. Rubin, the chairman of the National Economic Council, who remind the President of his budget limitations, and senior advisers George Stephanopoulos and David R. Gergen, who remind the President of his political limitations.
"It is difficult in terms of balancing what our commitments have been in terms of investments, against the Administration's larger objective in terms of deficit reduction," a Transportation Department official said. "People here believe the best thing to do for the economy is stick to deficit reduction goals. Everybody believes that in the abstract."
But the abstract has run up hard against the reality of Mr. Clinton's policy goals. The Department of Labor is pleading for money to pay for job training programs. The Department of Health and Human Services, the Government's largest agency, is hoping to avoid cutting full-time employees so it can staff new Administration commitments to alter the welfare and health care systems and improve the Head Start preschool program. And the Department of Housing and Urban Development is holding the President to a promise to provide additional financing to fight homelessness.
 
Possibility of Layoffs
 Because of its budget dilemma, the Clinton Administration has found itself, in essence, at war with itself. And the proposed cuts could run far deeper than merely delaying the start of new programs. At the Department of Health and Human Services, the cuts could result in layoffs.
Most agency officials are cautious about complaining too loudly about their plight, mostly because they do not know what their colleagues in other Cabinet departments might be up to. Lacking a clear view of the bottom line, they hesitate to handicap their chances without knowing what others might be accomplishing. One Cabinet official called it a "prisoners' dilemma."

HEADLINE: MILITARY MARRIAGE SEEN AS NO THREAT

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
An exhaustive high-level Pentagon report ordered last summer by Defense Secretary Les Aspin after the Marine Corps tried to ban married recruits has reached this conclusion: marriage is not a threat to national security.
Since August, scores of generals and admirals and their top aides have been poring over reams of reports on military pay, housing, child care and demographics to determine whether married recruits hurt combat readiness and, in general, are bad risks for the armed forces. 
 What they have found, according to a confidential summary of the 600-page report, cries out for an explanation of why it took four months to divine this piece of common wisdom: military life is hard on marriages, but most couples make it work.
As one general involved in the review muttered, "This was like hitting a gnat with a sledgehammer."
 
No Surprises
 Another military officer who has been briefed about the study said, "If you're looking for a big, front-page story out of this, you're going to be disappointed."
To be sure, the study did find that the military needs to spruce up the barracks that single soldiers live in, and to improve family and financial counseling for young troops, many of whom enter the armed services at age 17 or 18.
Senior Pentagon officials are putting the finishing touches on the report and its recommendations, which Mr. Aspin, who announced today that he would retire, is expected to announce with great fanfare next week.
To be or not to be married became an issue in August when Gen. Carl E. Mundy Jr., the Marine Corps commandant approved a new policy that would phase out enlistments of married men and women beginning this year.
Marine officials expressed concern that many young married recruits failed to re-enlist after long tours away from home. These young recruits also had higher divorce rates than older married marines, the officials said. There would have been no restrictions on marriage once recruits joined the service.
 
Storm of Criticism
 The policy drew a storm of criticism, largely because neither President Clinton nor Mr. Aspin had been made aware of the plan. Mr. Aspin immediately canceled General Mundy's policy and ordered the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness, Edwin Dorn, to carry out a militarywide study.
Four panels were created to study military pay, housing, demographics, family support programs and the impact on combat readiness that young married recruits would have.
Pentagon officials said much of the information had been compiled in independent studies and merely had to be collected and analyzed. Military and civilian Pentagon officials also conducted scores of interviews to gather new information.
Under the direction of Nicolia Timenes, the Pentagon's principal director for military manpower and personnel policy, and aided by several senior generals and admirals, the team of experts produced a report that contradicted the Marines' premise.
 
Premise Doesn't Stand
 "The presumption was that getting married early was a problem, but that's not what they found," said another Defense Department official. "What they found are that the problems are more financial."
Specifically, the report found "no direct, clear, meaningful and statistically valid relationship (positive or negative) between marital status and readiness."
In addition, the report also concluded that "trying to become a warrior, spouse and perhaps a parent simultaneously is a real challenge; most meet it, but it's tough."
A third finding was that the military "can do a better job of helping our junior members, both married and single, meet the challenge."
General Mundy and other military commanders have worried about economic incentives in the services for young troops to marry. In the Marines, for example, officers say a substantial number of 17- and 18-year-old enlisted troops to have wives who are as young as 14 or 15.
The report found that younger women and men in general who are in the military were more likely to marry than their civilian peers.
Among the recommendations Mr. Aspin is expected to embrace are several that do not cost anything. The reports recommendations include financial and family counseling, a review of barracks policy to allow more younger families to live on base, and generally, improved family-support.
 
Some Costly Options
 The report also suggested several options that would require an estimated $200 million to $300 million. One would be to increase the housing allowance given to military personnel who live off-base. Another increase could come in cost-of-living pay.
Some senior Defense Department officials questioned spending more money on a problem that apparently was not as serious as officials initially thought.
The report conclusions applied broadly to all four armed services, but it did note the particular problem facing the Marine Corps, which is the smallest of the services but whose forces spend increasingly more time overseas.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD TRADE AGREEMENT: The Turning Point;
A Call From Clinton, and Then a Deal

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 15

 BODY:
It was early dawn on the day before the deadline for a world trade agreement when, after another night of fruitless haggling with European officials over trade in movies, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, called President Clinton.
"As in any negotiation, every tough issue had been reserved until last," Mr. Kantor recalled in an interview today. "I gave the President my advice on the movie issue, based on the last European offer; the President thought about it a while and called me back. The answer was firm -- we could not buy into something that compromised on free expression." 
 If the seven-year-old negotiations surrounding the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, completed today, had a single turning point, this was perhaps it. President Clinton's decision effectively insured that a GATT deal would be done, but would not include the contentious issue involving movies, television and musical recordings.
Mr. Kantor then talked with Samuel Berger, the United States deputy national security adviser, and then invited a weary Sir Leon Brittan, the top trade negotiator for the European Community, into a private room. "I told him the answer is no," Mr. Kantor said in his hoarse voice. "We're walking away from the table."
 
'Our Position Would Not Change'
 "Sir Leon asked me if I was sure," Mr. Kantor said today, "and I said that our position would not change. Then he asked, 'You mean you're going to let the French win?' I said that in the end, it's the French people who are going to lose."
Mr. Kantor's decisive conversation with the President underlined a pattern repeated during the negotiations.
In Brussels a week earlier, when the two sides had again negotiated through the night and seemed on the verge of a comprehensive accord that included the movie issue, it was the President who had decided that the proposal was unacceptable, Mr. Kantor said.
"The President told me about how far I could go, and then left me a great deal of room," Mr. Kantor said as he drove to the Geneva airport, clutching a gift-wrapped present for his daughter. "He showed a lot of trust and I am grateful for that. But the last decisions were his. He knows this GATT deal backwards and forwards."
The last European offer on access in Europe for American films and fast-emerging technologies like cable and pay-per-view had been limited, Mr. Kantor said, falling short of an American compromise proposal involving the lifting of Europe's quotas on American programming shown in prime time. The American plan also involved channeling a portion of the tax revenue collected by France on United States films to American entertainment companies on the condition that the money would be reinvested in Europe.
Mr. Kantor said Sir Leon offered a binding European commitment that the quota on American-made programs on television, now limited to 49 percent of broadcasts, would not be made more severe and would be applied equally to services like video-on-demand.
Sir Leon also offered to negotiate a change in the French levies on box-office tickets and blank audio and video cassettes "as soon as possible," Mr. Kantor said, but without committing to a deadline. Sir Leon could not be reached for comment.
The United States objects to the French levies because nearly 60 percent of the French box-office taxes on foreign films come from American movies and many of the cassettes are used to record American music or films. But all the money raised goes to subsidizing the French cinema.
 
A Question of Fairness
 "We felt very strongly on the philosophical issue," Mr. Kantor said. "This was an economic question, sure, but it was also about free expression and fairness. U.S. artists are being denied their financial rights, which is incomprehensible. Also, what the Europeans refer to as 'culture' was being invoked as a means to deny free speech."
Mr. Kantor said he had argued the fairness question several times with Sir Leon in recent weeks before giving up. Then they tried to find a formula to settle each side's demands and came close several times. "But," he added, "you're not negotiating with a United States of Europe. You're negotiating with 12 nation states, and that was complicated."
After President Clinton rejected Europe's offer on film, other issues were settled quickly.
Within four hours, and after quick showers, Mr. Kantor and Sir Leon were ready to announce to the world that they had reached "comprehensive agreement."
In fact, of course, it was much less than that. But Mr. Kantor said he was "elated" by the result. "There is now a seamless web between domestic and foreign economic issues," he added. "The President understands this and has therefore put trade and international economics to the fore, as a means to reinforce our national security."

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Rises 0.9%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The nation's factories and mines posted their biggest gain in output in a year during November, driven by a sharp upswing in auto production, the Government said today.
The Federal Reserve Board's industrial production index surged nine-tenths of a percent in November -- the sixth consecutive monthly increase. It followed a gain of seven-tenths of a percent in October. Analysts said November's gain provided further evidence of robust economic growth. 
 "It basically fits with an economy that is growing rather strongly -- at a 4.9 percent rate this quarter," said Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.
 
Increase in Auto Industry
 About half the November gain was a result of higher production in motor vehicles and parts, which has jumped by 20 percent in the last four months. Low interest rates have encouraged consumers to replace aging cars and trucks.
But even when auto manufacturing was excluded, output expanded by a healthy five-tenths of a percent in November.
These strong gains meant that American factories were working harder and faster in November, using 83 percent of their productive capacity, the Fed said.
This pushed capacity utilization to its highest level since August 1989, when it stood at 83.2 percent. The November rate was up six-tenths of a percent from the previous month. A year earlier, the rate was at 80.8 percent in November.
Although these high levels of factory use normally flash warnings that inflationary pressures may be building, analysts say this is not a worry. With much of the global economy in a slump, price pressures in the United States are likely to remain muted, they said.
Production of business equipment, which has been one of the bright spots in the slow 33-month-long recovery, advanced 1.3 percent in November following a gain of eight-tenths of a percent in November.
Construction supplies also increased by a strong 1.1 percent in November, compared with a three-tenths of a percent gain in October.
Separately, the Commerce Department said today that business inventories were steady in October while sales rose for a third straight month, up four-tenths of a percent after a gain of half a percent in September.

(Source: Federal Reserve Board); "Industrial Production" tracks monthly index of total industrial production, seasonally adjusted, over the same period. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Planning for Desegregation: 22 Guides to Lead 11 Forums

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 10

 BODY:
It was the last day of training for the 22 people selected to help local officials and parents draft plans for integrating public schools, as a new Connecticut law requires. What, they were asked, could state officials say to help them, in introducing them to the public forums that convene next month?
"Tell them it's not our fault," someone quickly said. 
 No state has ever asked communities to write their own plans for addressing segregated schools, and no one expects it to be easy. Connecticut's new law sets no specific goals, but it does require cities and suburbs to talk to one another about racial and economic disparities. It will be the jobs of the 22 people, called facilitators, to help the 11 regional forums organize themselves and get to work.
 
Establishing Neutrality
 Amid an atmosphere of anxiety and anger so intense that state education officials have been shouted down at some public meetings, the facilitators' first challenge will be to establish their neutrality before groups likely to include reluctant, suspicious or even hostile people.
When the 11 forums convene in January, they will range in size from 22 to 58, depending on the number of communities in a region. They will include each community's chief elected official and school board chairman, plus two teachers and four parents. Each forum will be assigned two facilitators.
Facilitators, increasingly common in the corporate world, guide groups as they make decisions. Not part of the group, they aid progress by helping to plan agendas; by moderating discussion, and by clarifying issues.
 
Like a Game Show Host
 In action, moving around to draw people out, dashing to a blackboard to record suggestions, facilitators may appear to be animated leaders. But their role is much more like a game-show host, moving things along. Their goal is a meeting that is conducted fairly and efficiently and that achieves consensus.
These facilitators, selected from more than 200 applicants, include management consultants, professional facilitators, trainers and mediators, lawyers, college professors and administrators, and teachers. One once was a relief worker for Cambodian refugees in Thailand; another worked with gangs in New Haven; one is a Democratic town chairwoman. To avoid conflicts of interest, no facilitator will be assigned to the forum that dealing with his or her community.
Seventeen are women and five are men. Seventeen are white, four are black and one is Hispanic. Going through exercises that sorted them according to various categories, they discovered that more than half are first-born children.
 
A Professional Challenge
 During four days of training in a classroom here, they said they were attracted to the assignment both by the importance of the subject, and by the professional challenge that the forums would present.
"You really needed to look deep within yourself as to why you wanted to do this," said Deanne Shapiro, a management consultant from West Hartford with two children in public school. "Even though we're being paid for attending the meetings, in essence we're volunteering our time."
"I think of it as Connecticut's great adventure," she said. "I think it will shape the future of Connecticut and the country no matter how it turns out. And as a parent, I want the best education for my kids and all kids."
But the facilitators also agreed that their opinions about the integration law, and about anything else, was "their stuff," and that they should keep "their stuff" to themselves. Their role was to help the regional forums do whatever they could agree to do.
Agreeing on regional plans could be easy or hard, depending on how much a forum's members want to do, said Howard Rifkin, who as director of the Institute for Public Service at the University of Connecticut is in charge of convening the forums.
"If people come to the forums believing that they have an obligation to do something, the meetings will be very contentious and emotional," Mr. Rifkin said. "If people meet and speak platitudes for five months, they won't be."
 
Collaboration Uppermost
 Before any forum can begin debating issues of education or integration, however, its facilitators will have to help its members master a new way of doing business.
Facilitators rely on collaboration, helping a group's members see themselves as a team. But the forums will be made up of elected officials used to running things themselves, plus a handful of parents whose idea of debate might be a verbal free-for-all. Everyone will have to agree on ground rules.
Working as teams also tends to exclude the public, which will be intensely interested in the forums' progress and eager to have its say. But all meetings will be open, in a process that has as much to do with politics as with education, and so the local politicians who make up the forums will have to decide how to accommodate the public.
"The public hates this cooperative-working method because it's very hard to observe," said Michael Rion, former president of the Hartford Seminary, who is also the facilitator for the State Commission on Educational Excellence.
"Traditional meetings are terrible places to discuss and get things done, but they're perfect for the public to see everything," he said. "Work groups, by their nature, exclude observers."
At bottom, each forum's members will have to decide whether to have confidence in their facilitators, or to view them with suspicion as agents of the state with an unspoken agenda.
On their last day of training, feeling anxious themselves, the facilitators asked Mr. Rifkin and other officials what everyone wants to know: What kind of regional plan will satisfy the state?
Many kinds, they were told; to say more, the state would risk seeming to have a plan it wanted to impose. "This is very much where ambiguity takes over from clarity," Mr. Rifkin said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vivette Payne, left, and Nancy Brodsky led a training session in West Hartford for facilitators, those people who under a new law will have the job of counseling officials and parents on how to integrate Connecticut's schools. The group of 22 people will help the 11 regional forums get the task under way. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD TRADE AGREEMENT: The View in Washington;
Clinton and Some in Congress See Less Trouble This Time

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton kicked off his campaign today to get the new world trade agreement approved by Congress, saying it would foster an American export boom and that it "cements our position of leadership in the new global economy."
At a hastily called news conference at the White House, within minutes of the approval of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade accord in Geneva, Mr. Clinton said he was formally notifying Congress of his intention to sign the accord. Asked if he thought this accord would have as much trouble being approved by Congress as the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mr. Clinton responded categorically: "No." 
 Senior lawmakers said they shared Mr. Clinton's optimism. The opposition to GATT in Congress is much more balkanized: there is no clear enemy, like Mexico, for opponents to focus upon and no one has stepped forward to lead a charge against the accord, which offers much larger potential benefits for the American economy.
 
Contrast in Scale
 While the North American accord opens a market, Mexico, that represents 5 percent of American gross domestic product, GATT opens a market, 116 other countries, that is three times the American G.D.P. It opens them less deeply than the North American pact does, but much more broadly.
Nevertheless, lawmakers cautioned that it would take at least 18 months to rewrite the American trade laws as required by the agreement, to hold hearings on its contents in both the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee, and to decide how to replace the roughly $10 billion in lost tariffs that will result from the treaty. They said GATT would almost certainly take until June or July 1995 to be voted upon.
"Round One is completed; it took seven years," said Lawrence O'Donnell, chief of staff of the Senate Finance Committee. "Round 2 is now beginning with the Congress." He added: "Popping the champagne is extremely premature. Our champagne is still on ice."
With an eye to the Congressional debate, Mr. Clinton took the offensive today in trying to explain to the American public why the complicated accord was a good deal.
 
Not Entirely Satisfied
 He acknowledged that it "did not accomplish everything we wanted." For example, the United States agreed to deal with the much-disputed issue of tariffs on American television programs and movies in separate negotiations.
The President said, "We must continue to fight for more open markets, for entertainment, for insurance, for banking and for other industries." And he said the export boom fostered by the agreement's tariff cuts "will create hundreds of thousands of good-paying American jobs."
He also said the agreement would discourage nations from discriminating against American businesses in such industries as computer services, construction, engineering and architecture, and would crack down on piracy of American products.
Finally, Mr. Clinton said, the pact preserves "our ability to retaliate against unfair trade practices and our right to set strong environmental and consumer protection standards for economic activity here in the United States."
 
Dissent Is Emerging
 Opposition groups are beginning to coalesce. William Farley, chairman and chief executive of Fruit of the Loom and one of the most vocal corporate opponents of the GATT accord, vowed to continue his fight against the pact in Congress. "I have already today talked to four Congressmen and three Senators and two Governors to raise the visibility of this issue to see if we can block passage of the agreement in Congress," he said.
President Clinton has until April 15 to sign the trade pact. Under an agreement with Congress, Mr. Clinton was required to notify Congress by midnight tonight that he intended to enter into the agreement. Because Mr. Clinton met that deadline, the accord will be considered under a "fast track" arrangement, in which lawmakers are barred from rewriting provisions or adding amendments. Instead, they are resticted to a simple vote of "yes" or "no," as they were with the North American Free Trade Agreement.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Municipal Prices Slip; Treasuries Up

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
A rush of new issues kept prices in the municipal bond market subdued yesterday, but helped lift Treasury prices, ending a three-day slide.
As has been the case recently, Treasury trading was light and directionless, as prices and yields remained in their recent trading ranges. 
 In the municipal market, about $2 billion in new issues were sold, according to Bloomberg Business News, led by a $756 million issue for the New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency. Traders said the high volume of new issues -- more than $5 billion this week -- is keeping prices flat after a sharp rally last week.
Because many of the new municipal bonds are being used to pay off older, higher-interest rate bonds, they can help the Treasury market when trading is light. That is because the escrow funds set up to pay off the old bonds are filled with Treasury securities.
 
Economic Data Ignored
 The economic data released yesterday seemed to have little impact on traders and investors. The Federal Reserve reported that industrial production rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in November, which was a little higher than expectations on Wall Street.
But the data still were in line with what seems to be the consensus outlook for the fourth quarter: that the economy will grow at a rate around 4 percent, after adjustment for inflation. The uncertainity that is keeping the market in its trading range is about the first part of next year, and whether the growth pace will slow.
Many forecasters are predicting that growth will slow to around 3 percent and that inflation will remain moderate, around the increase of less than 3 percent now expected for 1993. If this is the case, these analysts are arguing that there should be little upward pressure on long-term interest rates.
Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers, said yesterday that he expected inflation to remain below 3 percent next year and that long-term interest rates would be in the 6 percent range, little changed from where they are now.
 
Long Bond Price Up
 In late trading in the secondary market, the price of the 30-year bond due in August 2023 was up 5/32 while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 6.28 percent, from 6.29 percent Tuesday. The price of the two-year note was up 3/32 as the yield fell to 4.18 percent from 4.23 percent.
The Treasury announced that it would sell $17 billion of two-year notes next Tuesday and $11 billion of five-year notes Wednesday. The size of the auctions fits with expectations in the market.
In the when-issued, or pre-auction, market late yesterday, the yield on the two-year note was 4.25 percent while the yield on the five-year note was 5.20 percent.
The $756 million issue from the New York State Medical Care Facilities Financing Agency was tentatively priced to yield 5.75 percent on the bond due in 2019. That is a tax equivalent yield of 8.98 percent in the new 36 percent tax bracket. The serial bonds due in 1999 were priced to yield 4.75 percent, which is a tax equivalent yield of 7.42 percent. The lead underwriter for the deal was Morgan Stanley & Company.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher as Concerns Remain About Russian Vote

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly higher yesterday in light trading amid continuing concerns about the political future of Russia.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery closed at $389 an ounce, up 40 cents. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $387 an ounce, up 25 cents. 
 The dollar did well against the Japanese yen in Tokyo and London, giving it strength in New York, said Erik Nickerson, a foreign exchange economist with the Bank of America.
 
Dollar at 109.30 Yen in Tokyo
 In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 109.30 yen, up 0.46 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at the higher rate of 109.65 yen. In New York, the dollar finished at 109.78 yen, up from 109.40 Tuesday.
"It gave confidence to buy dollars against the mark as well," Mr. Nickerson said.
In fact, when the London market closed, there was a rally in New York, Kevin Lawrie, a foreign exchange manager with the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said.
It was a matter of "people just seeing what was up there," he said.
The dollar ended its European trading at 1.7160 German marks, up from 1.7140 late Tuesday. In New York, the dollar ended at 1.7175 German marks, up from 1.7150 late Tuesday.
Meanwhile, Mr. Lawrie added: "The market is thin and there is some underlying bull sentiment. Everything still favors the dollar."
 
'A Risk Potential'
 Analysts said that the dollar was favored because the Russian political situation was unsettled. A leading vote-getter in the parliamentary elections over the weekend was a hard-line nationalist, Vladimir Zhirinovsky.
"They see a risk potential there, but it's not immediate," Mr. Nickerson said. "It provides another reason to make dollars attractive, although we don't see a huge move into dollars." Traders generally favor the dollar as a safe haven in times of international uncertainty.
Also, the market found signs of a strengthening economy in a Federal Reserve report that said the output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities shot up nine-tenths of 1 percent in November. This was the sixth straight monthly gain and the largest in a year.
In New York, the British pound fell to $1.4790, from $1.4885 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The villain theory about savings and loans gets some backing.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
EVERYBODY -- everybody, that is, but economists -- knows that the great savings and loan bust of the 1980's was the handiwork of thieves. Now, a couple of heavyweight academics, George Ackerlof and Paul Romer of the University of California at Berkeley, have come around to the popular view. Indeed, in an article to be published later this month in the Brookings Institution's Papers on Economic Activity, they go much further, blaming the perpetrators of the savings and loan scam for the junk bond and corporate takeover excesses of the decade.
Where the truth lies is still unclear. What is clear, though, is that the Ackerlof-Romer "looting" hypothesis will raise the dander of economists who are convinced that the financial scandal had much more to do with perverse Government incentives than outright villainy. 
 Common sense suggests that it takes bad people to make bad things happen. And certainly all the anecdotes about the Sun Belt hustlers who drank Dom Perignon while their savings and loans crumbled have done nothing to change the conventional wisdom. But specialists in financial regulation have generally been uncomfortable with the idea that the Devil alone made them do it.
Dan Brumbaugh, a former economist with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board who has written extensively about the savings and loan crisis, emphasizes the industry's predicament in the early 1980's. Obliged to pay double-digit interest rates to keep deposits, yet stuck with portfolios of home mortgages paying far less, many savings and loans were, as a practical matter, insolvent by 1982.
But Federal regulators did not have reserves to pay off the insured depositors. So rather than ordering the institutions to shut down, Washington actively encouraged insolvent savings and loans to grow their way out of the cash squeeze.
The savings and loans, Mr. Brumbaugh acknowledges, "had neither the experience nor the expertise" to invest in commercial real estate. That, however, is where most of their depositors' money ended up because that is where the action (and hope of resurrection) was. The result, of course, was to convert a major headache for the deposit insurance system into a catastrophe for taxpayers.
Who is to blame for the billions of dollars in losses on see-through office buildings and ghost town housing tracts? Lawrence White, a former savings regulator who teaches economics at the Stern School of Business of New York University, dismisses hindsight about the inevitability of the commercial real estate collapse. In 1983, he notes, "there were a lot of people who still thought oil prices were headed for $50 a barrel, and even more who didn't foresee the 1986 Tax Reform Act."
But Mr. Ackerlof and Mr. Romer believe much worse was involved than aggressive risk-taking egged on by Washington. The Government's casual regulatory stance, they argue, offered the owners of savings institutions an alluring opportunity to profit from bankruptcy.
The idea was to borrow enormous sums from the public, courtesy of deposit insurance, and lend the money to anyone who would agree to pay high fees up front that could be paid out as bonuses or dividends. Real estate development was the ideal vehicle, they suggest, because it permitted the institutions to book "profits" on interest payments for years before a project would actually have to prove its worth in the marketplace.
Of course, the train would eventually run out of gravy. But the owner of an insolvent savings institution who was careful to stop short of provable fraud could end up rich -- and free to go and sin again.
Worse, argue the Berkeley pair, the waste wrought by bankruptcy-for-profit scams extended far beyond the shady transactions. Overbuilding also brought down honest developers who entered the market early on, in expectation that their competitors' behavior would be governed by the wisdom of Adam Smith rather than that of Cheech and Chong.
Bankruptcy-for-profit may also have generated the money to support the market in junk bonds that, in turn, supported the rash of leveraged buyouts in the late 1980's. While the two economists concede that savings and loan purchases of high-risk bonds represented just a tiny fraction of such bonds issued, they calculate that the sums were sufficient to prop up the borrowers most likely to default, thereby allowing the principals to take home huge fees and commissions for years longer.
Who makes the better case? The Ackerlof-Romer hypothesis is both plausible and logically consistent -- and it meshes well with increasingly dark contemporary interpretations of America's 1980's love affair with cowboy capitalism.
But as Mr. White notes, the Berkeley pair offer no acid test for separating the crooks from the incompetents. And for true connoisseurs of doom, the old story still holds attractions. Which, after all, is worse: a financial market in which the knaves took temporary advantage of rapid (and in the long term desirable) change to steal a fortune, or one so complicated and fragile that it is inherently beyond control by fallible politicians and regulators?

HEADLINE: Where The Boys Are: Home Ec

BYLINE: By LISA M. MILLER

DATELINE: FAIRFAX , Va.

 BODY:
GRAHAM McMAMEE stood at a counter in a classroom kitchen at his school preparing lunch for a group of hungry toddlers.
"Hopefully, I will work with children, maybe in day care, after I graduate," said Mr. McMamee, an 18-year-old senior at Robinson Secondary School in Fairfax, Va., a suburb of Washington. 
 Some of the boys at Robinson still wouldn't be caught dead in them, and many still think they're only for girls. Yet, slowly but surely, home economics classes at other schools across the country are attracting boys who want to learn how to become good parents, improve their communications skills, cook pasta or have better relationships with their families.
Stereotyped for decades as "girls' classes," for teen-agers preparing to be good wives, home economics has a new focus and, in some parts of the country, even a new name -- Work and Family Studies or Life-Management Education.
And with those changes has come a new following.
Nick Rhoton, 17, a senior at Gate City (Va.) High School, likes to play tennis and basketball and acts in community theaters in his spare time. But Mr. Rhoton has an unusual item on his resume: he is the national president of a somewhat forgotten student organization, the Future Homemakers of America. He is the third young man to hold that office in the last eight years. "Males are realizing their roles in society," Mr. Rhoton said. "Everyone is a homemaker. Everyone will run a home. Home economics isn't just a class: it shows how to live in your society."
Of the estimated 5.3 million students in the United States enrolled in home economics classes this year in grades 7 through 12, 41.5 percent are boys, compared with 4.2 percent of 2.2 million students in 1968, said Alan T. Rains Jr., the executive director of Future Homemakers, in Reston, Va.
The group that Mr. Rains oversees started out in 1945 as a sister organization to the Future Farmers of America. Back then, its purpose was to use extracurricular activities to teach girls how to become better cooks and seamstresses. Future Homemakers has changed with the times, and since the early 1970's has aimed its programs at both boys and girls, teaching how to "balance work and family roles," Mr. Rains said.
The number of boys who call themselves Future Homemakers has risen steadily since 1965, from less than 1 percent of the group's membership to 16 percent this year. Nonetheless, the group is struggling to keep going, as overall membership has fallen steadily, from a high of 549,488 in 1965 (when the group merged with the New Homemakers of America, which operated in black schools in the segregated South) to 262,239 this year.
Mr. Rains attributed the drop in part to a declining high school population, lingering stereotypes about women who stay at home and what he said was a "decrease in the amount of extracurricular time a student has." In 1971, to increase its membership, the group started its Home Economics Related Occupations division, which helps schools develop a broad array of courses in skills that range from resume writing and preparing for interviews to entrepreneurship, family problem solving and financial management.
And to recruit more boys, it has also been stressing subjects that take into account the multiple roles that men can play in the family, with classes like Family Communications Skills.
Although the organization's overall focus, the family, has not changed, the "definition of what family is has changed," Mr. Rains said.
In some places, not just the curriculum, but even the course name is different. Last year in Virginia, Home Economics was changed to Work and Family Studies.
"The change is going on in junior high, high schools and universities all over the country," Mr. Rains said. "Some school systems are calling it Life-Management Education, Family and Consumer Sciences or Human Environment Ecology." Even Future Homemakers has debated over the years whether to change its name.
Whatever home economics is called, more boys are finding that so-called girls' classes can be interesting and helpful in their pursuit of an occupation or in their everyday lives.
"I'm learning how to coordinate my wardrobe and my room," said Vinnie Johar, a ninth grader at Robinson Secondary School who is taking Housing and Interior Design, a course that helps students make decisions on selecting, furnishing and decorating a home. "I don't want it as a career," he said. "I wanted to learn something new."
The idea that learning how to cook and manage a household might involve a process of education beyond the folkloric learning at one's mother's knee was largely an American invention. In 1841, a domestic reformer, Catherine Beecher, whose younger sister was Harriet Beecher Stowe, published her "Treatise on Domestic Economy," in which she complained that "women are not trained for their profession," and offered details on techniques for cooking, cleaning and furnishing a home.
The outlines of homemaking and home economics as a quasi science emerged early in this century. Two women whose husbands were disciples of the industrial-efficiency expert Frederick Winslow Taylor offered guides to rationalizing and "scientifically" simplifying the work of the homemaker along the lines of more tangibly productive work, like farming and manufacturing.
Christine Frederick wrote "Household Engineering" in 1915 and later created a correspondence course based on its ideas.
Lillian Gilbreth, a pioneer of household engineering -- she practiced it daily as the mother of 12 children and became known to millions through the book "Cheaper by the Dozen," written by two of her children -- helped make home economics a respectable academic discipline with several books, including "The Homemaker and Her Job."
By the early 1900's, home economics courses were taught at many colleges and universities, including the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Columbia University.
At Robinson, which Future Homemakers points to as a success, courses are offered that are much different from the how-to-make-a-good-pot-roast classes of the 1940's and '50's -- courses like Relationships, in which students are taught through class discussions and role playing how to interact with family, friends and society; Child Development and Parenting, about the growth patterns of children from birth to age 6, and Teen Living, which covers cooking techniques, table manners, nutrition and the art of maintaining satisfactory relationships. Zach Nichols, an eighth grader, had a very simple reason for signing up for Teen Living. "I'm in this class because I like to eat food," he said. "And if I don't get married, I'm going to have to cook my own food."
One teacher who has been involved in many of the changes in Fairfax is Nancy Henderson. She has been teaching home economics in Fairfax since 1972, but started in the fall of 1954 in small rural towns in Texas.
"Back then, we were teaching young ladies how to function in a nuclear family," said Mrs. Henderson, who was on the board of Future Homemakers from 1986 to 1990. "Their primary focus was to learn how to decorate their homes, raise their children and become involved in community service. Now, both parents are going to work and supervise the home."
Although studies show that women still do most of the housework, there are no specific courses at Robinson that teach students solely about housekeeping.
"We teach some housekeeping skills to an extent in each class," Mrs. Henderson said. "Seventh and eighth graders learn about laundry and mending. Older students learn how to clean in the kitchen and use the washer and dryer."
While some boys have a lot of catching up to do, for many girls, like Chantel Chuck, 13, an eighth grader at Robinson, home economics classes are simple reinforcement. "Girls know the stuff already," she said, "so it's an easy A."
Such attitudes, though, aren't lost on some of the boys -- boys like Alan Rindfleisch, 14, who is taking Fitness and Foods at Robinson. "It's a break in the day from all the hard classes," he said.
But many male students, like Mr. Rhoton, take the subject more seriously and have found it has led them to highly visible leadership positions. Thomas Lucas became the first male national president of Future Homemakers in 1986-87 while attending Barboursville (W.Va.) High School; Corey Brown held the post last school year while a student at Gettysburg (S.D.) High School. The president is elected by student delegates from around the country every July at the group's national convention.
Mr. Rhoton, the current president of Future Homemakers, whose mother was a home economics teacher and who points to her as an inspiration, said that the communications skills he learned in an eighth-grade family-management class at Gate City Middle School will remain with him for the rest of his life. He plans to start college next year to study broadcast journalism. "I am so confident about public speaking and talking to people," he said, "that whatever I choose to do, the organization would have benefited me more than anything else."
