HEADLINE: Thanks, Mom. Here's Your New House.

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
IN a material world, perhaps there is no greater gift than a house.
"Any kid growing up in the ghetto wishes to buy Mama a decent house," said Shabba Ranks, 27, a Jamaican reggae star. Mr. Ranks bought his mother, Constance Christie, a house in Kingston, Jamaica. Mother and son are to move in at the end of this month. 
 Mr. Ranks's action is in the house-giving tradition of many performers who have made it big. Among them is Desmond Child, a rock songwriter, who gave his mother a condominium in Florida in 1989. And in 1984, Chris Frantz and Tina Weymouth of the group Talking Heads bought her parents a sailboat, a water-borne home, since her father retired as a vice admiral in the Navy.
"I think of it -- supplying the old folks with a homestead -- as people coming from the bottom rungs of the society, economically," said Jerry Wexler, who has produced records for performers like Ray Charles and Wilson Pickett. "A classic story is a black young man who is one of 16 siblings, who makes it big with a rap group or in the N.B.A. and furnishes Mom with a home."
But the tradition spans classes, races and cultures. And as Mr. Wexler noted, it's a gesture that carries a lot of sentiment.
Mr. Ranks, one of seven children, is a classic example. His image is that of a lover (a special edition of his record "X-Tra Naked" had a condom tucked into the sleeve). But beneath the surface of this star, whose first and third records each sold at least 500,000 copies, is a mama's boy.
His father, Ivan Gordon, who died in 1990, was a mason. "My father used to do a man's job -- he supported us," said Mr. Ranks, who spoke of his father as if he were a distant memory. But when he talked about his mother, emotion filled his deep voice.
In Kingston, Mr. Ranks's mother worked on buses, first as a conductor, then as a driver. She and Mr. Gordon, who never married, had two daughters and five sons. Mr. Ranks, whose given name is Rexton Gordon, is the middle child. Shabba Ranks is his stage name.
In 1983, Ms. Christie and Mr. Ranks, who has been recording since he was 14, bought their first home, a house in Kingston with two bedrooms -- one for the parents, the other for the children. "We grew up in nothing," Mr. Ranks said, describing the one-room house he first lived in. But he knew how to save money. In school, children had their own penny bank books, into which they put money two days a week. "If we have 6 cents, we spend 4 cents and hide 2 cents," he said.
In 1992, vandals broke into the home, tied up his brothers and wrecked music awards he had won. Last year, Mr. Ranks bought a 20-year-old house, which has just been renovated. "I'm going to live as close as possible to my mom," he said. They will live opposite each other, in fact, each in a wing of the house, separated only by a swimming pool.
The house has many rooms, he said. How many? He counted, quietly, to 16. Behind the house is a garden. He recited a litany of the fruit there, including mangoes, papayas, sweetsops, cherries and coconuts.
When his mother moves in she will sit on leather sofas and dining chairs made of hand-carved mahogany. As the sun sets in Kingston, the house will be lighted by crystal chandeliers, said Cindy Breakspeare, the interior designer of the house.
Ms. Christie takes no credit for raising her children alone. "The father gave them love," she said.
And Shabba is a joy to her. "He has given me pleasure, courage," she said. "He is so important to me, because I am everything in his life."
Elena Casals has also inspired generosity from her son Desmond Child, 40, who wrote songs like "Livin' on a Prayer" and "You Give Love a Bad Name" and others recorded by performers like Bon Jovi and Cher.
In 1989, he bought her a condominium in the South Beach section of Miami Beach, where, from her windows, she can watch fashion models posing in the sand for photographers. She moved from a one-story house in Overtown, a neighborhood in Miami, where her windows were covered with steel bars and where she was once robbed.
Mr. Child was born in Gainesville, Fla. His mother, who is Cuban, was married to John Barrett, an American geologist. They divorced when Mr. Child, whose given name is John Charles Barrett, was 4 1/2 and his brother, Fred, was 2. They moved from Gainesville to Miami, where home was a housing project and the furniture was plastic, some of it broken. Mrs. Casals, who remarried, raised her sons by working different jobs.
Some families yearn for a house. Mrs. Casals had a more modest dream. She wanted furniture. When the children were young, she took them to furniture stores, where they sat on the pristine sofas and chairs, bounced on the cushions and imagined the furniture in their home.
In 1989, Mr. Child bought two homes: one for himself -- a $2 million Spanish-style home in Santa Monica, Calif. -- and the smaller place in Florida for his mother. "I felt I had neglected my mom," he said. After she was robbed, he flew to Miami and drove her to Miami Beach, where he saw a brand-new pink building. They stopped, asked to see a two-bedroom model apartment on the ninth floor and bought it, for $140,000, on the spot.
Then they shopped -- at the same furniture stores they had gone to 20 years before. "We finally got to do it for real life," Mr. Child said. They chose a "a beautiful ivory grand piano, beautiful off-white rugs, beautiful urns," he said.
Across the street from the condominium is a discotheque. "I hear the beautiful music," said Mrs. Casals, who is now a real-estate agent part time. She is mesmerized by the view. "You see the big boats coming in and out, the surfers," she said.
Some people's living quarters afford views from the opposite perspective. Take Ralph and Lo Weymouth, the parents of Tina Weymouth. They spend four to five months a year on the Katrinka, a 48-foot sloop that Ms. Weymouth and her husband, Chris Frantz, bought for them.
The boat is kept in Nassau, the Bahamas. The Weymouths, both of whom are in their 70's, spend four to five months a year on it.
"It's absolutely idyllic," Mrs. Weymouth said from Nassau. "I wish you could see the view, see the breakers coming in, and the palm trees waving here, and the reef, which is turquoise, and the ocean, which is dark blue."
Ms. Weymouth, 42, is one of eight children born to a family of seafarers. Her father built his first boat when he was 11. Ms. Weymouth's great-great-grandfather Egbert Sewall was the captain and owner of the Istria, a clipper ship, in the 1850's and 1860's. Mr. Sewall once sailed around the Adriatic Sea with his family. He even kept a cow on board, so the children could have milk.
"That has been a family dream -- reducing life to its real essentials by escaping on a boat," Ms. Weymouth said. "I hear my parents dream their dreams."
Ralph and Lo Weymouth made their home on naval bases from Honolulu to Iceland. In 1984, Ms. Weymouth and Mr. Frantz, 42, made the Weymouth family dream come true.
That year, the Talking Heads (with Ms. Weymouth on bass and Mr. Frantz on drums) had spent nine months on the road, promoting the film "Stop Making Sense" and the album "Speaking in Tongues." "That brought us considerable fame, and all the problems that entailed," Mr. Frantz said. "A sort of burnout."
To refuel, they bought the boat and invited her parents to sail. "Usually when rock stars arrive, they give a home to their parents," Mrs. Weymouth said. "But Tina said: 'You don't need a home. Daddy needs a boat.' "
But not all rock stars are generous. Albert Goldman, the author of "The Lives of John Lennon" (William Morrow, 1988), said there have been plenty of big stars who did not buy their parents homes, stars like Jim Morrison, the lead singer of the Doors, whose life and death are part of rock lore. He "described his parents as dead when they were alive," Mr. Goldman said.

HEADLINE: Corrections

 BODY:
A front-page chart yesterday about the highlights of the world trade agreement referred incorrectly in some editions to the timetable for its approval by Congress. The agreement requires the President's signature by April 15; he may submit it to Congress at any time after signing it. The pact is scheduled to go into effect July 1, 1995. If Congress has not approved it by then, the United States will be vulnerable to trade sanctions.
A related front-page article yesterday about how free trade promotes growth misstated the first name of an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. She is Kim Elliott, not Tim. 
 A news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about the agreement referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of participating nations. There are 117, not 116.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: After Seven Years, a Global Gift

 BODY:
The trade agreement completed yesterday after seven tortuous years of negotiations among 117 countries is good for the U.S. and good for the world. Its real importance lies less in its individual provisions than in its vibrant message; the world's trading partners have now pledged to keep marching relentlessly toward liberalized trade. And that, in turn, will bring higher living standards than any other government policy will.
For the first time, agriculture, services, textiles and investment will be covered by international rules of fair trade. Tariffs and trade barriers will tumble. Those changes should drive down consumer prices on everything from clothing to computers. And lower prices will mean higher living standards, especially for the poor. 
 Around-the-clock bargaining between Mickey Kantor of the U.S. and Sir Leon Brittan of the European Union was decisive in bringing negotiations to a successful close. Their efforts paid off; had the talks collapsed, momentum would have shifted toward countries that seek advantage by raising tariffs. Eventually, the law of the jungle would have shrunk economies everywhere.
For the U.S., the agreement makes important headway. It reduces tariffs by about a third. U.S. exporters will sell more construction equipment, computer chips and pharmaceuticals. Some concessions took real political courage. The new Japanese Government, for example, agreed to import rice, a product of mythic importance to the Japanese.
For the first time, international rules will protect copyrights and patents on books, computer software and other intellectual property that have been routinely pirated. The agreement, also for the first time, protects the right of service-sector companies -- accounting, management consulting and other industries in which the U.S. is strong -- to operate on foreign soil free of discriminatory laws.
The agreement sets up effective procedures for resolving disputes. Under current rules, countries accused of violating trade agreements can block a judicial panel's negative ruling; under the new rules, defendants would have no such power.
That said, the treaty falls shy of the goals set out in 1986 when the Uruguay Round started. Important industries, like movies, shipping and telecommunications, were left out of the agreement. The U.S. pulled financial services -- including banking, securities and other industries dominated by the U.S. -- from the accord because Japan and other Asian countries refused to grant the same unfettered access to U.S. firms that the U.S. grants to them. And third-world countries did not receive the access they deserved to textile markets in the industrialized countries.
The third world is also displeased by some provisions on unfair trade practices. Under current rules, countries may retaliate against products that are unfairly subsidized by foreign governments or sold at prices below the foreigner's cost of production -- a practice known as dumping. But many countries, including the U.S., have abused that right by raising tariffs on legitimate goods in order to protect domestic industry. The Uruguay Round will not eliminate the foul play.
The Uruguay Round's purpose was to liberalize trade, thereby subjecting producers everywhere to more intense competition. The agreement could have been better. But it's a victory for the U.S., opening up markets for many of the goods it produces best, and a victory for the global economy.

HEADLINE: SKIING;
The Looks Don't Count With Equipment

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
Tamara McKinney, the 1989 World Cup skiing champion, still moves with power and precision on the slopes. But at 5 feet 3 inches, she is a relatively small racer who has always chosen skis and boots that are more flexible than bigger ski competitors require.
Stiff skis and boots are more responsive for edging than softer ones, but they also tend to be uncomfortable and unnecessary for skiers who do not have trophies on the mind. When it comes to advice for women who are shopping for recreational equipment, McKinney, 31 years old and a competitor in an annual Tournament of Champions league, advises, "Look out for the impostors." 
 The impostors to which McKinney refers are manufacturers who are deluging the market with products developed for the female skier. "You can see a big difference in your skiing by getting on equipment that responds the way it is supposed to," McKinney said during a recent interview.
Impostors tend to hide behind cosmetic changes in their skis and boots -- such as light, feminine colors and glitzy graphics -- without making the essential design differences that separate the needs of men and women skiers, McKinney said.
 
The Market Is There
 The rush to accommodate women has economic roots. "Skiing until very recently has been a male-dominated industry," said Jeanne-Marie Gand, director of advertising for Rossignol in the United States. "But there has been a big wake-up call this year to women in skiing. The market is there, and women have become much more savvy buyers."
The National Sporting Goods Association estimates that of the 10.8 million skiers in 1992, 40 percent were women. In 1989, 35 percent of skiers were women. This year, the first magazine for women in the sport, Skiing for Women, was introduced by the Times Mirror Corporation.
Some experts question how much women need special equipment. Tait Wardlaw, a technical editor at Ski Racing, a competitors' journal, and Ski magazine, said recently that gear for women was more important in boots than in skis.
"Much of it's lip service as much as anything else," Wardlaw said about ski design. "When you get to a level where you can tell the difference between men's skis and women's skis, most of those women are so good and so strong that they would just as soon ski on a men's ski."
The editors of Skiing for Women tend to agree. "If you're looking for real power out of the turn and rock-solid edge grip on the ice, you'd best begin your search among unisex racing models," the magazine said in its winter 1994 issue. The magazine rated 12 ski companies offering special designs for women that generally are best if "ease of turning, comfort and improvement in your technique are your goals."
 
The Strength Factor
 Seth Masia, a technical expert with K2 Skis, concedes that expert women perform just as well on a unisex ski, but for average skiers there is a need to design especially for women. K2 does market a line of women's skis, including the popular LTP.
Masia said that the main difference between male and female skiers has to do with upper body strength. "Anything else doesn't address the real issue," Masia said. "A guy with good upper body strength uses the pole to assist in directional change while women, who generally have 30-40 percent less upper body strength, don't have that option."
But what about boots? Manufacturers are generally concluding that women's boots should be shaped differently from men's. Designers are allowing for narrower heels in women's boots and compensating for calf muscles that are lower on the leg by dropping a boot's cuff. Some are also adding heel lifts to adjust for what they see as a lower center of gravity among women.
To address the gender gap in equipment, Rossignol is offering four skiing workshops for women this year. The $195 cost of the two-day clinics includes the use of Rossignol's new skis and boots designed for women.
McKinney, sponsored by Rossignol for the last 10 years, will be on hand for instruction, as well as two former United States world ski champions, Christin Cooper and Kiki Cutter.
The first workshop is scheduled for this weekend at Killington, Vt. Others are planned for ski resorts in Colorado, Minnesota and California later in the season. Rossignol can be called at (802) 863-2511 for more information.
 
Midwest Alternative
 As part of her series of women's clinics, Jeannie Thoren of Duluth, Minn., focuses on equipment. In addition to providing a choice of additional equipment from various manufacturers, Thoren also advises students on ways to adjust their own gear to improve its performance. Her advice includes an unorthodox suggestion that women move their bindings forward about an inch from the standard position to counteract a lower center of gravity.
For information on the daylong clinics, which cost under $50 and are located mostly in the Midwest, Thoren can be reached at (218) 724-5809.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD TRADE AGREEMENT: The Overview;
GATT Talks End in Joy and Relief

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 15

 BODY:
A small wooden gavel came down on a table here today, signaling, with a sharp tap, the completion of the long-contested world trade agreement intended to provide the basis for global economic growth and cohesion into the 21st century.
As he lowered his hammer like an auctioneer completing a sale, Peter Sutherland, the Irish lawyer who oversaw the last phase of the seven-year trade negotiations as GATT's Director General, declared, "I gavel the Uruguay Round as concluded." 
 Representatives from the 117 member nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade leaped to their feet in the brown-carpeted, granite-walled conference hall here -- applauding, cheering, even succumbing to bear hugs.
 
The Worst Is Past
 Their sense of relief was palpable: A deal had finally been done and the worst averted, after a negotiation that at times seemed more likely to reveal the irreconcilable trade rivalries of the post-cold-war world than its determination to pursue a quest for freer trade, lower tariffs and greater economic cooperation.
"There are those, not without reason, who find the post-cold-war world full of new risks and tensions," Mr. Sutherland said. "Today, the world has chosen openness and cooperation instead of uncertainty and conflict. This is a success that will reinforce economic growth."
In fact, as several delegates remarked here today, the 400-page Final Act of the negotiations ended as an incomplete compromise, much better than nothing, but far less than once hoped.
"To conclude this is, in itself, a major achievement," said Luiz Felipe Palmeira Lampreia, Brazil's representative here, "even if we are left with mixed feelings."
 
Close Call for Clinton
 The agreement came after a first, formal deadline in December 1990 was missed and later target dates produced nothing. In the end, Mr. Sutherland announced the conclusion just 10 hours before the cutoff of President Clinton's "fast track" authority, allowing him to send the GATT accord to Congress to be voted on without amendments.
Within an hour of agreement, President Clinton said he would submit the pact to Congress. "This agreement did not accomplish everything we wanted, but today's GATT accord does meet the test of a good agreement," he said in Washington.
After approval by Congress last month of the North American Free Trade Agreement -- and the intense battle the President waged to gain that approval -- the new accord underscored the Administration's once-doubted commitment to free trade. It also indicated the belief of Mr. Clinton and his advisers that jobs, growth and national security are, in the end, better served by an open world trading system than protectionism or recourse to regional trading blocs.
In Paris, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur, who repeatedly clashed with the President over issues ranging from agriculture to access for American films to European markets, declared in Parliament that the accord was in France's interest.
"The cultural identity of Europe is protected, the future of French agriculture assured," he said, before winning a vote of confidence by 466 to 90 in the lower house.
Under the agreement, to be signed in Morocco in April and due to come into effect in 1995, worldwide tariffs were cut by an average of one-third, encouraging the freer movement of goods, and industries like agriculture were brought under GATT rules for the first time, implying the gradual elimination of subsidies that are costly to taxpayers.
 
Little Gain on Many Services
 But accords on the world's trillion-dollar annual trade in services like banking and the movie and entertainment industries proved elusive, leaving some of the fastest-developing parts of the world's economy encumbered by national or regional protectionism of the sort that discourages foreign investment.
The agreement, before coming into effect, faces potentially contentious legislative battles in the United States and elsewhere.
Today, South Korean students, angered by the lifting of the country's ban on rice imports, rioted and shouted "Yankee go home." And some Indian legislators denounced what they depicted as the sale of the country to American imperialists after it was announced that the Government had accepted the accord and an eventual lowering of tariffs on textiles.
The agreement came after a series of last-minute flurries. The American trade representative, Mickey Kantor, won an 11th-hour change of name for the new international trade organization that is to be established in 1995 to police the accord and settle trade disputes.
Instead of the Multilateral Trade Organization, it will be called the World Trade Organization.
"It just sounds a lot less bureaucratic and has more gravitas," Mr. Kantor said.
The United States, concerned for some time that the organization could compromise the effectiveness of national trade legislation, withheld final approval of the new body until today.
The European Community bickered among itself to the last.
 
At the End, Portuguese Textiles
 At a meeting in Brussels, European foreign ministers had to allocate more than $450 million to Portugal to compensate it for the GATT accord's effect on the country's textile industry before Portugal would accept it. The Portuguese had argued that the community's gradual lowering of barriers to textile imports was not sufficiently compensated by openings in the textile markets in the United States and in big Asian countries.
The European ministers also approved a speeded-up procedure for taking trade action against countries selling products below cost in the European market before France would announce its approval.
The French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, emerging from the meeting, remarked, "I never want to hear the word GATT again."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 23, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Dec. 16, with articles about the conclusion of talks on a General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, misstated an estimate made by Myron E. Ullman 3d, chairman and chief executive of R. H. Macy & Company, of the amount that American consumers pay extra for clothing because of tariffs and quotas on imported apparel and fabrics. He estimated the amount at $46 billion a year, not $46 million.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "I gavel the Uruguay Round as concluded," said Peter Sutherland, who closed the meetings of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. "Today, the world has chosen openness and cooperation instead of uncertainty and conflict," Mr. Sutherland declared. (Associated Press) (pg. D1); About 40 Belgian farmers yesterday protested the accord reached under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which they fear will threaten their livelihoods. The farmers set fire to a tractor during the demonstration outside the headquarters of the European Community in Brussels. (Reuters)
 
Chart: "GATT: The Effect on Industry"
 It took seven year for 117 countries to agree on a pact that would modify world trade for the firt time since 1979. But in expanding rules that would cut some tariffs and eliminate others as a way to stimulate business and investment, negotiators have not satisfied every industry in the United States, despite some estimates the agreement could generate as much as $200 billion in new business. President Clinton notified Congress yesterday that the United States intended to sign the agreement on April 15. Here is a closer look at the industries that won, lost or came away with a draw under GATT.
 
Agriculture DRAW
 Some groups, like the National Farmers Organization, say freer trade under GATT is bad for agriculture everywhere because it increases efficiency to a point where less efficient farmers are driven out of business and some rural communities threatened with extinction. But most American grain farmers expect to benefit from reduction in worldwide export subsidies under GATT, although some grumble that the side agreement with the Europeans slowed the pace of subsidy reduction from the Blair House accord of 1992. Fruit, vegetable and rice growers expect better access to foreign markets. Domestic crops protected by strict quotas, like sugar, cotton and peanuts, will see slight increases in import competition over time.
 
Banking DRAW
 The stakes for the banking industry were small, and the results were inconclusive. The agreement neither opened new markets for American banks nor restricted the ability of the United States to retaliate against countries that maintain barrier. "We did not get stuck with the door locked open," said Christopher Rieck, a spokesman for the American Bankers Association. Since banks already have access to markets in Europe and Japan, the industry's only concern, which is subject to future negotiations, is gaining the right to open branches in developing countries. This mainly affects Citibank, which is the only American bank interested in running retail branches overeas.
 
Brokerage firms DRAW
The failure of GATT negotiators to agree on a plan for foreign countries to drop barriers to American securities firms was disappointing, said David G. Strongin, director of international finance at the Securities Industry Association. Securities dealer were pleased, however, that the agreement leaves the United States Government the right to negotiate with individual countries about their barrier, rather than requiring use of GATT's formal dispute settlement system. At Merrill Lynch, GATT was viewed as less important than the North American Free Trade Agreement earlier in the year, which called for Mexico to open its borders to foreign securities firms.
 
Insurance DRAW
"We were disappointed that we did not get an agreement for foreign countries to remove barriers protecting their insurance industry, but the mere fact that, for the firt time, financial services such as insurance were on the GATT agenda was important progress," said George Henry, vice president of the American Insurance Association. The GATT talks did produce an agreement to give foreign countries an extra six months beyond the start of GATT on July 1, 1995 to remove barriers protecting their insurance industry. After that, the United States is free to impose trade sanctions against those countries.
 
Capital Goods WINNER
The gradual elimination of tariffs should help American makers of capital goods by stimulating world economies and thus demand for manufactured products. The United States capital goods industry also has some of the world's lowest- cost producer, who are well positioned to compete on price and will not miss losing the protection of antidumping suits at home. It was "certainly not all we wanted, but our bottom line was this was one heck of a good agreement," said Timothy Elder, a spokesman for Caterpillar, a heavy-equipment maker.
 
Forest Products DRAW
The trade pact is expected to be more welcome to the paper industry than to lumber. The United States exports only limited amounts of lumber, and prices of American lumber have not been particularly competitive since efforts to protect the spotted owl made logging more expensive. American paper makers have more to gain. Until now, they have had to contend with 6 percent tariffs on any liner board, their principal export to the European Community and 9 percent on bleached board.
 
Medical Equipment WINNER
 Medical device and equipment makers said smaller companies would be the main winners as tariffs fall by $500 million a year and exports grow by $200 million to $300 million, creating about 3,000 jobs. Even larger companies with overeas plants were pleased. "Lowering trade barriers and eliminating tariffs through GATT is very good news for us," said raymond V. Gilmartin, chairman of Becton, Dickinson & Company
 
Pharmaceuticals LOSER
The pharmaceutical industry, which lobbied hard for the GATT agreement, was set back by a provision that gives developing countries like India and Brazil 10 year before they will be required to honor foreign patent claims. Trade negotiators said American drug makers lose $4.8 billion in annual sales. Noting that other types of patents must be respected after a five-year transition, Merck & Company, the world's largest drug maker, complained that pharmaceutial patents had been made the objects of discrimination. But the industry also won on some points, including 20-year patent protection from the filing date.
 
Retail WINNER
Retailers have been urging an end to quotas and tariffs on imported apparel and fabrics, which they say increase the cost of their merchandise to consumer. Myron E. Ullman 3d, chairman and chief executive of r. H. Macy & Company, which makes much of its private-label apparel abroad, says consumers pay $46 million a year extra. The GATT accord will phase out the tariff and quota system and give retailers the chance to lower prices.
 
Semiconductors WINNER
American manufacturers retained the right not to license foreign competitors who would make their products. They also kept the ability to file dumping complaints like those used to fight Japanese competition in the 1980's. There was also a modest gain on European tariffs, which will fall from 14 percent to 7 percent on imported memory products after five years.
 
Textiles LOSER
The textile industry will, over 10 year, lose the complex system of quotas that has served as a barriers to increased imports of fabrics manufactured abroad. "I consider this to be just a complete sellout of this industry," said William Farley, chairman and chief executive of Fruit of the Loom. Manufacturers had pushed for a 15-year phase-out of the current arrangement, which imposes tariffs and quotas on imported fabrics and apparel. And they wanted a reduction of tariffs and quotas to be dependent upon other countries like India and Pakistan opening their markets to American textiles. Neither of those proposals made it into the final package.
 
Toys WINNER
 "We look at this as a win-win situation for us," said David A. Miller, president of the Toy Manufacturers of America, a trade association that represents more than 200 companies. Lower tariffs will benefit the toy industry because two-thirds of the toys, games and dolls sold in the world are made by American companies. The reduced tariffs will also presumably benefit consumers with lower prices. In the case of stuffed toys and dolls, a $600 million combined business this year, the 80 percent of the companies' products made overeas now face import duties of 6 percent and 12 percent, respectively, Mr. Miller said. Without them, he said, companies would save as much as $150 million. (pg. D8)

HEADLINE: CHANGE AT THE PENTAGON;
Wounded in Policy Wars

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.,, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Les Aspin had studied all his life for the job. But he failed to master some key lessons, and instead of providing the capstone for his career, his service as Secretary of Defense lasted only a year and ended in ambiguity, with a decidedly equivocal record.
 To move across the Potomac to the Pentagon, Mr. Aspin had to abandon a safe Congressional seat and his post as chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. He did not do so lightly, because he knew it would be difficult if not impossible to restart an elective career in his late 50's. But after some hesitation, he decided this would probably be his only chance at the secretary's job, and he took it. 
That is one of the main reasons that the national-security insiders in Washington, who have known him well for decades, put little credence in his explanation that he wanted a break from government service. One of them commented tonight: "He thrived on this stuff; to tell the truth, he didn't have much of a life outside his work, and he'll be lost without it."
 
'Time to Pass the Baton<HHE>
 Asked whether he had been forced out, one of the Secretary's closest co-workers answered: "You know how this town operates as well as I do. I can only say I think my friend read the evidence and made the right decision. It's a relay race, not a marathon, and he decided that one lap was enough: it was time to pass the baton."
 Mr. Aspin worked hard to develop new policies on difficult issues that grew out of the end of the cold war, like the reduction in the size of American armed forces, the intensified problem of proliferation of nuclear weapons and heightened regional dangers. He also wrestled with tough questions that he told friends he would not have chosen and that others might have shirked: homosexuals in the armed forces, women in combat roles and the Tailhook convention, at which naval aviators made sexual assaults on women.
 But his policies and his actions cut across entrenched interests, and that hurt him. So, several senior officials said, did his decision not to reinforce American troops in Somalia, when officers on the scene had urged quick action. When American Rangers were pinned down, suffering 18 deaths and 75 injuries, a cry went up for his scalp.
 "We have a dilemma, which Somalia exemplified," an ally of Mr. Aspin said. "We haven't worked out when, where and how we are going to commit our forces in this new age. Les hasn't worked it out, nobody's worked it out. He opposed the use of force in Haiti and Bosnia and won, but he lost in Somalia -- and in that sense he is a victim of our failure to make a national decision.
 "Mr. and Mrs. Couch Potato want us to stop civil wars and save the hungry. They see the military as the best way to do that, but when people get killed, they won't stand for it. The President will have to resolve that issue."
 
Hailed at Beginning
 It is President Clinton's responsibility, of course, to make the final decisions on all the big issues. But Mr. Aspin got tangled in one controversy after another, and he was an obvious target when leading Democrats began pressing for change in the foreign policy team. A change was more urgent than it might otherwise have been, many of them said, because of Mr. Clinton's own unusually weak background in and feeling for foreign policy and military affairs.
 Mr. Aspin has always been better at the substance of things than at the political penumbra that surrounds them. At one point, he was briefly forced out of his chairmanship because of his failure to perform even the most rudimentary acts of constituency-building within the Democratic membership.
 He promised to reform, but he was not very apt at covering his political flanks at the Pentagon, either.
 When the President announced that he had chosen Mr. Aspin, the Wisconsin legislator was widely hailed in Washington as the most thoroughly qualified nominee for the position since Harold Brown, who was Secretary under President Jimmy Carter.
 Both men could be described as military intellectuals, but Mr. Brown had an important advantage. He had run things before taking charge at the Defense Department. So had Dick Cheney, George Bush's Secretary, who had served as White House chief of staff in the Ford Administration before entering Congress.
 Mr. Aspin, on the other hand, was almost entirely a creature of the House of Representatives. After studying at Yale, Oxford and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he earned his Ph.D. in 1965, and after teaching economics for a while, he had worked in the Pentagon and in Vietnam as one of Robert S. McNamara's "Whiz Kids." But he was elected to Congress in 1970, when he was only 32, and had served there for 22 uninterrupted years.
 "He was an idea man when he was up here, a guy who liked to sit around and talk theory more than he liked to make decisions and issue orders," said Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who flew Navy attack planes over Vietnam at the same time as Mr. Aspin was analyzing the war in Saigon and Washington. "I admire him tremendously, but it's very hard to make the transition from thinking and talking to administering and commanding.
 "Cheney did it, but his background was a lot more varied than Les's."
 A burly and engaging man, Mr. Aspin was something of an absent-minded professor, whose friends teased him when he would ask them to his house and forget to offer them drinks because he was so deeply enmeshed in explaining the arcana of defense policy. And he was never strong on organization.
 
Worked as 'Chairman'
 Once he arrived at the Pentagon, his rumpled, discursive, informal style, which almost everyone found charming outside the office, drew criticism from top uniformed officers, from counterparts at the Central Intelligence Agency and, ultimately, from his former colleagues on Capitol Hill. His testimony before Congressional committees was attacked as woolly and nonresponsive.
 In his defense, his friends said tonight that he had functioned as a "chairman of the board," leaving management of the Pentagon to aides like John Deutch, an undersecretary whom Mr. Aspin had known for many years. The system worked efficiently, they said, but that was not the majority view.
 Whatever the details of his thinking, which he has apparently disclosed to very few people, Mr. Aspin is clearly worn out. His doctor gave him a clean bill of health, but he looked wan and gray when he appeared in the Oval Office this afternoon, and he seemed to have concluded that the White House viewed him as a political liability.
 "He didn't say so in so many words," one associate commented, "but he gave me the strong impression that if the President had given him a resounding vote of confidence, he would have found the energy to carry on. I talked with him every day, more or less, and he didn't strike me as a man who was leaving of his own volition."

HEADLINE: CHANGE AT THE PENTAGON: Man in the News -- Bobby Ray Inman;
An Operator for the Pentagon

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
More than a decade ago Bobby Ray Inman left Washington in a huff, vowing never to return. The city was too mean, the bureaucratic infighting too enervating, the backbiting too intense, he told intimates after serving 16 uncomfortable months as deputy to William J. Casey, who was then Director of Central Intelligence.
Shucking a long Government career, Mr. Inman went home and set up a business in Austin, Tex. But his heart never left the Potomac. Using the tools he had acquired as a four-star admiral and a spy master -- stealth and discipline -- he managed to keep his finger on the pulse of power. 
 "I am an operator," the 62-year-old Mr. Inman bluntly told reporters today after President Clinton announced his nomination to succeed Les Aspin as Secretary of Defense. "Hopefully with a strategic view."
Although he may have been using the expression the way people in uniform use it -- to make the point that he had not been just a desk-bound paper-pusher during his 31 years in the Navy, but also a man in the field -- it was natural that those who know him interpreted the word differently.
"Operator: that's arguably the magic word," said Robin West, a petroleum executive who has known Mr. Inman for nearly two decades. "He's a brilliant creature of the inside, a man who can help educate the President."
 
Essential Qualities
 Mr. Inman is one of those Washington figures whose accomplishments and peculiarities have made him a legend in the capital and a fixture on corporate boards and Government commissions, although his name is probably unknown to most of America.
Senior Administration officials say he brings to his new job three qualities that Mr. Aspin seemed to lack: credibility with the military, a highly developed sense of organization and the ability to articulate policy positions in public.
Since his days as a prize-winning whiz kid on a radio quiz show in his hometown of Rhonesboro, Tex., he has been known as a prodigy.
Under President Jimmy Carter, Mr. Inman, then a 46-year-old career Navy intelligence officer, became the youngest Director in the history of the National Security Agency, the supersecret organization that eavesdrops overseas. He was the first intelligence officer ever to receive a fourth star, and with confirmation by the Senate he will become the first career military officer since George C. Marshall to head the Pentagon.
In his years since leaving full-time Government work, Mr. Inman has nonetheless kept his hand in. Among other things, he has headed a Reagan Administration commission on embassy security and the Bush Administration's Presidential Intelligence Foreign Policy Advisory Board and served on a number of Congressional panels on intelligence.
He replaced Secretary of State Warren Christopher as vice-chairman of the New York-based Council on Foreign Relations and has served on the boards of 11 nonprofit organizations and a number of companies.
 
Endearing Style
 Along the way, he has perfected an endearing style characterized by bureaucratic finesse and intellectual grace.
He has maintained in interviews that he is so clumsy that he cannot walk across a room without bumping into the furniture but is so disciplined that when he was at the Central Intelligence Agency he rose every morning at 4 o'clock to prepare for the day by reading a huge bag of classified documents.
His gap-toothed smile and self-deprecating demeanor conceal a steely center, an extraordinary intellect and a remarkable ability to shape quietly the opinions of other officials.
Over the years, Mr. Inman has maintained political independence, a characteristic that was on display during the Rose Garden announcement today.
 
Didn't Vote for Clinton
 "I would tell you up front, honestly, I did not vote for President Clinton," he volunteered. "I voted for President Bush, even though I was mad at him about his handling of the economy, but because I considered him a personal friend."
Mr. Inman also confessed that he had neither sought nor wanted the Pentagon job, which he said he had accepted because of "duty and country."
Indeed, in the fall of 1990, after assigning himself the role of saving the contentious nomination of Robert M. Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence, he said in an interview: "I will never come back to Government. I have zero Potomac fever. I don't have the patience anymore. Watching this process has absolutely locked that in concrete."
Last year, during the transition between Presidencies, Mr. Inman was discreetly asked whether he would be interested in becoming Bill Clinton's top intelligence chief, and he politely but firmly declined. But Washington insiders who claim to know him well say he has always coveted the job of either Secretary of State or Defense Secretary. Even Mr. Inman admitted in the 1990 interview that if, at the beginning of the Bush Administration, "somebody had offered me Secretary of Defense, I might have taken it."
 
Business Years Stressed
 Today, Mr. Inman touted his business experience as perhaps the most important asset he brings to the Defense Department.
"In these last 10 years," he said, "I've learned a lot about how business works, and I would hope to spend a lot of my time on bringing the best business practices to the Department of Defense."
In fact, though, his business record has been mixed.
In 1983, he founded the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, a consortium of computer companies, to compete with Japan's electronics giants. During his tenure, many big companies refused to join, and some that did sign on refused to provide their best researchers.
When Mr. Inman brought in talent from the outside, he angered some of the companies, which feared that unless their own technicians were in the consortium, it would be hard to use the technologies in their own products. Mr. Inman complained in a 1984 interview that some of the corporate partners were "sitting back and sipping with a long straw," and two years later he stepped down.
 
Frustrating Experience
 In 1987, Mr. Inman was made chairman and chief executive of Tracor Holdings, a large military contractor in Texas that had heavy debt from a leveraged buyout. He failed to respond adequately to the shrinking of the military, he conceded later, and two years after joining Tracor, he resigned as the company was posting enormous losses.
"I have been very frustrated with this," he said in an interview at the time. "I feel infinitely better now that this will be put in the hands of an old pro, someone who has been to the table before. I bring no expertise to bear as we proceed with asset sales and begin to restructure."
 
Ties to Arms Dealer
 A line on Mr. Inman's resume that is expected to be raised in Senate confirmation hearings concerns his relationship with a corrupt arms merchant, James Guerin, who is now serving a 15-year prison sentence for fraud, money laundering and illegal exports of military technology to South Africa and Iraq.
In 1975, when Admiral Inman was director of naval intelligence, the United States sought to spy on Soviet ships off the South African coast. Mr. Guerin's company shipped electronic eavesdropping gear to South Africa. Beginning in 1977, after President Carter severed the intelligence relationship between Washington and Pretoria, Mr. Guerin served as an intelligence agent for the United States on South Africa's nuclear-weapons program.
Then, in 1982, Mr. Inman served on a special board of outside directors for Mr. Guerin's arms company, International Signal and Control. The board's responsibility was to prevent classified information from leaking.
 
Illegal Sales of Weaponry
 Throughout the 1980's, Mr. Guerin's company illegally sold weaponry to South Africa and cluster-bomb technology to a Chilean arms merchant who helped arm Iraq.
Mr. Guerin's attempt to sell his company to a British concern resulted in a swindle that a Federal judge described in 1991 as "the largest fraud ever perpetrated in North America."
At Mr. Guerin's 1992 sentencing, Mr. Inman wrote a letter vouching for Mr. Guerin's patriotism for his spying on South Africa, although he did not advocate leniency for him.
It was unclear whether Admiral Inman knew about the arms shipments or Mr. Guerin's illegal activities, and he said in an interview at the time that he was certain that American intelligence agencies had never approved illegal conduct by Mr. Guerin's firm.
 
Unassuming Beginning
 Bobby Ray Inman was born in the dusty East Texas hamlet of Rhonesboro, the son of a service station owner, a point Mr. Clinton made today.
After graduating from the University of Texas in history at 19, he taught at an elementary school, hoping to attend Stanford Business School.
When the Korean War broke out, and he thought he would be drafted, he signed up for trhe Navy's officer candidate school and was soon decoding secret messages on an aircraft carrier. He became the American cryptographer in Paris and then studied at the Navy's intelligence school in Washington although unlike most senior flag officers, he never graduated from the Naval Academy at Annapolis.
He rose rapidly through the ranks, serving as chief intelligence officer for the 7th fleet, naval attache in Sweden, Director of Naval Intellgience and vice director of the Defense Intellgience Agency before becoming head of the National Security Agency.
 
Appeal From Reagan
 When Ronald Reagan named Mr. Casey the nation's intelligence chief, Admiral Inman resisted taking the job as deputy. According to an oft-told story, Mr. Casey had to persuade Mr. Reagan to make a personal appeal, which he did, telling him, "Admiral, I need you."
But Admiral Inman never trusted Mr. Casey, who shut him out of covert operations and was a disorganized manager, and the admiral left the job and left town as soon as it was politically acceptable.
After a 60-day, 11,000 mile driving tour of the western United States with his wife, Nancy, and their two sons, the gangly, 6-foot-2 military man with the brush cut and the boyish grin went back to Texas.

HEADLINE: CHANGE AT THE PENTAGON;
Statements by President Clinton and His Nominee to Head the Pentagon

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Clinton's announcement yesterday of the appointment of Bobby Ray Inman as Secretary of Defense and Mr. Inman's acceptance of that appointment, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times:
 
By PRESIDENT CLINTON
Ladies and gentlemen, yesterday I announced that Secretary Aspin would be stepping down as Secretary of Defense next month after a year of devoted service. I want to stress again how deeply grateful I am on behalf of all Americans for his hard work and his many unique contributions to the Pentagon and to our national defense. 
 To insure the greatest possible continuity, I wanted to announce the successor as soon as possible. So today I am very pleased to announce my intent to nominate Adm. Bob Inman as the next Secretary of Defense.
Admiral Inman was one of our nation's highest-ranking and most-respected military officers. He was a four-star admiral whose career in the Navy and in our intelligence community and in private business has won him praise from both Democrats and Republicans who admire his intellect, his integrity and his leadership ability.
The admiral's experience in serving our nation is truly impressive. He personally briefed Presidents Eisenhower and Kennedy. He held senior positions under Presidents Ford, Carter, Reagan and Bush. Former Secretary of Defense James Schlesinger called Admiral Inman a national asset, and I know he will be a national asset as Secretary of Defense.
He brings to this job the kind of character all Americans respect. The son of a gas station owner in a small East Texas town, he rose to distinction and success on the basis of his brains, his talent and his hard work.
He finished high school at 15, graduate from college at 19, joined the Naval Reserve at 20 and then launched an impressive 31-year career in the Navy. He served on an aircraft carrier, two cruisers and a destroyer as well as in onshore assignments as an analyst for naval intelligence. In 1976, at the age of 45, he became the youngest vice admiral in peacetime history.
Bob Inman's stellar intelligence work caught the attention of many military and civilian leaders and prompted his elevation to several high posts in the intelligence community. He served as vice director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, director of the National Security Agency and deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Because of his outstanding service, he was awarded the National Security Medal by President Carter.
Over the past decade, since Admiral Inman left government, he's served in a wide range of private sector positions, including C.E.O. of two private sector electronics firms, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas and a teacher at his alma mater, the University of Texas. He's also served on 11 not-for-profit corporate boards. And in all these roles, Admiral Inman has established a reputation for penetrating analysis, strong leadership and a rock-solid commitment to this nation's security.
Those qualities will serve our nation well as the admiral becomes our next Secretary of Defense. This is a time of great change in our world. We must build on the work Les Aspin began with the bottom-up review to insure that we have the right forces and strategy for this new era. We must insure that even as we reduce force levels, our military remains ready to fight and win on a moment's notice.
We must insure that our men and women in uniform remain the best-trained, the best-equipped, the best-prepared fighting force on earth. And we must maintain and build strong bipartisan support in the Congress and in the country for the foreign policy and national defense interest of our nation.
I am confident that Admiral Inman is the right leader to meet these demanding challenges. I'm grateful that he's agreed to make the personal sacrifices necessary to return to full-time government service and to accept this important assignment at this pivotal time in world events.
I'm delighted that he will be joining our national security team, and I thank him for his service to the nation. Admiral.
 
By MR. INMAN
Thank you, Mr. President.
You do me great honor with this appointment. Notwithstanding all the wonderful things you said, I am an imperfect human being who has been provided many wonderful opportunities -- none quite yet of the status of this. I've not done all of them as well as I would like. But I've always worked hard at them, and I will work hard at this one.
As you know, I did not seek the job, honestly, and I did not want the job. Ultimately, you would ask then, why am I here?
Duty and country. I was persuaded from our lengthy conversations of the President's absolute commitment to build a strong bipartisan support for where this country needs to go in the years out ahead. I would tell you up front, honestly, I did not vote for President Clinton. I voted for President Bush, even though I was mad at him about his handling of the economy, but because I considered him a personal friend. The President did know that when he asked me to take this job.
I look forward to the challenges that are in front of us. I particularly look forward to working with the senior members of the national security team. Warren Christopher I consider an old friend, and someone I not only enjoy working with but I greatly admire. Tony Lake is a new acquaintance to me but in these very few short days, there's been a great start.
But ultimately, the key to my being willing to do this, to give up a very happy and prosperous life, was the President's commitment and our interaction. I had to be comfortable that he was persuaded I was the right choice for this time frame. And, Mr. President, as you know, I had to reach a level of comfort that we could work together, that I would be very comfortable in your role as the Commander in Chief, President, while I was Secretary of Defense. And I have found that level of comfort.
As I look at the challenges in front of us, the road ahead is already pretty well mapped. I've had the privilege of knowing Les Aspin for more than 15 years. He is truly one of the great intellects in this country. From the first meeting, he's always been challenging: What was the best approach to national security for this country? I'm persuaded that the work he's done over these last 11 months will make it vastly easier for his successor. But it won't be an easy job.
As I've tried to describe myself, I'm an operator, hopefully with a strategic view. I would hope, in the years ahead, to focus on an area that may surprise you. I've noted the media coverage this morning has focused almost entirely on my intelligence background. But in these last 10 years I've learned a lot about how business works, and I would hope to spend a lot of my time on bringing best business practices to the Department of Defense. My sense in traveling the country is that the public is less concerned about what we're doing overseas or our commitments than whether we are getting a dollar value for a dollar spent on defense.
And I would hope at the end of our years of working together, we will have persuaded them, Mr. President, that they are. And I would hope to insure that we practice standards of ethics and integrity in the Department of Defense that will be a beacon for the rest of government.
Finally, to my many friends in the media, both here and around the country -- there've been, at my last count, some 82 calls last night and this morning for interviews -- if we are going to build a bipartisan support for national security, it has to begin with establishing the best relationship with the Congress. I will be deeply respectful of the Senate's approach to the confirmation process. I believe, therefore, it will be wisest if I limit my public remarks on issues until the confirmation process is through, and then I will try to be as available to all of you in the future as I have been in the past.
Thank you very much and thank you, Mr. President, for your confidence.

HEADLINE: Gore Signs Pacts in Moscow on Joint Shuttle Crews and Oil and Gas

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Insisting that they would not be deterred by political uncertainty, the United States and Russia formally joined as partners today on an international space station and announced that the first Russian astronaut would fly in the space shuttle Discovery in six weeks.
While both sides had agreed to the basic space accord, the agreement today formally ended decades of rivalry between Moscow and Washington. 
 Russia also accepted an invitation to join the United States, Europe, Japan and Canada in building a revamped space station. An orbiting space laboratory involving all the partners could be operating by 2001.
Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin also signed agreements on economic development, high-technology ventures, the environment and oil and gas exploration. Some pacts were for small but possibly fruitful projects, like plans to build as many as 25 privately financed gas stations in Russia.
 
Commitment to Yeltsin
 Mr. Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin said at a news conference that the 17 agreements were an important sign of Washington's commitment to Russia after parliamentary elections on Sunday in which a faction that opposes President Boris N. Yeltsin's political and economic reforms did far better than expected.
"The Russian Government is committed to reform," Mr. Gore said. "President Yeltsin and Prime Minister Chernomyrdin have reaffirmed the need to press forward." The agreements, he said, "demonstrated that we are building even more momentum."
Mr. Chernomyrdin closed the news conference with an appeal to Americans to take home the message that the two countries should put behind them the years of mutual mistrust. Waving his fist, he declared, "Tell them there's no need to be afraid of Russia, no reason to fear Russia."
In his last day in Moscow before traveling to St. Petersburg, Mr. Gore also sought to help Lubavitcher Jews in their long struggle to get the Russia State Library to release 12,000 sacred volumes that have been locked up for more than 70 years.
 
Sending a Book to Brooklyn
 After Mr. Gore examined several volumes at what was once called the Lenin Library, Yevgeny Y. Sidorov, the Culture Minister, gave him one volumes as "a token of good will and a step in the right direction."
Mr. Gore turned the book over to Rabbi Baruch Shlomo Cunin, who plans to fly to New York on Friday to deliver it to Menachem M. Schneerson, the Rebbe of Lubavich, who presides over the Hasidic sect from his headquarters in Brooklyn.
"This is a wonderful humanitarian gesture," Mr. Gore said, "and I am grateful for it."
The Vice President, who had pressed for release of the books when he was a Senator, said that talks on the collection were continuing and that he believed they would lead "toward a successful resolution."
 
Gazing Into Outer Space
 Most of Mr. Gore's visit was devoted to meetings with Mr. Chernomydrin, and much of the focus has been on space exploration.
In addition to assigning Russians to United States shuttles, one agreement calls for four or more American astronauts to spend 24-day stints aboard the Mir space station launched by Russia.
The United States is to pay the Russian space agency up to $400 million through 1997 for materials and other services for their joint ventures.
In another show of support, Mr. Gore went to the Russian space operations center when he arrived this week and spoke to a Russian astronaut in orbit. The astronaut, who has been on Mir for 166 days, told Mr. Gore: "We're looking forward to working together with the United States astronauts when they come aboard."
 
Expressions of Confidence
 Mr. Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin brushed aside the notion that the political turmoil in Russia could endanger Moscow's ability to fulfill its promises. Mr. Gore also rejected criticism by some experts in the United States that Russian launch facilities are in disrepair, saying, "We have every confidence that we will succeed."
Among the agreements signed today were these:
*A commitment to a joint United States-Russian technology center, scheduled to open in Tyumen in June, to improve the Russian oil and gas industry.
*A pledge by Russia to improve the safety of its older nuclear reactors and to join the United States in examining alternative energy sources.
*A treaty to limit the taxes paid by United States investors in Russia, which is intended to expand business.
Mr. Chernomyrdin and Mr. Gore met in Washington in September to pave the way for some of the agreements signed today. Mr. Chernomyrdin plans to return to Washington next year for further talks.

She led a group of Russian students on a photographic expedition in Red Square in Moscow, to produce pictures that will be seen by high school students in Washington. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Drug Spotlight Falls on an Unblinking Cali Cartel

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CALI, Colombia

 BODY:
When radio bulletins flashed the news of Pablo Escobar's death, residents of this city celebrated with caravans of horn-tooting cars. White flags flew from pharmacies owned by a prominent Cali cocaine-trafficking family.
Indeed, there is little doubt that the Cali cartel aided the Government in its drive against Mr. Escobar, leader of the rival Medellin trafficking ring, who was killed by the police on Dec. 2. 
 "Hey, we helped the Government with intelligence," said a man who identified himself as a midlevel member in the Cali cartel, asserting that the cartel "paid $5 million every two months to the Pepes," a death squad that hunted Mr. Escobar before he was killed.
The death of Mr. Escobar cemented the ascendancy of the Cali smugglers, who now control 75 percent of Colombia's cocaine and heroin exports. The Cali group is led by the brothers Miguel and Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela, but they are more loosely knit than the group run by Mr. Escobar. And because they have preferred bribes over bullets, the Cali smugglers have operated with relative impunity while the Government battled it out with the bloodthirsty Medellin traffickers.
 
Attention Switches to Cali
 But with the Medellin group largely dismantled, world attention has suddenly swiveled 200 miles south to Cali, long a quiet city set on the Cauca River in the green foothills of the Andes.
Cesar Gaviria, Colombia's President, vowed, "Not only the Cali cartel, but all the cartels have to know that our state has a firm policy of fighting drug trafficking and that we are going to persist."
The United States Ambassador to Colombia, Morris D. Busby, announced on national television: "Pablo Escobar's death and the dismantling of the Medellin cartel are great successes for Colombia. But now they should continue with the Cali cartel."
[On Dec. 15, the United States Embassy in Bogota announced that about 120 United States Army engineers were to arrive in Colombia in late December for a 10-week construction project on Malaga Bay, about 60 miles northwest of Cali.
[An embassy spokesman said the project, which calls for repairing roads and building a school and a hospital, "should have absolutely nothing to do with the proximity of the Cali cartel." But Colombian radio reports on the announcement spoke of the impending arrival of "gringo troops," and a newspaper wondered about a "U.S.A. Invasion."]
 
Deals Are in the Air
 Faced with this unwelcome new attention, leading traffickers no longer appear in restaurants and discotheques here, and have instructed their lawyers to speed up negotiations for deals, under a new penal code approved in November, that would legalize their multimillion-dollar fortunes in return for surrender and a few years in a local prison or under house arrest.
Several cartel leaders have said they want to pave the way for their Harvard- and Stanford-educated children to become legitimate business leaders. But many people are skeptical that the families will abandon the $25 billion a year cocaine business.
"No one is about to give it up," the midlevel trafficker said, talking on the condition that he not be identified by name. "Cali controls the markets. They have got planes, cocaine routes, big protection costs. Nobody believes that they are going to give up the business."
Many doubt that the Government will try hard to force them to give up. President Gaviria shows no sign of shifting to Cali the 3,000-strong military and police unit that was used to hunt Mr. Escobar in Medellin. Colombian society does not appear to have the stomach for a repeat of the frontal attack on the Medellin traffickers, a war that cost thousands of dead since 1989.
Decriminalization of cocaine, once a taboo topic, has been advocated in recent weeks by a series of Colombian notables: Gustavo de Greiff, the Attorney General; Antonio Navarro Wolf, a left-wing presidential candidate, and Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Nobel Prize-winning Colombian novelist.
 
Cartel Controls the City
 Should it choose to attack, the Government faces a formidable foe.
"The Cali cartel is bigger than anyone gives it credit," an American drug expert said in Bogota. "Their political and economic influence is unprecedented. They have complete control of the city. They have bought the majority of the cops. If the cabdrivers at the airport see anyone suspicious, they call a special number and get several thousand pesos. There isn't a politician in the Valle del Cauca who isn't on the payroll or intimidated."
The self-described midlevel trafficker agreed. "It's a paradise for narcos here," the 32-year-old cartel veteran said as he took a visitor on an impromptu tour of the city. "The police and the airport are bought."
The cocaine business is so widely tolerated that a visiting reporter needs nothing more than a telephone to set up an appointment with a drug trafficker, in this case a gregarious man who enjoyed showing off his English.
Shaving red lights as he rocketed down Roosevelt Avenue in a big American sedan, he pointed out neon-lit shopping centers, new high-rises and luxury car dealerships -- all investments by gang leaders eager to build legitimate business empires. "It's starting to look like Miami, isn't it?" he said.
Construction cranes and boxy buildings are rapidly reshaping the skyline of a city of orange roofs that for four centuries was the genteel preserve of cotton, coffee and sugar cane baronies. Last year, Cali, with one-third of Bogota's population of six million, matched the capital in new construction.
On Sixth Avenue, traffic slowed to a crawl as luxury four-wheel-drive vehicles with tinted windows cruised past flashy new discos, like the three-story, lime green Latin Palace.
"You have 1,000 boys worth over $50 million," the driver said.
 
'Then They Shoot You'
 Called traquetos after the sound of a machine pistol, the younger gang lords are insecure millionaires. They demand instant respect.
"You see a nice car, it must be a mafioso, so you stay back," said the guide, an employee of an older, more established drug trafficking house. "The traquetos are very dangerous. You're sitting in a disco, and they say, 'Why are you looking at my girl?' Then they shoot you."
Traquetos have been known to sweep into a disco and announce that they will pick up everyone's tab. There is one proviso: no one can leave the premises before they do. Sometimes they stay for more than a day.
Traditionally known for its civility, Cali registered 1,268 murders in the first nine months of this year, just shy of Bogota's level. To cool the murder rate, the Mayor declared that all pistol permits were invalid from dusk to dawn on weekends. Enforced with police and army checkpoints, the program has cut the average number of weekend murders in half, to 14.
Repeatedly waved through army checkpoints during three hours of cruising the town, the guide had no worries about the authorities.
"A retired army lieutenant does our security," he said. "He knows which police officer has received how much, whose wife has received a new car."
"When the heat gets too strong, the police call the Rodriguez Orejuelas and say, 'We have to hit some labs,' " he said. "They pull out the drugs. There never is a big seizure in Valle."
 
A Nervous Moment
 Free of police worries, the tour guide showed genuine nervousness only once during an evening of horn-honking, lane-cutting driving.
Toward midnight, he was cruising Ciudad Jardin, an exclusive suburban neighborhood where winking Christmas lights festooned front yards. As he approached the 10-foot-high floodlit walls that hid from public view one of the Rodriguez Orejuela residences, he accelerated and sped past .
"They have their own patrol cars," he said. "It's best not to attract attention."
Cali authorities believe that the United States is unfairly targeting their city.
"Why don't Americans start looking for the California cartel, or the New York cartel?" asked Carlos Holguin Sardi, Governor of Valle del Cauca State, of which Cali is capital. "There is no drug trade, no refining and no transportation from Valle."
Others acknowledge that cocaine trafficking accounts for part of the state's $7 billion economy, but they insist that it is a small part.
"We have recorded half a century of steady economic growth in Valle,"said Fabio Rodriguez Gonzalez, president of the Cali Chamber of Commerce.
 
A Threat Brings Yawns
 Valle has factories from 40 multinational companies, a stock exchange that is second only to Bogota's, and a Pacific Ocean port, Buenaventura, that handles 60 percent of Colombia's legitimate foreign trade.
But with Cali's clandestine cocaine industry injecting hundreds of millions of dollars into the local economy every year, it is hard to find a voice here advocating radical action against it.
A few days after Mr. Escobar's death, Octavio Vargas Silva, the police general who directed the manhunt, publicly warned leaders of the Cali cartel to surrender "or suffer the same fate as Pablo Escobar."

HEADLINE: South Korea Changes Premiers Over Rice Protest

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Accelerating a drive for reform that has shaken the Government, President Kim Young Sam dismissed his Prime Minister today and replaced him with a former Supreme Court justice.
The reform efforts, in which Mr. Kim has taken on some of the country's most powerful institutions, have been little noticed outside South Korea, largely because they have been overshadowed by the showdown with North Korea over its nuclear program. 
 The new Prime Minister, Lee Hoi Chang, has become a popular figure in South Korea by leading an investigation into a corruption scandal that eventually forced some of the nation's military leadership to resign.
The ostensible reason for the dismissal of Prime Minister Hwang In Sung was the Government's highly unpopular decision to open South Korea's rice market as part of the world trade deal announced this week. Mr. Kim had repeatedly vowed never to allow foreign rice into the country, and his reversal prompted street protests.
Mr. Hwang said today that he was being sacrificed in an effort to quell the public outcry over the rice issue, which many South Koreans believe is far more important than North Korea's nuclear ambitions.
The Prime Minister's post in South Korea commands little real authority, but Mr. Hwang was considered something of a holdover from the military-backed Governments that ran South Korea for nearly three decades until Mr. Kim was elected a year ago. The choice of the 58-year-old Mr. Lee, officials said, was intended to signal that the Government's attack on corruption and the financial system will continue.
Mr. Kim's entire Cabinet offered to resign today, a traditional gesture when a new Prime Minister is appointed. And although Government officials said that several ministers with economic portfolios will likely be replaced, Mr. Kim was expected to retain the key ministers involved in the sensitive talks with North Korea and the United States over inspections of the North's suspected nuclear sites.
The new Prime Minister may in fact end up in a critical role in the continuing negotiations with North Korea. It is usually the Prime Minister, rather than South Korea's President, who negotiates with North Korean officials.
Mr. Lee had served as the head of the Board of Audit and Inspection, until this year a relatively powerless group within the South Korean Government. But as soon as Mr. Kim was elected, he began an investigation into charges that the military had sought bribes from defense contractors in return for awarding lucrative contracts that were part of a major expansion of South Korea's military capability.
By July, Mr. Lee had worked with prosecutors to arrest two former Defense Ministers and some senior uniformed officers. At one point the investigation seemed likely to engulf two former South Korean Presidents, Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo, both of whom were questioned. But no legal action was taken against either.
Mr. Lee's investigation made him one of South Korea's most popular figures, and the inquiry was considered remarkable in a country that just a few years ago openly wondered if the military would again seek to take power.
"This time the military could do nothing," a former senior Government official said. "There were no vacuums to fill, no way to claim that the country was being saved from chaos."
In another case Mr. Lee took on the powerful National Security Planning Agency, once known as the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, for exaggerating North Korea's alleged threat to flood Seoul by releasing millions of gallons of water stored by a so-called "Peace Dam" just above the North Korean border.
The warnings led to a huge project to build a compensating dam system that would contain or divert the water. Mr. Lee determined that much of the work was motivated by companies seeking Government contracts, rather than a real threat of flooding.
Based partly on those findings and partly on his suspicions of the intelligence agency that date back to his own years as an opposition leader, Mr. Kim has significantly scaled back the group's power and budget.
