HEADLINE: Tokyo Panel Calls for Wide Economic Reform

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 16

 BODY:
An advisory commission to Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa called today for wide-ranging reform of the Japanese economy, including lifting of regulations, increased spending on public works, development of an information superhighway, a cut in income taxes and renewed efforts to reduce Japan's towering trade surplus.
A basic theme of the commission's report, which is supposed to serve as a blueprint for Japan's economic development over the next few years, is that Japan must rely less on exports for future growth and more on greater spending within Japan to improve people's living standards. Many of the measures recommended by the commission have long been advocated by the United States and Japan's other trading partners. 
 But while the report was considered broad, it also lacked specifics, prompting the Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's leading newspapers, to conclude that the document "lacks power as a new prescription for the Japanese economy." And there are doubts about the extent to which the recommendations will be implemented.
Yotaro Kobayashi, chairman of the Fuji Xerox Company and a member of the commission, said he expected that the report would have "a very important impact on how Japan's economy will proceed in the years to come."
But he added that how influential it will ultimately be "will depend very much on how long Mr. Hosokawa's Government will last."
The Prime Minister, who has made improving the lot of Japan's consumers one of his platforms, is presiding over a shaky coalition Government that almost splintered this week over his decision to partly open the nation's rice market to imports.
He must still achieve reform of Japan's corruption-tainted electoral system and a new economic stimulus package. The current session of Parliament will be extended until the end of January to give him a chance to achieve those goals.
The Advisory Group for Economic Restructuring, as the commission is called, is headed by Gaishi Hiraiwa, chairman of the Keidanren, Japan's most powerful business lobbying organization. Appointed by Mr. Hosokawa, the commission has been meeting since September and issued a preliminary report in November calling for the elimination or easing of nearly 500 regulations.
Today's final report incorporates the deregulation recommendations but covers many other topics as well.
One new issue was the recommendation of an income tax cut of unspecified size in the near future to try to jolt Japan's economy out of its stubborn recession. Although the committee was charged with looking at medium- and long-term reform of the economy, it said there would be little point in talking about the long term unless Japan could escape from its short-term difficulties.
A United States official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the report "lays out a positive agenda, a reformist agenda that we think is moving in the right direction." But he added that "it depends on a strong government" to carry out the reforms.
Gerard Legris, a spokesman for the European Community's mission in Tokyo, also praised the report's direction, but said, "What we are looking for is not a list of intentions but assurance that they will be implemented."
Japan's powerful Government bureaucrats are resistant to deregulation that would weaken their control over business activity. Mr. Kobayashi of Fuji Xerox said bureaucrats were partly responsible for the report's being watered down so that, for instance, there are no figures as to how much taxes should be cut or how much public works spending should be increased.
The new report in some ways echoes a 1986 report that was also supposed to serve as a blueprint for the transformation of Japan's economy from being export-oriented to being driven by domestic demand. But many of the recommendations of the the 1986 document were not carried out. That was in part because a boom in the late 1980's removed some of the impetus for economic reform.

HEADLINE: Nantes Journal;
Unhappily, a Port Confronts Its Past: Slave Trade

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NANTES, France

 BODY:
Along the quays of the Loire, fine mansions speak of the time when Nantes was a great port that loomed large in France's colonial history.
Behind the pilasters and wrought-iron balconies lived the shipbuilders and sea captains who, local lore has it, bravely crossed the Atlantic and returned with precious produce from French possessions in the Americas. But few people here knew -- or chose to remember -- why exactly Nantes became so rich. 
 Breaking a taboo, the city has mounted an exhibition showing that its past wealth came largely from running slaves from Africa to the New World. So proficient was its fleet that Nantes became France's largest port and chief slave trader.
In the 18th century and well into the 19th, Nantes alone launched some 1,800 expeditions to buy African captives, hauling more than 500,000 men and women to the Americas. Slave ships from this port frequently sold their human cargo in Haiti, where plantation owners were often from Nantes, but they also dropped anchor elsewhere in the Caribbean and on the Louisiana coast.
Facing this painful past has not been easy for Nantes. "This exhibit had a hard time starting," said Marie Helene Juzeau, its present curator. "It seemed too sensitive, too difficult."
 
200,000 See Exhibit
 From 1984, plans were blocked by a conservative Mayor and prominent local families, including descendants of the slavers, who said the exhibition would stir no interest and only give the city a bad name. But three years ago a new Socialist Mayor agreed to finance the project.
Nearly 200,000 people have already come to the castle of the Dukes of Brittany where the exhibit opened a year ago. Now the city has decided to extend it until May 29.
Several other European cities are confronting their slavers' past, which schoolbooks have commonly glossed over. Le Havre, France, and Liege, Belgium, had exhibits on slave trading -- though modest ones -- in 1986 and 1989 respectively. In Britain, Liverpool, which became Europe's dominant slave-trading city in the 18th century, is preparing a large permanent exhibit on slavery to open next year.
 
A Triangular Trade
 At Nantes, documents, drawings and objects convey how the slave business operated here and how this and many other European cities profited from what became known as "the triangular trade." (The same ships carried European goods to Africa, exchanged them for slaves, took the slaves to the Americas and returned to Europe loaded with sugar, tobacco, coffee, cacao and other tropical produce.)
The exhibit explains how a Nantes shipowner, to spread his risks, would often sell shares in a "slaving expedition." The money raised would finance the crew, food needed on board and cargo destined for the tribal rulers of Africa's west coast who sold the slaves to the traders.
Records of the African-bound cargo are ample and typically include guns, alcohol, beads and textiles, to be bartered for slaves. Some documents include "useful tips," like what gifts were expected by African kings before they would even agree to discuss business.
Sometimes transactions are recorded in great detail, like those between a Nantes trader and King Pepel of Bany in the Niger delta. On May 20, 1790, the trader, for example, bought a female slave from the King for many items, including 2 cloths, 3 guns, 20 knives, a bowl, 4 hats, 4 chains.
Some documents also hint at the cruelty of the operation. One notes that plenty of drinking water was needed on board to preserve the lives of the human cargo. But once the hold of a slave ship was full and it set off across the ocean, documents note, conditions were often so bad that 10 to 20 percent of the 300 or more slaves might die on the journey. Upon arrival, the trader could get up to five times the price he paid for a captive in Africa.
 
Trade Spawns Own Economy
 In Nantes and elsewhere in Europe, the slave trade spawned its own economy. From 1707 to 1847, records show, 3,829 slaving "expeditions" left from France alone. They generated vast business for shipyards, timber merchants, rope and sail makers. Glassmakers in Bohemia and Venice sold masses of beads and other trinkets destined for barter. Smiths made chains, shackles, spiked collars and other instruments to control the slaves. Manufacturers produced guns and ammunition for the traders and for barter in Africa.
Textiles to pay for slaves became so important, the exhibit notes, that in 1780 Nantes had more than 10 textile mills, employing 4,500 workers.
One ship of slaves could yield up to three or four shiploads of coffee, sugar, indigo, cacao, cotton -- produced by slave labor. Back in Nantes, as elsewhere in Europe, this cargo spawned sugar, chocolate, textile mills. Because of this economic web, Nantes kept trading slaves clandestinely for almost 20 years after France banned it in 1817. Yet a 12-volume history of Nantes published in 1843 devotes just one page to slavery.
A number of African officials have visited the Nantes show and asked for it to travel to West Africa. But when Nantes asked if it would interest Bordeaux, another important slave-trading city, it was given short shrift. More interested in its links with wine, Bordeaux said: no thanks.

HEADLINE: Roles Shifted For Deputies By Giuliani

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Shuffling his deputies' powers even before he becomes Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he would broaden the duties of Ninfa Segarra, now a member of the Board of Education, putting her in charge of New York City's vast array of health agencies and social services.
The announcement of Ms. Segarra's expanded portfolio as a deputy mayor came as Mr. Giuliani appointed Fran Reiter to be the third of what will ultimately be four deputy mayors. He said Ms. Reiter, the chairwoman of the state's Liberal Party, would be in charge of planning and community relations, assuming some of the duties that Mr. Giuliani had assigned to Ms. Segarra only two weeks ago. 
"What I said at the time that I appointed Ninfa was all of these things were subject to change, based upon the other people we appointed," Mr. Giuliani said at a news conference at his transition headquarters in Manhattan. "So there really is no change at all."
 
Welfare and Foster Care
 Ms. Segarra will now oversee not only Mr. Giuliani's education policies but presumably also the city's Departments of Health, Youth Services and Aging, as well as the sprawling Human Resources Administration, which runs the welfare and foster-care systems.
In a city where more than 1 million residents receive some form of public assistance, health and social welfare are among the most significant and pressing issues facing Mr. Giuliani, particularly given the billion-dollar gaps he most close in the city's budget.
The expanded duties of Ms. Segarra drew immediate criticism from women's organizations and gay groups, particularly those angered by her views as a member of the conservative majority on the Board of Education that ousted Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez amid disputes over the distribution of condoms and lessons about AIDS.
"I'm scared about what this means for the AIDS crisis, which is the biggest health issue facing the city," said Denny Lee, a spokesman for Act Up, an AIDS protest group that staged an early-morning protest yesterday outside Mr. Giuliani's apartment on the Upper East Side. "She's not going to be healthy for the city."
With the appointments of Ms. Segarra, Ms. Reiter and Peter J. Powers, whom Mr. Giuliani has made his top deputy, the Mayor-elect has now assembled the core of his cabinet. So far, he has appointed three deputies who have virtually no experience in municipal government.
Mr. Giuliani said he would soon announce the last deputy mayor, to oversee finance and economic development. At that time, he said, he will provide a breakdown of agencies that fall under each of the four deputies.
The division of duties -- vital to the efficiency of City Hall and something over which Mr. Giuliani has often criticized Mayor David N. Dinkins -- has been discussed at some length by Mr. Giuliani and his aides as he assembles his administration.
Ms. Reiter, who as deputy campaign manager often acted as Mr. Giuliani's liaison to women and gay organizations, had been under consideration to take over the administration of the city's health agencies and social services.
Ms. Reiter said the discussions over who would be in charge of what continued through Wednesday. Mr. Powers said the division of duties had been "evolving over the last few days."
Mr. Giuliani said that in dividing the roles of his deputies, he was mindful of his pledge to reduce the size of his City Hall and that he expected "four deputy mayors will be doing the work of six" -- the number who now serve under Mayor Dinkins.
While commissioners are in charge of the day-to-day operations of the city's various agencies, deputy mayors have responsibility over broad areas of programs and policies. A deputy mayor's power, though, depends at least in part on his or her relationship with the Mayor.
 
'A Better Arrangement'
 "We decided that a better arrangement, given the talents and interests and the direction in which we wanted to see the city go, would be to give Ninfa the responsibility for what is a very major area of the city, of the city's budget," Mr. Giuliani said. "And therefore it made more sense for Fran to have responsibility in the community-relations areas."
Ms. Segarra, who is 43 and a lawyer, has served in a number of positions in city government since 1977, including as legal counsel to the Mayor's Office for the Handicapped and as executive director of the Voter Assistance Commission.
But she has little experience in managing a huge bureaucracy like the one Mr. Giuliani has assigned to her. Asked if he was worried about the relative inexperience of his three deputies, Mr. Giuliani replied with a smile, "Do I look worried?"
Mr. Giuliani expressed confidence in Ms. Segarra's ability to shove the city's health and social services in a new direction. "There are a lot of directions we want to go that are different than the current administration," he said.
The Mayor-elect demurred, however, when asked about specific changes he expected. Asked about the program of providing clean needles to drug addicts to combat the spread of AIDS, which Mr. Dinkins first opposed but later instituted, Mr. Giuliani repeated his opposition but said that he, as Mr. Dinkins had, would rethink it after a study of its viability.
Diane H. Welsh, president of New York City chapter of National Organization for Women, expressed concern that Ms. Segarra had not been involved in a broad range of issues involving health and social services and that her role would be "solely to cut programs that will be desperately needed." She added, "I don't think she'll be very sympathetic to a large range of concerns that have been raised in this city."
Ms. Reiter, who is 39 and has worked as a television marketing consultant for 15 years, will be responsible for the Department of Parks and Recreation, the Department of City Planning and the Community Development Agency, which distributes Federal poverty grants.
 
An Uncertain Fate
 Another agency that Ms. Reiter will oversee is the city's Human Rights Commission, which Mr. Giuliani has indicated might face elimination as an unnecessary replication of the role of the state's Human Rights Commission. The agency's possible elimination or consolidation, Mr. Giuliani said, is "one of the areas, along with many, many others" being studied by committees reviewing the city's agencies for him.
City Councilman Charles Millard, a Republican and Giuliani supporter who received Liberal Party backing, praised Ms. Reiter's appointment, saying she would prove an asset to the new Mayor in his dealings with an overwhelmingly Democratic Council.
"As the chairwoman of the Liberal Party, she can build bridges between Republicans and Democrats," he said. "Many Democrats in the Council don't owe anything to Rudy, but they owe things to her."
At yesterday's news conference, Mr. Giuliani also named Nydia Negron, a former television reporter, to be deputy press secretary, serving under Cristyne Lategano.

HEADLINE: Texas Lawyers to Vote on How Far Their Ads Can Go

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 16

 BODY:
In his most talked-about television advertisement, Brian Loncar is sitting at what appears to be his office desk. "If you've been injured in a car accident, do what hundreds of people have already done: bring your troubles to me," Mr. Loncar declares. An "800" number flashes on the screen. Then a car comes crashing through the ceiling above Mr. Loncar, smashing his balsa wood desk to smithereens.
"I'm attorney Brian Loncar and I can help," he continues, reaching under the wreckage for a telephone. "Hurt in a car accident? Haven't gotten your check yet? Call me." 
 Only the most reclusive resident of Dallas could possibly have missed the advertisement, which was broadcast some 800 times on five local television stations earlier this year. In local airwaves saturated with the sound of lawyers peddling their wares, Mr. Loncar is the undisputed sultan of salesmanship, spending nearly $500,000 a year on ads. But if the Texas legal establishment has its way, his flamboyant commercials and those of his competitors will soon become extinct.
Monday afternoon marks the deadline for Texas's 57,326 lawyers to vote in an unusual referendum. The question before them is whether to place restrictions on lawyer advertising, electronic and print, including bans on actors, jingles, dramatizations, pie-in-the-sky promises and appeals to the emotions.
Hardly anything is more quintessentially American than lawyers and advertising. But 16 years after the United States Supreme Court ruled that lawyers have a constitutional right to market themselves, the debate over their advertising continues to rage with surprising ferocity, particularly among lawyers themselves. Neither in its 1977 ruling nor in several subsequent decisions has the High Court pinpointed what is permissible. Texas is only one of several states still trying to draw the line.
 
Ads Have Grown Tame
 Though it may be hard to believe, lawyer advertising has grown more tame over time. Gone are the criminal defense lawyers impersonating death row inmates lamenting their choice of counsel, or divorce lawyers taking chain saws to furniture. But according to William E. Hornsby, staff counsel to the American Bar Association's Commission on Advertising, two-thirds of the states have re-evaluated their rules in the past three years. Half of those have either adopted or are considering curbs.
The restrictions take a variety of forms. Several states now require disclaimers, stating either that the decision to hire a lawyer should not be based solely on an advertisement, or that a lawyer's past success does not guarantee future victories. Some states ban the use of celebrities, at least when they are not real clients. Georgia prohibits instrumental music; Mississippi insists that lawyers touting their "juris doctor" degrees disclose that every lawyer has one.
The Texas proposal would amend the state's disciplinary rules to bar advertisements "likely to create an unjustified expectation" about results or that boast of a lawyer's superiority to others, unless he can prove it. Most important, it provides that all advertising "shall be presented without appeals primarily to emotion." That would presumably eliminate jail doors slamming shut, sirens wailing, horns honking, tires screeching, cars crashing, glass breaking and medical equipment beeping, though such questions would be for a new "lawyer advertisement and solicitation review committee" to ponder.
Here as elsewhere, the debate is impassioned, filled with talk of free speech, consumer protection, protectionism, professionalism and taste.
The campaign, which has gone into high gear since ballots were mailed last month, has exposed several fissures in the profession: between older and younger lawyers, established and upstart lawyers, rural and urban lawyers, plaintiffs' and defense lawyers, richer and poorer lawyers, nostalgic and realistic lawyers, corporate lawyers in large, conservative law firms and knots of lawyers in personal injury or criminal practices.
At first blush, the balance of forces on the referendum could not seem more lopsided. Standing behind the measure is the cream of the Texas legal establishment, including the State Bar of Texas, the Texas Trial Lawyers Association, the Texas Young Lawyers Association, the Texas Association of Defense Counsel and the bar associations of Houston and Dallas. Just about the only group against it is Texans Against Censorship, an ad hoc organization to which Mr. Loncar and other lawyer-advertisers belong.
But in this contest, Goliath appears to be the underdog. Whatever the vote on the merits, the referendum is null and void unless a majority of the lawyers in the state participate in it. The question everyone is asking, then, is not how many lawyers will vote for the new restrictions but how many lawyers will vote, period.
As of noon today, only 42.53 percent of the state's lawyers had sent their ballots to the State Bar in Austin. This is despite furious campaigning by the State Bar's current president, Lonny Morrison of Wichita Falls; a telephone bank set up by the Young Lawyers, and reminder cards sent to recalcitrant members by the State Bar, which offered replacement ballots to anyone who had tossed out the original.
"Everyone knows lawyers put things off to the very last minute," Mr. Morrison said. "But as of this moment, we're essentially 4,900 votes short, and unless something startling should develop, that's a lot of ballots to think will flutter in Friday and Monday. There's a good bit of apathy, I regret to say."
Supporters of the restrictions believe that a few cheesy ads have inflamed public antipathy toward the entire profession. "Some lawyers advertise their services as if they were the latest deodorant on the market or the newest detergent," Mr. Morrison said. "It makes us look hungrier than is consistent with our professional responsibilities." And if the lawyers of Texas do not get their own house in order and bring their own miscreants to heel, he and others add, the State Legislature gladly will.
Those who oppose restrictions counter that it is not the public that is upset with their commercials, but other lawyers. According to Mr. Loncar, these include lawyers for insurance companies; small-town lawyers losing clients to big-city advertisers and trial lawyers too cheap, hidebound or unimaginative to advertise themselves.
In its campaign literature, Texans Against Censorship has called the proposed changes "elitist, Neanderthal and self-serving." The ban on emotion-mongering has it especially upset. "When censors train their cross hair on advertising's ability to attract attention, they aim at the ads' effectiveness, not its deceptiveness," the group states. "The censors' furtive mission is to make advertising so meaningless that it won't work, to effectively silence those who dare to break tradition and overtly compete."
Mr. Loncar concedes that some lawyer advertising is undignified, but says that with a variety of negative images of lawyers being portrayed, restricting advertisements is not going improve the public's perception of the Bar.
If the proposal dies, however, the mortal blow may have been delivered by the state's largest law firms. Though marginally affected by the measure -- they would have to submit even their usually discrete, written solicitations for approval -- it has little emotional or economic relevance for them. The management at one of Houston's largest law firms, Vinson & Elkins, urged its lawyers to vote for the restrictions, but did not press the point. Turnout is far higher in outlying areas, like Lubbock and Amarillo, than in Dallas, Houston or Austin.
"People here are not terribly worked up one way or another," said Thomas P. Marinis Jr., a partner at Vinson & Elkins.
One need only watch television for an hour or so on any given morning (when lawyer-advertisers figure that the injured parties they seek are home sick) to see how prevalent lawyer advertising has become. Between the relentless cheeriness of "Happy Days" and "Laverne and Shirley" reruns on channel 11 in Dallas, for instance, marches a parade of accident victims, scofflaws, criminal suspects and assorted ordinary people -- or actors masquerading as them -- singing their lawyers' praises.
*A Sylvester Stallone look- and sound-alike glowers from behind bars. "If you're arrested for an outstanding ticket, you're probably in serious trouble, which means you need serious help, like attorney John L. Corn at 38-LEGAL," he says.
*A couple agonizes over a wrecked car, medical bills and collection letters. "I'm calling R. A. Gabriele," the husband declares, referring to a Dallas lawyer famed for sending flowers to his clients. "It's time we had someone on our side."
*"Jim Adler. He makes drunk drivers pay," states another announcer seconds later.
*A man washing his car holds up a settlement check and hails Jeff Slakter, "the attorney who cares."
*"For personal injury, call 748-0503," a woman sings.
After appeals from legal consortiums like "The Injury Health Line" and 1-800-722-LAWYER, comes the inescapable Mr. Loncar, who also advertises in The Dallas Morning News, the Yellow Pages and Howard Stern's radio program.
 
As Saying Goes, It Pays . . .
 Together, the advertisements have helped make the 33-year-old Mr. Loncar prosperous far beyond his years. His assets, he says, include two Mercedes, a $400,000 home and $500,000 in the bank; his office is several architectural cuts above the seedy digs of his competitors, including Mr. Slakter and Mr. Gabriele.
For all their electronic loquaciousness, Mr. Adler, Mr. Gabriele and Mr. Slakter declined to speak with a reporter. That left the talking to Mr. Loncar, who did not shrink from the task.
"People want to be entertained, whether it's selling lawyers or selling soap," he said. "God knows, lawyers are boring enough. If you make it so that all they can do is stand in front of a lot of books and say, 'I'm a lawyer, call me,' people will switch the channels as fast as they can."

HEADLINE: Report Says Filming Is Up By a Third

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
New York City's film and television production industry, which was devastated in 1990 by a Hollywood boycott, appears to have revived this year, the Dinkins administration said in a report yesterday.
The report largely credited the swath of wage reductions and other concessions the craft union accepted after a bitter conflict with Hollywood film makers three years ago. 
 For more than a decade, New York has been losing business to smaller but fiercely aggressive film centers in Canada, Florida, Texas and elsewhere, all of which offer far lower costs. The gap in costs, although narrowing, remains wide.
But this year, the report found, film production in the city soared 38 percent over the depressed level of 1992.
And while yesterday's report was released by a group of economists and film experts on the staff of outgoing Mayor David N. Dinkins it attributed the upturn mainly to changes within the film industry itself, not to city policy.
"The economics of the industry have shifted," said Richard Brick, the city's Commissioner of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. "Suddenly, the playing field has become more level."
Even during the slump in 1992, the report found, film making contributed $3 billion to the city's economy. That included the production of television programs, commercials and industrial films as well as feature films.
 
Jobs for 68,000
 The film industry employs 68,000 who work in New York City, or 2.6 percent of its private work force. According to the report, the infusion into the economy comes through a ripple effect.
"There is a good buzz that things are at least possible in New York, that you can get concessions here," said Barbara DeFina, a Manhattan resident who produced several movies directed by Martin Scorcese, including "Age of Innocence," "Cape Fear" and "Color of Money."
The biggest blow to New York City's film industry, which was already facing intense competition, came in a seven-month boycott of the city by Hollywood production companies that began in November 1990 and did not end until May of 1991. Studio executives, already upset over the high costs and routine headaches of making movies here, abandoned the city amid a labor dispute with New York's film craft union .
After the boycott ended, film production continued to suffer because of the recession.
But amid the downturn, according to yesterday's report and interviews with people in the industry, economic changes have made the city more welcoming to movie and television producers.
 
A New Agreement
 The industry's labor dispute, which led to the 1990 boycott, ended when the East Coast Council of the International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employees, which represents craft people here, agreed to accept reduced overtime pay.
Then, in series of amendments to its work rules, the union agreed to pay schedules that varied with the proposed budget of the film to be produced.
Previously, low-budget production companies had to pay their camera people, set designers, truck drivers and other crew members the same wages that a huge production would pay. The union agreed to permit lower wages for small productions provided that they would recoup their concessions in bonus checks if the little movie turned out to make big profits.
"We have created customized work rules," said Louis D'Agostino, executive director of the New York film industry union. Although the new rules were resisted by some crafts people, he said, they have now won wide support not only because they have attracted more production activity, but also because they have provided the film workers with wide creative options.
"Some of the people who left for Hollywood are coming back just because they can work on a $50 million film in one month, then go to work on a $4 million feature that gives them more room for experimentation," he said.
While union rules have changed, suppliers to the film industry -- a broad spectrum including hardware stores, lumber yards, trucking companies, lighting suppliers, caterers and photographic processors ---have lowered their prices.
The report included recommendations for broader city support of film makers. Among them were the use of a venture capital fund, financed partly by the city, to invest in small production companies.
That was proposed during the mayoral campaign by Mayor Dinkins, but would now have to win the approval of Rudolph W. Giuliani.
A smaller proposal in the report was for the city to set aside low-cost office space for film producers, relieving them of the need to hunt for offices when they are on tight production schedules. Another was to assist the film industry in finding a permanent garage for the trucks and lighting equipment that production crews use for work in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Ford to Build New Compacts At U.S. and Mexican Plants

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Eager to expand its production capacity and exploit the favorable regulations under the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would build its new compact cars in Mexico, as well as the United States, and greatly increase its exports to Mexico.
Ford's plans will touch off a series of production shifts in Mexican, Canadian and American factories, the company said, resulting in the creation of the equivalent of 550 jobs in the United States and Canada, and 300 jobs in Mexico. Ford projected that the total number of jobs, or "job equivalents," could climb to 6,000 when additional work at its suppliers' plants in the United States and Canada was taken into account, as well as overtime work. 
 The announcement by Ford lends support to the arguments of supporters of the trade pact, who had said the agreement would add jobs, especially for the automobile industry, which has had its opportunities to do business in Mexico severely constrained.
Ed Hagenlocker, executive vice president of North American operations for Ford, said the company's actions proved that the North American accord would benefit the economies of all three countries.
The United Automobile Workers union, which strongly opposed the trade deal, did not respond immediately to the announcement by Ford.
Because Mexico has imposed tariffs of 20 percent on imported vehicles, as well as complex local-content rules, Ford and other auto makers have relied mostly on local manufacturers for their sales.
This year, Ford will export only about 1,500 cars to Mexico from its plants in the United States and Canada, but next year that number is expected to rise to about 25,000. Ford projected that its exports to Mexico would rise to 50,000 by 1996. The auto maker will add the Lincoln Mark VIII and Ford Escort to the list of models it exports to Mexico.
Moreover, Ford and its parts suppliers now may export parts to Ford assembly plants in Mexico at a greatly reduced cost. Next year, the Mexican tariff will decline to 10 percent on cars, and will be eliminated after 10 years. Tariffs on trucks will be eliminated after five years.
The North American trade accord was one important factor in Ford's decision. The other was the very tight capacity at the No. 2 auto maker since the mid-1980's.
Ford said last year that it planned to build the new Mystique and Contour models at its assembly plant in Kansas City, Mo., next year, with a capacity of 250,000 cars annually. But the company said it believed that it could sell more of the models, which will replace the Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz, if it could find a place to build more. It had been reluctant to build a new assembly plant because of the expense and risk.
The Mexican plant and the reduction of the tariffs on parts neatly solve the problem, said Bert Serre, a spokesman for Ford in Dearborn, Mich., because "we don't believe there's enough demand to justify adding a whole plant with capacity of 250,000 more cars." Ford's assembly plant in Cuautitlan, Mexico, will be able to build about 74,000 Mystiques and Contours a year, about 24,000 for sale in Mexico.
Ford, meanwhile, will transfer the production of a small number of Thunderbirds and Mercury Cougars from that factory in Mexico to its Lorain, Ohio, plant that produces those models.

HEADLINE: October Trade Deficit Narrowed 1.6%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
After deepening through the spring and summer, the United States trade deficit stabilized in October, despite the largest gap with Japan in nearly seven years.
The difference between what Americans sold overseas and what they bought from abroad narrowed by 1.6 percent, to $10.5 billion, the Commerce Department said today. 
 The modest improvement came even though the deficit with Japan jumped 14 percent, to $6.1 billion, the largest since November 1986.
Over all in October, a 3.2 percent increase in exports, to a record $40.1 billion, outpaced a 2.1 percent rise in imports, to $50.6 billion, also a record.
 
Foreign Economies in Slump
 Slumps in Europe and Japan have cut demand for exports, economists said, at the same time that a moderate improvement in the United States economy has increased Americans' appetite for foreign goods.
For the first 10 months of the year, the trade gap is running at an annual rate of $117.8 billion, far exceeding last year's $84.5 billion. That puts the United States on track for its worst trade performance since 1988.
"We will continue to grow faster, so there's probably going to be more trade deterioration in 1994," Bruce Steinberg, an economist for Merrill Lynch, said. "Once you get a more solid recovery taking hold everywhere, you'll begin to see our trade deficit start shrinking again, probably in 1995."
Meanwhile, a separate report from the Labor Department found that 7,000 fewer Americans applied for unemployment benefits last week than the week before.
A seasonally adjusted 330,000 people claimed benefits during the week ended Dec. 11. A less-volatile four-week moving average of claims declined by 2,000, to a nine-week low of 332,000. The numbers were taken as signs of continued, although irregular, improvement in the job market.
Trade was one of the few strong components of the American economy during the 1990-91 recession, but it has turned into an economic drag this year. Still, Mr. Steinberg and other economists pointed to October's slight improvement as a sign that the deficit would not markedly worsen.
 
A "Flattening" Is Seen
 The evidence has been suggesting that "we're getting a flattening," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "It's a flattening at a very high number, to be sure, but it's a flattening nevertheless," he added.
The Clinton Administration is promising that the just-signed tariff-slashing pact under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the recently ratified North American Free Trade Agreement will overcome the nation's trade imbalance.
"Accelerating the growth of exports is the best path to improving the balance of trade," Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said. "To achieve this, our trading partners need to stimulate their economies to create growth."
The October gain in exports reflected increases of $447 million in civilian aircraft, $391 million in autos and parts, $181 million in gold, $141 million in telecommunications equipment, $135 million in semiconductors, $133 million in nuclear fuel and $106 million in industrial engines.
The increase in imports reflected an increase of $247 million in autos and parts, $222 million in computer accessories, $151 million in crude oil, $145 million in artwork and antiques and $124 million in fish.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Fleet Unit Settles Claims of Lending Bias

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 16

 BODY:
A unit of Fleet Financial Group Inc. has pledged $100 million in loan refunds and other relief to Georgia customers to settle allegations of discriminatory lending practices by the banking company.
The settlement, which was announced today, is the largest ever involving accusations of discrimination in mortgage lending against members of minorities. 
 Fleet Finance, an Atlanta mortgage lender, pledged between $30 million and $40 million in refunds and lower-rate mortgage loans to the company's 18,300 customers in Georgia. Fleet also agreed to set up a $70 million fund to issue mortgage loans for as low as two percentage points less than prevailing market rates in the next five years.
 
 
'Improper Pursuit of Profits'
 The Georgia Attorney General, Michael J. Bowers, said, "We found, as a result of our investigation, that arrogance and the improper pursuit of profits was to blame."
Fleet Finance, a unit of the nation's 14th-largest bank, did not admit guilt.
In a related move, Fleet Finance said it would pay $18 million to $20 million to settle a class-action lawsuit filed in Augusta, Ga., that accused the bank of selecting black neighborhoods for mortgage loans at annual rates that sometimes exceeded 30 percent.
Today's settlement closes a yearlong state investigation into allegations that Fleet Finance trapped lower-income people in high-rate mortgages. Fleet Finance was accused of lending to people who did not qualify for loans so that it could foreclose on them later and sell the property at a profit.
The loans prompted a rash of consumer complaints and several class-action lawsuits. No charges were filed by the Attorney General.
Under the settlement, Fleet agreed not to charge interest rates that exceed 12 percent above the prime interest rate. Fleet also agreed not to charge prepaid finance charges in excess of 5 percent of the face value of the loan amount. As part of the refund payments, Fleet said it would reduce by as much as half the interest rate charges to some borrowers.
Fleet Finance has offices in 22 states. The parent company, based in Providence, R.I., said the settlement would have no impact on fourth-quarter earnings.

HEADLINE: Gordon Griswold, 83, Utility Executive, Dies

 BODY:
Gordon C. Griswold Sr., who rose from a cadet engineer to board chairman in his 42 years at the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, died on Tuesday at a retirement community in Kalamazoo, Mich. He was 83 and had moved there from Westfield, N.J., in 1987.
The cause of death was congestive heart failure, his family said. 
 Mr. Griswold, a native of Denver, was a 1933 economics graduate of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. He joined Brooklyn Union that year, was elected a vice president in 1961, executive vice president and a director in 1961, president in 1968, and chairman and chief executive in 1974, the year before his retirement.
For many years he was a leader in the business community and in civic organizations in Brooklyn and Westfield. In 1974 he received the Gold Medal Award for distinguished service to Brooklyn from the Downtown Brooklyn Development Association, having served as its chairman in 1972. Earlier he served as president and a director of the Downtown Brooklyn Association.
He was a director of the United Hospital Fund of New York and president of the United Fund (United Way) of Westfield. He also was a past member of the Scotch Plains School Board.
His first wife, Emily, died in 1981. He is survived by his wife, Esther; three sons, Gordon C. Jr., of Westfield, John R., of Bethlehem, Pa., and Alan R., of Knoxville, Tenn.; a sister, Barbara Bishop of Shelburne Falls, Mass.; eight grandchildren and one great-grandson.

HEADLINE: Fed Rebutted by Bentsen On Bank Regulatory Plan

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Responding to sharp criticism from the Federal Reserve Board, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen yesterday defended the Clinton Administration's plan to create a single banking regulatory agency and contended that the Fed was merely trying to protect its turf.
"There is no question our proposal will result in the reduction of jobs, saving the taxpayers money," Mr. Bentsen said at a news conference in Manhattan. "Change can be painful for those that want to keep the status quo." 
 The Administration has proposed forming one agency to supervise all banks and savings and loan associations. Banks are now subject to the overlapping authority of the Federal Reserve, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Office of Thrift Supervision and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
Under the Clinton plan, the Fed would no longer examine banks, but would remain responsible for conducting monetary policy. It would also continue to serve as the lender of last resort to banks and securities firms, providing the nation's main defense against financial panic.
But the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, and other Fed officials have said that the Federal Reserve's role in bank regulation helps it perform its other duties by giving it more information on bank activities.
"The Fed's arguments fail on numbers alone," Mr. Bentsen said. "The Fed supervises 18 percent of commercial bank assets. It's hard to imagine that the integrity of monetary policy and the stability of the financial system rests on the continued oversight of those banks."
"Most financial crises have nothing to do with banking," he added. "The Fed has nothing to do with securities regulation but it handled the 1987 stock market crash. It never regulated the railroads, but it dealt just fine with the Penn Central bankruptcy. And it never regulated the silver market, but it managed to control the silver market collapse in 1980."
Still, under the Administration's proposal, the Fed would have access to all information gathered by the new agency. "We're looping the Fed in, not out," Mr. Bentsen said. A member of the Fed would be one of the five members of the proposed Federal Banking Commission that would supervise the new agency.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Mark Time

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market did not do very much of anything yesterday except prove how tightly it was locked into an aimless trading range as the end of the year approaches.
Early yesterday, Treasury prices fell and yields rose after a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia showing a sharp jump in the bank's index of regional business conditions. In December, the index leaped to 42.4. from 22.4 in November. This jump seems to indicate that the closely watched purchasing managers index could move up to 60, which would indicate another good month for manufacturing. 
 Still, the bond market's reaction to the report was calmer than expected. "Normally that would be worth a point off the price of the bond," said John Ryding, senior economist at Bear, Stearns & Company.
 
Inflation Would Pick Up
 The reason is that such a spurt in manufacturing activity could make traders worry more about a jump in overall growth that would make the pace of inflation pick up. And unlike many other economists, the Bear, Stearns chief economist, Lawrence A. Kudlow, is predicting 4 percent growth in both the fourth quarter of 1993 and the first quarter of 1994. The consensus outlook is for a slowdown in growth in the beginning of next year.
Matthew Alexy, the government trading strategist at CS First Boston, said he was also surprised that the bond market, especially at the long end, did not sell off much on the Philadelphia data. "It's a big number," he said.
In late trading at 5 P.M., the price of the 30-year bond was 9914/32 , down 5/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, inched up to 6.29 percent from 6.28 percent Wednesday. The price of the two-year Treasury note slipped 1/32 as the yield moved to 4.20 percent from 4.18 percent.
 
Firms Back Ban
 The list of municipal bond underwriters that have said they will join the voluntary ban on political contribution is growing. According to the Securities and Exchange Commission, nine new medium- and small-sized firms have endorsed the ban, which prohibits contributions that are made with the intent of winning lucrative underwriting business.
According to the Securities Data Corporation, the 51 companies that have endorsed the ban accounted for 78.6 percent percent of the underwriting business this year, when full credit for each issue is given to the lead manager.
The new companies, which include firms run by women and minorities, are the Artemis Capital Group; Barr Brothers & Company; Craigie Inc.; Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson; Hanifen, Imhoff; the LaSalle National Bank, E.A. Moos; Samuel A. Ramirez & Company, and William E. Simon & Sons Municipal Securities.
But there are still nine significant firms in the market that account for about 6.7 percent of the underwriting business that have not said whether they will endorse the ban.
 
Prison Issue
 The New York State Urban Development Corporation sold $216 million of bonds yesterday to be used for prison construction.
The sale has been opposed by State Comproller H. Carl McCall, who calls it "backdoor financing" that allows the state to sell bonds without voter approval and uses the bonding authority of the corporation for purposes not originally intended.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who in the past had approved the use of the corporation's bonding authority for prisons, is also now pushing a revision of the state's debt practices that would prevent such sales. The issue avoids the need for voter approval by depending on the Legislature to appropriate the payments to bondholders each year.
The issue came amid a recent flood of bonds with New York names and may have suffered a bit because of that. The lead underwriter, Merrill Lynch, had to increase the yields on several maturities to attract more buyers. Paul Kuhns, the co-head of municipal bond underwriting, said that the initial pricing was also very aggressive, meaning yields were pushed as low as possible.
The issue due in 2023 was priced to yield 5.786 percent, up from an initial pricing of 5.75 percent. The taxable equivalent yield in the 36 percent tax bracket is 9.04 percent.
The 10-year bonds were priced to yield 5.729 percent, up from an initial pricing of 5.70 percent. The taxable equivalent yield is 8.95 percent. The very small increase in yield between the 10-year maturity and the 30-year maturity is a reason many analysts advise investors to buy intermediate rather then longer-term bonds, which are more volatile and can have a much greater price drop if interest rates rise.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
MCI is expanding its ethnic marketing into long-distance business services.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
AND now a word from MCI: hola!
The MCI Communications Corporation is making its initial foray into aiming advertising for long-distance business services at ethnic markets. Its efforts, which could include hiring agencies that specialize in ethnic marketing, are intended to complement the ethnically oriented consumer campaigns it already runs as supplements to its general advertising. 
 Since last week, television viewers in Los Angeles and San Francisco have been able to watch a commercial featuring Bita Daryabari, an MCI account representative of Iranian descent. In the commercial, she recounts her success at signing business customers in the San Francisco area's Iranian community. And sometime early next year, MCI plans to introduce a comprehensive communications program in South Florida called "Hola! MCI/Positivamente Miami!" to try to increase its market share among Spanish-speaking owners of businesses there.
"We've done a tremendous amount of ethnic marketing on the consumer side," Kevin Bennis, MCI's senior vice president of marketing for business markets, said in a telephone interview from his office in Atlanta. "But our ethnic marketing to businesses has been only scattered.
"This is our first effort to really do a national business ethnic marketing program," he added. "If these markets are as big of an opportunity as we think, we'll invest behind them."
The decision by MCI to further segment its sales messages is emblematic of the growing importance that mainstream advertisers are placing on ethnic marketing. That is particularly true in intensely competitive product and service categories like telecommunications, soft drinks, beer, banking and fast food.
It has become fashionable to deride attempts to address anyone other than white, Anglo-Saxon males as "politically correct." But the campaigns being sponsored by companies like MCI simply acknowledge demographic trends. One need not wax rhapsodic over gorgeous mosaics or rainbow coalitions to recognize that the complexion of America's population is growing more diverse.
"Someone once made the staggering statement that one in five Americans will be of Hispanic descent by 2015," Mr. Bennis said.
In other words, never mind politically correct. Marketers are trying to be economically correct.
For the "Hola! MCI" program, Mr. Bennis said, MCI will seek proposals from three or four agencies that specialize in marketing to Spanish-speaking consumers. The longtime MCI agency, Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, which created the spot centering on Ms. Daryabari, will also be asked for a proposal, he added.
If "Hola! MCI" is successful, Mr. Bennis said, he foresees adapting it to other markets with large numbers of businesses owned by Spanish-speaking people, including California, New York and Texas. Nationally, these businesses spend $2 billion annually on long-distance services.
"There's no reason why we can't get 8 percent to 10 percent of that market in the next 24 months with this kind of targeted program," Mr. Bennis said, compared with MCI's current share of "a little higher than 5 percent."
It is too early to estimate MCI's budget for business-market ethnic campaigns, he said, adding that the company's overall 1994 spending on ads aimed at business customers would exceed $50 million.
In adding an ethnic component to its business market advertising, MCI is following its larger rival, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. A.T.& T. already runs campaigns directed at Spanish-speaking business owners, created by Bravo, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, and at Asian-American business owners, created by Amko Advertising in New York.
At the Sprint Corporation, the No. 3 long-distance carrier behind A.T.& T. and MCI, a review has begun to find an agency to create advertising for its new business services group. J. Walter Thompson San Francisco will remain Sprint's lead agency.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Profits Rise On Property Insurance

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Sharply lower losses from disasters have helped property and casualty insurance companies, which protect against accidents to buildings, cars and people, earn nearly $16 billion after taxes this year, more than double last year's $7.4 billion, the Insurance Information Institute said yesterday.
"The most notable event for insurers in 1993 was actually a nonevent: the much feared son or daughter of Andrew did not appear," said Sean Mooney, senior vice president at the institute, a trade group that is financed by the industry but does not lobby on its behalf. Hurricane Andrew caused about $16.5 billion of losses in Florida last year, making it the most costly disaster ever for insurers. 
 The 1993 profit relied heavily on investment income -- $31.6 billion of interest and dividends and one-time capital gains of $10.7 billion, thanks to rising stock and bond prices. The industry collected $233.7 billion of premiums, incurred losses of $190 billion and had other expenses of $63.3 billion.
 
Underwriting Results Lackluster
 Despite the high level of overall profits, John Snyder, senior vice president at the A. M. Best Company, an insurance rating firm, warns in a separate study to be published soon that for insurance underwriting -- the business of collecting premiums and paying claims -- "overall results are lackluster."
In addition, investment income will fall because of lower interest rates, Mr. Snyder said, and much of the 1993 capital gains came at the expense of future income. For example, companies that sell older, high-interest-rate bonds at a gain will collect less interest in the future than if they still held the bonds.
The companies' financial condition appears stronger now, Mr. Snyder said, because of $3 billion of unrealized capital gains from investments still on their books, but that could be jeopardized by a drop in stock prices. "What comes easy also can disappear easily," he said.
 
Liability Insurance Growing
 Mr. Mooney of the insurance institute noted that liability insurance, which now accounts for nearly 60 percent of premiums collected by property and casualty companies, can be very profitable even if claims payments exceed premiums because the companies can invest the premiums for several years before claims are paid. The growth of liability insurance, he added, makes it unlikely that the property and casualty industry will ever again collect more in premiums than it pays for losses and expenses.
For other lines of property and casualty insurance, high claims are a greater problem because companies have only a short time -- often less than a year -- to invest premiums before claims are paid.
Mr. Snyder said that many lines of personal insurance, such as homeowners' policies, were producing claims and expenses so much greater than premiums that some large companies, which sell through independent agencies and have higher expenses, were pulling back from those businesses.
Losses from catastrophes -- big disasters that usually cost more than $5 million in losses -- totaled $6 billion this year, the third highest ever, but were down from $23 billion a year earlier, the insurance institute said. The year's biggest catastrophes included the March blizzard, which cost $1.8 billion, the Los Angeles fires, $950 million, and the bombing of the World Trade Center, $510 million.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Eases Against Yen And Slips in Other Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar eased against the yen yesterday after a Government report that the United States trade deficit with Japan hit a seven-year high in October.
It also slipped against European currencies on news that Germany left its interest rates untouched. Investors had been betting on a rate cut in light of Germany's weak economy. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 109.56 yen, down from 109.78 yen on Wednesday. It also dropped to 1.7105 German marks from 1.7175 marks.
Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most active futures contract, dropped $1.50, to $387.50 an ounce.
The United States trade deficit narrowed by less than many economists had predicted, to $10.46 billion in October from a revised $10.62 billion in September.
Moreover, the nation's trade gap with Japan widened to $6.09 billion, from $5.323 billion the prior month. The dollar quickly eased against the yen, since a lower dollar has often been used to combat a high Japanese surplus.
 
 
Trade Figure 'Shock'
 "There was a shock from the trade figure," said Amy Smith, currency analyst at IDEA. "People had expected a widening of the bilateral deficit, but that number was way above expectations."
Later, the market shrugged of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen's comment that the White House was comfortable with the dollar-yen rate.
News that Germany's money supply grew sharply in November tipped off the market early that the German bank probably would not cut official interest rates at its weekly council meeting, this year's last.
That suspicion was borne out when the Bundesbank said it would hold rates steady.
The dollar declined against the mark after the money supply report as dealers bought back marks sold earlier on the off chance the Bundesbank would ease.
Lower German rates would have made mark-based assets relatively less attractive than investments denominated in other currencies.
The British pound rose in New York to $1.4855, from $1.4788 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.4604 Swiss francs, down from 1.4680; 5.8415 French francs, down from 5.8610; 1,689 Italian lire, down from 1,691, and $1.3330 (Canadian), down from $1.3332.

HEADLINE: Review/Architecture;
Isozaki's Designs for an Insecure Postwar World

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
"Arata Isozaki: Works in Architecture," now on view at the Brooklyn Museum, may put you in mind of Nietzsche's warning against looking too long into the abyss lest the abyss look back into you. A show that begins with a glimpse into the cultural void of postwar Japan gives way to the queasy sensation that the West has also been swallowed up by a nuclear-age vacuum. This is a beautiful show, and it looks terrific in the great big blond galleries Mr. Isozaki has designed with James Stewart Polshek for the Brooklyn Museum's newly renovated West Wing. But a profound malaise lurks beneath the beauty.
Born in 1931 in Oita, Japan, Mr. Isozaki came of age in a country that was not only physically and economically in tatters but had also been torn from its cultural moorings. With its emperor demoted from a god to a figurehead and many of its ancient social customs outlawed by a new constitution, Japan veered toward the condition of a blank cultural slate. It is apt that the country later cornered the market in cameras, tape recorders and VCR's. With its own culture in a state of partial erasure, it is as if Japan had no choice but to fill the vacuum by recording the sights and sounds of the world beyond its borders. 
 This 30-year retrospective suggests that Mr. Isozaki has been the architectural equivalent of a recording machine, a tourist's camera looking to frame the best shots. He started out as a kind of modernist day-tripper. Early Japanese projects, like the City in the Air (1960-63) and the Oita Prefectural Library (1962-66), bear the influence of Le Corbusier, Louis I. Kahn and the British architectural group Archigram, as well of that of Kenzo Tange, Mr. Isozaki's early mentor in Tokyo. Later, as Mr. Isozaki's international career accelerated, his designs absorbed the classical high spots of the traditional European grand tour. The Tsukuba Center Building of 1979 to 1983, for example, visualizes the civic center for a new Japanese town as a stone collage of references to Michelangelo, Borromini and Ledoux.
The paradox is that the West was scarcely better equipped than Japan to offer a firm historical footing to an architect of Mr. Isozaki's generation. In contrast to the 19th century, when Japan's modernization was sustained by Europe's confident view of progress as the fulfillment of history, Mr. Isozaki embarked on his career just as the West was losing its faith in modern progress. Mr. Isozaki's eclectic cribbings are like a mirror held up to that crisis. Unlike those American post-modernists who believed that classicism held the key to a usable past, Mr. Isozaki appeared to understand that no amount of historical excavation could uncover a firm foundation on which to build the present. He perceived that a time that had lost its faith in the future had also lost its grip on the past.
Mr. Isozaki grasped this lesson early on. In 1968, he created a project for the Milan Triennale, called the Electric Labyrinth, in which images of ruined, futuristic cities were projected onto a screen printed with a panoramic view of Hiroshima flattened by the bomb. Although only the screen is included in the Brooklyn show, much of the subsequent work on view could be regarded as a continuation of that early apocalyptic vision. Each building is an image, briefly flashed onto a narrow strip of time between an irretrievable past and an uncertain future. Mr. Isozaki's design for the Tsukuba Center Building, for instance, is not only composed of fragments: it is also depicted in a series of silk-screen prints as a ruin of the future, the skeleton of an expired present.
When Mr. Isozaki uses traditional Western forms, he is not so much appealing to the past as he is embracing a present in which the Japanese have become global explorers. A trip to the Campidoglio in Rome is modernity to him, and so is the use of industrial technology and geometric abstraction. He does not cede the pyramid franchise to I. M. Pei, or the latest high tech to Richard Rogers. And Mr. Isozaki can use traditional forms toward explicitly anti-traditional ends. On a wall panel, he explains that the classical forms of the Tsukuba Center Building were intended as a polemic against the resurgence of Japanese nationalism. Foreign tradition, in other words, becomes a tool for opposing tradition at home.
Mr. Isozaki's eclecticism is double-edged. While refusing to restrict himself to a signature style, he differs from some of his post-modern contemporaries in allowing that esthetic freedom can be a road to triviality. The liberation from modernist orthodoxy is not something to be mindlessly celebrated, and it may even be cause for dread. And the present can be a scary place. The most recent project in the show, Mr. Isozaki's 1992 design for the Nara Convention Hall in Nara, Japan, is an immense black shell that recalls at once the exquisite modeling of ancient pottery and the sleek precision of military hardware. Inside the hall, glass-walled auditoriums blaze with crystal fire, but also with the unearthly brilliance of shattered electrons. In one rendering, the black hall hulks beneath sulfurous yellow skies, perhaps offering shelter from atmospheric pollution, just as possibly adding to it.
Team Disney headquarters, completed in 1990, epitomizes Mr. Isozaki's unsettling synthesis of the malignant and the benign. Straddling an artificial pond in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., the stunning building consists of two long office wings hinged at the center by an immense truncated cone, 120 feet high, that somewhat resembles a nuclear reactor dressed up as a festive party bonbon, an atomic bombe glacee. The cone's windowless interior, bridged by a Piranesian catwalk, is exposed to the sky, while a gigantic stylus protrudes across the mouth, casting shadows on a vast sundial inscribed on the cone's inner wall.
This is perhaps meant to demonstrate ma, a Japanese word signifying the merging of space and time, which was the subject of a traveling exhibition Mr. Isozaki created in 1978. But other, less welcome fusions -- between reality and entertainment; between corporate culture and global politics -- may be taking place in Disney's electric labyrinth, mergers between entities that should perhaps remain visibly distinct. One enters the cone through a tunnel cast in the form of an extruded pair of Mickey Mouse ears. Listen, and you can almost hear the echoes of an infernal laugh track bouncing off the walls as audiences line up to be vaporized by Team Disney: anesthetized by beauty, then quickly tickled to death.
Originally organized by the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, the show is skillfully designed. Such a visually diverse body of work could easily end up looking like a yard sale. Mr. Isozaki has prevented this by devising a display format that presents each project in three parts. A large blue wall panel, accompanied by a single defining image, is inscribed with a text that explains the concept behind each of the 22 projects on view. A group of drawings and prints traces the design development. Wooden scale models display the final design.
The format weaves the projects together in a loose, three-dimensional version of the tartan patterns that occur in Mr. Isozaki's buildings. It also lends cohesion to the galleries themselves. Mr. Isozaki has banished photographs from the main part of the show to an adjoining room, where a high-definition video monitor screens a continuous program of supernaturally crisp color pictures.
"Arata Isozaki: Works in Architecture" remains at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, through Feb. 27.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A computer-generated rendering of Arata Isozaki's design for the Team Disney headquarters in Florida. (Brooklyn Museum)

HEADLINE: Quick Fix at Defense

 BODY:
President Clinton has made a safe and smart choice in nominating retired Adm. Bobby Ray Inman to be his second Secretary of Defense. The national security establishment is already singing the nominee's praises. That has to be music to the ears of a President who may feel vulnerable about his own weak national security credentials.
Admiral Inman would bring a sharp mind, government experience and bipartisan respect to the Pentagon post. A retired four-star admiral and formerly Director of the National Security Agency, Deputy Director of Central Intelligence and chief executive of a private-sector computer consortium, Mr. Inman is known for the kind of management skills the incumbent Secretary, Les Aspin, is said to lack. 
 Senators will want to examine his management record in and out of government and satisfy themselves that his military and intelligence background in no way detracts from his ability to exercise strong civilian control over America's armed forces. Such control is crucial because Admiral Inman will have to plug the $50 billion, five-year defense budget gap that was reportedly the last straw in an increasing tense Clinton-Aspin relationship. That will require establishing a firm hand over the service chiefs, whose requests will need to be scaled back if even a fraction of Mr. Clinton's domestic goals are to be financed.
At the same time, the new Secretary will need to get up to speed quickly on the complex nuclear bargaining now going on with North Korea. And it will be his responsibility to assess the military implications of the rise of aggressive nationalists in a nuclear-armed Russia.
The Secretary of Defense is a key member of any Administration's national security team, an influential voice on wider issues of diplomatic and even economic strategy. This Administration's team has not yet jelled, and will not until the President himself begins to give personal direction.
Mr. Clinton's notion of simply leaving Bush Administration foreign policy on autopilot has not worked. Many Bush policies had already become outdated in the swiftly changed environment following the cold war. In other areas, what Mr. Bush left behind were not coherent policies, but time bombs waiting to explode after months of procrastination and evasion; for example, Bosnia and Haiti. Mr. Aspin took the heat for some of the consequences. So will his successor, unless American objectives are systematically rethought.
Whether the Clinton Administration can now begin to perform more smoothly on national security issues depends not only on the new Defense Secretary, but on the President's ability to absorb the lessons of a shaky first year.
Mr. Clinton deserves some credit for avoiding a major debacle in 1993, but he and Secretary-designate Inman have to reach for a higher mark in 1994.

HEADLINE: Restraining Property Seizures

 BODY:
Property seizures can be valuable supplements to law enforcement. By confiscating drug dealers' houses, cars, yachts and other property, Federal agents can disable their enterprises and deprive them of ill-gotten gains. But as the Supreme Court is beginning to suspect, such seizures can be abused to raise revenues.
Explaining the need for legal safeguards for seizures and forfeitures the other day, the high court cited a 1990 Justice Department memorandum to its far-flung agents. "We must significantly increase production to reach our budget target," the memo said. "Failure to achieve the $470 million projection would expose the Department's forfeiture program to criticism and undermine confidence in our budget projections." 
 When the Government has a strong economic motive to grab a person's house for budget-balancing purposes, the courts need to be vigilant to insure fairness, the Court said. A 5-to-4 majority ruled that property owners are entitled to advance notice and a hearing before Federal agents take their homes or land in connection with a drug case.
The decision was perhaps only a temporary victory for James Daniel Good, a small-time drug violator whose home in Hawaii was seized four years after he pleaded guilty to a marijuana charge and served a year in prison. After his hearing, Mr. Good and others whose homes are targeted may still lose their property, but not without a chance to contest the forfeiture.
In recent cases the increasingly cautious justices have blocked the seizure of a house from an owner if she can prove she was unaware that drug money was used to buy the home. They also served notice that some seizures can be so valuable compared with the crime as to violate the Eighth Amendment's ban on excessive fines.
The best way to achieve the law enforcement objectives of property seizures while curbing overzealous acquisitions is to reallocate where the money goes. Congress ought to require that forfeiture proceeds go to the general Treasury rather than to the law enforcement agencies that are making the seizures, thus removing any temptation to pad revenues with unwarranted property grabs.

HEADLINE: The Truth Rebuked on Haiti

 BODY:
John Shattuck is the State Department's highest human rights official. He is also an honest man. After a firsthand look at the deteriorating situation in Haiti, Mr. Shattuck concluded that the collapse of efforts to restore President Jean-Bertrand Aristide had intensified repression, and that a new wave of refugees would soon be on the way. He urged the Clinton Administration to review its policy of turning back every boat that attempts to flee Haiti. He wanted to assure that those with a legitimate claim to asylum get a fair chance to present their cases. What he got was an official rebuke.
So continues the cruel charade that has gone on since the Bush Administration started pretending that all those fleeing the terror unleashed by Haiti's September 1991 coup were economic refugees. That pretense was used to justify indiscriminate return, a policy that mocks American principles of asylum and one that is applied to Haitians alone. 
The real reason for this perverse policy is fear that the arrival of poor black Haitians, no matter how legitimate their claims, could provoke an ugly backlash. Rather than stand up for principle, two successive Presidents have bowed to political expediency. When he was a candidate, Bill Clinton denounced the Bush policy. But from the day he took office, he adopted that policy as his own. And while some of his senior people don't like the policy -- Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, reportedly called it a "dark stain" on the Administration's record -- it remains in place.
Neither Administration has chosen to intervene with force, and they were right to be cautious in this regard. But basic standards of fairness need to be followed. The U.S. has not hesitated to grant political asylum to all arriving Cubans, prompting speculation about politically driven distinctions. In particular, efforts to woo right-wing Floridians appear to dictate the admission of Cubans and the exclusion of Haitians, without fair regard to the justice of individual claims.
True, a just policy would cost money. While most departing Haitians do not qualify for political asylum, letting in those who do could burden some communities' economies. Washington would need to help offset these local costs.
Repression in Haiti is increasing. Military intervention has been ruled out. Diplomacy is stalled. The one remaining tool, U.N. economic sanctions, imposes heavy sacrifices on millions of poor people in order to squeeze a handful of insulated and recalcitrant coup leaders.
In this context, it is not too much to ask the Clinton Administration to absorb the modest costs of extending to Haitians the refugee standards available to everyone else.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Russia: Who's to Blame?

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
For days phone calls have been coming in from Russian friends, explaining to me and themselves how in their homeland a fascist nationalist could have become a strong contender for power.
In their explanations, and much of the American intellectual and political reaction, ran a theme of Western failure or guilt: 
 President Clinton was guilty for sticking so strongly to Boris Yeltsin. The NATO powers failed to soothe the fears of the Russian military. The West should have provided more money to stabilize the Russian economy.
Western guilt -- I think not. Russia did this to Russia.
Russians, not Westerners, checked the ballots; and a quarter of them, in a choice of national parties, selected the leadership of the man who promised another dictatorship and resurgent armed forces on the march. The memory of German voters helping Hitler leap to power is inevitable and valid.
Russian centuries did this -- centuries of czarist and Communist despots and church and state bigotry. Faced with the perils of freedom, a frightening number of voters turned to fascists, or Communists. They returned to the security of obedience, and the passions of Holy Russia that exclude all others as foreign to themselves and God.
This shocks the West. It should. We had forgotten how the realities of the old Russia could linger into the new. Remembering Russia's history does not diminish the importance of Russia's destruction of the Soviet prison empire, but makes it stand out greater, more thrilling.
Russians who oppose return to despotism will draw their own lessons. But it is important for foreigners not to make scapegoats of the Yeltsin people. They made mistakes, but their problems were not simply what they did but what they hoped for and could not achieve because of the heritage of Russian history.
The West must make its own military, economic and political decisions, to protect itself and help save the revolution from its enemies.
Militarily, talk of integrating Russia into NATO, or the halfway house of a military "Partnership for Peace," should be put aside. Neither can happen, or should, until any realistic threat of a new Russian despotism ends. To pretend otherwise now is a hoax.
Western nations should examine their own armed forces. Vladimir Zhirinovsky, and ilk, may not wait sweetly until the next election to take the presidency, but lunge for power anytime from tomorrow on. Not to examine Western readiness would be unthinkable negligence.
Economics: The free market is a road and a goal, not a religion. Russians, so many of them, are frightened by the price -- particularly unemployment. And why not? The West itself is not yet a fully free market. And we not only set our own pace but make sure the risks are protected by unemployment insurance and Social Security. We expect the Russians to leap from the trapeze with no net at all -- and like it.
If a slower pace is what Russians want, they are entitled to choose it -- without the blackmail of the threat of withdrawal of Western aid.
Politically Mr. Clinton is right not to give any sign of sidling away from Mr. Yeltsin. America has enough trouble already convincing foreign friends that it will be around tomorrow to finish what it starts today.
The President also should continue to make clear that the chasm between America and this Zhirinovsky is unbridgeable. A demagogue in command of Russian armed forces is a direct threat to the United States and its allies.
Already we read stories about how he will be more cooperative en route to the presidency, and that maybe he had a Jewish father. That would make him even more dangerous. Jews spreading anti-Semitism are straight-out lunatics, so deep in self-hatred that they cannot surrender hatred of anybody else.
On an October Sunday in 1965, The New York Times printed a story that a top leader of the American Nazi Party was a Jew. That day he shot himself. Mr. Zhirinovsky may not oblige, but in a cold winter it is a warming thought.
Mr. Clinton's duty is not simply to support a Yeltsin or oppose a Zhirinovsky but to remain true to the democratic ideals that helped bring about the anti-Communist revolution and still inspire so many Russians. That fidelity remains Russia's greatest asset, and America's.
