HEADLINE: Getting a Diversified Start in the Market

BYLINE: By DEBORAH M. RANKIN

 BODY:
You're sitting with a little pot of money -- perhaps a year-end bonus, or an inheritance from your Aunt Edith. And you've decided that it's finally time to venture beyond mutual funds into some individual stocks.
"What most novice investors do, as a practical matter, is to become enamored of some stock they've just read about," said Michael Stolper, president of Stolper & Company, a San Diego firm that evaluates investment managers for wealthy individuals. "If they enjoy the experience -- that is, if they make some money -- they'll keep at it. The problem is that they usually wind up with a collection of consumer stocks without any diversification at all." 
 Investment professionals agree that the best way to enter the stock market is to spread your holdings among different areas.
"Most studies show that you need 8 to 12 stocks, in unrelated industries, to achieve adequate diversification," said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors, a Chicago educational organization. "At the very least, you need five stocks."
How much money do you need? Estimates range from just $5,000 to $50,000. Another factor, as important as sufficient funds, is whether you have the time and temperament to monitor a stock portfolio.
If you lack the money or the will, you may be far better off with an equity mutual fund, which has lower minimum investment requirements and provides professional portfolio management.
Assuming you have both, create a list of attractive but unrelated industries. Mr. Markese suggests checking whether the companies in the various industries share a product market (like fast-food outlets or prescription drugs), resources (like oil or lumber) and labor unions (like mine workers or airline pilots). Eliminate industries that overlap and winnow the list to five or six industries.
Mr. Markese then recommends buying in a round lot, say 100 shares, what you consider to be the best company in each industry. Continue this practice every quarter over a period of two to two and a half years, he advises.
This approach, however, does not provide instant diversification. For that reason, Peggy Schmeltz, a Bowling Green, Ohio, homemaker and individual investor, suggests an alternative. Mrs. Schmeltz, who has parlayed $75,000 that she inherited 15 years ago into a portfolio worth 20 times that amount, recommends buying the top stocks in three industries for starters.
"One may do well, one may go sideways, and one may go down," she said. Although the commissions on three transactions will be higher than on a single one, she said, "the chances are that you'll do better over all than if you sunk all your money into just one stock and it later drops by several points."
For the final selections, Mrs. Schmeltz looks for stocks that she thinks will double in value over five years. She focuses on a company's growth in sales and earnings, and favors stocks that have had steady year-to-year increases. She also looks for stocks that are attractively priced, with price-earnings ratios close to their growth rates and to their average ratio for the previous five years.
Linda D. Marcelli, a senior vice president with Merrill Lynch and manager of its largest branch office, at the World Financial Center in New York, suggests spreading purchases among large-company stocks, small-company stocks, growth stocks, value stocks, domestic stocks and international stocks.
"You want your portfolio to represent a number of different investment styles," she said. "The idea is to be positioned so you can participate in any market upturn."
She advises investing a third to half of your money immediately, and dollar-cost averaging the remaining balance for a year. Using the averaging technique, investors put a fixed amount each month in stocks, which allows them to buy more when share prices are low and less when prices are high.
Below are some other tips for novice investors.
*Expect to strike out a few times. Mrs. Schmeltz admits that even she stumbled: "A broker friend of mine recommended General Motors as my first purchase, and I bought it even though I didn't realize at the time that the auto industry is a cyclical one that goes up and down with changes in the economy. I bought it at $50, watched it go up to about $70, and then rode it down into the $60's, the $50's and the $40's. I now own more than 100 stocks, but that was my first and last cyclical."
*Use dividend reinvestment plans when possible. These plans, available widely with at least 120 stocks, allow you to reinvest dividends directly in additional shares of stock. This way, you buy automatically regardless of market conditions and pay little or no commissions.
*Expect to spend a fair amount of time monitoring your investments. Mrs. Schmeltz, for example, tries to devote 12 to 15 hours a week to her holdings, though this time is dwindling because of her new duties as chairwoman of the National Association of Investment Clubs. She also maintains a card file on some 200 prospective stocks, keeping track of company data like quarterly earnings, price-earnings ratios and returns on investment and equity.
If after you buy a stock, it declines and you still consider it a good buy, Mrs. Schmeltz recommends adding to your position. Then once you have about $10,000 more to invest, she advocates choosing three different industries and repeating the selection process.
If drugs, food and regional banks were represented in the first round, she said, you might look into restaurants, leisure time and health maintenance organizations for your next purchases.
Other sources of information are the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago, (312) 280-1625, and the National Association of Investment Clubs in Royal Oak, Mich. (313) 543-0612.
The stocks that appear most frequently in the portfolios of investment clubs are McDonald's, Wal-Mart and Pepsico, according to the national association.
A major issue is whether to place your first stock purchase through a full-service broker, like Merrill Lynch or Smith Barney Shearson, which provides investment advice as well as order execution, or through a discount broker like Fidelity or Charles Schwab, which only executes trades.
There's no doubt you will save commission dollars -- up to half -- by using a discounter. But if you are uneasy about making investment decisions, you may feel more comfortable using a full-service broker, who can provide research reports on companies and advice on how to fashion a stock portfolio that is appropriate for your situation.
In any case, do not let concern over minimizing commission costs be the tail that wags the dog. Mrs. Marcelli cites "the 99:1 rule," which holds that 90 percent of the return of a portfolio is determined by the way money is allocated among different asset classes, 9 percent of the return is determined by the performance of the individual stocks or bonds selected and 1 percent of the return is determined by the execution of the order.
Although this rule works to the advantage of a full-service broker like Merrill Lynch, by minimizing the importance of its higher transaction costs, Mrs. Marcelli rightly notes that most people would benefit by devoting the bulk of their energy to deciding on asset classes and industry groups. "But most people concentrate on the 9 percent and the 1 percent, and spend very little time on the 90 percent," she said.
Whichever approach you follow, don't procrastinate. As Mr. Markese said: "Most people never start. First, they worry that the market is too high and wait for it to correct. But when the market comes down, it looks too gruesome, so then they wait for it to recover."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peggy Schmeltz of the National Association of Investment Clubs at the New York Stock Exchange. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New-Home Starts Are Up 3.9% As Buyers' Demand Turns Brisk

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Spurred by eager buyers, the nation's builders broke ground on new homes at an annual rate of 1,432,000 last month, a pace 3.9 percent faster than in October and the highest rate since early 1990.
The increase in housing starts, the fourth straight, consisted entirely of single-family homes, reflecting what analysts say has become a sizable migration of apartment dwellers from rental units to their first houses. 
 The biggest spur to housing construction, which began to accelerate in August, has been the lowest interest rates in 20 to 25 years. The low rates, combined with generally stable or declining prices, have made homes more affordable than at any time many renters under 45 can recall.
 
'Excellent' Buying Conditions
 "Affordability conditions are excellent, with mortgage interest rates still at around 7 percent," J. Roger Glunt, president of the National Association of Home Builders, said earlier this month after the Government reported new-home sales for October. "Those low rates are prompting many people to buy their first homes."
Even the relatively dormant Northeast participated in the November advance. Construction began in the region on 142,000 new homes, at a seasonally adjusted rate, the second-highest pace of the year. Housing starts also jumped in the South but fell slightly in the Midwest and West.
"The housing sector continues to strengthen," economists at Merrill Lynch told clients in reaction to the Commerce Department's report. "There were only two months in the past 15 years where a higher level of single-family starts was recorded."
Permits for future construction bounded ahead 4.8 percent in November, a sign that the housing market -- and related sales of appliances, carpeting and other furnishings -- will remain vigorous in the new year. Housing gains have a strong "multiplier" effect on the economy, rippling through many trades and industries for months.
The revival in home building, along with a comeback for the automotive industry, has been a principal engine of economic acceleration this autumn, contributing heavily to what is expected to be a rate of growth in gross domestic product of more than 4 percent for the October-December quarter. The economy would be even stronger were it not for the shrinking military sector and a wave of corporate revamping that continues to stunt job growth.
Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis economic consulting company, said today that it was raising its forecast for housing starts and residential construction for the quarter by about $2 billion, pushing its estimate for gross domestic product up by nearly two-tenths of a point.
An uptick in mortgage rates since mid-October seems to have led some fence-sitting buyers to conclude that nothing further was to be gained from holding off and that the time to act had arrived.
Such reversals "always move buyers," said Robert J. Strudler, chairman of the U.S. Home Corporation, the country's fourth-largest builder. He noted that decisions these days are quickly translated into new business since those willing to hold, or finance, large inventories of homes are becoming scarce.
"Most of us are building to order," Mr. Strudler said, adding that few builders were putting up houses speculatively, hoping to find buyers after they were built.
Although new homes tend to be more expensive than resales, many new homes today are being tailored to first-time buyers' pocketbooks.
Interest rates bottomed at 6.74 percent for 30-year mortgages in the week that ended on Oct. 22, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, and have climbed to 7.17 this week. The current level, however, is still nearly a full percentage point below what it was, 8.14 percent, at the start of 1993.
Unlike many analysts, who expect interest rates to creep up, the chief economist of the National Association of Home Builders, David F. Seiders, predicts that long-term rates will edge back down. But he has not raised his estimate that 1,385,000 homes will be built next year, a pace below November's.
Last month's rise in starts of single-family homes was 4.5 percent, to a rate of 1,269,000, the Government reported, with a small gain in structures of two to four units offset by a small decline for larger buildings.
Multifamily construction remains depressed even though reinstatement in August of the tax credit for low-income housing halted a long decline and apparently brought stability to this segment of the market.
Starts in the Northeast jumped 17.4 percent, to a 142,000 annual rate, while those in the much busier South rose 8.4 percent, to a rate of 635,000. The declines in the Midwest, to 341,000, and in the West, to 314,000, were less than 3 percent.
The department slightly reduced its tally of nationwide starts for October but raised its September total by about the same amount, the report also showed. For the first 11 months of the year, starts ran 6 percent ahead of the period in 1992.
The actual number of dwellings started last month, without seasonal adjustment, was 102,900, down from 122,100 in October, as colder weather affected work in much of the country.
Permits for construction, seasonally adjusted, rose in all regions and included a moderate rebound for units in large buildings. The rise was 2.1 percent in the Northeast, 4 percent in the South, 4.2 percent in the West and 8.2 percent in the Midwest.

HEADLINE: Former Head of Power Authority Is Chosen to Be a Deputy Mayor

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday named John S. Dyson, a former chairman of the State Power Authority, as his Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, filling out the top tier of his administration.
Mr. Dyson, who has also served as State Agriculture and Commerce Commissioner and pioneered the "I Love New York" promotional campaign, became the last of four deputy mayors to be appointed to City Hall, and the only one who has had significant government experience. While their party affiliations vary, all the deputies were crucial campaign supporters of Mr. Giuliani in either his first or second race for mayor. 
 Mr. Dyson, 50, a wealthy Dutchess County businessman and investor, said his talks with Mr. Giuliani about the deputy mayor's post began unexpectedly about two days ago after he sent the Mayor-elect a paper outlining 12 ideas for the city's economic development.
 
Unable to Persuade Parsons
 Until recently, Mr. Giuliani had been trying to persuade Richard D. Parsons, the chairman of the Dime Savings Bank and Mr. Giuliani's most prominent black supporter, to become a deputy mayor, aides said.
Introducing Mr. Dyson at a news conference, Mr. Giuliani, who had promised after a racially polarized vote to assemble a government representative of the city's diversity, showed impatience when questioned about the lack of a black official among his appointments so far.
"Give us a chance to put the government together before you criticize," Mr. Giuliani said, noting that he had not completed his top 30 to 40 appointments. "Why don't you give us a chance?"
Besides the deputy mayors, he has named a police commissioner, budget director, corporation counsel, press secretary, deputy press secretary and speech writer.
In keeping with his pledges to streamline government, Mr. Giuliani has eliminated two of the deputy posts that had existed under Mayor David N. Dinkins -- the first deputy mayor and the deputy mayor for public safety. He has said that the police commissioner, budget director and commissioner of investigation will all report to him directly.
Mr. Giuliani, seeking to blunt questions about relative lack of government experience among his Deputy Mayors, said, "There is going to be no inner cabinet," and added, "I very much think this city gets managed through commissioners."
"A government that was elected in order to make changes should be a government that has a substantial number of people who haven't been in government before," he said, "as well as some people who have been in government before so you have people you can rely on who have an understanding of what happens to that government."
In his 10 years in various state positions under two Democratic Governors, Hugh L . Carey and Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Dyson was known for his flamboyance, his advertising campaigns to sell the state and its products, and his quick, though acerbic, wit. When Republicans in the State Legislature were threatening to bar his face from being used in advertisements by the Commerce Department, Mr. Dyson showed up at a legislative hearing in a Lone Ranger mask.
 
'Open for Business'
 He served as Commerce Commissioner for Mr. Carey during a period in which the Democratic administration reduced the top personal income tax rate and took credit for stemming a loss of jobs from the state. He stepped down from government in 1985, when he resigned as chairman of the State Power Authority. Yesterday Mr. Dyson vowed to "unfurl a new banner over our skyline that says, 'New York is open for business.' "
Echoing Mr. Giuliani's own priorities, he said the city government had to improve its business climate by signaling that "we are beginning to cut taxes." Mr. Dyson said his mission was also to mount an assault on red tape and "rigid bureaucratic procedures," to bring an entrepreneurial spirit to government and to let businesses know "that we will cherish them, not punish them."
He also said the city should clean up its airports and the highways leading from them, to prevent arriving executives from getting a bad impression. "Safe streets are a business issue," he said.
As Deputy Mayor for economic development, Mr. Dyson will not only oversee such departments as Finance, Business Services, Employment, Telecommunications and Energy, but also Cultural Affairs, which Mr. Giuliani called crucial to the economy of the city.
While Mr. Dyson is a Democrat, he was a prominent supporter of Mr. Giuliani in 1989, campaigning at his side and becoming a major fund-raiser for the Republican-Liberal, responsible for $50,000 in contributions and a $100,000 loan. He said he provided occasional advice again in this campaign.
But he was solicited to join the Giuliani administration only over the last few days, promoted by a combination of Mr. Carey; the Liberal Party leader, Raymond B. Harding, and Mr. Giuliani's campaign media strategist, David Garth, said an adviser to Mr. Giuliani, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity.
"This was not 100 percent expected, you might understand," Mr. Dyson said yesterday.
Mr. Dyson has been running the Millbrook Vineyards winery and an investment company, Dyson Sinclair. His new job requires that he live in the city, and he said he would move to a "pied-a-terre" he keeps on Fifth Avenue. He said he would close his investment firm and put his holdings in a blind trust.
Mr. Dyson, who lost a 1986 Democratic Senate primary to Mark Green after spending $6 million of his own money, had been mentioned as a possible candidate for state comptroller next year. But he said yesterday, "I think I'll be too busy for the next two years to run for any office."

Joining them at the announcement at the transition headquarters were Mr. Dyson's daughter Eliza, left, and his wife, Kathe, far right. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times) (pg. 26)

HEADLINE: After Years of Ignoring AIDS Epidemic, Kenya Has Begun Facing Up to It

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 17

 BODY:
John Wainaina had heard about AIDS for years but never thought it was an illness that could touch him or his friends. Life was good. The 40-year-old construction worker was healthy and had a job, a family and, like many of his contemporaries, several girlfriends.
Today, 16 months after testing positive for H.I.V., Mr. Wainaina, emaciated and weak, shares a bed with another patient in Kenyatta Hospital here, too ashamed and too frightened to tell his friends and relatives that he has AIDS. At first, he did not even tell his doctor. 
 Mr. Wainaina is a victim of a growing epidemic that the Government and health officials say threatens to destroy the economic backbone of East Africa's wealthiest country in the next decade.
 
Government Starting to Act
 After years of passivity, the Government is finally facing up to the threat and taking a forceful role in the fight against AIDS.
Mr. Wainaina's four children in a nearby suburb are healthy, but his wife has tested positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, though she has no symptoms of the disease.
Three of his friends have died of AIDS, and Mr. Wainaina guesses that at least five other friends who saw the same women must also be H.I.V. positive.
"Of course I was aware" that AIDS existed, he said. "But back then I was a young man, with a job, a car. None of us used condoms. People thought that if you get AIDS, you die right away. So if you stay healthy, you're O.K.
"I am so ashamed. I cannot even tell my brothers. If I tell my friends, they will sneak away and they won't help. And then what will happen to my children when we are gone?"
This year the AIDS epidemic was debated in Kenya's Parliament and Cabinet for the first time. Leading Government officials, including President Daniel arap Moi and Vice President George Saitoti regularly warn the public in speeches to avoid infection. National officials are instructing district administrators, including local tribal chiefs, to tell people that they must take responsibility for their future by practicing safe sex and limiting their sexual partners.
"We have not come out as fast as we should have in talking about AIDS," said Naftali Agata, director of the Health Ministry's program for AIDS prevention. "The Government has now made a definite commitment."
The Government estimates that 800,000 people in this country of 22 million are infected with H.I.V., including 30,000 children. The exact number of AIDS cases in Kenya is not known, but a recent survey by the Agency for International Development put the number at about 100,000.
Roughly 900,000 Kenyans are expected to die of AIDS by the year 2000, and another 2 million will be infected by the turn of the century, Government officials say.
Already struggling with inadequate financing and a surge in tropical diseases like malaria, Kenya's public health system will be unable to cope, and the loss of millions of young and skilled workers will devastate the country's already faltering economy, experts say.
Though the virus has been racing through sub-Saharan Africa since the early 1980's, Kenya has been far slower than many of its neighbors to acknowledge the epidemic or combat it through education and prevention programs.
Its record presents a paradox. Despite an economic decline linked to corruption and the collapse of global commodity prices, Kenya is still the wealthiest country in East Africa and has been relatively stable since it won independence from Britain the 1960's. If any country in the region could have coped with AIDS, experts reasoned, it would have been Kenya.
 
Threat to Tourism Feared
 But unlike neighbors like Uganda, where the Government of President Yoweri Museveni opened an aggressive campaign to halt the spread of AIDS in the mid-1980's, the Kenyan Government tended to play down the threat for fear that it would keep tourists and much-needed cash away from its game parks and beach resorts.
Though Kenyan doctors diagnosed their first AIDS case in 1984, the Government did not release national statistics on the malady until 1986. That year it listed one AIDS-related death.
After years of semiofficial neglect, the Government must now do far more than simply acknowledge the epidemic, Kenyan officials now say.
"We have to develop strategies that are broader than just writing something in the media," said Mr. Agata, the head of the Government's AIDS prevention program. "Unless awareness of AIDS is going to change behavior, we are not going to achieve anything."
Among the biggest challenges the Government faces are a general reluctance among Kenyans to talk about sexuality, the illusion that AIDS can be contained within certain population groups and the shame people feel when they discover that they have the disease.
Attitudes of patients here contrast with those in Uganda, which has the highest number of recorded cases of H.I.V. infection in Africa -- around 1.5 million. There, AIDS has touched virtually every family and much of the cultural, religious and psychological stigma of the disease has slipped away. Uganda and several other African countries have developed grass-roots strategies to cope with the epidemic, including home care networks and community support and counseling groups.
In Kenya, with an abundance of victims like Mr. Wainaina, who heard about AIDS years ago but never thought he could contract it, the Government will have to find ways to "personalize" the disease.
Here, as in other African countries, the virus is transmitted mainly through heterosexual contact among young adults. It has spread through East Africa in the wake of wars and political upheaval, and more recently along the long-haul truck routes linking Tanzanian and Kenyan ports to the landlocked interior of Ethiopia, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi and the eastern part of Zaire.
More than two-thirds of all estimated AIDS cases worldwide are in sub-Saharan Africa, according to the most recent survey by the World Health Organization. The cumulative total of H.I.V. infection on the continent is close to 10 million, with 1.5 million new infections this year, according to M. H. Merson, executive director of the World Health Organization's global program on AIDS. Experts projected this week that 20 million Africans will have been infected by the end of the century.
 
Estimates of Infection
 Estimates of H.I.V. infection are based on scientifically compiled samples and are considered far more reliable than country-by-country tallies of AIDS cases, which are provided by the African governments.
In Kenya, experts report, H.I.V. is generally more prevalent among people with higher-paid jobs, like businessmen in Nairobi and Mombasa and truck drivers who ply the roads from the eastern coast to the interior.
Kenya's bigger cities have became magnets for men in search of work. Separated from their families for months, many eventually contract H.I.V. and bring it back to their villages. A great number of women in the cities who have been abandoned by men or in need of extra income turn to prostitution.
Dr. Frank Plummer, an associate professor at the Universities of Manitoba and Nairobi who is an expert on infectious disease, estimated that 12 percent of young adults in the city were now H.I.V. positive.
The Kenyan Health Ministry estimates that by the year 2000 the cost of AIDS will be the equivalent of 15 percent of the country's gross domestic product. At the same time that it is coming to terms with the AIDS threat, the Kenyan Government is struggling to come up with money to combat other diseases. Malaria is still the biggest killer, with more than 10,000 deaths attributed to it last year, Mr. Agata said.
 
Spending on Prevention
 In 1993, 20 percent of the Kenyan Health Ministry's budget of about $60 million went to AIDS prevention, a figure that Mr. Agata described as "totally inadequate."
The Government has made an extra allocation of $77,000 for AIDS programs for 1994. But most of the money for AIDS prevention comes from foreign donors like the United States Agency for International Development. It provided about $2 million this year for prevention programs and expects to supply $4 million in 1994, including $2 million worth of free condoms.
Given the limits on their resources, Kenyan Government officials say they need to focus on changing sexual behavior, mainly by counseling abstention, monogamy and the use of condoms.
The Agency for International Development calculated in one survey that only 12 percent of Kenyan men currently use condoms. But the chief of the agency's population and health sector, Gary Newton, said the figure had probably been close to zero only three years ago.
In the long term, international experts say, Kenya must also establish a far-flung program of home care for AIDS sufferers. A survey by the Agency for International Development says that AIDS patients currently occupy 15 percent of the country's hospital beds.
At Kenyatta Hospital, which with 2,000 beds is one of the largest hospitals in sub-Saharan Africa, the wards are so crowded that patients share beds and lie curled on blankets on the floor.
On an average day, the hospital is short of cancer drugs, penicillin, plastic gloves, disposable needles and linen. One official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the hospital had received no screening kits in the last six months to test for the presence of H.I.V. in donated blood.
"The health infrastructure will never be able to bear the burden of AIDS when it is full-blown," warned the hospital's director, Dr. Julius Meme. "We even have a shortage of blood. People used to donate quite freely. Not any more. They're scared.
"We can't keep burying our head in the sand and say it doesn't exist," he added.

HEADLINE: NEW YELTSIN MOVES MAY SIGNAL EASING IN ECONOMY REFORM

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 17

 BODY:
In what may be a sign of a weakening of economic resolve after his electoral rebuff on Sunday, President Boris N. Yeltsin today granted new heavily subsidized loans that could aggravate the budget deficit and inflation.
At the same time, after an extended debate, Mr. Yeltsin's Government approved the draft of a weaker, less centralized privatization program over objections from well-known reformers, including First Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar and Privatization Minister Anatoly B. Chubais. 
 The economic actions may or may not be straws in the wind, and Mr. Yeltsin's ultimate course may not be known until next week. At that time, his aides say, Mr. Yeltsin plans to comment for the first time on the election, in which there was a surge of support for critics of reform and for the caustic nationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky.
 
Gore Critical of I.M.F.
 But the steps taken today, including the $120 million in subsidized loans for agriculture enterprises, came at a time when the International Monetary Fund has been criticized by Vice President Al Gore as being insensitive to the plight of those in Russia who have lost their jobs because of sharp cuts in Russian military spending.
On Thursday in Moscow, Mr. Gore accused the monetary fund of being too strict in its conditions for loans to Russia, even though the fund has loosened its normal requirements to provide Russia $2.5 billion on the basis of Government promises of financial restraint that have not been met.
"Every country with representatives on the I.M.F. board has been slow to recognize the hardship caused by some of what has been done in the past," Mr. Gore said. "That may cause a diplomatic incident, but I don't care."
 
$1.5 Billion Is Delayed
 The fund has delayed a second installment of $1.5 billion in special financing because of poor Russian financial management, arguing that such loans are useless unless tied to a serious program to stabilize the economy and reduce inflation of 15 to 20 percent a month.
Mr. Gore's statement, which diplomats said they assumed had been coordinated with the White House, seemed to reflect a possible shift of support toward more direct Western subsidy of Russia's work force during the painful transition to a market economy.
Many Russians have criticized the West for providing lots of advice, but little money to back it up. But many Western countries fear that easing credit terms would destroy the credibility of the fund around the world. Some suggest that perhaps a new agency should be given the task of subsidizing the economic transformation of Russia, if that is what Washington intends.
Mr. Yeltsin handed out the loans today while the reformist Finance Minister, Boris G. Fyodorov, was meeting officials of the Group of Seven nations in Paris to discuss Western aid and debt relief for Russia. The loans were for farm machinery enterprises at 25 percent interest a year, far below the Central Bank's discount rate of 210 percent, the Interfax news agency said.
Mr. Fyodorov and Western economic advisers to the Government had said before the elections that the days of such artificially cheap loans, at interest rates well below the rate of inflation, were over.
[A senior United States Treasury official said in Washington that Mr. Fyodorov had told the Group of Seven in Paris that there would be a continuation of economic reforms in Russia, and that the approval of the new Russian Constitution on Sunday would help carry them out.]
The handout will add to a Government deficit that is bound to swell in the new year, as about $4 billion in deferred Government payments to farmers, miners and the military are finally paid. The major Western industrialized countries are looking for Russia to get its budget deficit down and monthly inflation to less than 10 percent this year.
 
No Mandate for Reformers
 But the West's expectations that Russia's reformers would have the mandate to push through a tough economic stabilization program after the elections have been dashed.
Mr. Yeltsin, aides said, may deliver a long statement on the election at a news conference next week. His silence has baffled many supporters, leading to suggestions that he is seeking ways to work with Mr. Zhirinovsky, who won the largest share of party preference votes on Sunday and will command the second-largest bloc in the lower house of Parliament.
The aides also said there was likely to be a Government reshuffle, though Mr. Yeltsin will reaffirm support for Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who did not run in the election, and "the core" of pro-reform ministers.
But it seems likely that Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Chernomyrdin will shy away from calls to throw their support fully behind the reformers, instead trying to pull in some officials from centrist parties who have opposed the current pace of economic change.
The privatization measures for 1994 were approved at a long and contentious Government meeting run by Mr. Chernomyrdin's favorite deputy, Oleg N. Soskovets.
Well-known reformers like the Privatization Minister, Mr. Chubais, complained that the draft gave far more rights and discretion to the regions than the previous program and imposes more curbs on the privatization of property, Interfax said.
Mr. Gaidar, the First Deputy Prime Minister, complained that it would be "irresponsible to tamper with the privatization program" until July 1, when the period for using privatization vouchers, issued to every Russian citizen, expires.
While all these economic steps were being debated and carried out, the vote on Sunday remained a focus of uncertainty today. At a news conference, the head of the Central Election Committee, Nikolai Ryabov, said that even the preliminary vote count was not yet completed, raising concerns about possible manipulation of the results.
According to almost complete preliminary counts, he said, Mr. Yeltsin's strong-presidency Constitution was approved in a general turnout of 54.8 percent of the 106.1 million registered voters. A minimum 50 percent turnout was required to make the constitutional referendum valid.
Mr. Ryabov also said 32.9 million people, or 58.4 percent of those voting, had voted for the constitution. If he is right, that would mean a turnout for the constitution ballot alone of only 53.1 percent.
 
Discrepancy Not Explained
 But Itar-Tass, citing "reliable sources," said tonight that only 50.14 percent of registered Russian voters had turned out, extremely close to the minimum required. There was no immediate explanation for the discrepancy.
In 8 of the 20 ethnic republics, Mr. Ryabov said, less than 50 percent of voters turned out, casting a shadow on the results. Those 8 were Tatarstan (where less than 25 percent voted), Bashkortostan, Dagestan, Tuva, Chuvashia, Mordovia, Adyegya and Karachayevo-Cherkasia. Chechnya, which has declared independence, did not vote.
Mr. Ryabov did not detail the party affiliations of those elected to the lower house. Half the 450 seats are filled through proportional representation, from party lists, and the other half are filled by direct constituency election, as is the entire upper house.
No single bloc or faction will have a working majority in the lower house, which will be controlled by the 130 or so elected as independents.
The upper house will have few, if any, Zhirinovsky supporters, but it will include many Yeltsin foes.

HEADLINE: U.S. Disenchantment With Aristide Growing

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
In the latest public suggestion that they are growing disenchanted with Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Clinton Administration officials today expressed tepid support for the exiled Haitian leader and grumbled privately about their frustrations with him.
For now at least, they say, they will continue efforts to restore him to power. But they are wringing their hands over what they call his inflexibility. 
 "I don't pretend at all that the path will be easy," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said at the State Department today. "But the United States is resolute about pursuing the restoration of democracy and the return of President Aristide."
But Mr. Christopher was less than enthusiastic about the Haitian leader, saying only that he had been "responsive and effective" in meetings.
 
Sign of Displeasure
 Senior State Department officials said later that Mr. Christopher intended to signal the Administration's displeasure with Father Aristide. "I would not describe the Secretary's comments as effusive with respect to Aristide," a senior State Department official said.
Administration officials are furious with Father Aristide for scuttling an initiative by Robert Malval, his hand-picked Prime Minister, that was intended to ease the Catholic priest's return from exile in Washington. The initiative involved the convening of a conference held by a cross section of segments of Haitian society, including the military.
Military leaders like Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras have refused to abide by the so-called Governors Island Accords, reached last summer in New York, which were supposed to lead to the exiled President's return on Oct. 30.
Father Aristide originally backed the new initiative by Mr. Malval but last week withdrew his support, saying the safety of his supporters who might attend such a conference could not be guaranteed.
 
Reservations Expressed
 "A lot of people expressed reservations to Malval about the possibility of holding such a meeting under the current circumstances," said Michael K. Barnes, Father Aristide's legal adviser here. "The security situation in the country, in the view of most knowledgeable observers, makes it impossible to hold a meeting where people feel they could participate without being killed."
On Wednesday, Mr. Malval's resignation became effective. Though he will stay on until a successor is named, Father Aristide has instructed him not to undertake any new initiatives.
At a news conference on Wednesday, Mr. Malval broke into tears after telling reporters that Haiti, whose economy has been battered by a United Nations oil embargo, was "in a desperate situation."
Aides to Father Aristide acknowledge that they sense a rising level of irritation on the part of Administration officials. But one adviser said he believed it reflected the anger of Administration officials with their own inability to carry through with their promise to return Father Aristide to power.
Administration officials freely acknowledge they are at a loss on what they should do next if Haiti's military leaders continue to defy the entreaties of the international community for Aristide to return. Military intervention has been ruled out, and there is increasing concern over the hardship the oil embargo is causing to the average Haitian.
And there are signs of divisions within the Administration over some of the most fundamental questions of Haitian policy, such as whether the United States would participate in a military mission to monitor and retrain the Haitian military if they agree to let Father Aristide return.

HEADLINE: Pentagon's Budget Gap Is Narrowed to $31 Billion

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Anxious to put to rest a public dispute between the Pentagon and the White House before Bobby Ray Inman takes over as Defense Secretary, senior Administration officials today produced more optimistic inflation estimates showing that a $50 billion Pentagon shortfall had shrunk to $31 billion.
A top White House official also told reporters that President Clinton was determined to maintain the Pentagon strategy of preparing to fight two regional wars virtually at once and to buy the aircraft carriers and maintain the Army divisions and Air Force wings necessary to carry out the strategy. 
 "The President said he is committed to funding the strategy," Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, said today after he met with Mr. Clinton, Defense Secretary Les Aspin and Leon E. Panetta, the budget director. "That will be the assumption."
The comments by Mr. Lake and other top White House and Pentagon officials were intended to strengthen ties with the military and rebut Republican assertions that Mr. Aspin was leaving because of budget cuts that would undermine the armed forces.
 
Optimistic Assumptions
 The economic assumptions that reduced the shortfall for the Pentagon's five-year plan were developed by the Council of Economic Advisers, whose estimate is more optimistic than the one the Pentagon had been using to develop its budget for 1995-1999.
The gap stems from the decision to raise military pay and faulty inflation estimates developed earlier this year. With the Administration committed to reducing the deficit, funds that go to the Pentagon to help make up its shortfall will come at the expense of other agencies, including hard-pressed domestic spending programs.
Top Pentagon and White House officials, gathering in an unusual display of unity, summoned reporters for the latest White House inflation estimate.
But the officials refused to say how much of the $31 billion shortfall, which the Pentagon had estimated at $47.5 billion, would have to be absorbed in new Pentagon cuts, or if the Defense Department would have to reopen its comprehensive "bottom up review" of military spending. They said the budget issue still needed to be worked out.
The officials also declined to say whether the Pentagon would receive more funds if the White House's latest inflation estimate turned out to be low.
 
Sense of Harmony Seen
 Some budget experts on Capitol Hill said the White House assertion that inflation would be less than had been projected earlier was plausible, although they said they would reserve judgment until they examined details of the Administration's economic forecasts.
But some military officials said they were suspicious that the problem was being papered over to create a sense of harmony before Mr. Inman replaces Mr. Aspin as Secretary of Defense.
"We are not falling off our foreign policy commitments," one general said. "We are not falling off our level of projected forces. It does not add up."
Mr. Aspin discussed several options for cuts in military programs in a 90-minute meeting this morning with the President, and has also presented the options to the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
The issue has to be resolved soon so that the Pentagon and the other departments and agencies can complete their budget requests for next year. Mr. Clinton will make the final decisions on the Defense Department budget before Christmas.
 
Committed to Aspin Plan
 As the President considered the options, top Administration officials said the White House was still committed to maintaining a force of 12 aircraft carriers, 10 active Army divisions and 20 active and reserve Air Force tactical air wings. That was the force proposed by Mr. Aspin's review to maintain the ability to fight two wars "nearly simultaneously."
The officials also said that, to maintain the combat readiness of the armed forces, they intended to continue with military training and to buy the necessary spare parts. This means that any offsetting budget cuts must come from programs for new weapons and areas like environmental cleanup.
The Defense Department, in addition to the budget shortfall it is facing with its five-year plan, is trying to identify $13 billion in offsetting cuts to accommodate the forces it wants to keep.
The Pentagon is not the only department that faces a gap between what it wants for the 1995 fiscal year, which begins next Oct. 1, and what the White House is proposing to request from Congress. The Central Intelligence Agency wants White House support for its budget request.
 
State Department Shortfall
 And Secretary of State Warren Christopher met today with Mr. Clinton to ask for additional funds to cover the shortfall between the State Department's plans for foreign aid, dues to the United Nations, funds for international organizations to contain population growth and preserve the environment, and money to operate American embassies around the world.
One senior State Department official said the gap for next years' budget was about $3 billion, though Mike McCurry, a spokesman for the department, insisted that figure was not accurate.
Mr. McCurry said Secretary Christopher had been arguing "passionately" for White House support for the department's foreign affairs budget.
"He's been selling hard for some time," Mr. McCurry said. "He feels very strongly that diplomacy deserves to be funded at adequate levels and that you can't continue to sort of nickel and dime the diplomatic function within the Federal budget as this country has over the last decade."
Senior Administration officials said that the President had discussed military spending with Mr. Inman and indicated that whatever happened he would not seek less military spending for next year than had been previously planned. Mr. Panetta has publicly made such an assurance.

HEADLINE: U.S. Envoy Says Crackdown Strengthened Aidid's Faction

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's special envoy to Somalia said today that the failed effort to hunt down Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid during the summer actually strengthened the Somali faction leader politically and militarily.
In a speech to a group of reporters in Washington, Robert B. Oakley, who represented President Clinton in Somalia, said that General Aidid remains a "threat" to United Nations efforts to rebuild Somalia. 
 "Up until the first of November the net result of what had begun on June 5 had strengthened him considerably," Mr. Oakley said. The earlier date was when 24 Pakistani peacekeepers were killed by fighters believed to be part of Gen. Aidid's forces.
After the June clash, the United Nations branded General Aidid a criminal, setting off a manhunt that resulted in numerous street battles between United Nations forces and Aidid militia members. Those clashes culminated on Oct. 3 with a battle that left 18 Americans dead and 75 wounded.
 
Caused an Uproar
 The raid caused an uproar in the United States and produced demands in Congress for an immediate withdrawal. Instead, President Clinton opted for a withdrawal by March 31.
Mr. Oakley's remarks came as the first American combat unit began leaving. Some 450 infantrymen from the 10th Mountain Division left for Fort Drum, N.Y.
Members of the battalion, two of whom died and 24 of whom were wounded in the fighting on Oct. 3, told Reuters that Somalia shattered their ideas of saving famine victims.
"I didn't see one starving person in my five months here," said Sgt. Steve Andrews, 28, who is from Baltimore. "And we certainly did a lot more chasing Aidid than we expected."
 
More of a Threat
 In his speech today, Mr. Oakley said that General Aidid "is perceived by the rest of the country as being more of a threat than he was before.
But Mr. Oakley said that General Aidid had not gained strength in the rest of the country and does not have the military might to bring the other Somali clans under his sway.
General Aidid's strength is one of factors the Administration is considering as it ponders changing the focus of its aid efforts in Somalia.
Efforts to broker a peace collapsed last week, leading some United Nations officials to fear that fighting would renew after the United States completes its withdrawal.
Earlier this week, Richard McCall, chief of staff for the Agency for International Development, told reporters that the United States and other countries were considering limiting efforts to rebuild Somalia to areas where there is no factional fighting, and trying to isolate areas controlled by factions that do not cooperate.
Mr. Oakley said today that a lull in fighting has continued.
"The crisis is simmering, rather than exploding like a volcano," he said.

HEADLINE: Holiday Shoppers Are Whipping Out the Plastic

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Retailers and credit card companies say shoppers are charging more purchases this holiday season, a sign of improving consumer confidence.
The volume of retail sales cleared through Mastercard's network jumped almost 20 percent between the day after Thanksgiving and last Friday. Over the last weekend, Visa processed about 850 transactions in its peak second, beating out 811 calls in last year's peak second, which fell on the Saturday before Christmas. 
 But merchants and credit industry analysts caution that the leap in purchases on credit, a trend that has been building since the beginning of the year, will not necessarily translate into equally robust sales increases. In part, consumers are responding to promotions and incentives like mileage points for dollars spent, using cards instead of cash.
"The growth you're seeing in the use of bank cards is apart from retail sales growth," said Kurt Peters, publisher of Credit Card News, which is published by Faulkner & Gray Inc.
 
Sales Up in Malls
 Sales in shopping malls through the first 17 days of the holiday season rose 5.7 percent, according to a survey by the International Council of Shopping Centers. In comparison, sales charged to Visa cards were up 28 percent from the day after Thanksgiving through last Saturday.
"It doesn't necessarily tell us how robust sales will be, but it does tell us the customer seems to be regaining some confidence," said Bernard Fuchs, chairman and chief executive of Specialty Retailers Inc., which operates Palais Royale and Bealls department stores in Texas.
While retailers welcome any sign of renewed shopping vigor, some consultants are concerned that the increased credit card volume may be a damper on sales in the new year. Last year, use of credit cards also heated up at Christmas time, with sales up an average of 8 percent. After the bills arrived in January, however, consumers clamped down on further purchasing until August.
"The increased use of credit cards means, in my opinion, that the consumer who is going to be hit with higher taxes anyway will cut back on spending," said Walter F. Loeb, a retail consultant.
Credit card companies say, however, that while use has skyrocketed, card holders are also paying off bigger portions of their balances. Mr. Fuchs of Specialty Retailers said that the main factor encouraging credit card use during the 1992 holiday season -- euphoria in the aftermath of the Presidential election -- was not driving usage this year. "I think people are feeling more secure about their prospects, and I think they're being smarter about how they use their cards," he said.
Use of cards like Visa and Mastercard, as well as Specialty Retailers' own proprietary credit cards has increased about 2 percent or 3 percent during the season, Mr. Fuchs said, and other retailers, particularly department stores, report even greater increases in card use. Don Shinkle, a spokesman for Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the country's largest retailer, said card use had increased about 35 percent this year. "That trend is holding the same over the holidays," he said.
Mr. Peters and others say special incentives that credit cards companies are offering, combined with lower interest rates, are paying off.
Mastercard and Visa have both beefed up their holiday promotions, and some department stores are using their credit cards to promote their Christmas business. Both Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's held special shopping nights for their best credit card customers, and in February, Saks First card holders, the premier group, will receive a bonus certificate equal to 10 percent of their purchases in November and December, which can be redeemed for merchandise early next year.
 
Catalogue Sales Consistent
 While sales in stores have seesawed up and down during the holiday season, catalogue sales, which are largely through credit cards, have been fairly consistent. Major discounters have installed new technology that improves credit card processing, and Sears, Roebuck & Company, the country's third-largest retailer, just started accepting Visa and Mastercard this year.
"We've seen quite an increase in mail- and phone-order activity, as well as a somewhat smaller increase in transactions at discount stores," Albert Coscia, a Visa spokesman, said.
Mastercard has increased the number of merchants participating in its Master Values program, which gives holiday shoppers as much as a 25 percent discount on items purchased from participating retailers like Camelot Music stores, Mattel Toys and the Right Start catalogue. Visa changed its annual holiday promotion to increase the number of card users likely to benefit from it and gave merchants incentives to promote it, as well.
 
Co-Branded Cards Growing
 But the real engine powering the explosion of credit card purchases year-round, credit card experts and retailers say, is the growth of co-branded cards like the GM Card, a Mastercard that gives users a rebate toward the purchase of General Motors cars and trucks, and Citibank's program with American Airlines that gives shoppers frequent flier miles.
"The frequency of usage of our co-branded cards is always higher than our regular cards," said Stephen J. Bartell, vice president of co-branded and affinity marketing at Mastercard. "People will go in and start using them in lieu of cash because they want the rewards."
Mr. Shinkle of Wal-Mart said that in addition to such incentives, speedier processing had also fueled the use of credit cards. He said Wal-Mart installed technology a little more than a year ago that made the approval process almost instant. "Not too long ago, customers hesitated to use their cards because it took so doggone long to get a transaction processed," he said.

HEADLINE: Accord on Health Care Reached in Albany

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 17

 BODY:
After eight months of tortuous negotiation over health care financing, the State Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo struck an agreement tonight to grant hospitals a modest increase in revenues and provide new incentives for improving preventive and family care.
Because the bill would leave New York's health care system largely intact, critics said it would fall far short of the blueprint for change once envisioned by Mr. Cuomo. The Governor abandoned proposals to grant no rise in financing to hospitals, to cap doctors' fees and to tighten the state's control over the proliferation of expensive medical equipment. 
 With President Clinton and Congress considering a radical overhaul of the country's health care system, Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature left the most difficult decisions about New York's health system for another day. They did not consider creating a universal health care system or debate other sweeping changes in the insurance system.
"There's a lot of good in this package," said Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Health Committee. "But it's hard to do major system reform when the Federal Government is on the verge of changing all the rules of the game."
 
More Aid to Hospitals
 Leading legislators and Cuomo administration aides said the bill would increase revenues at the state's hospitals about 5.6 percent a year for the next two years. They said it would also funnel new money to struggling hospitals, to training for emergency medical technicians, to hospital tuberculosis units and to programs to care for infants with AIDS.
Assembly Democrats failed in the final talks to win agreement from Senate Republicans to expand eligibility for a popular program of state-subsidized health insurance for the children of the working poor.
The bill passed both the Senate and Assembly late tonight.
With the state's hospital reimbursement system scheduled to expire on Dec. 31, the bill's sponsors said they were relieved to have an agreement at last that would allow the state's hospitals to budget for the next year. Hospital executives had predicted fiscal chaos if the deadline lapsed without a bill.
 
Albany Controls Repayments
 Through an intricate formula, the state controls the rates that Medicaid and private insurers use to reimburse hospitals for various procedures. It can also use the formula to direct money to hospitals in particular regions or to those with fiscal problems caused by heavy caseloads of poor or chronically ill patients.
The formula expires every two or three years, and the ensuing battle to revise it is driven by the competing interests of doctors, hospitals, insurance companies and citizens' groups.
The Senate sponsor of the bill, Michael J. Tully of Roslyn Heights, L.I., said he hoped the agreement would not lead to increases in health insurance fees. But leaders of patients' groups predicted that it would.
"There is no cost containment but almost a billion more dollars spent on hospitals and only a fraction of that on primary care," said Richard Kirsch, director of Citizen Action, a patients' group. "The Governor and Legislature have utterly failed at health care reform."
 
Cuomo Agrees to a Change
 But Richard M. Cook, the Governor's deputy secretary for health, disagreed. "This bill is the most significant increase in primary care that the state has made in 10 years," he said. Mr. Cook added that the Cuomo administration would continue to push for controlling the growth in health care costs.
Mr. Cuomo originally proposed to limit health care costs by not increasing hospital reimbursement rates, which currently generate about $10 billion in revenues, according to the State Health Department. But with hospitals facing deep new cuts in Federal Medicare payments, he eventually agreed to a Senate plan that would funnel an additional $181 million a year to hospitals.
That increase is about 1.8 percent on top of a 3.8 percent increase that is already built into the hospital financing formula to keep pace with inflation, said Peter Slocum, a Health Department spokesman.
Daniel Sisto, president of the Hospital Association of New York State, said the higher payments to hospitals would barely offset the losses inflicted this year by Congress through cuts in Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly.
 
Help for Poorly Served Areas
 "Next year we're looking at a $170 million loss from Medicare," Mr. Sisto said. "This should help stabilize hospitals in 1994 and give them time to prepare for the initiatives in Clinton's health security act."
The bill would add $13 million a year to an existing $22 million for grants to doctors, hospitals and clinics that set up preventive and family care practices in underserved areas. It would also spend about $15 million to forgive medical school loans for family doctors, give grants to medical schools that stress family and preventive medicine, increase aid to schools that recruit minority doctors, and give scholarships to aspiring midwives, nurse practitioners and physician's assistants.
The Democrats who control the Assembly fought to expand the eligibility for the state's Child Health Plus program. Created in 1990, the program provides health coverage for children under 13 from families that cannot afford insurance but are not poor enough to qualify for Medicaid.
The Assembly majority proposed expanding the program to cover 13-year-olds next year and 14-year-olds in 1995, at a cost of $5 million the first year and $12 million the second.
 
Opposed by Catholic Group
 The state Catholic Conference opposed the expansion on the ground that it might make state-financed abortions available to young teen-agers. Senate leaders said they were not persuaded by that argument but were opposing the proposal because it was not affordable.
Instead, all sides agreed to increase money for the program so that the state can afford to cover more of the children who are now eligible. There are now 64,000 children enrolled out of an estimated 170,000 who are eligible. With the new money, about 80,000 children should be covered by the program next year, legislative aides said.

HEADLINE: Interest Rates Fall in Bond Market

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices spurted higher and interest rates fell yesterday after a newspaper report that the Federal Reserve Board did not see an immediate need to raise interest rates.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond was up 9/32 , and its yield fell to 6.27 percent, from 6.29 percent on Thursday. 
 The report, in The Washington Post, said that a number of senior central bank officials felt inflation pressures were insufficient to warrant higher rates. That helped allay concerns among many traders and investors who have come to believe that the Fed would nudge short-term yields higher early next year.
The sentiment has depressed bond prices in recent months, since higher rates on newly sold securities would hurt the value of bonds already sold, which pay a fixed rate of return.
The Fed's monetary policy-making panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, meets next week to discuss the direction of interest rates.
Treasury prices initially rose during Tokyo trading, which begins before New York's session, and maintained their gains in New York.
However, some analysts said reaction to The Post article was muted because rumors of its publication circulated in the market on Thursday. Among the rumors was that the Fed's vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr., had told The Post that the central bank would hold the line on interest rates for six months. In fact, the article cited comments from a speech he gave last week, not an interview, and did not mention a timetable.
Kathleen Camilli, chief economist at Maria Fiorini Ramirez Inc., said her firm had circulated the rumors on its electronic wire on Thursday morning. The wire goes out to 330 clients in 38 countries. She said she heard the rumors from three financial traders.
She said that turned bond prices around for the next 24 hours, but that by Sunday night, "we'll have something else to trade off of."
Also countering market enthusiasm was a Government report that housing starts jumped 3.9 percent in November. The report added to evidence that the economic recovery accelerated this quarter, raising the specter that inflation could increase from this year's level of roughly 3 percent. Inflation can diminish the value of fixed-income securities.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills were higher at 3.09 percent as the discount was up 0.01 percentage point at 3.03 percent. Six-month yields held at 3.31 percent as the discount was unchanged at 3.22 percent. One-year yields were lower at 3.56 percent as the discount fell 0.02 point to 3.43 percent.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 2 7/8 percent, down from 31/16 percent late Thursday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10310/32 , up 1/32 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.58 percent.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
DYSON NAMED A DEPUTY MAYOR
Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani named John S. Dyson, a former chairman of the State Power Authority, as his deputy mayor for finance and economic development, filling out the top tier of his administration. Page 1. 

PLAZA SPECTACLE, IN WHITE AND BLACK TIE
The middle-aged master builder finally decides to marry the actress-model mother of his infant child, a week after she unveils her new line of maternity clothes, in a ceremony at The Plaza, formerly managed by his former wife. Page 1.
 
TWO VERSIONS OF BLAST AFTERMATH
An executive of Consolidated Edison said that "within hours" of the 1989 blast near Grammercy Park, the company had told the city that it had found asbestos in test samples. But a former deputy mayor said that "if someone had said that there was a problem, we'd have acted completely differently." Page 26.
 
OFF-DUTY OFFICER SHOT FOR HIS JACKET

HEADLINE: Judges in Trenton Reject Sports Betting Plan

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The two-year campaign by the 12 casinos in Atlantic City to legalize sports betting ended today when State Supreme Court ruled that such an extension of gambling would need voter approval under the State Constitution.
A bill to place the question before the voters on Nov. 2 cleared the State Senate but was blocked in the Assembly. The Casino Association of New Jersey last month asked the Casino Control Commission, which regulates the industry, to approve sports betting through regulation. The commission said it lacked such authority, and its position was upheld last week by an appeals court and today by the state's highest court. 
 "Obviously, we're disappointed," the lawyer for the casinos, Joel H. Sterns, said. "It's the end of the legal battle."
The casinos had until Jan. 1 to obtain state approval under the Federal Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act, which last year barred states that did not already have some form of sports betting from approving it in the future. Before final passage the bill was amended to allow New Jersey an extra year to decide whether it wanted sports betting because of the interest of the casinos.
 
'We Had Aa Tremendous Opportunity'
 "We had a tremendous opportunity to gain a competitive advantage that no other state had by approving sports betting in a state that has widespread illegal gambling on sports anyway," Mr. Sterns said.
Although the opportunity expires on Jan. 1 the casino operators are expected to continue to try to obtain a bipartisan expression of support for their proposal, so that they can mount another attempt to reopen the issue in Congress.
The Supreme Court did not write its opinion, but unanimously adopted the decision written by Judge Arnold M. Stein of the Appellate Division of Superior Court. Judge Stein wrote, "Except for constitutionally authorized simulcast horse-race betting, gambling casinos may operate only those games conducted solely in-house." Under simulcasting, casino customers can bet on races at tracks here and elsewhere.
The casinos based their request for approval by the casino commission on regulations in force in Las Vegas, Nev., where bets are taken on virtually all sports events, professional and amateur. The New Jersey proposal would not accept bets on contests in which a New Jersey school was a participant nor on election results.
The National Football League, the National Basketball Association, the National Hockey League and the Commissioner of Baseball fought the betting proposal in the Legislature and opposed it in the short-lived court test that ended today.
add betting
 
Billions in New Jersey Alone
 The defeat for the casinos here leaves Nevada with a virtual monopoly on the lucrative legalized sports-betting industry. Oregon has a sports lottery, and Delaware voters have approved wagering on athletic events, but state officials have not yet started that.
Officials of the Casino Association said that illegal sports betting in New Jersey alone was a $2.5 billion industry and that legalizing it would produce an extra $14 million a year in revenue for the state.
But the measure faced stiff opposition from the outset from amateur and professional sports alliances and leagues and from a host of legislators who worried that New Jersey was becoming too economically dependent on gambling revenues.
In a bid to win support the casinos backed off their initial demands that they be allowed to take bets on any college or professional sports activity and agreed instead to focus on just professional events. The proposed law would have also barred the casinos from taking bets by telephone, requiring gamblers instead to go to the casinos to place bets.

HEADLINE: New Pushcart Era Faces Old Threat;
Weak Sales and Low Prices Add to Problem of Paying Rent

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
It has been more than 50 years since Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia banned pushcarts, those mobile symbols of entrepreneurial initiative, from New York City streets.
Now the city is seeing the second rise -- and perhaps the second fall -- of pushcarts, with an important change. From bus and train terminals to the nooks and crannies of the World Trade Center to Citicorp office buildings in Manhattan and Queens to a Brooklyn shopping mall, the carts have gone inside. And they are big business. With access to thousands of scurrying commuters and shoppers in a good week, some post sales of more than $3,000. 
 But this has not been a good season, at least so far. Operators say sales are running way below last year, and they fear that they will not earn sufficient money to pay their rents. Rents for the holiday period are steep, running $700 to $1,200 a week, three times as high as the rest of the year.
"Nobody's stopping," said Kirit Sheth, who sells holographic pictures from a cart at an entrance to the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue in midtown. "Everybody's running for the bus."
 
Wobbly Demand, Large Discounts
 Pesia Romeo, who sells Victorian sachets from a cart beneath the World Trade Center, said, "I invested a lot of money, and it doesn't look like I'm going to get it back this year."
The problem is the same one afflicting retailers from the suburban malls to the cluttered shops on the Lower East Side to catalogue sellers. Consumer demand remains wobbly, while merchants cannibalize one another with deeply discounted prices.
"The stores have reduced their prices so low that they are now competing with the prices on the pushcarts," said Arlen A. Penn, operations director for Ports of Call Management Inc., which runs pushcart programs for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Grand Central Terminal and other locations.
That means some vendors will be forced out of the pushcart business, at least temporarily. Ms. Penn said she expected at least seven of the 22 carts at the bus terminal to drop out after the holidays. But replacements seem eager to take their stalls at rents that will fall, to $175 to $300 a week. About 15 people are on the waiting list for the terminal.
Some people go into the pushcart business because they want to be their own boss, no matter what the scale. Some are looking to move up to real stores. Many are immigrants, willing to work endless hours and able to converse just enough to sell Christmas tree ornaments made from bread dough by South American Indians at three for $10.
"This is a good start, I would say," said Nelson Villasante, who sells T-shirts, sweat shirts and other clothing with Art Deco designs at the South Street Seaport, paying $500 a week for rent plus 15 percent of all sales over $2,900 a week. In some cases operators pay rent and commission to the owners of the buildings where they work and in other cases the money goes to specialized companies that recruit cart operators and act as intermediaries with managers of buildings where they do business.
Jack DeMarco, who sells plastic key chains and decorations from a cart at the Gallery at Metrotech in downtown Brooklyn, said: "If I make $300 in a day I'm doing very well. But if that shoe store makes $300 in a day he's bankrupt."
From the perspective of realty owners the carts represent extra revenue, a chance to offer untested merchandise in small quantities, a service to customers and a way to force out less desired activities like panhandling.
"They're a very, very convenient way for someone to shop," Jack Brendlen, a real-estate manager for the Port Authority, said. "And they displace negative activity."
Customers like the convenience and novelty. At a cart that sells nothing but products in the color purple, Purple Mystique at the Seaport, two women bought each other presents, a purple backpack and a purple hat. "This is the first time I ever bought from a pushcart," said one of them, Nancy Landis, a bartender. "It has a low-pressure appeal."
 
The Usual and the Unusual
 Some carts sell totally expected items like costume jewelry, compact disks or ties to commuters in desperate need of last-minute gifts. Others offer unusual items.
The Leftorium, a cart in the A. & S. Plaza at Herald Square, sells goods designed for left-handed people.
All the carts rely on convenience, low prices and sharp display to move merchandise briskly.
The director of the development office at Grand Central, Jeanne Giordano, likened the pushcart trend to the flowering of so-called superstores that offer vast quantities of goods, from books to bath towels, at low prices. "These are the two extremes of the same phenomenon," she said. "People want value, and carts offer incredible variety and low prices in a small space."
In their modern incarnation, carts are a phenomenon that originated in shopping malls, specifically with the Rouse Company Faneuil Hall development in Boston in 1976. Rouse's goal was to build a diffuse retail center with no big development stores for anchors in an area previously occupied by an open-air market. Many stores that the company approached were afraid of the concept and were reluctant to lease.
"Fast thinking is the mother of invention," a spokeswoman for Rouse, Cathy Lickteig, said. "We had to the bring the merchandise out to the people. So we put it on little carts."
Rouse has gone on to put 1,500 carts into 70 of its 78 shopping centers. "It's become a multimillion-dollar business for us," Ms. Lickteig said. At the South Street Seaport, a Rouse development, pushcart sales have at a 15 percent annual pace.
Peter Lembo, an associate general manager for the owner of the A. & S. Plaza, the Simon Company, said he had a waiting list of 45 people for one of two pushcart spaces.
A spokesman for the International Council of Shopping Centers, Keith Fox, estimated that the number of shopping carts in shopping centers nationally had doubled, to at least 27,000 over the last decade.
 
'One of the Best' at the Market
 Perhaps because failures simply disappear, success stories abound. Ossam Elbardissy, now 28, emigrated from Egypt six years ago, and opened a pushcart selling Broadway posters and paraphernalia at the South Street Seaport. He expanded to a store, kept the pushcart and added a cart with cartoon-related products.
"It was one of the best pushcarts in the market," he said of cart No. 1. "I'm very proud."
Another established vendor is Adrian van der Plas, whose business is called Fine Art a la Cart. For $15 to $500 he sells paintings with New York themes from a prime location at Pier 17 in the seaport. With the rent he pays, more than $2,500 monthly, he said he could easily lease a nice gallery in TriBeCa, where he lives, but chose not to.
"I'm building something here for many years to come," he said. "People find me and come back."
Other vendors have felt compelled to roam the malls of America in search of success
Mr. DeMarco has taken his acrylic key chains to Sarasota, Fla.; Richmond; Ocean County, N.J., and countless stops in between. "Sometimes the economy is down, and my business goes up, because I'm selling a low-priced item," he said. "See, everybody wants to spend money when they go to a mall, but they don't have to spend $90 for boots."
Another vendor who has moved around is Ms. Romeo, who lives on Staten Island, where friends make the sachets she has sold for a decade from a dreamily lighted pushcart. The display has been attractive enough to make people to look, but no more. "If everybody who sniffed my merchandise had given me a $1 it would have been a good season already," she said.
And the work can be vexatious. "People can get really nasty, and you have to be nice to them," said Lalou Assayag, 22, a singer and songwriter from Belgium who sells women's accessories at Grand Central.
But merchants could put up with crabby customers, if only they were buying. And that is what is not happening so far this season.
At the bus terminal Kimmy Wang, who immigrated from Beijing two years ago and who sells costume jewelry to support a husband conducting postdoctoral research in mathematics at Columbia University, said, "This business is no good."
Upstairs, Adnan Faruque, an immigrant from Bangladesh who turned to selling perfume from a pushcart after his photo store went bankrupt, said, "I'm very frustrated."
Ms. Penn of Ports of Call offered hope that things might improve in the final days of the season. "A last-minute shopper," she said, "won't go to a store and stand in line for an hour."
