HEADLINE: Chip Fight Persisting With Japan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The American and European share of the Japanese computer-chip market is continuing to fall, making it likely that the United States will seek special trade talks with Japan early next year, American officials said today.
Preliminary estimates suggest that non-Japanese makers, most of those American, had 18 to 19 percent of the Japanese chip market in the third quarter, the lowest level in a year, a senior Administration trade official said today. 
 The figures throw a harsh light on trade friction with Japan, which persists despite the new world trade accord completed in Geneva this week under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 
Provision for Consultations
 As a result of the continuing slide in foreign chip business, the United States is likely to invoke an "emergency consultations" provision of the 1991 Semiconductor Arrangement with Japan, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The United States will present specific proposals -- ways that Japan might open its computer chip market, but will not immediately raise the threat of sanctions, the official added.
The 1991 arrangement established a 20 percent goal of the Japanese market for foreign chip makers by the end of 1992. These companies reached 20.2 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, but the figure has since been falling. It was 19.6 percent in the first quarter of this year, and 19.2 percent in the second.
Third-quarter figures, scheduled for release next week, will probably fall between 18 and 19 percent, depending on a statistical review by Americans and Japanese here early in the week, the official said.
 
Another Foreign Policy Problem
 The figures present a political and diplomatic problem for the Clinton Administration, which wants to make more extensive use of numerical targets in trade agreements. It is seeking new agreements covering cars, car parts, insurance and government purchasing practices as part of a framework of negotiations set up during the summer in Tokyo. The framework calls for these agreements to be completed before Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa meets with President Clinton on Feb. 11.
Until now, no talks on computer chips had been scheduled other than routine meetings under the 1991 accord. But the American semiconductor industry is pushing for some sort of government action, and points out that American companies are gaining market share in the rest of the world. It argues that its share should not be falling in Japan "when it's headed up elsewhere in the world," as Andrew A. Procassini, president of the Semiconductor Industry Association in San Jose, Calif., put it.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said in the spring that to prove that the fourth quarter 1992 figures were not a fluke, Japan should assure that American chip companies maintain an average market share of 20 percent through all of 1993.
However, Seiichiro Noboru, the top economics official at the Japanese Embassy, said talk of special consultations should wait until after the market-share figures are tallied next week.
The GATT accord just reached in Geneva emphasized tariff cuts. It did nothing to improve Japanese-American trade relations because the two countries already have very low tariffs. For instance, each charges no tariff at all on the other's computer chips. The long-lasting dispute between them over American access to the Japanese market has instead focused on charges of collusive business relationships between chip producers and chip users in Japan.
The first indication that the United States might seek special talks came in a little-noticed speech on Thursday by Charlene Barshefsky, the deputy United States trade representative for Asia. Ms. Barshefsky said the talks would be sought, but the senior Administration official said today that she had spoken without obtaining a consensus among agencies. However, the consensus will probably be to seek the consultations, the official acknowledged.
Stan Anderson, the American trade lawyer who represents Japanese chip makers, said the current attention to market share overlooked that American sales of chips in Japan were rising in dollar terms.
But Daryl Hatano, a trade expert at the Semiconductor Industry Association, said the increase reflected the increased value of the yen. And Michael C. Maibach, director of government affairs at the Intel Corporation, said that chip sales were rising around the world but that the 1991 agreement focused on market-share figures.
The Administration of President Ronald Reagan requested special talks in 1987 under the 1986 U.S.-Japanese Semiconductor Arrangement, which was replaced by the 1991 version with many of the same provisions. The 1987 talks failed to satisfy Mr. Reagan and his officials, who imposed 100 percent taxes on Japanese color television sets and power tools.
These punitive taxes, which covered $300 million a year in imports, were gradually lifted over the succeeding years and disappeared with the 1991 pact. They remain the harshest trade sanctions the United States has imposed on Japan since the end of World War II.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Above 110 Yen But Is Lower Against Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar reached a five-month high against the Japanese yen yesterday, but it drifted against European currencies.
Gold prices also rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most active futures contract, gained $1.40, to $388.90 an ounce. 
 The dollar pushed through 110 yen, a technical level that has proved a formidable barrier in the past, without fanfare. It peaked at 110.20 yen, its highest rate since July 12.
"There were no fireworks when the dollar went through 110," said Randolph Donney, senior research director at Pegasus Econometric. He said there was little enthusiasm to drive the dollar much higher, since trading volume thins considerably as the end of the year approaches.
"It's like trying to get a football game together with only four players," he said.
Nevertheless, dealers said the breach of 110 yen boded well for further gains in the dollar.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 110.19 yen, up from 109.56 yen on Thursday.
Technical factors depressed the yen against the mark, which in turn helped the German currency post gains against the dollar, dealers said.
They said the dollar's moves were largely dictated by gyrations in other currencies. There was little reaction to news that housing starts rose an impressive 3.9 percent in November to an annualized rate of 1.432 million units.
The dollar fell to 1.7075 German marks in New York, from 1.7105 marks late Thursday.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4875, up from $1.4855 late Thursday.
The dollar did see some action against the Canadian dollar, which weakened after Standard & Poor's said that some Canadian provinces with negative outlooks could see their debt downgraded in the future.
The Bank of Canada reportedly bought Canadian dollars for United States dollars repeatedly to stem the slide. The dollar closed at $1.3405 (Canadian) in New York, up from $1.3330 (Canadian) on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Thursday's quotes, included: 1.4590 Swiss francs, down from 1.4604; 5.8360 French francs, down from 5.8415, and 1,685 Italian lire, down from 1,689.

HEADLINE: Rifkin Unable To Heed Rights, Expert Testifies

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 17

 BODY:
A psychologist who examined Joel Rifkin, the unemployed landscaper who has confessed to killing 17 women, said today that at the time of his arrest, Mr. Rifkin was "quite disturbed and incapable of understanding the Miranda warnings" that the state police read to him.
Dr. Naftali G. Berrill, a clinical psychologist at the New York Forensic Health Group in Brooklyn, said that Mr. Rifkin's judgment was "impaired" and his thinking "strained" on the morning of his arrest because he had not slept for three days and was suffering from depression. 
 He added that the fact that there was a dead body in Mr. Rifkin's house contributed to his deteriorating state. "The fact that there was a corpse in his house for three or four days made it so that his judgment was not quite clear," Dr. Berrill said at a pretrial hearing. Mr. Rifkin's lawyer is trying to have his confession and other evidence excluded from his pending murder trial.
Dr. Berrill, who said he offered his services to Mr. Rifkin's first lawyer, Robert Sale, after reading about the case in the newspaper, said he based his findings on school records, school psychologists' reports, and interviews with Mr. Rifkin, his mother, his sister, and two close friends, John Griselle and Christina Buffalino, Mr. Rifkin's ex-girlfriend.
The prosecutor, Fred Klein, challenged the documents on which Dr. Berrill based his testimony.
Producing them for the witness, Mr. Klein noted that the copies of the school records that were used by the psychologist were illegible, one lacked a letterhead, and that he had not pursued information about the psychologist Mr. Rifkin had seen when he was 17 and 18 years old.

LENGTH: 428 words

HEADLINE: Repeal the Pol Tax

 BODY:
A politician's favorite tax is one that spares the home folks; for example, taxing hotel rooms. The victims are out-of-towners. Supposedly. But when the tax is so high that out-of-towners stay away, as is the case with New York City's tax, the victims are the home folks -- jobless hotel workers and every store, restaurant and pinball palace that does less business when visitors don't visit.
The tax in New York City averages 21.25 percent. It is the world's highest hotel tax, a distinction that carries no honor. Gov. Mario Cuomo has the power to correct this -- the power of leadership. He should call for a reduction in the tax in his budget next month, rather than leaving it to the Legislature, as he did last year. 
 The 21.25 percent represents the effect of five state and city taxes on an average room: the 4 percent state sales tax, the city's 4.25 percent sales tax, a $2 per night city tax on rooms costing $40 or more, a 6 percent city occupancy tax and, finally, a 5 percent tax the State Legislature imposed in 1990 on rooms over $100. If that latest tax were repealed, the city would still have the highest hotel tax in America, but it would be only marginally higher than other major cities, and close enough to be competitive.
The 5 percent state tax yields $73 million a year, a flyspeck in a $32 billion budget. More significantly, the city's hoteliers say state revenue would increase if the tax were repealed, because the city would get more conventions. They calculate that spending for the business of the conventions themselves, plus shopping and recreational spending by those who attend, would yield substantially more in sales taxes than the $73 million from the hotel tax.
While New York hotels are jammed to overflowing right now, that's Christmas. On the convention front business has plunged, from 890 meetings in 1988 to 594 this year. Spending by the conventions and their delegates has shrunk from $1.7 billion to barely $1 billion, according to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. The recession probably hurt the most, but the high cost of bedding down surely mattered; convention arrangers notice taxes, more than tourists who don't hear about the tax until they check out.
 Mayor-elect Rudolph Giuliani has promised to continue Mayor David Dinkins's pressure for repeal. If the Legislature and the Governor approve, the hotels must do their part by passing the tax cut through to their customers. The tax is too high, but there would be no gain from repeal if room rates climbed when the tax came down.

HEADLINE: Nigerians Prefer Military Rule to Chaos

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In response to your report on the new military Government in Nigeria (news article, Dec. 2):
A major objective of the Nigerian state is to develop stable and lasting democratic structures. The country has gone through problems and difficulties necessitating several military interventions. 
 But at no time did we give up the pursuit of the democratic objective. None of the military governments intended to remain in power indefinitely. All saw themselves as corrective regimes determined to restore peace and stability, and to chart a new course for political and economic development, based on democracy and free enterprise.
Thus, although most Nigerians prefer democratic rule, they almost invariably welcome military interventions, which they see as better than allowing the country to slide into chaos, with unpredictable consequences.
The military, for its part, rules in full consultations with the general public, by nationwide debates and setting up elected institutions to chart a new political future. In addition, the military runs the country in cooperation with civilians.
In the present military government led by Gen. Sani Abacha, all but two members of the 33-man cabinet are accomplished and experienced politicians and administrators, contrary to your quoted allegation that they are "all brawn, no brains." By deciding to include in his Government pro-democracy activists and to call for a constitutional conference, General Abacha has demonstrated he does not intend to stay in power indefinitely.
Moreover, all Nigerian military governments respect human rights and due process. It is true that some people are detained from time to time, but only if they are involved in criminal offenses, such as organizing riots, in which many innocent people lose their lives or property. But even such criminals are released after some time. Nigerian military regimes have never deliberately engaged in brutalities, large-scale repression and murder of political opponents. Freedom of speech and expression is always allowed.
Like many other countries, Nigeria is encountering serious economic problems. In our case, these are accentuated by our economic recovery program. But the standard of living of our people has risen considerably since independence, with the provision of electricity, pipe-borne water, hospitals and secondary schools in the rural areas during the military regimes that we had in the 1970's and 80's.
 
ZUBAIR MAHMUD KAZAURE
Ambassador of Nigeria
Washington, Dec. 6, 1993

LENGTH: 3160 words

HEADLINE: ELLEN BAXTER

BYLINE: By DAVID C. ANDERSON; David C. Anderson writes about criminal justice, the homeless and other urban issues.

 BODY:
On a bright autumn morning, a crowd has gathered in front of one of New York City's most notorious places: the Fort Washington Armory, in upper Manhattan. In the worst years, on the coldest nights, as many as 1,200 homeless men would claim the cots set less than two feet apart on the cavernous drill floor. Crackheads, drunks, panhandlers, hustlers, muggers, burglars, sociopaths and psychopaths -- all were jammed in with runaway kids, the jobless and others down on their luck.
 But on this day, sparkling with promise, Mayor David N. Dinkins announces "a terrific proposal" for the armory. There won't be any more cots on the drill floor. Instead, it will be used once again for regional high-school track meets. A new tower above the armory will provide 200 low- and moderate-income apartments, youth and day-care centers, space for art programs and a community theater. 
 After a succession of city officials laud the redevelopment plan, a shy, diminutive woman with the Nordic features of a young Liv Ullmann approaches the microphone. She speaks for only a minute or two, nervously insisting to the assembled group, "This really happened because of you. This is your victory." But when she is done, the crowd of neighborhood leaders and residents erupts in cheers and applause. Over the years, people living near the Fort Washington Armory have learned to respect Ellen Baxter, who is perhaps the city's most accomplished not-for-profit entrepreneur.
To help the most distressed of the homeless population, Baxter has reinvented the single-room-occupancy (S.R.O.) residential hotels that once offered cheap lodgings to a collection of former mental hospital patients, aging pensioners and skid row bums. But unlike the old S.R.O. hotels despised by city planners as squalid warrens, Baxter's residences are well maintained and come with social service staffing.
Five of these "supported S.R.O.'s" now operate in Washington Heights, one of the city's more drug-ridden neighborhoods. Even with caseworkers on the premises five days a week, these residences are less expensive to operate than shelters like the Fort Washington Armory. A bed on the armory floor cost New York City more than $40 a night; a private room at one of Baxter's residences costs less than $20. This means that the $80 million or so that the city and state spend each year to provide minimal shelter for some 5,300 people could house thousands more in supported S.R.O.'s and also help many of them overcome the obstacles that caused their homelessness. Doing that for a few years might actually bring the problem of homelessness under control.
Although Baxter has insisted on integrating the most troubled homeless with everyone else, city officials have thus far resisted. They see the armory project as a way to relieve pressure on welfare hotels and shelters for homeless families and to increase the general supply of low- and middle-income apartments. People with "special needs," these officials contend, are incompatible with family life.
That disagreement aside, the Dinkins Administration did embrace the idea of turning major responsibility for the homeless over to nonprofit groups like the one headed by Baxter, the Committee for the Heights-Inwood Homeless. During the mayoral campaign Rudolph W. Giuliani, now the Mayor-elect, attacked the Dinkins Administration's overall approach to the homeless issue but also called for more supported housing.
Ellen Baxter's lesson reaches beyond New York City. The Corporation for Supportive Housing was established in 1991 in New York and now has $21 million in foundation grants. Its mandate: to jump-start supported housing for homeless people suffering from mental illness, addiction or AIDS. To date it has provided seed money and technical advice to nonprofit groups not only in New York but in Minneapolis, Chicago, Atlanta, the San Francisco Bay area and Connecticut.
WOMAN WHO FIERCELY guards her privacy, Ellen Baxter offers an interviewer only sketchy details of her personal life. She lives with Tony Hannigan, head of Columbia University Community Services, their 4-year-old son and her 14-year-old daughter. Last year, prompted by concern for the children's safety, they moved from New York City to Westchester. It was a painful decision, given Baxter and Hannigan's close ties to the Washington Heights neighborhood. "Our toddler would mimic the pop, pop, pop of gunshots and the sirens that followed." A police officer explained the shooting as a side effect of gun sales going on nearby, as customers test-fired their purchases.
The move has given Baxter the space for a flower garden, which she tends with care. Otherwise, she says, "we just try to lead a regular life." Weekends are devoted to catching up with her newspaper reading, going to movies and spending time with the kids.
Baxter's career as an entrepreneur began with a place called the Heights. Today it is one of the better-looking buildings on its block of West 178th Street -- the only one, certainly, with morning glory vines creeping from window boxes and up around the iron bars that protect the first-floor window.
The 55 residents of the Heights include the mentally ill, recovering substance abusers and those who for other reasons wound up on the streets. Their ages range from 24 to 74. Some will engage a visitor in animated conversation; others are painfully shy. Those with business on the outside -- medical appointments, classes, jobs -- come and go. Others prepare meals in the kitchens on each floor or gather for a staff-run bingo game in the common room off the entrance hall. A few keep to themselves in their rooms.
Though things seem peaceful enough, currents of tension rise and fall. From the day the place opened, in February 1986, Baxter and the social workers found themselves settling disputes over matters like the cleaning of the communal kitchens, thefts of food from the refrigerators, noisy neighbors, personality conflicts and gross neglect of personal hygiene.
These days Baxter spends less time at the Heights, as her other four residences in upper Manhattan also demand attention. (A total of 220 people live in her S.R.O.'s.) She spends the better part of her days maintaining contacts with neighborhood leaders and politicians, untangling bureaucratic red tape, fighting City Hall.
"Ellen looks like one of those quietly industrious women sewing in a shaft of sunlight in a Vermeer interior," says her friend Kim Hopper, a medical anthropologist. "But she has the instincts of a street fighter and the tenacity of a badger."
In the early 1980's Baxter and Hopper were working for the Community Service Society on a study of how the homeless survived in New York City. At the same time, Robert Hayes, a young corporate lawyer, was spending his spare time preparing to sue the city on behalf of homeless men. The three combined forces. Hayes finally forced the city to provide shelter on demand, but the victory turned sour as the city piled the homeless into shelters that offered neither privacy nor much control and that soon became nightmares of dirt, disease, danger and chaos.
In 1981, when the city suddenly turned the huge Fort Washington Armory into a shelter, Baxter mobilized her neighbors to support an alternative. If the razing of old S.R.O.'s by real-estate developers was one cause of the homeless problem, then a new kind of S.R.O. might offer a humane solution.
She sought help from Columbia University Community Services. (Created in the wake of the university's embarrassment over evicting people from old S.R.O.'s in Morningside Heights in order to build dormitories, the group is now known as the Center for Urban Community Services.) It brought together law, social work and architecture students to explore housing options for the homeless. They were put to work searching out possible sites and sponsors for a new S.R.O.
It took almost three years to open the Heights. Baxter's group, the Committee for the Heights-Inwood Homeless, was committed to developing a permanent residence. But a number of city officials, who still considered S.R.O.'s a disreputable form of housing however they were managed, opposed the idea.
Undeterred, Baxter obtained a list of vacant properties in the area from the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. With no previous experience in real estate, she revealed an unexpected aptitude for entrepreneurship. She learned how to assemble supporters in the community and make sure they got the proper credit. She learned the art of tactical compromise. And she learned that in prolonged battles with city bureaucrats the person who never ever took no for an answer might well prevail.
Hopper and Hayes lent their advice. The Community Service Society kept Baxter on its payroll and provided a financial adviser. But it was Baxter who systematically worked her way through a maze of housing regulations and funding options.
Did a deputy mayor appear nervous about the level of neighborhood support? She worked the phone to produce letters of support from ministers, civic groups, a city councilman. Were prospective lenders interested but reluctant to take the plunge? She called and cajoled, keeping everyone aboard until someone finally made a commitment. Did a housing bureaucrat question whether the project qualified for city funds? She assembled legal opinions and found a state official to turn the obstructor around. Did a neighborhood group threaten opposition? She found the leaders, met with them and followed up with letters politely but forcefully refuting their objections.
In the meantime Baxter took a step that would be crucial to the eventual success of the Heights. She rented an apartment on West 174th Street to serve as a drop-in center. It offered the homeless a place to shower, pick up clean clothes, store belongings and get a meal. Two caseworkers were on hand as well. The homeless who began to appear were offered help finding treatment for drug or alcohol abuse, medical or psychiatric care, education and job training. With an address to receive a check in the mail, they could apply for benefits.
Baxter organized outreach teams to bring in would-be tenants for the new S.R.O. They found Jack Langford living at the end of a subway platform, with swollen, lacerated legs. He was persuaded to go to the hospital, where he was laid up for about two months. At first he was silent, but before long "he became very sociable," Baxter recalls. "So then all the people from the apartment started to go visit Jack at the hospital because it was something to do." When he was discharged, he refused to consider city shelters. So he was given a spare room at the 174th Street apartment. Today, Langford -- a painfully thin man who walks with the deliberate grace of a wading bird -- lives at the Heights in a room whose walls he has covered with magazine and newspaper fashion spreads.
In early 1986 all the pieces of the new S.R.O. came together: a building located on West 178th Street; a $1.2 million package of state, city and private money to acquire the place and create 55 single rooms with a kitchen and three bathrooms on each floor; a commitment from Columbia University Community Services to provide a resident social work staff; and a relatively cohesive group of people ready to move in. In February 1986 the new residence opened as the first S.R.O. in New York for single homeless people. Given a sense of place, safety and privacy, residents of the Heights could focus on the rest of their lives.
Baxter found that a supported S.R.O. permitted certain economies of scale. Accommodating several hundred homeless people in a huge hall requires legions of managers and guards -- who cost plenty even though they never seem to maintain order or security. In a supported S.R.O., each resident has a private room, social workers head off potential conflicts, and the more functional tenants are asked to work at the reception desk or patrol the corridors.
An S.R.O. can also take advantage of state and Federal revenues. Nearly every homeless person on the street qualifies for some kind of entitlement, from the city and state's home-relief allowance of $215 a month to more than $1,000 a month from the Federal Government for a disabled veteran. (The transient nature of living in a city shelter makes it difficult to capture much of this revenue.) At Baxter's S.R.O.'s, 30 percent of a resident's benefits or income goes to rent. In addition, such residences qualify for Federal housing funds that make up the difference between a tenant's contribution and market rent.
 UNTIL THE COURTS forced the city to limit the number of people it could send to the Fort Washington Armory, the shelter was a stark reminder of official policy failure every night of the year, as bus loads of the homeless arrived from downtown intake centers. Beyond the spiritual degradation, concentrating people at risk for AIDS and tuberculosis in a confined space of dirt, drug abuse and violence created a public-health horror show.
"The mattresses were all urinated on; they had bedbugs," recalls Carlos Pabon, a Heights resident who spent one night at the armory and never went back. "There were fights over cigarettes, fights over towels, clothes. Somebody might look at somebody else a little too hard and before you knew it there was a fight." Everyone worried about their sneakers or shoes. "What most guys would do is to lift up the bed and put one sneaker under each leg. So if somebody wanted your sneakers, they would have to lift the bed and you would wake up."
For Baxter the armory became the symbol of everything wrong with homeless policy -- the antithesis of what she had learned at a place called Geel (pronounced hail).
The Belgian village of Geel is home to the shrine of St. Dympna, patron saint of the mentally ill. Its residents have taken in mental patients as boarders since the late Middle Ages, and the town has evolved into a long-term experiment in community mental health care unique in the world. In 1975 Geel's population was 30,000, with some 1,000 families boarding 1,100 mental patients in their homes. That summer, a Geelian family also took in Ellen Baxter.
She was 21 years old and had just graduated from Bowdoin College in Maine. A psychology major, she had become interested in the movement against institutionalizing the mentally ill. During her sophomore year, she persuaded a psychiatrist to commit her to Augusta State Hospital, where she feigned symptoms for a week in order to experience institutional life. She found the treatment of inmates barbaric but left for another reason. "It bothered me that I was getting friendly with the other patients," she says. She didn't want to go on deceiving them.
In the course of her studies, she came across an article about Geel in The American Journal of Psychiatry. Baxter speaks Dutch, having attended high school in The Netherlands. (Her father, an engineer for an international firm, had moved his family around the world.) When she won a fellowship for a year of postgraduate study anywhere she chose, she headed for Geel.
The Geelians, she found, had no trouble accepting the occasionally bizarre behavior of their guests. "Some boarders really had remarkably deviant behavior, like screaming loudly, nonstop," she recalls. "Why didn't they consider offering the person some medication that would help control that?" The family would explain, "Well, we really don't believe in that. We're used to him. He's always been that way."
The average length of stay in Geel for a boarder with a host, Baxter found, was 23 years. The government had built a psychiatric hospital in town, but it was only for crises. Hosts were expected to make boarders part of their households, often trusting them to run errands and help care for the children.
Geel radicalized Baxter on the issue of care for the mentally ill. She had seen how easily a community could accept mental patients who were not violent or deeply depressed. Granting them basic dignity and a place in daily life left both the patients and the community better off.
SOMEWHAT GRUDGINGLY, the city began to recognize Baxter's pioneering efforts at the Heights. By 1987 the Mayor's office made capital financing available for supported S.R.O.'s. Baxter opened four more residences. The newest and largest is an apartment house called the Rio, whose facade gracefully follows the curve of Fort Washington Avenue as it merges into Broadway. Opened in late 1991, it has 82 units and its penthouse serves as Baxter's headquarters.
Others also took notice. In 1990 New York State signed an agreement with City Hall to cooperate in the financing and development of more supported S.R.O.'s. A judge ruling in a class action suit ordered city hospitals to stop discharging mental patients to the streets and instead insure that they find "stable housing with available supportive services."
Word spread to Washington. Aides to Jack F. Kemp, then Housing Secretary, came to New York to look at S.R.O.'s and were impressed by their economy and efficiency. A Federal Task Force on Homelessness and Severe Mental Illness also called for more supported S.R.O. housing.
The Clinton Administration promises active support. Henry G. Cisneros, the new Housing Secretary, considers homelessness his first priority. Soon after taking office, he drafted Andrew M. Cuomo as his Assistant Secretary for Community Development; Cuomo had written a report for Mayor Dinkins that emphasized principles similar to those guiding Baxter's work. But Cisneros has been bedeviled by bureaucratic impediments.
"We'll spend hours talking through a strategy for meeting all the objections to move our homeless initiative through the Office of Management and Budget and Congressional committees," he said recently. "Meanwhile it's dusk and people are starting to bed down for the night -- for one more night in the park outside the window."
What sustains Baxter in the face of similar frustrations?
To anyone who has spent time with her, the answer is clear. It lies in her sense of the homeless as unique individuals -- the Jack Langfords and the Stella Levines.
Asked why she named her second residence the Stella, Baxter recalls the middle-aged heroin addict she found sleeping in a bus terminal restroom. Levine would become one of the founding tenants of the Heights, living there until her death, from cancer, in 1987. Thin and barely five feet tall, she dressed in flashy colors, heavy jewelry and makeup. She was a friendly, generous soul, often bringing to her housemates gifts of objects she had picked up on the street. When angered, she could curse like a Marine.
"Although she continued to have her problems with drug abuse," Baxter says, "Stella was a survivor." She had a spirit that deserved to be honored, a name that deserved to live on.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 64; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Out Man in a Mig

BYLINE: By Peter Passell; Peter Passell writes about economics and other subjects for The New York Times.

 BODY:
MY FIRST LOOK AT POST-SOVIET AVIation was not confidence-building. From the rusting outhouse to the old planes lining the Tarmac in various stages of cannibalization, the little airfield some 100 miles west of Moscow might have been home to a fly-by-night crop-duster in a 1940's B movie.
Why, then, am I -- the sort who buckles his seat belt to move the car in the driveway -- perched on a bench in the tumbledown flight-operations center, struggling to memorize the three ways to trigger a VS-1-BRI rocket-assisted aircraft ejection seat? 
 It all started with an advertisement in a half-dozen newspapers known to be read by large numbers of 25- to-59-year-old males with considerable discretionary income. "Fly a MIG-29 at Mach 2.5 in Moscow (no, really)," it teased. And like several hundred other latter-day Walter Mittys, I phoned the advertiser, a company called MIGS Etc., in Sarasota, Fla.
Yes, really, insisted Kent Ertugrul, a former software entrepreneur and partner in MIGS Etc. Rides in the MIG-25, MIG-29, MIG-31 and Sukhoi-27 -- collectively the pride of the Soviet military-industrial complex -- were indeed available, starting at $9,945 plus air fare to Moscow. No, the Russian Air Force had not been privatized by peaceniks who decided to skip the plowshare stage and go straight to the theme park. The handful of Russian state enterprises that designed and tested high-performance aircraft, Ertugrul explained, were feeling underappreciated in the new world order and thus eager to show off their wares to opinion makers and potential customers. Anyone in reasonable health with $9,945 to spend fit the profile.
A few days later I was struggling into a helmet and an oxygen mask, wondering why I hadn't managed to come up with a tamer way to work through midlife crisis.
In fact, the preflight jitters soon evaporated. My cheerful pilot, Arkady, a former air force instructor, radiated competence. And one glance at the Czech-made L-39 subsonic-jet trainer, a savory before the main-course MIG, instantly transformed me into an aerospace groupie. The needle-nosed little plane, with its compact, rakish wings, pressurized cockpit and green camouflage paint, looked ready to boogie.
It was. Moments after the starter-motor whine of the engine turned to a gentle roar, the L-39 was in the air and punching through the clouds. Arkady leveled off at 15,000 feet and spent a few minutes demonstrating how the stick tilted the plane left and right, up and down. Then, stretching his knowledge of English to the limit, he ordered me to "take controls."
Believe it or not (I don't), I did. And was it fun! Or as Sarah MacT. Davidson, a 32-year-old New York investment banker and the other satisfied MIGS Etc. customer that day, later put it: "Was it as good for you as it was for me?"
The L-39 responded instantly to a nudge, swooping like a hawk in the winter sunshine. There was no sound but the authoritative growl of the engine occasionally changing pitch as the pilot throttled forward and back to keep me out of trouble.
Now it was time for Arkady to show what the plane could really do: a shallow dive to build speed to 400 miles an hour, then a steep climb until the plane was on its back and once again plummeting toward the snow-covered fields below. The G (gravity) meter registered 4 at the max, sufficient to paralyze my extremities with a crushing but curiously benign weight. Next a slow 360-degree roll to the left followed by one to the right, a maneuver I had been dreading on behalf of my inner ear. The rotation of the horizon was indeed disorienting but not in the least sickening -- courtesy of the Dramamine taken as a prophylactic or perhaps the natural endorphins left over from my interlude as a bird of prey.
Back to Earth for a cup of tea, a tuna salad sub and sign language chatter with the Russian flight instructors, who did not conceal their delight in our delight. In the helicopter returning to Moscow, the iron-gray sky seemed friendlier, the dead November farmland almost inviting. Could the MIG be anything but anticlimax?
In a word: yes.
The plane I wanted and expected to fly was the one I'd heard most about: the supersonic MIG-29, an incredibly maneuverable twin-engine fighter designed to go missile-to-missile with the American F-16. But this is the New Russia, where everything is possible and nothing is certain. One of the two MIG-29's stationed at the Zhukovsky aircraft test center, 30 miles south of Moscow, was on the way to the Dubai Air Show; the other was in the shop. So the Test Pilot Institute, which shares the Zhukovsky center with the elite Mikoyan, Sukhoi and Tupelov aircraft design bureaus, rolled out something equally exotic on short notice: a MIG-25 (NATO code-named Foxbat).
Before being permitted to fly, Sarah Davidson and I endured exhausting (if not exhaustive) medical exams followed by a four-course meal in the private dining room where Politburo biggies must have been feted before viewing the latest machines of mayhem (we nibbled on the rolls). That left maddeningly little daylight for thrills and chills. But a little proved a lot.
The MIG-25 is a plane unlike any other, a long-range, ultrahigh-altitude interceptor whose steel, titanium and aluminum body is at once crudely menacing and muscularly beautiful. Oversize rectangular air-intakes feed two turbojets capable of 48,000 pounds of thrust -- more power than a 100-passenger Boeing-737 and sufficient to push the MIG-25 past 1,800 miles an hour. Pilot and passenger sit above the heat-scorched snout, isolated from the beast's business parts.
I snuggle into a streamlined glass aerie normally reserved for the cameraman on reconnaissance missions. Trussed tight to the ejection seat, lifelines attached for oxygen, radio and inflatable anti-G suit, we taxi ponderously to the end of the 20,000-foot runway. Yevgeny, the pilot, pushes the throttles to 100 percent with the brakes locked, shouts "O.K., Pee-tur?" in the intercom and lets it rip.
My high-tech steed explodes forward on the supercharged power of its afterburners, trailing cones of blue-white fire. Up, up we climb at a 45-degree angle, the altimeter registering another 1,000 meters every few seconds. The MIG passes the speed of sound without a shiver, eventually leveling off at 60,000 feet. I am safe, serene in a quiet bubble, hurtling 1,500 miles an hour at the edge of space. Only the 200-degree heat of the glass canopy (which I have been warned not to touch) offers a clue to the rage of the elements clawing to get in.
Yevgeny gives me a few minutes to contemplate the black sky above and the ocean of beige clouds 10 miles below. A sunset, with perfect spectral bands from red to green to blue, highlights the curvature of the Earth. Then he tilts into a wrenching supersonic arc to the right; the Foxbat shudders for the first and only time as he adjusts the controls, gradually descending and slowing the plane to 500 miles an hour.
We skim the surface of the clouds, feathery wisps whipping by at unimaginable speed. Now the unexpected snap of a roll that barely takes more than an instant; now another and another. Yevgeny dives through the mist and buzzes the landing strip at 200 feet before accelerating into a hard, climbing turn on afterburner.
We circle the field and touch down with a delicate kiss to the concrete. Elapsed flying time: 36 minutes -- long enough to burn 2,500 gallons of kerosene, specially modified for high-altitude flight. I am poised between euphoria and post-adventure tristesse.
Is less than an hour in a MIG worth the $10,000-plus price? Is 1945 Chateau Latour worth $50 a sip? It is a matter of taste -- and, of course, how hard the money might be to come by.
For Sarah Davidson, who has been in love with fast airplanes since she was a teen-ager and eager to be the first non-Russian woman to fly a MIG, the calculus was easy. Most of MIGS Etc.'s clients fit the same mold: young professionals in search of adventure. But would-be jet jockeys are everywhere: Ertugrul reports that one of his next customers is a French parking lot attendant who has borrowed the cash deposit.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Visits to Peru Rebound As Obstacles Fade

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: LIMA, Per

 BODY:
STARTING in 1988, three scourges of a happy vacation cholera, hyperinflation and terrorist violence -- kept tourists away from Peru. But recently and without great fanfare, cholera and inflation have come under control and guerrilla violence has waned. Today, visitors are beginning to venture back to the land of the Incas.
For the first time in five years, foreign arrivals are up in Peru. Since April, 150,000 foreign visitors have come here -- a 36 percent rise over the same period last year.
Tourism's resurgence in Peru is most noticeable in Cuzco, where the number of foreigners buying tour packages increased this summer by 50 percent, to 9,500, according to the National Chamber of Tourism, a Lima-based organization. Betting on a long-term recovery, Lima's largest hotel, El Libertador, is doubling its capacity to 250 rooms. 
 "My business is up 70 percent this year," said Alfredo Ferreyros Gildemeister, president of Explorandes, a Lima travel agency with a largely foreign clientele.
Europeans and Latin Americans account for most of the new visitors. Americans still shy away, in part because of stark warnings by the United States Government. Issued in May, the latest State Department travel advisory begins: "U.S. citizens are warned against travel to Peru until further notice. With the exception of certain tourist areas, terrorist violence continues to affect a large part of the country."
Adding exclamation points to the travel advisory, guerrillas in late October exploded bombs at Lima's airport and at a Lima hotel. No tourists were wounded. But Peruvians, and many foreigners, increasingly say they are convinced that tourism will rebound strongly in the late 1990's. The World Bank is preparing a $35 million loan to rehabilitate the railroad from Cuzco to Machu Picchu. South Korea's Government is financing an $18 million renovation of Cuzco's airport.
By the end of next year, Peru's free-market Government plans to have sold all its state-owned hotels. Sprinkled over 39 towns and cities, the hotels are attracting inquiries from foreign investors, according to Alonso Rey, a lawyer who is directing the privatization program. An "open skies" airline deregulation program has already prompted a doubling in domestic air traffic in five years, he said. Pushing down air fares and extending scheduled service to 23 cities, the number of private airlines had increased from two in 1988 to eight today. Thanks to deregulation, foreign visitors can now skip Lima and enter Peru through the back door -- Cuzco, an Andean city reknown for its charming mix of colonial churches and Inca ruins. Tourists may want to avoid Lima, a grimy, overpopulated city that endures roughly half the terrorist incidents in the country.
For Andean tourists, Aeroperu inaugurated two weekly flights in October among La Paz, Bolivia and Cuzco.

HEADLINE: In Glenn Close, 'Sunset Boulevard' Finds Its Megastar

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
ONE THING WAS PERfectly clear the other night in Los Angeles, at least inside the Shubert Theater.
When the curtain came down on the last preview performance of "Sunset Boulevard," Andrew Lloyd Webber's elaborate, neo-Gothic musical adaptation of Billy Wilder's classic 1950 film, Glenn Close had suddenly become a big, exciting new star of the American musical theater of the 1990's. 
 It's not as if Ms. Close were unknown on the stage. She's a two-time Tony Award winner (for "The Real Thing" and "Death and the Maiden") and received warm reviews for her work in the 1980 Broadway musical "Barnum." "Sunset Boulevard" is something else. Her performance catapults her into the sphere of megastars. As the show serves her with material that effects a career transformation, she serves the show. Though not quite single-handedly, she takes the role of Norma Desmond, the demonic, reclusive silent-film queen whom Gloria Swanson made so dauntingly memorable, and fiercely shapes it into her own unexpected image.
This isn't a Glenn Close you have ever seen in movies. There have been hints of her reserves of power in "Dangerous Liaisons," "Reversal of Fortune" and even in "Fatal Attraction." Yet nothing she has done comes near the commanding figure she creates in this new Lloyd Webber extravaganza, which, with Patti LuPone as Norma Desmond, opened in July in London to mixed reviews.
Ms. Close's performance is ravishing. Her looks astonish -- the high cheekbones, the Rooseveltian jaw, the eyes staring out from the pale face beneath a thick layer of mascara. She somehow manages to suggest Lon Chaney's silent-screen Phantom of the Opera, and even the one in Mr. Lloyd Webber's long-running Broadway chestnut, without sacrificing either her beauty or her intelligence as an actress. She is no belter in the manner of Ms. LuPone. Yet her singing voice is lovely and strong, the phrasing capturing Norma's merciless determination and self-serving wit. If the lyrics tend to blur in moments of high melodrama, it's more because of the vagaries of stage mikes and the uncertain science of sound amplification in today's musical theater. Say this for Ms. Close: Her diction is far better than Joan Sutherland's.
Most important, the actress inhabits every square inch of the Shubert's immense stage with mesmerizing authority. She wears the space with the same elegant self-assurance with which she wears her succession of extraordinary outside-of-time Anthony Powell costumes. It's as if, like Norma Desmond, she knows that the rest of the world exists only as "all those wonderful people out there in the dark," that is, as an audience whose sole function is to attend her with adoration.
Ms. Close's triumph seems certain to complicate the question of who'll be playing Norma if the $10 million show comes to Broadway next fall. Though Ms. LuPone is under contract to play the role in New York, there's bound to be pressure now to bring in the star of the Los Angeles company.

 Mr. Lloyd Webber's "Sunset Boulevard" is not Billy Wilder's, though Trevor Nunn, the director, and Don Black and Christopher Hampton, who wrote the book and lyrics, appear to have adapted the film with something like abject fidelity. In fact, Mr. Lloyd Webber and his associates have subtly (some will say unforgivably) shifted the emphasis in transferring the film to the big stage.
What was once an evilly skeptical, bitter melodramatic comedy about Hollywood's self-infatuation has been turned into something quite other. This "Sunset Boulevard" is not a tragedy, though it ends badly. It's a melodramatic romance that buys the old fan magazine nonsense about how much great stars suffer to brighten the lives of us little people.
The real shocker is that with Ms. Close as Norma Desmond it works.
I'm aware that Mr. Wilder, who has seen the musical twice, has been quoted as saying that he loves the stage production but thinks the collaborators could have profited by being less reverent toward his work. To the extent that Mr. Lloyd Webber and company recreate the film virtually scene by scene, sometimes famous line by famous line, Mr. Wilder is right.
The show's first image, which is a stunner, comes directly from the film. The audience, as if huddled on the bottom of Norma Desmond's swimming pool, stares up at the body of Joe Gillis (Alan Campbell) floating face down on the pool's surface. With three bullets in him, Joe is quite dead but, out-of-work B-picture writer that he is, he won't shut up.
With Joe supplying the narration, there follows a frenzied succession of sequences, full of split-second scenery changes and numbing Lloyd Webber recitative (often in doggerel), that do with great labor what movies do effortlessly. They set up the time (1950), the place (Hollywood) and the initial circumstances that put Joe and Norma onto a course of fatal collision, much in the manner laid out in the screenplay by Mr. Wilder and his partner, Charles Brackett.
Yet Mr. Lloyd Webber and his collaborators veer off in their own direction after the first meeting of Norma and Joe. This is a scathingly funny sequence, and the only time when the romantic aims of Mr. Lloyd Webber and the satiric ones of Mr. Wilder coincide: Joe, being chased by repo men who are after his car, has turned into a Sunset Boulevard driveway. Having hidden his car in what he later learns is the Desmond garage, he finds himself mistaken for the undertaker who has been summoned to bury Norma's pet chimpanzee.
THE SCENE TAKES PLACE IN the centerpiece of John Napier's eye-popping production design, the cavernous drawing room of Norma's old Sunset Boulevard mansion. Almost as high as the nave of Notre Dame de Paris, the drawing room suggests the main lobby of the old Roxy Theater, being all tarnished gilt with plaster pillars that are vaguely Aztec and a little bit Sumerian but mostly 1920's picture-palace Renaissance. There are also a tile floor ("Valentino said tile is for tango," Norma tells Joe later on), a pipe organ, a massive sofa and a grand stairway that curves upward toward the loges. The only thing missing is a drinking fountain and a glass tube of Dixie cups.
As Joe looks on in awe, the imperious Norma stands by the makeshift bier, mourning her dead ape in a sweetly simple Lloyd Webber melody, with lyrics that are passionately inappropriate. The song is called "Surrender" and, in this time and place, it's both a howl and crazily affecting. Norma sings of the trials of life (the chimp's and of hers) in terms of wars, of battlefields, of tracer bullets lighting up the sky, and of the peace that comes only with surrender. She sings that she won't see her beloved again until she surrenders, which is something she has no intention of doing any time soon.
Mastering her grief, she sizes up the handsome, needy young Joe and hires him to work on her script about Salome, which is to be her return to the screen. For the money she's paying, she also expects him to share her bed. Joe becomes restive only when he doesn't see any money. Instead, Norma showers him with expensive clothes, champagne, caviar and a gold cigarette case. Though rich and slightly mad, Norma is a tightwad, one of the reasons she has held onto her money over the years.

 Yet Mr. Lloyd Webber's "Sunset Boulevard" doesn't simply pity Norma, as Mr. Wilder's does, it also salutes her crazy grandeur. It recognizes that in 1950, Norma, at age 50, would be only 20-some years past her peak. As Joe tells Norma, "There's nothing wrong with being 50, unless you are acting 20." But in the silent-film era in which Norma is locked, youth is all.
The musical also recognizes that the technological divide between silent and sound films has marooned her, left her isolated on the far side of a metaphorical Grand Canyon. Mr. Lloyd Webber agrees when first Norma, and later Max von Mayerling (George Hearn), her butler, former director and ex-husband, sing that they gave the world "new ways to dream."
Mr. Wilder's "Sunset Boulevard" doesn't sentimentalize Norma Desmond. It seems to understand (without saying so) that it was Edison, among others, who gave the world new ways to dream. The Norma Desmonds, Mary Pickfords and Gloria Swansons were just the figures with which those dreams were illustrated, at no great hardship to themselves, for enormous fame and large pots of money.
But over and over again Mr. Lloyd Webber's "Sunset Boulevard" salutes Norma's mad courage and her delusions. Her cuckoo dreams are encouraged. And in numbers such as "Surrender," "With One Look" and "The Greatest Star of All," he makes a convincing case for his romantic view of human nature and movie history.
Mr. Lloyd Webber's score is a good one, though the handful of songs is so shamelessly reprised you suspect it might be the music that's pushing Norma over the edge, not Fate, and not the feckless Joe's clandestine pursuit of someone else. Possibly nothing in the score is as witty as Mr. Lloyd Webber's melodic doomy overture. It, too, is repeated in one form and another throughout the rest of the show.
The overture evokes every movie score, great and schmaltzy, ever written by those exotically named screen composers of my youth: Miklos Rozsa, Bronislau Kaper, Erich Wolfgang Korngold, Max Steiner, and Franz Waxman, the man who actually wrote the music for the Wilder film, though it sounds nothing like Mr. Lloyd Webber's.
Mr. Hearn sings beautifully while giving a wonderful interpretation of Erich von Stroheim's screen performance as Max von Mayerling. All the other voices are first-rate, including Mr. Campbell's, but the actor seems a very lightweight Joe Gillis. Unlike William Holden, who played Joe in the film, Mr. Campbell looks like a juvenile out of a musical of the 40's or 50's, someone without any concept of the terrors of economic desperation or, for that matter, of the joys of sleazy opportunism. The time devoted to Joe's relationship with Betty Schaefer (Judy Kuhn), the pretty, sweet, utterly vacuous script reader, is time wasted. So is almost every scene set outside Norma's mansion, away from Ms. Close.
The show's coup de theatre occurs as Mr. Napier effectively splits the stage in two, horizontally, when Joe abandons Norma on New Year's Eve to go to a party given by his impoverished peers. At that moment, the entire Sunset mansion set, still containing a hysterical, champagne-swilling Norma and her faithful Max, magically levitates to reveal, below, the cramped little apartment containing Joe's heedless merrymaking peers. You're allowed to say "Wow!"
Will "Sunset Boulevard" become a Lloyd Webber super-hit on the order of his "Phantom of the Opera"? As someone who could barely sit through "Phantom," and who, when the chandelier softly plummeted, felt cheated (no blood or mangled tiaras in sight), I would say that "Sunset Boulevard" delivers almost everything it promises. It has class.
Yet to achieve the kind of longevity enjoyed by "Phantom" and "Cats," "Sunset Boulevard" must be perceived as a family show, which it definitely isn't. It's going to be a hard matinee sell for toddlers and all other pre-adolescents.
'My Fair Lady'
Toddlers and pre-adolescents were much in evidence at the Sunday matinee I caught of the sleepy, newish revival of "My Fair Lady," directed by Howard Davies, of the Royal National Theater in London. The children spent much of their time running up and down the aisles of the Virginia Theater, where the musical, having been on the road for nearly eight months, is now catching 40 winks. Should the youngsters have accidentally looked at the stage at any point, their innocence was safe: Shaw's subversive wit is still effectively disguised in the glorious Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe work.
This is a touring show and looks it. It's rather small and efficient, in spite of a scenic design "based on original designs by Ralph Koltai," with the assistance of Mr. Davies and (unbilled) of Heidi Landesman. Their collaborative touch is most evident in the rather surreal Ascot scene in which the Ascot crowd descends on individual swings from above. The image is handsome but spare.
Another odd touch in the otherwise plain production: Henry Higgins's laboratory, featuring a lot of Dr. Frankenstein-like test tubes and other glassware, plus a giant model of a human head, the brain and the vocal organs outlined in neon. The point seems to be that, like Frankenstein, linguist Higgins is challenging God in making a new woman of Eliza Doolittle. Oh, please.
RICHARD CHAMBERLAIN GIVES a reasonable facsimile of Rex Harrison's unbeatable performance as Higgins, while seeming to remain detached from everyone around him. Melissa Errico has a lovely voice, a pretty-doll face and little stage presence. The reliable Paxton Whitehead plays Colonel Pickering, Julian Holloway (Stanley's son) plays Alfred P. Doolittle, and Robert Sella is Freddie Eynsford-Hill, the penniless twit who courts Eliza.
There's nothing terribly wrong with the production, and nothing surprisingly right. It lacks urgency and, in its Henry Higgins and Eliza Doolittle, heart.
In his chatty afterword to "Pygmalion," the source of the musical, Shaw says that following the play's end, Eliza should marry not Higgins but foolish Freddie. This may be the only production of "My Fair Lady" to convince you that Shaw was right.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN TOKYO

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER; DAVID E. SANGER is head of the Tokyo bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
If Asia has a capital city, Tokyo is it. From the air and even from the highway, it may look like an unrelieved ode to urban gray, but at ground level it is one of the most bustling and international cities in the Far East, and in some ways the most deceiving. The apparent Western air -- the glitzy boutiques in the Ginza, the English-language signs everywhere -- leads many visitors to the quick conclusion that this is a familiar place, albeit one so sprawling that getting around is a bit intimidating. In fact, getting around is a cinch, with an outstanding subway and train system. The hard part is sorting out the two Tokyos -- the caffeine-charged city of all-day business and all-night drinking, and quiet neighborhoods where old men in their yukata robes and geta, or clunky wooden sandals, make their way back home from the public baths.
Most visitors spend their time in the high-tech and Western Tokyo, from the electronics shops of the Akihabara district, stocked with goods that have yet to hit America, to the coffee shops filled with young people who seem to feel equally at home in New York, Honolulu or the Ginza. But it is still worth searching for the tiny enclaves of the second city. That is where the few remaining geisha alight from rickshaws and head for the ryotei, or private restaurants of the wealthy and powerful, and you are left standing in wonder at the hidden life. 
 The latter Tokyo, the Tokyo from the wonderful lithographs of the city as Westerners first discovered it 130 years ago, gets harder to find every year. There are far fewer women in kimono on the subways than just five years ago; the old wooden houses in many neighborhoods are falling to wrecking balls, in favor of Western comforts. But if you are willing to wander, particularly in the out-of-the-way neighborhoods that seem to live independently of much of the city, the remnants of Edo are still there to sample.
Unfortunately, never before has the prospect of visiting Tokyo seemed so financially daunting as it does these days. Since the spring, the dollar has hovered at record-weak levels, around 105 to 107 yen to the dollar, making the normally outrageous expense of visiting the city even worse.
But there is hope. The surprisingly severe economic downturn in Tokyo has not cast many people into the street, but it has resulted some bargains -- discounts at major stores, better prices on set-course meals at restaurants.
The usual rules apply: Eat what the Japanese eat, stay out of hotel shops and restaurants, be willing to get lost.
You will never be far from a subway entrance, and there is no safer city in the world. And the best part of Tokyo, the life on the streets and the temple grounds, is free.
 
Events
 The New Year's holiday, one of the most magical periods to be in Tokyo, offers a tremendous variety of special events. On Dec. 23, the Emperor's birthday, and again on Jan. 2, the public is allowed into the grounds of the Imperial Palace; the rest of the year only the gardens are open. The royal family greets everyone, from a distance of course, from 9:30 A.M. to 11 A.M. On Dec. 27 to 29 there is a year-end fair, called Toshi-no-Ichi, at Yagenbori Fudoson Temple right near Higashi-Nihonbashi Station, and another on Dec. 28 at Meguro Fudoson Temple, near Meguro Station. Those fairs have everything from food to stalls selling old wares; they are usually open until late at night, when the trains stop.
"Omisoka," or New Year's Eve, the whole city heads out to neighborhood temples, to hear 108 peals of the temple bell at midnight. One of the best celebrations, full of smiling Buddhist priests and great food stalls and sake, is at Zojoji Temple; go to Onarimon, Shiba-Koen or Daimon Stations, and follow the crowds. Other famous celebrations are at Gokokuji Temple by the subway station of the same name, and at Sensoji near Asakusa, but even a small neighborhood temple will be full of charm, as residents build bonfires and bring their pets to be blessed.
On the days just after New Year's, many Tokyo residents -- foreigners and Japanese alike -- take an annual trek to "Shitamachi," literally the "low city," the center of Tokyo life until a century and a half ago. It is on the far side of the river from Asakusa, and the neighborhood is littered with small temples that each have a long connection in the history and mythology of the area.
At each temple, you purchase, for about $4 each, seven minature "lucky gods," made of pottery. Some are gods of health, some are gods of happiness and many are gods of wealth.
During the year you place them on a small model boat intended to carry you with good luck through the new year.
Start by crossing the big bridge at Asakusa over the Sumida River, turn left under the highway and then right around the huge building with the giant radish sculpture on top, and follow the crowds to Mimeguri Jinja, or shrine.
There are a few posted maps of the route to the rest of the temples. The whole walk takes about two and a half hours, maybe a bit longer if you dawdle over a hot bowl of noodles along the way, and winds through a charming neighborhood of Tokyo that most tourists never visit.
 
Where to Stay
 The boxy but efficient Shiba Park Hotel, phone 3433-4141, fax 5470-7519, has a wonderful location near the Daimon subway stop and Shiba Koen, one of the nicer parks in downtown. Units in the 400-room hotel run about $220 and up for two.
In a similar price range, the Takanawa Prince Hotel, built on the site of the home of a former member of the imperial family; it shares a wonderful Japanese garden with the New Takanawa Prince next door, a modern, 946-room hotel popular among tour groups. It is in the southern part of the city near Shinagawa Station; phone 3447-1111, fax 3446-0849.
The Fairmont Hotel, phone 3262-1151, fax 3256-2476, is right on the edge of the moat of the Imperial Palace, a great place for jogging enthusiasts. It has 208 rooms, which start at about $190 for two.
Budget: The Y.M.C.A., in Mitoshiro-cho, phone 3293-1911, fax 3293-1926, has 40 small but new rooms; twins start at $180. And the location is excellent, surrounded by good book shops and noodle joints.
Right in the middle of the Ginza is Hotel Atamiso, 4-14-3 Ginza, phone 3541-3621, fax 3541-3263, with 76 rooms. The nicer are the tatami rooms with futons rather than beds, starting at $150. A twin-bedded room for two begins at $185.
Luxury: At the famed 875-room Okura Hotel, scene of trade negotiations and economic summit meetings, there is, naturally, a fax machine in every room. Double rooms at the Okura these days run from $350 a night and up for a twin. (3582-0111, fax 3582-3707).
The Four Seasons Hotel Chinzanso, at 2-10-8 Sekiguchi in Bunkyo-ku, is in the midst of a spectacular Japanese garden. Doubles start at $320. (3943-7178, fax 3943-0294).
 
Where to Eat
 A raging argument in Tokyo is just how many restaurants there are -- some say 80,000, some say 120,000. No matter where the truth lies, this city has some of the best eating in Asia, and not just for Japanese food. There are scores of French restaurants, hundreds of Asian specialty restaurants -- the list is endless. The trick is finding them in a city with few street names; the best bet is to call ahead and have a map faxed to your hotel, something every restaurateur is accustomed to doing.
For a quick bite, on the cheap, head for the noodle shops. Some of the best are under the bullet train tracks at Yurakucho Station, near the Ginza, but every neighborhood has them, with plastic replicas of the offerings in windows or cases out front. At night, yakitori is the fare of the "salari-man" -- office workers out with their colleagues -- and a popular choice is Agatha's in Roppongi (3470-2234), near the Self-Defense Agency; set menus of 8 to 10 sticks of chicken, fish and grilled vegetables run about $30 a plate. (Add another $4 to $5 for beer.) Nearby, and in several other locations, is Nanban-tei (3402-0606 for the original outlet, a smoky bar), with menus in English and courses that start at about $25.
Great Cambodian food can be found in Ebisu at Phnom Penh (3461-2769), 1-10-14 Ebisu-Nishi; count on $35 to $45 a person and order the egg plant with chili sauce and the miniature spring rolls. Not far away is Khumbila (3440-2638), the city's best Nepalese restaurant at 5-22-3 Hiroo, with similar prices. A few blocks away, just by the exit of Hiroo Station, is an exceptional Thai restaurant, Gold Leaf (3448-1521), but it can be pricey, with dinners from $80 a person and up.
Kaiseki dinners, an assortment of spectacularly presented small dishes, mostly vegetables and fish, are usually reserved for the most exclusive and expensive restaurants, places where you can't get a reservation unless you are a politician or executive with the right connections. But one bargain place to sample it, in high-tech elegance, is Sai-Sai (3441-9006), near Hiroo station, where exquisitely presented dinner sets start at about $50 a person. Shirogane (3449-0033), with its spectacular bamboo dining room, has a fine selection of sashimi, tempura and Japanese beef. Dinners run from $80 to $150 a person, but lunches start at about $35. One of the area's best traditional Japanese garden restaurants is 10 minutes from Takao Station. Ukai Toriyama (0426-61-0739) is a series of marvelous tea houses and country-style rooms where kaiseki meals cost $80 a person and up.
 
Shopping
 Some of the best shopping in the city is for "mingei," or traditional crafts, everything from $25 handmade tea cups to $100 cherry wood boxes, that convey some of Japan's design esthetic in the smallest and most practical things. Bingoya (3202-8778), Tokyo's best shop for crafts from across the country, is four floors of pottery, wonderful paper products, fabrics, wood carvings and whimsical toys, some for as little as $10. Call for a map, or take bus 76 or 74 from the west exit of Shinjuku Station to the 8th stop, Kawada-cho.
Bargain hunters should head to the stores surrounding the Tsukiji Fish Market (take the Hibiya line subway to Tsukiji) for an incredible array of Japanese cooking goods, hand-made knives, from $100 handmade knives to $20 or $30 bamboo steamers, and a wide selection of pottery. This is where Tokyo restaurateurs shop. The alleys around the fish market are teeming with small shops, but there are also bigger pottery outlets along Harumi Dori, leading to the expensive Ginza shopping area. The closer you get to Ginza, the more expensive the goods become. Shop early; the stores close when the fish market does in midafternoon.
Mitsukoshi's main store, in Nihombashi (3421-3311, closed Mondays), right on top of the subway stop of the same name, has traditionally designed goods, kimonos and unusual kitchenware.
Other areas good for shopping and strolling are the souvenir markets around the Asakusa temple, the doll stores around nearby Asakakusa-bashi, (dolls run from $50 and up), and my favorite, the print and book shops in Kanda, surrounding the Jimbocho subway stop. This is the best place to look for ukiyoe, the traditional woodblock prints of scenes in Japan in the 19th century Omote-Sando, the classiest shopping district in the city, is the place for boutiques and designer goods.
