HEADLINE: U.S. IS HARDENING ITS STAND ON IRAQ

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Hardening its position toward Saddam Hussein's Government, the Clinton Administration wants to impose tough new requirements for lifting the United Nations ban on Iraqi oil exports.
The United States is urging other members of the United Nations Security Council to insist that Baghdad recognize Kuwait as an independent country and stop persecuting dissident Kurds and Shiite Muslims. 
 These conditions would be in addition to the Security Council's demands, made at the end of the Persian Gulf war, that Iraq disarm and let the United Nations monitor its military industries.
The American position, supported by Britain, France and Russia, three of the Council's other four permanent members, stems from mistrust of Mr. Hussein, officials said. It makes it less likely than seemed to be the case a few months ago that Iraq will start selling oil again soon. The position of China, the fifth permanent member, is not known.
 
Drop in Price of Oil
 Over the last year, the price of oil has dropped from about $18 to $19 a barrel to about $14.50. This was mainly because of weak demand but also because the market concluded that Iraq was trying to strike a deal with the Security Council that would allow it to sell oil again. The tougher United States policy on lifting the embargo could lead to a rise in prices.
Setting out the Administration's position in an interview on Friday, Madeleine K. Albright, the United States representative at the United Nations, called for "a two-phased approach" to lifting the ban on Iraqi oil sales.
First, she said, Rolf Ekeus, head of the United Nations commission overseeing Iraq's disarmament, must certify that Iraq has abandoned its nuclear, chemical and biological weapon programs as called for in Security Council Resolution 687.
The special commission must also show, she said, that it is able to monitor Iraqi industry to make sure Iraq does not try to make such weapons again.
 
'A Proven Track Record'
 "I've said we want a proven track record of 6 to 12 months' monitoring," Ms. Albright said.
But in addition, she said, Iraq's compliance with other Security Council resolutions must be taken into account in "any assessment of its readiness to rejoin society."
This means Mr. Hussein must give "clear evidence of respect for Kuwait's borders" and also "show respect for his own people" by ending his blockade of the Kurds in the north and his attacks against dissident Shiite Muslims in the south.
"There has to be an overall package here," she said.
The Administration's position recalls the stance taken by President George Bush and Prime Minister John Major of Britain, who both said they favored maintaining sanctions against Iraq as long as Mr. Hussein was in power.
 
Changes in Clinton's Attitude
 President Clinton's attitude toward the Iraqi leader has seemed somewhat ambivalent. At first he appeared to distance himself from Mr. Bush's hard line, saying in an interview before his inauguration that he was ready for a fresh start if the Iraqi leader changed his ways and cooperated with the United Nations. Saying he was not "obsessed" by Mr. Hussein, Mr. Clinton said he could imagine a normal relationship with him if he behaved according to international norms.
But in June, saying an investigation showed Iraq backed a plot to assassinate Mr. Bush on a visit to Kuwait, Mr. Clinton ordered a missile attack on an Iraqi intelligence headquarters in a suburb of Baghdad.
This summer, Mr. Ekeus got a green light from Washington, Paris and London before going to Baghdad to try to persuade Iraqi officials their best chance of getting the oil embargo lifted was by cooperating with the disarmament requirements imposed at the end of the Persian Gulf war.
This meant providing missing details of prohibited weapons programs and accepting long-term industrial monitoring.
 
Terms for Ending Sanctions
 Mr. Ekeus based his talks on a literal reading of Resolution 687, which says the ban on purchase of Iraqi oil by foreign countries "shall have no further force or effect" once the Council decides Iraq has complied fully with its disarmament demands.
Iraq would thus be free to resume oil exports, and reap billions of dollars in revenue, though the Security Council is expected to insist that a third of the money be used as compensation for victims of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
But United States officials now argue that the Security Council is effectively being asked to judge the likelihood that Mr. Hussein will continue respecting those provisions after the ban on oil sales is lifted.
And it is difficult to believe Mr. Hussein would continue to comply, they said, when he still says Kuwait is a province of Iraq and his forces continue to oppress dissident Kurds and Shiite Muslims.
"If the pattern of Iraq's behavior outside the demands of Paragraph 22 of Resolution 687 is still one of generalized noncompliance then it is difficult to believe Baghdad is sincere," an Administration official said.
After talks here in November, Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq said Baghdad was finally ready to accept the long-term monitoring and would also provide missing information about its weapon programs.
 
Will Iraq Stop Cooperating?
 It is possible that Baghdad, feeling it has been deceived by Mr. Ekeus, will now stop cooperating with his arms inspectors and that the commission's industrial monitoring plans will come to nothing.
Another possibility, analysts said, is that Iraq will make a new attempt to sell oil under another Security Council resolution.
Resolution 706 permits Iraq to sell $1.6 billion worth of oil to pay for imports of essential goods provided the United Nations closely monitors the distribution of these supplies.
Iraq opened talks with the United Nations this summer about selling oil under these terms but then abruptly broke them off.
Part of the reason appears to have been Mr. Ekeus's success in persuading the leadership they had a good chance of getting the oil embargo lifted completely by cooperating with his disarmament program.
But Iraqi officials have complained that Resolution 706 violates Iraq's sovereignty in unacceptable ways by putting the United Nations rather than Mr. Hussein in charge of distributing the goods Iraq buys and requiring that Kurds and Shiites get their fair share.
"It would turn Iraq into a United Nations refugee camp" a senior Iraqi official said recently.

HEADLINE: U.S. ASKS GERMANY TO PUSH RUSSIA AID

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUDWIGSHAFEN, Germany, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore appealed to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany today to put aside any doubts about Russia's political stability and to speed up aid to the country.
In a nearly two hour meeting at Mr. Kohl's home, Mr. Gore also raised the question of whether the International Monetary Fund should ease the inflation quotas put on Russia so the country can get aid faster to relieve its severe social and economic troubles. 
 Those issues were "a central topic of our conversation," Mr. Kohl said after the meeting near this heavily industrialized city in central Germany. The Chancellor said that "economic reform will only be successful" if Russia can "bring about a social situation that offers a clear and helpful perspective."
Mr. Gore's visit with Mr. Kohl was the last stop on his way home from a weeklong trip to Russia, Kyrgyzstan and Kazakhstan, where he met with leaders and signed several accords to promote economic development and other ties to the United States. Mr. Kohl apparently had been waiting for a briefing from the Vice President before making any policy decisions in response to the unexpectedly strong showing in the Russian Parliamentary elections by the ultranationalist Liberal Democratic Party led by Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky.
 
Aid to Russia Reconsidered
 Mr. Zhirinovsky has emerged as the most visible opponent of President Boris N. Yeltsin's economic and political reforms. The resulting political confusion has put pressure on Mr. Kohl to reconsider the extent of Germany's aid. Many mainstream German politicians have expressed serious concerns about Mr. Zhirinovsky's showing, particularly because he has close connections to the German People's Union, a right-wing extremist party.
"We discussed some recent elections in Russia," Mr. Gore said after the meeting, "and we agreed to continue consulting each other."
Neither Mr. Gore nor Mr. Kohl discussed the specifics of their meeting, but Mr. Kohl echoed Mr. Gore's contention that the election results should only encourage both countries to reach out to Russia.
"The election results of last Sunday showed how important it is that all of us work together and pool our resources to support the forces of reform," the German Chancellor said.
Germany has contributed nearly $50 billion to Russia and other former Soviet republics since 1989, and has called on other countries to donate as well. But as the United States steps up its aid to the region, some American officials said Mr. Kohl has been more reluctant to continue the spending. German officials contend that Germany is suffering from a sour economy and has done its share already.
 
Doubts on a Broader NATO
 In an interview in a right-wing German newspaper this week. Mr. Zhirinovsky advocated that the Germans and the Russians unite in an "eternal alliance," and said he favored "close military cooperation with Germany," raising the memory of the bond forged by Hitler and Stalin in 1939.
Since the elections last week, Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of Germany has sounded less sure that his country would still support an American proposal to increase cooperation between members of NATO and former members of the Warsaw Pact. The issue is expected to be discussed at a meeting of leaders of the Atlantic Alliance next month in Brussels.
In another effort to try to resolve lingering disputes over the nuclear arsenal of the former Soviet Union, Mr. Gore met with President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine in Budapest before arriving here. Ukraine has been reluctant to dismantle the nuclear missiles on its territory, and has not ratified the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty.
"The United States is trying to play a constructive role in resolving this issue," Mr. Gore said, adding that "all sides will tell you progress is being made," though he was not more specific.
Strobe Talbott, the United States Ambassador at Large to the former Soviet Republics, met with Mr. Kravchuk earlier this week, but Mr. Gore would not discuss those talks.

HEADLINE: Farrakhan Urges Black Cleanup of Violence

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
After serving as the catalyst for a bitter debate in this year's mayoral contest, the Rev. Louis Farrakhan finally made his postponed public address yesterday, combining a message of black pride with a denunciation of what he called the corrupted moral tenor of the nation.
In a fiery speech, Mr. Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, told an audience of nearly 25,000 in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan of the need for black people to take greater responsibility for addressing the violence in the black community and the necessity to develop stronger spiritual discipline. 
 "Look, men: We must make our community decent for our women, children and the elderly," said Mr. Farrakhan, whose organization provides security services for some urban areas plagued by drugs. "We can do it better than the police. If we clean up our communities, we will be able to walk the streets in peace and security."
The appearance of Mr. Farrakhan -- originally scheduled for three days before the Nov. 2 mayoral election -- was a heated issue during the campaign. Mr. Farrakhan, while admired by many young black people for his message of economic power and discipline, has been bitterly criticized by many people for his comments nine years ago calling Judaism a "gutter religion."
 
Embarrassment Feared
 The rally, originally scheduled for Yankee Stadium on Oct. 30, was seen as being potentially embarrassing to Mayor David N. Dinkins, who has often faulted the black Muslim leader. Rudolph W. Giuliani, then Mr. Dinkins's opponent, criticized the Mayor for allowing the minister to use the stadium, which is operated by the city. Mr. Giuliani said he would have sought to prevent Mr. Farrakhan from using the stadium, a stand that drew fire from many elected officials and the American Civil Liberties Union.
Ultimately, the speech was postponed, after some of the Mayor's close black political allies asked Mr. Farrakhan to wait until after the election.
Yesterday, before the speech, Mayor-elect Giuliani said Mr. Farrakhan's message in the past had been "despicable, and I think almost everyone in New York feels that way." Mr. Giuliani added that "he has a right, like others do, to express their opinion, even if you believe that opinion is despicable."
 
Two-Hour Speech
 Mr. Farrakhan's address attracted a cross-section of black New Yorkers, from Wall Street bankers and managers in Park Avenue corporations to high school dropouts and the unemployed. Some of the audience had to watch on closed-circuit television screens in an adjacent room.
The rally, at which Mr. Farrakhan made his first public speech in New York since an appearance at Madison Square Garden in 1985, also drew a collection of people representing celebrity and controversy. They ranged from the Rev. Al Sharpton, the political activist, and Leonard Jeffries, who was deposed and reinstated as head of the black studies department at City College, to Stephanie Mills, the Broadway singer and recording artist, and Wesley Snipes, the actor.
In the "Stop the Killing" rally, whose ticket prices ranged from $10 to $100, Mr. Farrakhan spoke for nearly two hours, touching on everything from a defense of the entertainer Michael Jackson to a perspective on the sexual misconduct of some Catholic priests.
Most of Mr. Farrakhan's speech dealt with topics religious and moral. Time and time again, he said that the reason for the violence within the black community was not only the proliferation of guns and drugs but also what he described as the decay of morality in the United States.
"The United States of America, the greatest nation on earth, invincible to any outside force," Mr. Farrakhan said, "is now vulnerable because of an internal rot and corruption." The country, he said "is a brilliant nation that can send men and women to outer space to correct a telescope, but can't help students out of high school with a 30 percent functional illiteracy. The morality of the country has gone to the depth of a bottomless pit."
 
Mostly the Young
 The rally was attended principally by young black men and women, many of whom stood in line waiting to enter for nearly an hour and most of whom were followers of Mr. Farrakhan. They included ever-courteous, crisply dressed men in dark suits and bow ties and women dressed all in white, with long dresses, gloves and hair coverings.
Some of Mr. Farrakhan's rhetoric was racially charged, suggesting frequently that the history of white Americans had been filled with instances of oppression of black, Hispanic and Asian people not only in the United States but abroad.
But he added: "I'm neither a racist nor an anti-Semite. But if I point out your evil with truth, then call me a preacher of truth. And if you will correct your behavior, then love will come as a result. But you can't pass hate on me."

HEADLINE: 1784 SPANISH SHIP IS FOUND IN GULF

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
A lost treasure ship whose sinking in 1784 played a minor role in the early history of the United States has been discovered in 300 feet of water about 50 miles off Louisiana and part of the cargo has been recovered, the finders reported last week.
The vessel, El Cazador, or the Hunter, had been sent by Spain from its port in New Orleans to pick up Mexican coins for its holdings in Louisiana, with the aim of stabilizing their currency. The ship's manifest listed 450,000 pesos. She left Veracruz, Mexico, on Jan. 11, 1784, but never arrived back in New Orleans. The ship was eventually declared lost. 
 As the Louisiana holdings failed to pick up economically, they were ceded by Spain in 1800 back to France, which sold them in 1803 to the United States as the Louisiana Purchase, doubling the size of the young republic.
The lost ship, an armed vessel called a brigantine of war, was about 90 feet long, with a shallow draft and two masts. She probably carried 18 guns, the finders said.
 
Found by Accident
 The wreckage was discovered by accident in August when a fishing vessel snagged its net on an underwater obstruction. The raised net dropped hundreds of coins onto the fishing vessel's deck, all of them minted in Mexico City and most of them dated 1783.
The fishing vessel's owner, Jim Reahard of Grand Bay, Ala., who sails out of Pascagoula, Miss., approached an admiralty lawyer in Key West, Fla., David Paul Horan, who then filed a claim on the wreck for Mr. Reahard. An underwater salvage concern, Marex International Inc. of Memphis, was hired to explore the site.
In September, Marex used a sonar and a small underwater robot to find the wreck. "It took only one hour to locate the target and then three days to properly photograph it with underwater video," Marex said in a statement. "Coins could be seen covering the wreck site."
In October and November, the company used divers and robots to begin recovery operations. To date, Marex said, the findings include some 12,000 silver coins as well as the ship's bell. The recovery operation was suspended last month because of rough weather.
 
Records From Spain
 Robert Stenuit, a historian in Brussels who studies old Spanish wrecks by using the Archives of the Indies, historical records kept in Seville, Spain, was hired to make an identification based on the evidence in hand.
His inquiry showed that no other large sum of cash from Mexico was lost by shipwreck in the Gulf of Mexico between 1783 and 1785, he wrote the finders. "It follows," Mr. Stenuit said, "that the wreck you found cannot be any other wreck but the one of the brig of war El Cazador."
Mr. Horan, the lawyer, said in a presentation in New Orleans on Dec. 6 that the overall salvage group, known as the Grumpy partnership, was "vitally interested in proper conservation of the artifacts and the educational aspects of this adventure." In the partnership, Myrna Reahard, the wife of the fishing vessel's owner, is in charge of counting the coins and keeping track of all the artifacts and recoveries from the wreck site.
Marex, in a statement, said that because of the depth of the water and the muddy bottom, the company "expects to find many historically significant artifacts in a good state of preservation."
Henry N. Hudson, a Marex vice president, said in a telephone interview on Friday: "We're hoping for a 70 to 80 percent recovery. In the salvage business that's a full recovery."
He added that the company expected to work the site of the historic wreck as weather permits.

HEADLINE: Atlanta's Olympic Park Plan Reveals The Complications of Urban Renewal

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Midway between Atlanta's surprise designation as the site of the next Summer Olympics and July 1996, when perhaps two million people will descend on Atlanta for the Games, time is running out for the grand dreams of urban renaissance that the Olympics fostered here.
And nothing to date has brought home the political, economic and racial complications that come with trying to mount an event as big as the Olympics in an American inner city as a proposal to bulldoze a ragged, 72-acre swath of downtown Atlanta for a park that could provide the focal point for the Games. 
 Supporters say the $100 million project would provide a much needed public gathering place for the Olympics and would generate new development that would transform a largely seedy part of downtown. Skeptics see the project as a dubious quick fix that would drain money from needy neighborhoods and leave behind a forlorn park and an inner city as poor after the Games as before.
 
Much at Stake
 At the least, however, the proposed Centennial Olympic Park is a reminder of how much is at stake in the Olympics, which are expected to have a $5.1 billion economic impact on Georgia, and how widespread are the fears that Atlanta is in danger of failing to capitalize on the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity 944 days away.
"The Olympics are like a flying saucer that's landed in the midst of a community," said Lyn May, an Olympic spokeswoman. "It's done exactly what you would expect in terms of raising expectations and creating fear and loathing. And the ultimate fear is that the flying saucer will take off and leave only scorched earth behind."
Organizers bill the Games, the 100th anniversary of the Olympics, as the largest single event in American history, one comparable to six Super Bowls a day for 17 days. But despite the boom they mean for the region around Atlanta, the Games will be held in the middle of a city that is 70 percent black, accounts for only 400,000 of the 2.7 million people in the metropolitan area, and is one of the poorest in the country.
Atlanta's successful bid for the Games set off widespread expectations of dramatic urban revitalization. Now, almost everyone agrees those expectations were wildly inflated.
"There was a sense the Olympics could do everything for everybody," said Billy Payne, President of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, known as ACOG. "Of course it was an over-expectation, because we have governments which financially are unable to help. But I don't think ACOG can even be remotely accused of not addressing our civic responsibilities."
From the start, Mr. Payne has stressed that his committee planned to raise $1.6 billion in private donations for the "inside-the-fence" aspects of the Olympics -- the competition sites, buildings and resources needed to put on the Games. The "outside-the-fence" aspects like road improvements, downtown renewal and refurbishing low-income areas adjacent to the Olympic sites were left to public bodies.
So far, the inside activities are roughly on schedule. And Olympic officials say they will leave behind $500 million in projects paid for with private money, including the $211 million Olympic stadium, athletic sites at the historically black Atlanta University Center and student housing at Georgia Tech and Georgia State University.
But outside, there are only glimmers of progress, like a $38 million Federal grant for the rehabilitation of a housing project that is between the Olympic Village and the proposed park.
 
Political Overtones
 Most of the obstacles are financial, caused by the city's small size and tax base and a public climate hostile to the spending of tax money to support the Games.
But the slow pace also has roots in politics and race, and the desire of the City of Atlanta to control Olympic-related development despite the suburban roots and largely white leadership at the organizing committee. The result was Mayor Maynard Jackson's establishment of the Corporation for Olympic Development, which was designated as the agency in charge of development plans. The agency has drawn up a list of $220 million in possible projects, most of them in 15 low-income neighborhoods near the Olympic events.
But the development corporation has no money and as a city venture it lacks the political clout of a broader metropolitan or statewide body. Mayor-elect Bill Campbell said one of his main priorities was to come up with money to further the agency's agenda. A bond issue or sales tax increase is possible but both face political obstacles.
"My challenge and the challenge of the city for the next three years is to try not to let any more time go by without rebuilding our infrastructure and improving our neighborhoods," he said in an interview. "It's going to take a commitment that will be unyielding for the next three years."
Amid growing concerns about the slow pace of development, Mr. Payne last month unveiled his $100 million plan for the park, which would be financed by businesses and foundations. He called for bulldozing 72 acres of downtown that now consists largely of rundown buildings and dingy warehouses. After the Olympics, about 20 acres would remain as a park and the rest would be developed.
For the Olympics the park has impeccable logic, replacing an eyesore between the Olympic Village and major arenas with a green oasis. Supporters include Atlanta's political leadership and its most powerful business interests.
But there are doubters as well, most conspicuously the operators of businesses in the area who would be displaced by the park.
"I feel such sorrow in my heart about this," said Thelma Grundy, owner of Thelma's Kitchen, a popular home-style restaurant that would be displaced. "When I first heard about it I almost fainted."
 
Effect on the Poor
 But many others who have seen the Olympics as an engine for neighborhood development see the park as both a competitor that will consume resources and a confirmation of fears that poor neighborhoods and their residents are more likely to be displaced than helped by the Games.
"Nobody's pulling for the neighborhoods," said Douglas Dean, President of Summerhill Neighborhood Inc., a development group in the low-income area near the stadium. "And let me tell you, if anyone thinks we can sponsor this Olympics by '96, and we don't change the quality of life for the underclass, they're going to be surprised. The underclass has gotten sophisticated enough, that if they don't get some help, they know how to irritate people who have got something."
The park proposal has such powerful interests behind it that few prominent people are willing to express reservations. But privately some are unconvinced that a downtown park would become anything other than a haven for the homeless. And many see in the plan, both in the way it was hatched and in its broad-brush urban renewal approach, a reminder that Atlanta's political leadership may have changed from white to black, but the real power has not.
"It's a vision sort of dropped from on high, another big fix," said Tom Weyandt, a former Atlanta Commissioner of Planning and Development. "But I think the soul of the city and the real vision of the city is in a lot of little things that this will distract us from and draw money away from."
Mr. Payne said Atlanta could do both.
"I will refer you to a moment in time when we started bidding for the Games, and people said, 'What is this crazy idiot out there doing, espousing an idea so big,' " he said.
Almost every Olympic city at some point finds itself anxiously pondering whether it is going to get everything done on time. But Atlanta's commitment to put on the Games without public money and the high aspirations that the Games would bring social uplift along with sport, pose particular hurdles to Atlanta. And everyone agrees that two-and-a-half years is not much time for all the things, including the park, that Atlanta wants to do. Even the park, which would be built on land now owned by almost 200 different people, is viewed a difficult task to accomplish.
"The time has already passed to use the Olympics as a stimulus for some of the things we've talked about," said Joe Martin, a local developer. "Plans are great. But plans without implementation mean nothing."

HEADLINE: Ex-Convict Slays 2 in Oklahoma

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HUGO, Okla., Dec. 18

 BODY:
An ex-convict bought an assault rifle from a pawn shop and opened fire in a store parking lot on Friday, killing two people before driving down a dead-end road to end his own life.
Two other people were wounded outside the Wal-Mart store in this southeastern Oklahoma town of 6,000 people. The police are trying to find a motive for the attack by the gunman, David Mack Flinn, a 39-year-old convicted burglar who was unemployed. 
 Detectives from the Oklahoma State Bureau of Investigation said that hours before the shootings, Mr. Flinn lodged a complaint about a neighbor shooting his dog.
"I'll prosecute this myself," Mr. Flinn told a deputy before storming out of the sheriff's office. A Choctaw County Sheriff's deputy who checked out the complaint found no dog and no sign of violence at Mr. Flinn's house.
Mr. Flinn's next stop apparently was a pawn shop, where he lied about his string of theft and burglary convictions to buy the .223-caliber semiautomatic assault rifle and ammunition.
About two hours later, Luke Sheehan, 52, and Mary Sheehan, 49, were killed as they walked out of Wal-Mart, the bureau said.
Minutes later, Mr. Flinn was found dead in his truck on a dirt road a few miles away. Three guns and ammunition were in his truck. He killed himself with a single shot, Assistant District Attorney Larry Grant said.
The motive for Mr. Flinn's shooting spree remains a mystery, apart from a complaint about the dog.
"Basically this is just a random shooting," Assistant District Attorney Clark LeForce said.
Mr. Flinn's record lists a string of burglary and theft convictions in Pamona, Calif., and Dallas from 1976 to 1987. He also pleaded guilty in 1979 to a charge of assault with a deadly weapon in San Bernadino, Calif., records show.

HEADLINE: Russian Premier Assails Reformers in Cabinet for 'Poorly Thought-Out Experiments'

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 18

 BODY:
In another strong signal of a shift against economic reform after the Russian elections, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin was quoted today as scathingly accusing Westernized reformers in his own Cabinet of "poorly thought-out experiments" and a failure "to think about the people, for the sake of whom the reforms were started."
Mr. Chernomyrdin said the Government would now focus less on tight monetary and spending controls, which would reduce Russia's high rate of inflation, and more on social protection and on state and private investment to create jobs. 
 Russian voters stunned their leaders a week ago by voting in substantial numbers for the ultranationalist politician Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky and for the Communist and Agrarian parties. Expectations that pro-reform parties led by Government ministers would win a majority in the lower house of Parliament were dashed, and Mr. Zhirinovsky will end up with the second-biggest bloc of seats there.
Speaking to the trade-union newspaper Trud in an interview, Mr. Chernomyrdin blamed his reformist colleagues for the election results.
 
People Voted 'Against'
 "We should face the truth and admit that many people voted not so much for a particular platform or party as against the hardships and mistakes of the current reforms," the Prime Minister said. "As many as 35 million Russians live below the poverty line, which means that some 30 percent of the electorate were potentially 'against.' "
"Naturally," Mr. Chernomyrdin continued, "any 'shock' methods must be precluded in the future."
That reference was to the economic policies of Yegor T. Gaidar, who is the First Deputy Prime Minister and the leader of the reformist party Russia's Choice. He is also Mr. Chernomyrdin's predecessor, having been forced out of Government a year ago by the old Parliament.
Mr. Gaidar is considered the chief of the Government's Westernized reformers, including Privatization Minister Anatoly B. Chubais and Finance Minister Boris G. Fyodorov, who are pressing for stepped-up reform as the best response to the economic misery felt by voters.
Mr. Chernomyrdin has clearly takenanother view, something that President Boris N. Yeltsin may also choose to do when he finally speaks to the nation about the elections next week.
 
'Personal Defeat' Seen
 "The election defeat is a personal evaluation of Gaidar's work, but not as a representative of the whole Government, but as the person responsible for the Economy Ministry," Mr. Chernomyrdin said. "The same goes for Chubais. It's his personal defeat. So they should think it over hard. They have a lot to think about now."
In essence, Mr. Chernomyrdin seemed to be suggesting that Mr. Gaidar and Mr. Chubais resign.
If they have a lot to think about, as Mr. Chernoymrdin put it, so does the West. The United States and other Western nations have generally approached Russian economic reform through the agency of the International Monetary Fund, which is known for its emphasis on controlling inflation through controls on Government spending. This week, Vice President Al Gore criticized the fund and its member nations for insensitivity to the plight of Russians who lost their jobs because of sharp cuts in Russian military spending.
"Every country with representatives on the I.M.F. board has been slow to recognize the hardship caused by some of what has been done in the past," Mr. Gore said in Moscow on Thursday. "That may cause a diplomatic incident, but I don't care."
 
Gore Meets Chernomyrdin
 Mr. Gore spoke after a series of meetings with Mr. Chernomyrdin. The two men are chairmen of a joint committee on the problems involved in converting Russia's huge military sector so it can produce civilian products.
The fund argues that its loans can be useful only if Russia achieves genuine economic stability. Privately, fund officials say that if the Clinton Administration and the West now want to start a welfare program to keep Russian workers employed and happy, they should do it directly.
It is inevitable, senior diplomats said, that the Group of Seven major industrialized countries review their policy toward Russia. If a significant shift takes place in Russian policy, the West may decide to concentrate less on aid to the Government than on aid directly aimed at the growing private sector.
In the interview, Mr. Chernomyrdin emphasized nonetheless that reforms were still needed. "It was a correct decision to reform," he said. "But it is also true that serious miscalculations were made and that no one thought about the near future and the people, for the sake of whom the reforms were started."
 
'Very Dangerous' Experiments
 "Russia is no small country," he continued, "and poorly thought-out experiments are very dangerous in this case."
No politician in Russia is against "reform." Even Mr. Zhirinovsky professes to favor it. But when Mr. Chernomyrdin talks of reform, he has in mind a much slower, statist policy than Mr. Gaidar or the International Monetary Fund does.
Mr. Chernomyrdin spoke today, as he usually does, of increasing Russian industrial production as the highest priority. The Westernized economists stress the need to reduce the monthly inflation rate of 15 percent, which makes it difficult for Russia to secure private investment or restructure its industries.
Government figures indicate that Russian industrial production has stopped falling, although many factories are limping along on Government subsidies and delays in paying debts they owe to one another.
 
Unworried by Inflation
 While Mr. Gaidar views the current rate of inflation as prohibitive and dangerous, Mr. Chernomyrdin said today that it was fine, adding: "Rigid monetary policy has played its role. Now the time has come for investments and production."
Russia must "carry out an industrial revolution," much as Germany and Japan did after World War II, he said, to produce modern, competitive products. But Washington is hardly likely to provide a Marshall Plan for Russia these days.
In St. Petersburg, Mr. Gore said on Friday that United States support "for Boris Yeltsin's proposals here in Russia are linked to Boris Yeltsin's commitment to reform and democracy, and the support for him is just as strong as his support for these principles."
But Washington is now reflecting on what kind of democracy and what kind of reform Russia will embrace.
Mr. Chernomyrdin, who did not run in the Dec. 12 elections but supported a centrist bloc of another Deputy Prime Minister, Sergei Shakrai, is expected to remain Prime Minister in a shuffled government. That is in part because of his generally centrist views and calm management style, and in part because Mr. Yeltsin is unlikely to want to give the new Parliament the chance to confirm or reject a new prime minister.
 
Subsidized Loans Approved
 The post-election trend toward slowing reform was visible on Friday when Mr. Yeltsin decreed $120 million in cheap, subsidized loans to agricultural enterprises, and when the Government approved a weaker privatization program over the objections of Mr. Gaidar and Mr. Chubais at a meeting led by a close ally of Mr. Chernomyrdin, Oleg Soskovets.
Mr. Yeltsin also decreed new immigration controls on Russia's frontiers and new rules for employing non-Russians, to reduce the number of people from former Soviet republics seeking work and refuge here, one of Mr. Zhirinovsky's biggest complaints.
Mr. Chernomyrdin, after lambasting Mr. Gaidar and his allies for what has been the policy of his own Government for a year, said, "We should not blame now those who launched this great undertaking, but examine calmly the progress of reforms and past mistakes."
But it now seems likely that Mr. Gaidar, while leading the biggest bloc of votes in the new lower house of Parliament, will soon find himself demoted, at the least, and very possibly out of government once more.

HEADLINE: Traveling to Camden

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
In a state frequently given to bizarre political playmaking, it should come as little surprise that a professional basketball team is at the center of the latest political dispute in New Jersey.
But a decision by the owner of the Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association to begin talks about moving his team across the Delaware River to Camden has put Gov. Jim Florio and Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman at odds publicly and set off a political debate. 
 It has also revived memories of a high-stake political fight 20 years ago, which also fell during a gubernatorial transition, when New Jersey lured the New York Giants of the National Football League to a patch of swampy land just west of Manhattan.
Frustrated in his efforts to have a new arena built in Philadelphia, the 76ers' owner, Harold Katz, began negotiating with Mr. Florio about moving the team to Camden shortly before the Nov. 2 election, in which Mrs. Whitman defeated Mr. Florio. Both sides say that they expect an agreement within a few days.
 
Paying for Itself
 The question now is whether a new $80 million arena, which is what it would take to lure the 76ers to Camden, could pay for itself.
Governor Florio, who is privy to a confidential feasibility study by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, has said yes.
Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia, who is eager to keep the 76ers and who has a chorus of fiscal experts backing him, has said no.
And a cautious Mrs. Whitman, backed by an even more reticent Republican-controlled Legislature, has given a very qualified maybe, saying that she will support the deal only if it there is no cost to taxpayers.
Saddled with what he has called the worst lease in professional sports -- an arrangement in which he pays rent to Spectacor, the parent company of the Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League, to play in the Spectrum -- Mr. Katz has long been on the lookout for a better deal.
 
Philadelphia Deal Dies
 Once before, in 1989, Mr. Katz and the Flyers' owner, Ed Snider, flirted with New Jersey officials about building a new arena in Camden that they would jointly own. But with incentives from Philadelphia, the two men agreed to help build a new arena to replace the Spectrum, the 18,168-seat center that has been the 76ers' home since it opened in September 1967.
Late last month, after many revisions, the deal fell apart and Mr. Katz again turned to Camden.
The new talks have had a special urgency, partly because Mr. Florio leaves office in a month and partly because Mr. Katz faces a Feb. 1 deadline to decide whether to continue the 76ers' lease at the Spectrum.
Luring the 76ers to Camden would allow Mr. Florio to leave office on a political high. It would also be a plum to the city that has been the base of his political fief during his nearly 30 years in politics.
 
Whitman Fears Bond Debt
 If things proceed as Mr. Katz and Mr. Florio want, come the 1995-96 N.B.A. season, the Philadelphia 76ers, as they will still be called, will be playing in a new arena on the Camden riverfront, built near the state's new aquarium with bonds issued by the Sports and Exposition Authority. The authority's revenue to pay off the bonds would come from the new arena, not its other properties.
Mrs. Whitman, who ran on a pledge to cut state taxes and spending, is worried that the proposed arena may not generate enough income to pay off the $80 million in bonds.
"We are waiting until a review by our staff is completed," said Mrs. Whitman's chief spokesman, Carl Golden. "She is very sensitive to her obligation that taxpayers not be called upon to pay for a new arena."
Mr. Golden said Mrs. Whitman would not object to Mr. Florio's concluding a deal with the 76ers before she takes office on Jan. 18, but only if her concerns are satisfied.
 
Impact on Philadelphia
 Mr. Rendell has played down the economic impact that the departure of the 76ers would cost his city, whose residents would still provide most of the fans. He has said the direct economic impact to the city -- taxes, parking and concession revenues -- amounts to $1 million to $1.5 million a year from the N.B.A. franchise, not counting the indirect benefits like hotel and restaurant income.
"But we would rather not lose the $1.5 million and whatever indirect economic benefit, and we would rather not lose the prestige of being one of the few cities in the country with all four professional sports teams within the city limits," said the Mayor's chief of staff, David L. Cohen.
Philadelphia's City Hall has given out a memo with what it called "some observations on the financial status" of the Sports Authority.
It concluded that the Authority's cash flow from the Meadowlands and its other sites does not cover its debt service -- a $12 million to $18 million shortfall, according to the document -- and that "there are no excess funds to subsidize a new arena."
 
Silence From Sports Authority
 The Sports Authority has refused to comment publicly on the negotiations. Privately, they call Philadelphia's response sour grapes.
New Jersey went through a similar but much more rancorous debate in the early 1970's when its departing Governor, William T. Cahill, started a push for development of the Meadowlands complex in East Rutherford and began talks to bring the New York Giants to the proposed stadium.
New York fought bitterly to stall the project, using the Rockefeller family to try to discourage bond investors from financing the project.

HEADLINE: A Flat Economy Is Forecast For the Island's Near Future

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 16

 BODY:
The Long Island economy will remain flat for the next few years, with a surge of job growth and industrial development around the turn of the century and through the year 2010, according to a study by the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
After World War II, Long Island had the fastest growing economy in the nation, the report said, but with the end of the cold war, growth has come to a standstill. More than 100,000 jobs were lost over the last four and a half years, many of them high-paying jobs with military contractors. 
 Since every manufacturing job represents a multiplier impact of at least two to one, the impact of the loss of defense jobs has been substantial, said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the board.
As a result, she said, Long Island has been slow to recover from the recession, and the options for a quick recovery are limited. She said the job losses may end next year, with the possible gain of at least 5,000. If there is any growth "it will be moderate," she said.
 
White-Collars Affected
 She said the downsizing of the military industry is only part of the structural changes on the Island. Many white-collar workers are also being displaced because of automation.
Moreover, there are significant local impediments to a sound economy, the report said. They include high taxes, high energy costs, transportation inefficiencies, lack of affordable housing and a negative business climate.
"The two top negatives holding back the Island's economy are the cost of energy and taxes," said Lee E. Koppelman, the planning board's executive director. "The cost of both electricity and property tax rates remain the highest in the country, making it difficult for the Island to compete in the world marketplace for new industries."
Long Island's population leveled off at 2.6 million in the mid-1970's, but there have been significant changes in the racial composition of the population.
Between 1980 and 1990, the Island's white population declined by 84,000, or about 4 percent, while its black population increased by 31,000 persons, or 19 percent. The Hispanic population increased by 63,000, or 62 percent, while the Asian population rose by 38,000, or 250 percent.
 
10th-Biggest Area
 As of 1990, the Island ranked as the 10th most populous metropolitan statistical area in the United States and larger than that of 20 states.
Service industries have replaced the defense sector as the Island's dominant employer in terms of both employment and income generation. These include jobs in supermarkets, financial institutions, transportation, communications utilities and health-care facilities.
Only one manufacturer, the Grumman Corporation, remained among the 10 largest non-governmental employers on Long Island as of 1993. Grumman, which employed nearly 30,000 people in 1980, now has less than 12,000 workers.
To fill the void created by declines in military manufacturing, the panel recommends targeting certain key manufacturing industries, including biotechnology and biomedical research and information technology.
 
Educational Challenge
 To help use the scientific and technical skills of displaced military workers, the report urged the Island's higher educational institutions to rise to the challenge with a diverse array of advanced graduate programs.
The panel urged colleges and universities to abandon their "ivory tower" mentality and adopt a pragmatic approach that will equip large segments of the Island's adult population with the skills needed by regional employers.
Among the plan's other key recommendations is a $22 million military conversion fund to help manufacturers. Suffolk County has allocated $500,000 and Nassau is to consider a similar amount when it votes on its 1994 budget early next week. The state government would contribute $2 million and a consortium of banks would provide the rest of the money.
The report also calls for commercial air cargo service at Calverton Airport, a repeal of the 5 percent state tourism tax on rooms costing more than $100, the importation of cheaper gas and electricity from Canada and upstate New York and property tax abatements to aid strategic new industries.
Matthew T. Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, the region's principal business and civic organization, welcomed the findings of the planning board. He said the L.I.A. intended to use the report as a research base and springboard for an economic summit in September.
"We hope to work very closely with leaders in government and the private sector to build a consensus on what needs to be done and ways to convert it into action," Mr. Crosson said.

HEADLINE: Contemplating a Future Without Jobs

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FULTON, N.Y., Dec. 13

 BODY:
With the shortened days of December, happy hour at the Canal Point Restaurant and Bar here gets an early start. By 4:30 P.M. on a recent Friday, the small, wood-paneled barroom was already crowded and abuzz with two dozen people. Most had cans of Miller beer in front of them.
"I'll probably always drink it," said Ralph Thompson. "It's a good beer." 
 "I'll keep drinking it for now," said Bob Scheemaker. "But I could re-evaluate that next year. I'll have to see."
Ordinarily, loyalty to a brand of beer is evidence of little more than personal taste or a successful advertising campaign. But the situation here is different. Mr. Thompson, Mr. Scheemaker, and almost everyone else in this room work at a Miller brewery less than a mile away. They make the beer; and it's tempting to view their choice whether to drink it now as a referendum of sorts. Because, in all likelihood, these employees and more than 700 colleagues will be losing their jobs.
The Phillip Morris Companies, the consumer-products giant that owns the Miller Brewing Company, announced on Dec. 1 that it plans to close the 1.2 million-square-foot Miller brewery, which lies in Oswego County in the town of Volney, about 25 miles north of Syracuse. Of the plant's 731 employees, 300 are scheduled to be laid off in January 1994. The rest are expected to be gone by October 1994. The call-back list for 170 workers who were laid off workers earlier will be thrown out.
 
Dropping Beer Sales
 The shutdown is part of a larger Phillip Morris reorganization plan, unveiled Nov. 24, that will eliminate an estimated 14,000 jobs over the next three years. The move comes amid projections that Phillip Morris' 1993 earnings will be 16 percent lower than in 1992.
The 17-year-old Volney plant, which sits less than a mile from the Fulton city line, would be the only one of Miller's seven breweries to close. Company officials blame the choice primarily on sagging beer sales in the Northeast. And in that sagging market, Miller trailed Anheuser-Busch, whose leading beers carry the Budweiser label.
"I wasn't too surprised to hear about it -- the rumor mill became too hard to ignore," said Mr. Scheemaker, 39, a 17-year Miller veteran who runs filling and labeling machines in the packaging department. "There were already some layoffs and we kind of had a little cloud up over our heads."
Yet others, including union leaders, said they were shocked.
"When they announced it to us, it was like we were in a boxing ring and I got knocked down," said Tim Phillips, president of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers Local 2587.
 
'Best Kept Secrets'
 Denis Ray is the union's secretary-treasurer. "We got absolutely no advance notice," said Mr. Ray. "It was one of the best kept secrets that they have ever had."
Since the announcement, the machinists' union has been holding private talks with Miller officials in an effort to keep the brewery open. There has been no indication so far that the company will reverse its decision.
"I think the problem goes beyond concessions," said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Saying there is little chance of keeping the Miller brewery open, Mr. Cuomo has instead assembled a team of state officials to work with local authorities and lure a new business, not necessarily a brewer, to the site. "It won't be easy," said Mr. Cuomo. "But we're certainly looking."
If a new occupant is not found, Oswego County and the roughly 20,000 people who live in the Fulton area may have a difficult time ahead.
"Unemployment rates will see a steep climb," said Roger Evans, an economist with the New York State Department of Labor. "If all the Miller layoffs happened right now, we'd see the unemployment rate in the county increase from 6.7 percent up to 8.4 percent," Mr. Evans said. "But even broken out over a longer time, the layoffs will still be a devastating blow."
Mr. Evans said an additional, long-term ripple effect could eliminate one or two jobs in the community for every position lost at Miller.
At an estimated $19 an hour, Miller's average wage is one of the highest in Central New York manufacturing.
"I've got a better chance of seeing God than to find a similar paying job," said George Gridley, 47, who works in the brewing section.
For Victor Blair, a 43-year-old packaging department worker and his family, the imminent layoff has done more than just serve up a pink slip. It has jeopardized a dream.
Nearly two years ago, Mr Blair, his wife Teresa, and their two sons moved from a cramped, three-bedroom house near the brewery to a new home five miles into the country. Aside from laying the foundation and erecting the outer walls, Mr. Miller built the house himself.
Sitting around the dining room table, the family nodded in agreement when Mr. Blair said, "We love it here."
They are determined to keep the house if they can, but there is money owed to the contractor, a mortgage and college loan repayments for a son who was recently laid off.
Still Mr. Blair is lucky to be in the last wave of layoffs. That gives his wife time to look for work and gives him time to explore opening a business of his own, repairing small engines.
Mr. Blair's youngest son, Ryan, 15, standing in his classically teen-age bedroom, with posters on the wall and shoeboxes filled with sports trading cards, stared at the carpet.
"All the things I used to think about: my cards; stuff at school; or maybe buying clothes, now I never think about them anymore," he said. "I guess maybe everything's sort of confusing me."

HEADLINE: Helping the Neediest Women

 BODY:
A refugee arrives in New York from Belarus. At 56, she has endured for decades a marriage to an abusive, alcoholic husband who has, at least once, come close to killing her. She speaks no English; but immigrant organizations help her to adjust. They arrange English classes. As her confidence grows, she finds the courage, for the first time in her life, to ask for help.
In desperation, she calls the agency that has already helped her so much, an agency supported in part by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She finds herself in the office of Victoria Neznansky, a vibrant young woman from Odessa who speaks her language, understands her plight, tells her she's not alone and offers support. 
 Ms. Neznansky was such an immigrant herself in 1989. The New York Association for New Americans, supported by the United Jewish Appeal, helped her to find a home, friends and a job. Eventually she won a scholarship to study at New York University for a master's degree in social work. Once she got her degree, she returned to the agency that had helped her. She works with immigrant women from the former Soviet Union who suffer from domestic violence.
Many of these women come from rural societies in which a wife is considered her husband's property. Often they adjust more quickly than their husbands to life in the United States, learning English faster and enjoying their new-found freedom. But freedom for a wife can mean humiliation for her husband. Sometimes the last straw comes when a woman finds work and her husband is still unemployed. With their status in the immigrant community diminished and feeling they are losing control of their families, some husbands turn violent. Others continue a pattern started in the old country, where such abuse was tolerated.
Sometimes, Ms. Neznansky finds, talking to such a husband can help. She explains that this kind of behavior is against the law here. She sympathizes with the difficulty of adjusting to new ways. But she also cautions that if his wife is in danger, as a professional she is obliged to call on law enforcement to protect her. She offers her help. She estimates that in 40 percent of these cases the husband's behavior changes. For the others, she arranges new housing and support to help the wife start a new life.
Ms. Neznansky is one of many people working for agencies supported by the Neediest Cases Fund who have started as clients and ended up as helpers.
In her own case, her drive, her command of the language (she taught English in Odessa before emigrating) and her determination not to depend on welfare caught the attention of agency workers. They felt she would be a good interpreter and hired her. Eventually, after getting her degree, she returned to the work she is doing now -- partly with the help of Times readers who have contributed to the Neediest Cases Fund.
The fund channels all contributions to social service organizations; none is held back for administration or solicitation. The money could end up paying the rent for a young mother who needs to escape an abusive relationship -- or for some other life-saving form of help.
Contributions are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law, and any amount is welcome. Checks should be payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and mailed to Post Office Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087.

HEADLINE: Segregation's Threat to the Economy

 BODY:
According to a Harvard University study, the nation's schools are now more segregated than they have been in 25 years. The segregation is not only racial, with more and more African-American and Latino students attending schools with predominantly minority enrollment. It is also economic, with more minority students from low-income families clustered together.
The nation long ago recognized that integration was a moral and political imperative. These statistics also make clear that to remain economically viable and competitive, the United States cannot keep pushing large numbers of black and Latino children further and further to the margins of society. Fully one-third of those entering the work force in the next decade will be minorities. It makes no sense to keep so many of these future workers isolated in schools that are educationally inferior. 
 The study was conducted by the Harvard Project on School Desegregation and led by Gary Orfield, a professor of education. He and his researchers looked at patterns of segregation across the country in 1991-92.
They found that 66 percent of black public school students were in schools where enrollment was more than 50 percent black or Latino or both. That's the highest level since 1968 when 76 percent of black students attended such schools. Latino students were even more segregated, with 73 percent at schools that were predominantly minority.
The researchers attributed the increasing concentration of minority students to higher birth rates and immigration, rather than to flight of white students. But school and housing segregation tend to go hand in hand.
Several other factors, separately and together, help guarantee the isolation of low-income minority children. Many neighborhoods are not economically diverse and states often restrict students to their neighborhood schools by drawing smaller and smaller school-district lines.
A 1974 Supreme Court decision discouraged desegregation remedies that crossed district lines. And 12 years of Federal policies during the Reagan and Bush Administrations virtually wiped out funding for voluntary desegregation efforts and encouraged legal efforts to terminate successful desegregation orders.
Making matters worse, districts with concentrations of poor, minority students generally have less political clout than affluent white districts and are often shortchanged in funding by state legislatures. But while efforts to equalize funding should continue, improving the life prospects of these students requires the targeting of extra resources -- and a re-commitment to the ideal of integration.
Professor Orfield recommends more Federal funding to encourage voluntary desegregation efforts, using tools like magnet schools and consolidation of districts. He would also link Federal housing funds to school desegregation efforts. And in newly desegregated schools, he thinks more funding should be provided to train teachers and develop multicultural curriculums.
Since the work force is becoming increasingly diverse, it's worse than shortsighted not to educate all future employees to their fullest potential. And it is easier for a diverse group of employees to work together if they share common educational experiences. That makes school desegregation not just an essential political goal, but a matter of economic strength as well.

HEADLINE: The Clinton Challenge in Russia

 BODY:
President Clinton has dismissed Vladimir Zhirinovsky's surprisingly strong showing in Russia's election as a protest vote by citizens who may not have known much about him. But the support for this virulent nationalist may reflect more than the mood of the moment.
Many Russians fear radical reform and respond to the appeal of nationalism. They share Mr. Zhirinovsky's nostalgia for the good old days of empire when Russia kept "lesser breeds" under heel. 
 To head him off, President Boris Yeltsin may preach more populism and nationalism himself. That will make Americans uneasy and will frighten Poles, Czechs and others in Russia's neighborhood.
Mr. Zhirinovsky's showing raises two important issues for the Clinton Administration. Should it continue to push for economic reforms that could jeopardize the reformers' political survival by identifying them too closely with the West and by increasing misery among the Russian people? And what should it do to reassure jittery Eastern Europeans -- extend NATO membership to them at the risk of an anti-Western reaction in Russia?
Mr. Zhirinovsky's 78 seats will give him a loud but not decisive voice in the new 450-member State Duma, the lower house of Parliament. The Communist Party and its rural ally, the Agrarian Party, will have another sizable bloc. While these two parties will resist reform, they are less likely to form a feared "Red-Brown" coalition with Mr. Zhirinovsky than to hold themselves out as an alternative to him and to the democratic reformers.
The threat from the far right and old left may finally compel the reformers to coalesce, but it will probably strengthen the gradualists. Indeed, some reformers are backtracking. The U.S. has no need to push a particular pace or brand of economic reform. It can back reformers of all stripes so long as they do not return Russia to its old autocratic ways.
Washington must also do much more to reassure Eastern Europe. The best approach is to lower barriers to trade and immigration and open the door to closer security cooperation. But it is provocative to talk about NATO membership prematurely. It is vital to keep NATO intact as insurance in case Russia really becomes belligerent; NATO doesn't need another divisive debate now.
For now Eastern Europeans have at least as much to fear from one another as from Russia. The resurgence of Russian nationalism is a long way from reviving the Red Army and moving to restore the empire.
Extending NATO's security guarantee to Eastern Europe now while excluding Russia would only fire up Russian nationalism and seriously weaken Russia's reformers. And Americans are no more ready to commit their troops in Eastern Europe than they were eager to intervene in Bosnia.
Past Western appeasement that led to the dismemberment of Eastern Europe half a century ago hangs heavy on the hearts and minds of many Eastern Europeans. But the appeasers of the 1930's faced a Hitler already in power. Today's challenge is to keep a new Hitler from taking power, in Russia or elsewhere. That means reassuring Eastern Europeans without isolating Russia and undermining its reformers.
