HEADLINE: Millions for Us, Pennies for You

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
BEATRICE GINDEA thought the lawyers were on her side. Now she's not so sure.
In 1988, the retiree invested $10,000 -- a large chunk of her nest egg -- in a real estate fund sponsored by Prudential-Bache Securities through the firm's Morristown, N.J., office. It seemed like a good investment -- Prudential guaranteed her 12 percent annually for three years, and then all her money back. But the promises were false, and the investment collapsed. 
 Last month, when the check to settle her claim against Prudential and other defendants finally arrived, Mrs. Gindea was aghast. "Out of the $10,000, I thought I would only see 50 percent of it back," she said. Instead, she got $423.53. For every dollar she had invested, Mrs. Gindea received a bit more than four pennies.
"I was astonished," Mrs. Gindea said. "I thought I was being cheated."
Meanwhile, the law firm that represented Mrs. Gindea and thousands of others in the class action was paid as much as $6 million in fees, plus expenses. Adding to the sting, some investors in the same fund who sued separately came away with far more money -- sometimes more than 100 percent of their investment, plus interest and legal fees.
Many thousands of limited-partnership investors like Mrs. Gindea are learning the troubling truth about class-action litigation brought in their names. Without ever going to the effort of a trial to fight for a better deal, the law firms representing these investors can win approval for settlements of a few cents on the dollar for their clients while pocketing millions of dollars -- even tens of millions -- in legal fees for themselves. The class-action lawyers argue that their clients could have done no better, but that is cold comfort for those who watch some fellow investors who have hired their own lawyers go to trial or arbitration and then come away fully compensated.
Even more frustrating for such investors, anyone who is part of a class-action settlement waives all rights to further claims, even if the Government later affirms accusations of fraud against the partnership. For example, investors who earlier settled with Prudential in class actions for a small fraction of their investment are excluded from sharing in a fund of $371 million set up in October to repay some losses by customers who had been falsely assured about the safety and returns of the partnerships.
 
The Players
 A number of law firms have staked out business in class actions involving limited partnerships. Milberg Weiss Bershad Specthrie & Lerach, in New York City, for example, represented Mrs. Gindea. Bernstein Litowitz Berger & Grossmann, also in New York, is the lead counsel in the action involving the Prudential Bache Energy Income Funds.
But the most active in the field may well be the small Chicago law firm called Beigel & Sandler Ltd. Run by Herbert Beigel, a onetime prosecutor of mob members, it has made millions off the travails of limited-partnership investors. And some critics say the amounts it has made and the way it has done so epitomize what is wrong with this part of the legal system.
A review of cases involving the firm by The New York Times shows that Beigel & Sandler has never taken a significant class action to trial, settling rather than fighting for a bigger award even when it had a strong case. At the same time, the firm that so many investors are trusting to recover their investments has been repeatedly criticized by Federal judges for sloppy legal work and frivolous filings.
But Mr. Beigel said such criticism and setbacks are the price of playing in the class-action arena. He said the small amounts he wins for investors in class-action settlements are better than what would come out of a case that goes to court, where many judges have no sympathy for those they view as having gambled on an investment and lost.
"That's the reason you see cheap settlements," Mr. Beigel said. "These cases have a chance of losing and they are thrown out constantly."
In the settlements that have been reached, Mr. Beigel said, "we like to think we have done a good job in some very difficult cases."
But Mr. Beigel does not dismiss critics out of hand. "No one should be in a class action who has a strong individual claim," he said, "except for a person whose claim is of such small monetary value that it would be economically unfeasible to bring a claim any other way."
Those kinds of small-claim cases are largely responsible for the rapid growth in class actions over the last two decades. Such litigation has been used in many kinds of disputes, from product liability to price fixing, and lawyers often receive multimillion-dollar fees from the settlements. But class actions alleging fraud at investment partnerships are notable in that most plaintiffs have suffered huge losses rather than small ones, and therefore have a lot more to lose in an unsatisfactory settlement.
One problem is that lawyers representing investors in a class action don't need their approval of a settlement. Of course, investors can opt out of a class action and sue on their own. But most can't afford it.
Given the outcome of many of the limited-partnership class actions, some experts are asking whether the time has come for reform.
"Class actions are not an appropriate vehicle for people who have lost substantial sums of money," said Samantha Rabin, senior editor of Securities Arbitration Commentator, a newsletter in Maplewood, N.J. "The only people who make money in these are the claimants' lawyers, and the defendants themselves, who shut off a lot of potential liability."
Many critics hesitate to raise objections, in part because class actions are the only option for some investors, particularly those without money for legal fees or with losses too small to attract lawyers willing to work for a portion of what they win. Nevertheless, some are urging efforts to disclose more clearly to investors what they would receive in a settlement, to force higher standards in determining a deal's fairness, and to insure that fees reflect how clients fared.
"We don't want to turn back the clock and restrict plaintiff's attorneys from bringing suit," said Nancy Smith, New Mexico's securities regulator. "But we should take a sober view and make an assessment of how investors are faring in these kinds of class actions and determine what reforms might be necessary."
A GOOD place to begin that assessment might be at Beigel & Sandler. Flip through the filings in most major class actions against limited partnerships, and chances are its name will pop up.
Beigel & Sandler was the lead counsel in one of two 1991 settlements involving investments with VMS Realty that were sold through the firm now known as Prudential Securities. It was lead counsel in settlements involving Prudential deals sponsored by Clifton Harrison, a convicted felon whose past was not disclosed to investors. The firm also participated in the settlement involving the Prudential energy income partnerships. And it was lead counsel in reaching a settlement with Merrill Lynch over the Arvida partnerships.
Many of these deals have been widely criticized as inadequate. "From what I have seen of their previous cases, they have generally settled for a small fraction of the recovery sought," James Beckley, a Chicago lawyer who is a member of the Securities Industry Conference on Arbitration, said of Beigel & Sandler.
The class action involving VMS Realty illustrates how firms can accept low-paying settlements, sometimes sacrificing some investor protections, yet still collect large fees.
The $25 million deal Beigel & Sandler negotiated left investors with less than two cents on the dollar. But Beigel & Sandler walked away with more than $6 million in fees -- the 25 percent typically authorized by the court in class actions -- as well as $350,000 for expenses and additional fees for administering the settlement fund. For all that money, the firm did less court work than some lawyers representing individual clients who went to court or arbitration to fight for full compensation. Those lawyers made far less money for their efforts.
As part of the settlement, Beigel & Sandler waived the rights the investors had, through their partnership agreement, to approve of any future sales of properties held by the VMS partnerships. This created "the potential for sales that might benefit VMS and not provide cash to the investors, but instead leave them with a big tax bill to pay," said Jack VanWoerkom, a real estate consultant in Marblehead, Mass.
All in all, "it was a great deal for the defendant, and it was a great deal for Beigel & Sandler, but it was a pretty lousy deal for the investors," Mr. VanWoerkom said.
Mr. Beigel said the settlements were low because the cases would have been very hard to prove in a trial. Indeed, he said that shortly after some of the defendants settled part of the VMS case, suits against other defendants were thrown out.
But others see it differently. The problem, say legal experts, is that once a deal is on the table, any class-action lawyer would find it hard to walk away from the millions in fees.
"THE lawyers' interest shifts from protecting the investor to protecting the deal," said John L. Grayson, a Houston lawyer who represents a number of plaintiffs involved in Prudential litigation. "If there is not a deal, the attorneys don't get paid, and the litigation drags on."
The only protection for investors comes from the judges who must determine that a deal is fair before approving it. But too often, lawyers said, the judges are under pressure to get the deal done.
Only by writing to the court with a declaration to opt out can an investor reject the settlement. Many of these people are unsophisticated in finance and law, yet must decide whether to walk away on the basis of a disclosure notice written in thick legalese.
"People don't understand the class-action notices, even people who have been relatively successful in business," Mr. Beckley said.
The notices are written by lawyers, and approved by a judge. But everyone involved -- from the plaintiffs' lawyers looking for fees, to the defendant hoping to close off liability, to the judge interested in cleaning out the docket -- has an interest in getting the deal approved. That, some lawyers say, causes all the parties to approve confusing language that leads investors to accept the deal.
HERBERT BEIGEL cut his teeth in Chicago in the early 1970's as part of the Justice Department's organized-crime strike force. A decade ago he formed his own firm with a single associate, just as Wall Street was quickening its drive to sell limited partnerships in assets like real estate and oil. With the collapse of many partnerships, Mr. Beigel found a niche.
Today, Mr. Beigel -- with offices in New York and Los Angeles, and teamed with Louis Sandler, a lawyer in Manhattan -- oversees some 40 lawyers, with specialties not only in limited partnerships but also matrimonial and entertainment law.
Beigel & Sandler has re-invented the class action to what critics say is the firm's own benefit. Where in a conventional class action lawyers assume all risk, with payment fixed as a percentage of money won, Beigel & Sandler in some cases requires each investor to put up a retainer of as much as several thousand dollars.
Mr. Beigel said that clients in such cases, which he calls group actions, do better than those in class actions, because once there is a settlement, there are fewer people with whom to divide the pot, because only those who pay are part of the group.
But critics say that group actions allow Beigel & Sandler to pursue cases while shifting the risk onto the clients. Moreover, at the end, the firm's fees are not subject to court approval, as they would be in a traditional class action, because technically the lawyer and the client have already agreed on fees.
Beigel & Sandler at times spends more on a case than might have been expected, simply because the firm is ordered so often by judges to pay sanctions for doing a bad job.
Sometimes, the judges criticize the firm for submitting silly claims that evidence little work. "The court is confronted with 27 equally frivolous complaints filed by the same law firm, Beigel & Sandler," wrote Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan in April 1992 in Kushner v. D.B.G. Properties (a limited partnership). "It appears to the court as if the complaints were spun out of a word-processed original, with little attention to the details of each partnership and its private placement memorandum. Each complaint is as groundless as the next."
Judge Griesa ordered the firm to pay some $25,000 to the defendants for legal costs.
Mr. Beigel makes no apologies for the case, and its outcome tells a good deal about the firm's method of operation. Even before Judge Griesa's decision, Mr. Beigel said, the defendants had settled for a sizable sum.
ANOTHER case where the firm took it on the chin is Crigler v. Pennzoil. In that case, Texaco bondholders claimed they had been damaged by Pennzoil's pursuit of its $10 billion judgment against the oil company for interfering with Pennzoil's contract to purchase stock in Getty Oil. The judge in the case dismissed the bondholders' case, saying that the claimants were essentially trying to punish Pennzoil for pursuing its legal claims.
"Thus is born a new star in our rogues' gallery of frivolous lawsuits," wrote Judge Gerard L. Goettel of the Federal District Court in Manhattan. "This case is a bit of nonsense, a transparent petition for a license to mine in Pennzoil's deep pockets, and I will not allow it. Indeed, we feel compelled to return the favor, and allow the defendants to rummage a bit in the plaintiffs' pockets." Beigel & Sandler was ordered to pay Pennzoil's legal costs for this case.
Mr. Beigel thinks his clients had a decent claim. "If you are not going to bring a case you believe has merit because a judge might take a look at it and penalize you, then you are not being a good lawyer," he said.
Questions about the quality of the firm's legal work were also raised last May by Judge James B. Zagel of Federal District Court in Chicago.
In this class-action case, Williams v. Balcor Pension Investors, Beigel & Sandler argued that the prospectuses of a number of partnerships were misleading. But while the firm had named six plaintiffs to represent the investors, Judge Zagel ruled that none met the necessary standard, which says that the plaintiffs must be typical of the class they represent.
Three of the plaintiffs had never read the prospectus in question. Another, identified as a trustee for a trust that had invested in the partnerships, in fact no longer held that job, so had no right to sue. Some plaintiffs were included in the case before the firm even spoke with them.
"Beigel & Sandler's investigation of the proposed class representatives was woefully inadequate," Judge Zagel wrote, adding that the troubles showed the firm's "inadequacy as class counsel."
Mr. Beigel was undeterred, saying that the case is still going, with a new set of class representatives.
For all the criticism, Mr. Beigel shows no signs of slowing down. "In this business," he said, "you have to have a thick skin."
 
 
 
TRY, TRY AGAIN
 NO CLASS action involving limited partnerships has attracted more debate among lawyers and regulators than the 3-year-old case involving the Prudential Energy Income Funds, a series of oil partnerships. Small wonder: The financial fate of hundreds of thousands of investors who put $1.3 billion into the deals hangs on the outcome.
When the case was filed in 1990, little was known about the widespread fraud in the sale of limited partnerships that the Government now contends took place. Over two years, the class-action lawyers, led by Edward A. Grossmann, uncovered evidence of wrongdoing.
By last year, the team of lawyers, which included Beigel & Sandler, reached a settlement with Prudential that some lawyers criticized as paying only a few cents on the dollar. But Mr. Grossman argued that investors would be hard pressed to do better. "The terms of the settlement provide for fair and adequate compensation," he said last February.
The deal would have provided $37 million in cash, and rolled up the partnerships into a single publicly traded entity that would give stock to the partners. The lawyers could expect $7 million in fees, but as a sign of good faith, Mr. Grossmann asked that his fee be half in the new company's stock.
But in June, Judge Marcel Livaudais Jr. of Federal District Court in New Orleans, who is hearing the case, sided with critics. He said he had "serious reservations about the fairness of the proposed settlement."
About that time, bidders emerged for the partnerships. The winner, the Parker & Parsley Petroleum Company, paid investors $491 million.
By October, a new settlement had been struck for some $120 million in cash. Mr. Grossmann and the other lawyers again are arguing that this deal is fair, saying it gives investors the best of all worlds.
"Class members who want to participate are guaranteed of getting money, and in my opinion will get it faster" than through either arbitration or the fund established in Prudential's settlement with regulators, Mr. Grossman said. "But if they want to go another route, they can."
Others criticize the deal. "There is no justifiable reason why class-action plaintiffs should be treated like second-class citizens and receive only 15 percent of what they could in arbitration," said Stuart Goldberg, a lawyer in Austin with many Prudential cases.

HEADLINE: Crash Russian Course For Procter & Gamble

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
IN its brief but intense experience in the quirky Russian market, Procter & Gamble, the Cincinnati-based consumer products giant, has had to learn a few lessons.
Lesson No. 1: Shoppers need help learning about Western products. "I was in a store in Volgograd, and people kept coming up to me asking what this or that product actually does," said Peter Smit, who heads the company's Russian operations. "You have to put yourself in the shoes of the Russian consumer. She wants to be educated." 
 Lesson No. 2: Russians must be taught to make choices from a dizzying variety of goods. After 70 years of seeing stores stocked with whatever was available, not what consumers wanted, Russians are bewildered.
Take shampoo. Soviet shampoo did little more than wash hair, which was all shoppers needed to know -- assuming they even found it on the shelves. Now beauty-care counters in many urban stores are groaning with variety -- French, German and American; for damaged, oily or dry hair.
Procter & Gamble, which in January 1992 introduced Vidal Sassoon's Wash and Go, is doing its best to help shoppers cope with variety. Of nine Procter & Gamble products on the market, four come with instructions in Russian. (On the back of the Wash and Go bottle, it adds a helpful hint in Russian -- "wash hair and go.")
Lesson No. 3: Russians who have extra money are willing to spend it on quality. And a lot of them do have it. As Western companies move in, many find that people have more disposable income than official statistics would indicate.
Procter & Gamble is not alone in this classroom. In the last year, imported products -- from shampoos to pet food -- have poured into Moscow and St. Petersburg, which together have a population of 15 million. What started as a trickle of often bootlegged goods traded on a crazy jumble of street markets and sidewalk kiosks has moved into the shops, heralded by a steady patter of Western television commercials (with Russian voice-overs).
The recently established American Chamber of Commerce in Moscow estimates that 500 to 700 American companies are now doing business in Russia, compared with 100 a year ago.
True, the market is still small: according to Procter & Gamble's surveys, only 10 to 15 percent of the population can afford Western brands, which generally cost at least three times their Russian-made equivalents.
But the long lines at the beauty-care counter at Moscow's elegant Petrovsky arcade, with its attractive display of Western goods, show that there are buyers. Tatyana Petrova, 50, a retired flight attendant from the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, recently spent about 60,000 rubles -- $50, or two-thirds of an average Russian's monthly salary -- on a monthly shopping spree.
"I like pretty things, and I can afford them," said Mrs. Petrova, who has virtually written off Russian-made goods. Her shopping bag revealed a brand-consciousness that Western companies could only dream of a year ago. Lancome face powder and Orlane cream for herself, Oil of Olay moisturizer for her daughter, Colgate toothpaste for the family and Old Spice aftershave for her husband, an evidently successful businessman.
Other shoppers were more modest but no less committed to their choices. Natasha Geyorgyan, a teacher, had come to buy Pantene shampoo because a commercial said it was kind to damaged hair. Sofiya Pavlova, a retiree, was in line for Blend-a-Med toothpaste because of its pleasant taste and Camay soap for its nice smell. The prices, she admitted, were high -- 1,470 rubles for the toothpaste, 860 for the soap -- but, she said cheerfully, her son made a good salary.
"A year and a half ago, most companies doing business in Russia were industrial -- I.B.M., G.E. and the like," said Bruce Macdonald, chief Moscow representative for BBDO, the advertising agency. "Now they are mostly packaged-goods companies scrambling for their share of the market."
Why now? For one thing, the ruble, after holding steady for several months at about 1,200 to the dollar, is now effectively convertible, so companies can take local earnings and translate them into hard currencies without going through tortuous barter deals.
But other hurdles remain, like the Russian Government's recent announcement that on Jan. 1 it will impose higher import duties on a wide range of goods. Add this to the confused political situation, and many Western businesses still keep their distance.
"It is still early," said John E. Pepper, Procter & Gamble's president for international business, here on a short trip recently. He called the market a baby that's "alive and kicking but with a lot of growing up to do."
Procter & Gamble, with worldwide sales of $30.43 billion, began operations in St. Petersburg in August 1991; its first partner was Leningrad State University, which is involved in joint research projects and proved helpful in finding office space and providing introductions to bureaucrats.
A year after putting Wash and Go on the St. Petersburg market, Procter & Gamble moved on to Moscow with products like Tix and Ariel detergents, Camay soap, Head and Shoulders and Pantene Pro-V shampoos, Oil of Olay, Blend-a-med and Old Spice. The prices are steep by Russian standards -- 7,100 rubles for Oil of Olay day cream (nearly 8 percent of the average monthly salary) and 8,400 for Old Spice after-shave.
"At a certain point," Mr. Smit said, "we want to branch out" beyond the two cities. "But in a country like this, you have to go step by step."
The company crossed a threshold last month when it signed an agreement with a detergent-manufacturing plant in Novomoskovsk 130 miles south of Moscow; it has been producing Ariel detergent there since December 1992. Procter & Gamble will buy 14 percent of the company's shares and invest $50 million over five years, after which it will become the plant's majority owner.
Most marketing companies here are moving slowly toward local production. First you introduce your product, said Joseph F. Condon, a former RJR Nabisco executive who has set up his own consulting company in Moscow. Next you assemble it locally and then move to production. "Those are the normal stages of development," he said.
Like other consumer companies, Procter & Gamble keeps a tight lid on information about its Russian operations -- refusing, for instance, to reveal sales volumes or production figures.
"The volumes are very low for the size of the country, but we are about where we expected it to be," Mr. Pepper said. The challenge, he said diplomatically, is "price and affordability" -- how to reach a market where most people have little money.
"We are pricing as low as we can," he said.
Mr. Pepper made his first scouting trip here in 1990, when it was still the Soviet Union. "With all the challenges that remain, what has happened so far is miraculous," he said, with the caution of a man who has weathered his share of bureaucratic battles.
One surprise, he said, has been the diligence and eagerness of the young Russians hired to fill about 80 jobs here. Getting Westerners to join them remains a problem, however. "This is tough duty," he said, although he noted that there are always adventurers willing to take up the challenge.
The high cost of a Moscow operation is one reason it is still so difficult for companies to break even. "This is the most expensive city in Europe now," Mr. Macdonald said. "To put a $100,000 officer in Moscow will cost you $500,000," including housing, security and periodic trips out of the couuntry.
Distribution remains a nightmarish challenge. Procter & Gamble ships its products -- mostly from Europe -- by sea to St. Petersburg, a route that has spared it the tie-ups that now plague truck traffic on the border. But getting them from warehouse to stores is still a problem -- part of the "Big L," as Mr. Smit refers to his daily logistical headaches.
The confusion in Russian retailing -- where fly-by-night sidewalk kiosks still compete with state-owned stores -- is one of the most annoying aspects for foreign companies. The business has attracted both amateurs and con artists, and it is often hard to tell the difference.
But in some ways, approaching the Russian consumer has been easier than many companies expected. Brand recognition has not been a problem; Russians have always been acutely aware of foreign products, even when Western goods could be bought only from visitors, or on the black market.
"In those days, a Russian would never ask you to buy a video or a television," Mr. Macdonald said. "They would always ask for a Sony and give you the precise model number." The same applied to simpler products, from Marlboro cigarettes to Levi's jeans.
"Made in the West" remains a powerful lure for Russians, who remain suspicious of local brands and even of labels printed in the Cyrillic alphabet. Pepsi-Cola, which has bottled soft drinks here since Soviet times, now has to defend itself against the perception that it is somehow a local, with a low-quality product. Even Russian-produced Marlboros are proving a hard sell.
For Procter & Gamble, establishing brand recognition has not been any more difficult than anywhere else. Taking advantage of relatively cheap advertising rates (it costs 4 cents to reach a thousand viewers here, compared with $6 in the United States), it has kept up a steady television campaign.
BESIDES selling the products, the commercials offer viewers a glimpse of Western kitchens, clothes and life styles -- all of which contribute to the products' lure. Where the Russian market has shown its peculiarities is in the absence of brand loyalty among consumers, Mr. Smit noted. "If the product was on the shelf," he said, "then she bought it no matter how badly she needed it."
Now, even with more goods available, shoppers often go by their old instincts, snapping up what they see in case it disappears.
Some of the Russian consumer's special problems have been picked up in Procter & Gamble's ads, although most are repeats of commercials broadcast worldwide. But in a country where relatively few families have washing machines, commercials for detergents -- here as elsewhere, the company's best-selling products -- have to aim at women who wash clothes by hand, in buckets.
"You have to talk to them in a way that makes them see you understand their laundry problems," Mr. Smit said. "A Western consumer is trained to see commercials and will grasp the message. The Russian consumer needs extra words and images, not because she is dumb but because you have to show her how to use the product."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Russians, accustomed to little choice, now can sometimes find a variety of goods, as at this Moscow store. John E. Pepper, a Procter & Gamble executive, on a visit to Moscow. (Photographs by James Hill for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: GATT's Big Payoff for the U.S.

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
PROBABLY the most long-lasting benefit for the United States of the recently negotiated global trade pact isn't the most obvious, like being able to sell more beef to Europe and more supercomputers to Japan. Instead, it may be to encourage growth in many of the world's poor but aspiring nations. That -- contrary to the dire warnings of America's new isolationists like Pat Buchanan and Ross Perot -- would be good for most Americans, too, say most economists who focus on trade and growth.
"It's true that successful third world economies are competitors," said Paul Krugman, a trade economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "But they also become bigger markets for our products and they are also suppliers of better and cheaper products to our economy. Those benefits almost surely outweigh the adverse effects of increased competition." 
 Today, $4 of every $10 spent on jets, tractors, grain, movies and other American exports head for destinations outside of Canada, Japan and Europe, even though import barriers in much of Asia and Latin America are still as high as they used to be in the United States 40 years ago. What's more, even conservative growth forecasts suggest that the economies of less developed countries should grow two or three times as fast, on average, during the 1990's as those of the industrial nations.
"If 2 billion people get richer and smarter, will they buy more or less of our stuff?" David Rolley, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill who analyzes trade, asked rhetorically. "To ask the question is to answer it."
Briefly, the agreement reached last week under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will trim tariffs on manufactured products in most countries by one-third, giving exporters a leg up, and will ease barriers against grain imports. More important for many developing countries, the new GATT rules would gradually eliminate quotas on textiles and clothing, which have artificially held down third world exports by tens of billions of dollars a year, and make it much harder for any country to impose new quantitative restrictions, like America's now-defunct quotas on steel imports.
Apart from the obvious -- that making it cheaper to export will increase poor countries' incomes -- there are at least three reasons for thinking that these seemingly pedestrian provisions could make it easier for many developing countries to prosper.
First, the adoption of the GATT accord keeps rich countries -- overwhelmingly the most important export market for poor ones -- committed to keeping their markets open at a time when Europe and Japan are suffering their worst economic setbacks since the Great Depression, a time when protectionism became rampant.
The beneficiaries are not the poorest of the poor but the semi-industrial countries: India, China (which is not yet a GATT member) and Mexico as well as countries on the Pacific Rim and in Latin America.
"MARKET access and growth in exports is worth much, much more than all the aid in the world put together," said Sherman Robinson, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley who is an expert on Latin America. "You generate foreign exchange. You buy capital goods and supplies. You get the technology. On the product side, you learn by exporting."
He added, "What these countries want now is to be part of the game."
Further, the GATT agreement commits lower-income countries, which until the 1980's were for the most part pursuing highly protectionist, inward-oriented growth strategies, to continue opening their markets.
"In a way, the developing countries have really signed onto a program that the O.E.C.D. countries bought into in the 1950's and 60's," said Professor Robinson, referring to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a group of more than 20 industrialized nations. "The O.E.C.D. countries did well with trade liberalization. There's no reason why these countries can't perform comparably."
FINALLY, trade is vital for growth and seems to benefit nations that open their economies even in the short run.
"Economists used to have a gut feeling that trade liberalization meant short-term loss and long-term gain," said Michael Bruno, chief economist at the World Bank. "But now studies show that even in the short run you can't find job losses in the countries that unilaterally lowered trade barriers."
What happens, he said, is that imports lower the cost of many goods, which in turn increases workers' real purchasing power. Increased competition rechannels workers from inefficient to efficient industries, making employment more profitable.
In the longer run, the intangible benefits loom very large indeed. A new school of development economics emphasizes that ideas -- imitation, invention, innovation -- rather than resources are the elixir of growth, and trade is a prime vehicle for acquiring new ideas. Besides, relying on exports tends to discourage governments from pursuing self-destructive economic policies like high inflation, and that is also good for growth.
But what makes prosperity in the third world good for the United States?
Exports, for one thing. In part, America's export performance has lately been better than Europe's or Japan's because this country's companies have a better foothold in fast-growing markets like Brazil and Indonesia.
"GATT will make these countries push liberalization forward," said Gary Hufbauer, an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, noting that many countries from Mexico to Indonesia had lowered some of their trade barriers even before the GATT agreement. "Bigger hunks of our trade will be going to them."
A SECOND reason, one that no politician in these mercantilist times would admit, is imports.
"The worry I have is that the debate gets very mercantilist," said Professor Robinson at Berkeley. "Exports are supposed to be good and imports are supposed to be bad."
But as economists from Adam Smith onward have long recognized, the whole point of exporting is to be able to import -- just as the point of selling your labor is to be able to buy a doctor's services or groceries.
"If China expands production of toys or clothes, then that almost certainly raises America's real income because the United States is getting things cheaper," even though some American workers in the toy or clothing business may have to find new jobs, said Professor Krugman of M.I.T. "Plus China becomes a bigger market for U.S. airplanes and supercomputers."
More trade between the United States and the developing world should also increase opportunities for product specialization within many industries, as countries concentrate on products or components that they are best suited to make.
"The global specialization and division of labor is already happening," said Professor Robinson. "GATT facilitates this process by opening markets even further."
While some have argued that all manufacturing will move to low-wage countries -- the "giant sucking sound" Mr. Perot likes to talk about -- what has actually happened (between Germany and Spain, Japan and Malaysia and the United States and Mexico) is a growing specialization and an explosion of two-way trade in industries like cars and computers that has helped reinvigorate American industry.
"It's Adam Smith with a vengeance," Professor Robinson said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1646 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: December 12 - 17

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
Believe It or Not, a GATT Agreement (With Some Holes)
When seven years of world trade talks ended last week -- on schedule! -- it was really a bow to the inevitable. For even as political flash fires flare worldwide, the business world is rapidly making borders irrelevant -- a reality negotiators recognized in cutting many tariffs and moving toward ending subsidies. The goal was clear: raise everyone's living standards. And the cheers were equally clear. "The world has chosen openness and cooperation," said Peter Sutherland, GATT's director general. There was also a sense that in the deadline dash, negotiators lopped off anything sticky -- like a late spat over European limits on American movies -- to deal with another day. President Clinton met his "fast track" goal, however -- Congress must vote "yes" or "no," not amend the pact to death. A comment by France's Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, best captures the mood: "I never want to hear the word GATT again." 

Wisconsin Takes On Welfare
Wisconsin agrees on one thing: welfare needs an overhaul. What it can't agree on is a solution. Sounds familiar. Wisconsin, though, wants to probe this frontier. Last week, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson signed a law pledging, by 1999, to replace Federal welfare with a state plan. But all is not unity. Mr. Thompson, a Republican, has a time-worn formula: give business hiring incentives. Democrats have their own time-worn formula: create public-service jobs. Not an original idea in sight. But given the sorry state of the current system -- "a jailer of people," one Democrat called it -- Mr. Thompson has a point when he says, "The best thing to do is to start over fresh."
 
A November Spending Spree
People must really think the economy's out of the woods, because even last month, when shopping could easily be put off, they spent up a storm. The Commerce Department said last week that November retail sales rose 0.4 percent, a solid eighth straight rise. Americans spent nearly $180 billion, or about $700 for every woman, man and child. (Did they need that stuff? Don't ask.) And they're looking to the future, too: sales of durable goods provided the power, rising 0.9 percent. ("Durable" goods, by the way, are those meant to last three years.)
 
A Lucite Hyena! How Lovely!
You unwrap the package with trepidation, struggling to keep that joyful smile on your face, and there it is, the gift from hell -- the after-shave (you have a beard), the turtleneck (you loathe turtlenecks), the book you'll never read (but will take up shelf space till the statute of obligations runs out), the demitasse cups (does anyone use these?). What a waste, you sigh, and move glumly to the next gift. But this is an age when even sighs must be counted, so it's no surprise that one economist has put a dollar figure on that waste. In The American Economic Review, Joel Waldfogel, of Yale, estimates that of $40 billion spent annually on gifts, $4 billion, possibly even $10 billion or so, is a "deadweight loss" -- the difference between what the giver spends and the value the recipient puts on the gift. Like all Scrooges, though, he'll get his. Now, as he readily admits, "I'm afraid I may not get as many gifts."
 
Annenberg 'Bomb' for Schools
"I felt I had to drop a bomb on the situation," Walter Annenberg said. An apt image, for what spurred him to action last week was the growing violence in schools -- "so many youngsters," he lamented, "with knives and revolvers." And Mr. Annenberg, who at 85 has made billions in publishing ventures like TV Guide, can afford one heck of a "bomb." He's giving $500 million to groups involved in school reform, the largest single gift ever to public education.
 
Going Without Health Insurance
Lest anyone dream that the health care crisis will ease on its own, Government data showed last week that it's only getting worse. In 1992, the report said, the number of people without health insurance hit 38.9 million, up 2.3 million from 1991 -- a rise greater than in the two previous years combined. Not surprisingly, half the people making less than $10,000 lack coverage. But the problem is not just at small companies and among the unemployed -- the major trouble spots. Fully 19 percent of the uninsured are in the families of those who work for companies with more than 1,000 workers. No one is safe from this epidemic.
 
COMPANIES
 
A Bit Less Bloody at Toys 'R' Us
Hooded vampires stalk scantily clad sorority girls. If they catch them, they drill into their necks and drain their blood. Only the wide-eyed child at the controls can stop them. Wholesome stuff, right? Some people think so. Tom Zito, head of Digital Pictures, which makes the Sega game called Night Trap, says it's "actually very benign and is designed as a parody of a vampire movie." Yes, one can just hear some scholarly 10-year-old: "Awesome parody, dude!" But if kids aren't scared, retailers are (because, perhaps, the Senate is even now pondering curbs on video game violence?). Last week Toys 'R' Us stopped selling Night Trap, and F.A.O. Schwarz followed suit. "I'm thrilled," said Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut, a crusader against violent games. "This will help parents raise their children and not leave it to the video-game industry."
 
Con Ed Indicted for Blast
After a 1989 steam-pipe explosion in Manhattan, the Government says, Con Edison did not let on for four days that the blast had spewed out 200 pounds of asbestos. Last week Con Ed and two of its retired officials were indicted on charges of concealing that knowledge.
 
Mixed Signals on Shawmut
Washington didn't quite get its signals straight on Shawmut National. Just last month the Federal Reserve, citing lending bias, blocked a planned acquisition by Shawmut, New England's No. 3 banking company. But last week, when the Justice Department settled its bias case against the bank, Attorney General Janet Reno went out of her way to praise the corrective steps Shawmut took months ago. Shawmut, though denying any bias, agreed to pay $10,000 to $15,000 to any black or Hispanic customer who could show possible discrimination. But the Justice Department said the violations were from 1990 to 1992. Was the Fed a latecomer?
 
Lucky Stores Comes a Long Way
Diane Skillsky has been at Lucky Stores in California for 21 years, at one point working at a cash register next to her teen-age son. Her son was offered a shot at a better job; she wasn't. She, and a lot of others, refused to take it anymore. In a decade-long sex-discrimination battle, Lucky insisted that women weren't promoted because they didn't want better jobs. (Just as the homeless like it on the street.) But last week Lucky agreed to pay $75 million in damages to 14,000 women and to invest $20 million in affirmative action, one of the largest sex-bias settlements ever. Said Ms. Skillsky: "This is a great day." And you can bet the rest of the grocery industry was watching very, very closely.
 
At Kodak, No Quick Fixes
Wall Street often thinks that one mere mortal can instantly reverse a corporate giant's fortunes. Sometimes it gets a rude reminder of its naivete. In October, when Eastman Kodak named George M. C. Fisher as chairman, replacing Kay R. Whitmore, who'd been criticized for being too timid a cost-cutter, Kodak stock shot up. But last week, Mr. Fisher said, in effect, "Wait a second, folks, it's not that easy." Forget record earnings next year, he said, "it looks more challenging." And, going right to that sacred issue, he added, "Cost-cutting alone is not the long-term answer." That did it. End of honeymoon. The shares plunged to Whitmore levels and below, losing $7.25 in a day, ending the week at $55.25.
 
United's Unions Try Again
United Airlines' unions made yet another stab at buying control of the airline last week, in a complex deal that includes concessions on wages and work rules. But investors were wary: even though the deal is valued at $173 a share, the stock fell to $143.375 by week's end.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
At Ford, Trade Pact Means Jobs
Backers of the North American Free Trade Agreement must have applauded. They'd said all along that the accord would mean more American jobs, not fewer, and last week some corroborating evidence bubbled out of the economy's laboratory: Ford said it would build its new compact cars in both Mexico and the United States and greatly increase exports to Mexico. The rejiggering of its operations, it said, will create 550 jobs in the United States and Canada and 300 in Mexico. One swallow does not make the case, though; this week some company may well slash payrolls, pinning the blame on the trade accord.
 
German Engineering Meets U.S. Accounting
Daimler-Benz badly wants to expand its horizons beyond a recession-battered Germany, but it's discovering that each step has a price. Planning to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange soon, it agreed to report its earnings the American way, stricter than the German method that allows moving funds in and out of reserves. But at the moment of truth, that fine point led to two starkly different numbers. Daimler said last week that in the first nine months of 1993 it lost $105 million -- but that ballooned to $1.19 billion under American accounting. True, Mercedes sales have improved, and it has plans for a new Alabama plant. But with that new number, one wonders if American investors will see the shares as quite so desirable.
 
Japan's Trade Surplus Slips
It took a while, but it's happening. The pricey yen is finally putting a dent in Japan's trade surplus, which has made Japan highly unpopular the world over. Last week, Tokyo reported that the surplus fell 2.2 percent in November from the year-earlier figure, the first such decline in nearly three years.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Westerners in Russia's Rough Weather

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
IMAGINE trying to launch a Russian investment fund last week. That was the unenviable task facing the Framlington Group, a London-based fund manager that had spent a year setting up a plan to attract Western capital and invest it in small and medium-sized Russian enterprises.
Yet despite the political chaos that engulfed Moscow in the wake of last weekend's parliamentary elections, Framlington's launch went smoothly. Along with two government-funded international agencies -- the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the World Bank's International Finance Corporation -- a hardy band of institutional investors, mostly from Britain, Europe and America, pledged more than $60 million to the fund, exceeding Framlington's $50 million goal. 
 "We've seen political crises come and go, and it has not affected underlying business opportunities in Russia," said Connell Gallagher, an investment analyst at Framlington. Mr. Gallagher, however, was one of the few analysts in Europe with nice things to say about Russia.
The strong showing of the ultra-nationalist Liberal Democratic party led by Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky sent shudders through European markets. Nowhere were the fears more apparent than in Frankfurt, where the DAX index fell sharply on Tuesday after Mr. Zhirinovsky was quoted as saying that he would not hesitate to use nuclear force against Germany.
Analysts said the nervousness about Russia was a factor in erratic performances in Paris, London and other European financial markets as well.
"The bond markets must hope that Yeltsin continues to outwit the growing threat to his position," said a report from Natwest Markets in London, referring to Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin.
The jitters were to some extent the usual first reaction of investors to political uncertainty in any big country. Some analysts, however, said the Russia factor could prove to be much more than a short-term phenomenon in the markets. In their view, the elections could cause political and military shifts with profound effects on foreign policy and on the economies of Russia and the West.
"The front-line Western European stock markets will be gradually hit over a long period as uncertainty in Russia rises," said David C. Roche, the global strategist at Morgan Stanley in London. "Remember, this is a creeping social cancer, not a coup."
Mr. Roche said that markets in Germany, Austria and Finland would be most vulnerable because of geography and politics, and because they are near record highs.
But he added that any major shift to the right in Russian foreign and domestic policy could spark responses in the West that would be felt far more broadly throughout the European markets. If the decline in military spending in the West has to be reversed, for example, many of the economic and budgetary assumptions underpinning investment decisions would have to be thrown out.
"It's going to affect all kinds of things in the West, and the West hasn't even begun to think about it yet," Mr. Roche said.
The results of the Russian elections were digested by the European markets during a week in which investors had plenty on which to chew.
There was the final deal on liberalizing world trade, widely viewed as a plus for the economies of Western Europe. Germany's Bundesbank said it saw inflation weakening, suggesting that it would continue to cut interest rates, but said it would adopt stricter targets for money-supply growth.
A sharp fall in unemployment in Britain heartened investors who have been looking for evidence that their faith in the British recovery was not misplaced. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares closed Friday at an all-time high of 3,337.1, up 75.8 points for the week, reflecting both the improved outlook for corporate earnings among British companies and the prospect of further interest-rate cuts.
In Frankfurt, the DAX index closed at 2,151.02 on Friday, down just over 10 points for the week. The CAC-40 in Paris closed at 2,196.44 on Friday, down 1.7 points for the week.
The markets gave hardly any notice to the trade deal completed under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. "Everyone expected GATT to pass, and it was fully priced into the market," Mr. Roche said. "The Russian thing is not in the market, and so far people want to ignore it."
Investors within Russia were clearly nervous about the prospects for continued progress toward a free-market system. There was a drop of nearly 20 percent in the price of Russia's only widely traded security, the vouchers used to purchase shares in businesses that are being privatized.
Despite having $60 million on the line, Mr. Gallagher of Framlington, the fund manager, was more sanguine. President Yeltsin, he said, had proved himself repeatedly to be an economic reformer, and with the nation having granted him enhanced powers under the new constitution approved in the vote last weekend, the Russian leader would have the chance to keep the nation heading down the road to capitalism.
"There's a huge lack of capital in Russia, and there's almost no long-term financing, but there's a lot being sold," said Mr. Gallagher, who said the fund would concentrate on investments in companies that have joint ventures with Western partners.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
New Future for Dreyfus Investors

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne

 BODY:
FOR Howard Stein, the chairman of the Dreyfus Corporation, the union of his company with Mellon Bank is more a realization of a long-held vision of a new world for investors than just a dollars-and-cents transaction.
His vision is that banks and mutual funds will eventually combine to create a new breed of financial institution that will provide a broader array of products than either institution can provide on its own. This reflects his fundamental belief that bank savers, who are now fleeing bank deposit accounts because of low interest rates, are never going to return once they've tasted the more exciting -- and potentially more financially rewarding -- world of investing. 
 "For a long time, I've felt that a new financial service institution was going to come into being," Mr. Stein said in an interview in his expansive and modern midtown Manhattan office just a few days after the Dreyfus-Mellon arrangement was announced on Dec. 6. The merger would create one of the largest pools of assets under management -- $84.4 billion, an amount in the same league with financial powerhouses like the California Public Employees Retirement System, Fidelity Investments and the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Fund.
"As we see bank savers becoming investors, they will not go back to being passbook savers when interest rates rise," said Mr. Stein, who is 67 years old and has headed Dreyfus since 1970. "The investment side of banks will completely and totally overshadow the savings side, and savings will become like the buggy whip. This is an inevitable change."
For Dreyfus's existing customers in its 125 funds, any changes from the merger will not be apparent for a while. But by the end of the summer, Dreyfus and Mellon will have a new computer system to provide investment advice, something Dreyfus does not now do, and more offerings. These offerings will not be new funds but services now offered by Mellon's century-old trust department.
"This is not going to be two institutions just cross-selling products," Mr. Stein said. "It will be a new way of serving people on all segments of their financial needs in one place for their entire lives."
He specifically plans to have Dreyfus work closely with Mellon's trust department to provide a cradle-to-grave set of products and services that Dreyfus does not offer on its own, including legal and estate planning. "You know Toys 'R' Us?" Mr. Stein said. "This will be Financial Services 'R' Us. All financial services in one system at a reasonable price."
Behind this strategy are some telling numbers. According to Mr. Stein, nearly 80 percent of Dreyfus's 900,000 customers have only about 20 percent of their assets with Dreyfus. Because of this, Mr. Stein said the purpose of the union with Mellon was not to get new client names but to further penetrate Dreyfus's existing client base.
"We want to be involved with personal-wealth building," Mr. Stein said. "We needed to be associated with a bank trust department to do that. We're not interested in selling a product in a bank lobby."
His vehicle for doing this is a computerized "superstation" that will be available to Dreyfus staff by the end of the summer to provide detailed investment and demographic information about clients.
"We will be able to give advice on which mutual fund to buy," Mr. Stein said. "If you have to deal with issues of wills or 401K planning, it will advise you what investments are most appropriate for you. It will be a total management program for people from the beginning of their investing lives through retirement. This is the perfect system to be used in association with a bank trust department."
Mr. Stein, who will become the largest shareholder in Mellon with shares valued at nearly $60 million, believes that other banks that want to expand into mutual funds do not necessarily have to run out and buy a fund company. Rather, he feels they can build on their existing trust departments. This may be a slower process than an acquisition. But, Mr. Stein said, it is an alternative many banks have overlooked.
"Banks already have an asset in their system, and the question is how to make that asset work for them," he said. "They have to learn how to sell that as a service instead of offering a product here and there. Banks can use the asset of their trust department and don't have to go through all the complications of a merger. Mellon's service ability and trust department was what this merger was all about."
Mr. Stein said he was so intrigued by the notion of bank-mutual fund combinations that he bought a bank several years ago -- one with less than $40 million in assets -- to learn how banks work. The bank, the Dreyfus Security Savings Bank, based in Paramus, N.J., has a mortgage banking operation and had a credit card operation that was sold.
"I wanted to learn about the banking business because I had a feeling they would come together," Mr. Stein said. "Now I see that as inevitable. And now that Mellon and Dreyfus are together, I think we're in advance of other institutions."

HEADLINE: Manager's Profile

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:

Richard B. Hoey
Fund: Dreyfus Growth and Income. $1.2 billion in assets. Manager since inception, Dec. 31, 1991. (Sponsor: Dreyfus Funds, New York.)
 
Born: May 8, 1943; Verona, N.J.
 
Education: B.A. in politics and economics, Yale University; M.B.A., New York University.

HEADLINE: NEEDIEST CASES;
Mother of Two Finds Material and Emotional Support

BYLINE: By Abby Goodnough

 BODY:
On the first bitter-cold night of December, Gail Adams roasts a chicken and digs out a dusty box of Christmas ornaments. A scraggly fir tree is propped up on the porch of her tiny white house, waiting to be decorated. Her children, Jessica and Ryan, dance dizzily around the tree as she prepares supper.
For Mrs. Adams, life is rarely this good. 
 Since she left her husband and moved from Long Island to Staten Island in 1990, she has lost three secretarial jobs because of the recession. She was injured in a car accident last May, and her old station wagon died a few months later. Her son, barely out of diapers, has been hospitalized three times for various illnesses.
The worst moment came on a chilly spring night last year when she tried to withdraw $20 from a bank machine and found she had a negative balance. That night, she learned that creditors had been authorized to take $2,500 from her account.
"I didn't even have money to buy diapers and milk," Mrs. Adams, 33, said in a quavery voice, brushing wisps of blond hair from her pale face. "I had to borrow from the neighbors. I couldn't think straight."
 
'I Wouldn't Have Made It'
 The next day, a friend told her to call Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York. But Mrs. Adams, who enjoyed a life of privilege as a child, was reluctant to pick up the phone.
"I've always been very independent, and I'm ashamed to ask for favors," she said. "But I wouldn't have made it through the week if I hadn't made that call."
Mrs. Adams is still incredulous that Catholic Charities gave her several boxes of food, $150 worth of vouchers for grocery shopping and $25 in cash. She kept in touch with case workers at the agency's Staten Island unit, and last Christmas they supplied her with an enormous holiday dinner and gifts for Jessica and Ryan.
"They brought two different kinds of pie and they even remembered whipped cream to put on top," she laughed. "If it wasn't for them, we wouldn't have had a Santa Claus."
Catholic Charities is one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which is conducting its 82d annual appeal for donations. All contributions go directly to the charities because The Times pays for the fund's expenses. This year's Neediest Cases appeal will end on Feb. 28.
 
Emotional Support
 Since Catholic Charities began helping Mrs. Adams, she said, she no longer has anxiety attacks or crying jags. She calls regularly to chat with caseworkers, and she has even donated several boxes of baby clothes to the agency.
"Whenever things get bad, they give me emotional support," she said. "They have been good friends."
As she slices an apple for her children, Mrs. Adams admits her life is far different from the one she planned for herself as a girl. The first book she read was a biography of Oliver Wendell Holmes, and she wanted to be a lawyer. She attended a Manhattan prep school and a four-year college in Boston where she received a degree in English. But since then, she has had two failed marriages and finds herself dogged from job to job by layoffs.
"My grandmother lived on Park Avenue and I spent my summers in Westhampton Beach," she said, her voice trailing off. "Look where it got me."
 
Barely Covering Expenses
 These days Mrs. Adams has a temporary job as an administrative assistant at a Manhattan real-estate development company. To get to work by 9 A.M., she must leave the house by 7, and she often does not return until after 7 P.M. She does not dare take a day off to stand in line and recertify for food stamps, she said, for fear that she would be dismissed.
Mrs. Adams loathes the long trips to and from work, which keep her from spending more time with her children. And her salary barely covers her expenses, which include $200 a week for baby sitters. But she said she would much rather have a low-paying job than collect welfare, which she did once before. If she were on welfare she would not be able to pay $575 a month for the four-room bungalow she has grown to love.
"When I lived in an apartment, the neighbors would treat me like dirt because I didn't have a husband," she said bitterly. "But this house is all mine, and nobody can tell me what to do. I come home every night and feel totally safe."
 
A Lonely Existence
 But Mrs. Adams also feels lonely. Both her parents are dead, and she has no siblings. Since she does not have a car, she leaves the house on weekends only to do laundry and buy groceries. She has not been to a movie theater in five years, and her last vacation was in 1985. More than anything, she said, she would like to go to church regularly.
"I've always wanted to go to midnight Mass on Christmas Eve," she said. "But there's nobody to stay with the kids, so I sit at home and watch television."
If she is offered a permanent job at the real-estate company, Mrs. Adams said, she will be able to save for a new car. Maybe she will have the money to send Ryan to nursery school.
Meanwhile there is a chicken in the oven and a Christmas tree to decorate. And there are Jessica and Ryan, who chase each other through the cramped rooms and brighten her mood with their giggles.
"Things might be easier without the kids, but everyone has to make sacrifices," she said. "Without them, I would have nothing."

HEADLINE: Inequity of Lobbying Deduction

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Congress's Wrong Turn on Lobbying" (Viewpoints, Nov. 28), Donald B. Susswein argues that the 1993 tax law's denial of Federal tax deductions for business lobbying expenses is not appropriate. However, he overlooks the similar penalty the tax code imposes on some forms of individual lobbying. 
 Of course, some benefits of individual lobbying, like increased civil liberties, are not subject to Federal income tax. But other individual lobbying can produce benefits that are reflected in higher taxable income.
Individuals can lobby for policies that would allow increased capital formation, foster job retraining, establish fair-hiring practices, bolster labor laws and trade protection and set higher minimum wages. Individuals can also press for measures that would increase the return on their taxable investments or reduce their state and local income and property taxes.
Since individuals are penalized because they are not allowed to deduct the costs of such lobbying while they must pay taxes on the associated benefits, it is unclear whether the 1993 tax law's imposition of a similar penalty on business lobbying is a step toward or away from a level playing field.
 
ALAN D. VIARD
Columbus, Ohio, Dec. 1
 
The writer is an assistant professor of economics at Ohio State University.

HEADLINE: Professional Pay Disparity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As the world turns away from the failed policies of managed economics, Derek Bok is advocating a return to the form of income controls that were integral to theoretical Communism. 
 Instead of advocating managing the incomes of those who are contributing to the creation of national wealth (business professionals) or those who have spent unending time and money becoming proficient in the medical or legal professions, why doesn't Mr. Bok comment on the excesses in the entertainment and sports industries?
And if Mr. Bok complains about the impoverishment in the educational field, he has only to relate its incomes to the hours of production to see that education's salary rates (plus the extravagant benefits) are on average probably among the highest.
 
CHARLES D. WERTHEIM
Dix Hills, L.I., Dec. 10
 
The writer recently retired as the owner of a printing business in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Marches Russia Toward Dictatorship;
Governing Better

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Marshall I. Goldman offers poor advice to Boris N. Yeltsin in "Yeltsin Needs a Fresh Mandate" (Op-Ed, Dec. 14) because, like many Western observers, he arranges the Russian context according to his own understanding of democracy. 
 Americans have no problem distinguishing political legitimacy from political competence. Elect a bunch of bums, and they are your bums until their terms expire, however badly they perform. If competence had anything to do with legitimacy in our system, we might be electing new officials every two weeks.
What sanctioned the czar was divine ordination. What sanctioned the Communist Party was the promise to overtake and outstrip the capitalist societies of the West, and the application of force when that promise proved idle. In simplest terms, the Soviet system dissolved mostly because it was not working well enough and because, in the end, no amount of force could have made it do better.
No new referendum will legitimize Mr. Yeltsin's regime in most Russian eyes, only an improvement in performance. As was abundantly clear to many of us who were in Moscow at the time, the October Days were a political and moral disaster because the regime handled the crisis so badly. The new parliament will be equally oppositional until Mr. Yeltsin's Government is legitimized by broad perceptions of social and economic betterment and a modicum of political stability, whatever its legal cover. A new referendum could bring chaos.
The regime needs to govern better. This requires taking into full account the vital forces of the country, fully revealed through the elections, and a better way than confrontation to diffuse those whose potential is destructive.
 
WILLIAM G. ROSENBERG
Prof. of Russian and Soviet History, University of Michigan
Ann Arbor, Mich., Dec. 14, 1993

HEADLINE: NEEDIEST CASES;
Remaining Hopeful Despite Troubles

 BODY:
Mary Sullivan awoke in a hospital bed, unaware that she had spent eight days on a respirator, unwilling to believe that a persistent cough had become pneumonia, and that the treatment had left her too weak to walk.
When the doctors explained that muscle relaxants she received during her treatment had caused her muscles to atrophy, she faced down her fear. She vowed to fight for her life and struggled through weeks of physical therapy, straining to breathe as she did leg lifts to regain her strength. 
 A devout Roman Catholic, she accepted six weeks in the hospital stoically. But when she was released 13 months ago and learned that the damage to her lungs had ended her working life, Ms. Sullivan broke down and wept.
"I always had work to look forward to," she said last week, sobbing briefly as she recalled being laid off from her job as office manager for a doctor in Brooklyn Heights. She had never married, and work, like the Church, had been a social focus of her life ever since she finished high school and took her first job as a secretary.
Although Ms. Sullivan misses most the social contacts and the feeling of usefulness that she found on the job, sudden unemployment brought financial hardship as well. Her savings disappeared quickly, and when her disability payments were delayed in a paperwork snarl last March, she found herself unable to pay for her medication or cover her electric bill.
 
'Falling Through the Cracks'
 Catholic Charities for the Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens covered the $150 shortfall with money raised by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, perhaps saving her from applying for public assistance. The agency is one of seven supported by the Neediest Cases Fund, which is now conducting its 82d annual campaign.
"It's amazing how little it takes to keep people from falling through the cracks," said Margaret Keavenig, a social worker at Catholic Charities. "We like to use the Times money as a bridge for people who are in crises. Long-term support is less and less the focus of our social service agency."
Ms. Sullivan's plight was typical for working people who benefit from the Neediest Cases Fund, Ms. Keavenig said. After the disability paperwork went through, Ms. Sullivan needed no further help. She was able to keep her rent-stabilized Park Slope apartment and cover her $100 monthly medication bill on the $700 disability pension.
"I have hope," said Ms. Sullivan, who is now 60 years old. "But it's hard living on the edge. If anything goes wrong, I don't know what I will do."
Ms. Sullivan has little money for even the smallest of luxuries, but her energy and enthusiasm for work are returning. She walked several blocks to a nearby restaurant to eat lunch with visitors last week, and spoke eagerly about her search for volunteer work in her neighborhood.
"There must be something I can do," she said. "I can't stay home and watch the talk shows."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSVILLE;
Renewal Plan Moves Ahead

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
Ground breaking is scheduled to begin next spring on an ambitious plan to restore one of the city's most impoverished areas -- 28 blocks in the northwestern portion of Ocean Hill-Brownsville and the southeastern portion of Bedford-Stuyvesant.
As part of the Saratoga Square plan, the city this month sent out requests for proposals to nonprofit community agencies for the marketing of 1,200 housing units -- a mixture of new two-family houses and renovated apartment buildings. The plan also calls for the creation of park areas and for new commercial development. 
 Saratoga Square is bounded roughly by Atlantic Avenue and Bainbridge Street and Ralph and Rockaway Avenues. It is the city's second largest neighborhood-renewal project, exeeded only by Harlem's 40-block Bradhurst redevelopment plan.
The Brooklyn plan includes the construction of about 400 two-family homes and the substantial rehabilitation of 80 abandoned, city-owned apartment buildings. In addition, it calls for the moderate rehabilitation of 30 occupied buildings.
This spring, construction is scheduled to begin on 63 of the two-family homes. Construction will be paid for by New York City ($10,000 per unit), New York State's Affordable Housing Program ($15,000 per unit) and the Borough of Brooklyn ($15,000 per unit).
In other aspects of the program, the city's Economic Development Corporation will market sites for commercial development along Fulton Street,two parks will be enlarged and two open-space sites will be developed in the vicinity of Somers and Fulton Streets. L.H.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Compendium Aims to Keep Local Money Local

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
The latest chapter in the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce's effort to sell Harlem's wares is a spiral-bound guide in red, purple and green, called "Harlem Means Business."
Its 80 pages cover everything from the history of Harlem to an overview of the community's major assets to a listing of businesses, including 10 art galleries, 30 funeral homes and one medical supply store. 
 "Our office is flooded by requests for companies that can do work, particularly in the housing development field and the construction field," said Lloyd Williams, the president of the chamber. The guide lists 33 companies that fit the description.
"The need has been there for a long time," Mr. Williams said, "but the demand is greater than ever."
The guide is being produced with the help of a grant from Citibank, which has recently begun a number of outreach programs in Harlem, as have other banks during the increasing move to develop the area over the last five years. Chamber officials say it is the first general guide produced in more than 40 years.
Twenty thousand copies of the book, which covers the chamber's service area from 90th to 168th Street, will be distributed to local businesses, community organizations, libraries and churches beginning in mid-January.
It will also be available in Citibank branches all over the city. E.M.B.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RICHMOND HILL/OZONE PARK;
Do Giant Stores Kill Small Shops? Survey Says No

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
How does the arrival of a retailing giant affect a neighborhood?
Here in Ozone Park, while some residents, merchants and civic leaders continue to try to halt construction of a Home Depot store at Aqueduct Race Track, partly out of a desire to protect smaller businesses, a recent city survey of a local 75,000-square-foot shopping center confirms a conclusion reached by some other residents: large retail chains do not necessarily discourage mom-and-pop-sized shops. 
 The survey, which was conducted by the Department of City Planning, indicates that the seven-year-old Clocktower Plaza shopping center on Atlantic Avenue, anchored by a 55,000 square-foot Pathmark supermarket, has not disrupted the stability of neighborhood retail strips.
Some of those who once opposed the center now say that it has provided new jobs, as well as greater choice for consumers -- a position supported by city planners and other officials who are trying to lure more large retail chains like Home Depot and Kmart into the city.
Simcha Waisman, the head of a block association that once bitterly opposed the shopping center, says that because the Pathmark center has not created the anticipated problems, but rather forced local businesses to be more responsive to the needs of customers, his group is supporting the Home Depot project.
"We feel the Home Depot will be an asset to our community," said Mr. Waisman, who heads the Richmond Hill Block Association.
The survey compared the number of small shops and other stores that existed before and after the Pathmark center opened in 1986, finding that the numbers were virtually the same between 1983 and 1993. City planners conducted a similar survey in Borough Park, Brooklyn, where another Pathmark shopping center opened in 1988, and reached the same conclusion.
Earlier this month, the city's Board of Standards and Appeals concluded hearings on the Home Depot project amid accusations that the giant retailer had not undergone the appropriate environmental, zoning and legal reviews before receiving a building permit -- a charge city and company officials deny.
The board is expected to make a ruling next month on the debate, which reflects the opposition that major retailers have faced as they slowly begin to move into the city.
Brian J. Herman, the president of the Coalition for Community Preservation and Stabilization, questioned the value of the recent survey, noting that the Home Depot project is about double the size of the Pathmark center and thus poses a greater economic and environmental threat to the area.
City planners acknowledge that there is a difference between the projects, but note that the concerns that arose seven years ago recalled those of today.
Mr. Herman, however, remains adamant. "The price of a Home Depot is a loss of businesses and a destabilization of a residential community," he said. R.H.
