HEADLINE: EVERGLADES CLASH THREATENS ACCORD

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
An agreement between farmers and government to help restore the endangered Everglades ecosystem fell apart this week because the two sides could not reconcile their visions of the region's future.
The conflict mirrors the clash of values in forestry, mining and other industries as the Clinton Administration seeks to turn away from piecemeal natural resource management to restoration of whole ecosystems. The idea is to negotiate broad agreements with local interests based on mutual advantages, but as the collapse of the Florida agreement shows, accord can be difficult when economic interests and the environment collide. 
 In the Everglades, it now appears that the promising but narrow agreement to clean up the phosphorous-laden water discharged from sugar and vegetable farms will have to go back to court.
The two sides had made substantial progress in court-ordered negotiations, even announcing an agreement in principle last July. But on Thursday, the negotiations over the details reached an impasse.
 
Farmers Sought Guarantee
 Growers of sugar cane and vegetables have prospered in a vast swath of farmland claimed from what was, a century ago, the upper reaches of an uninterrupted flow of water creeping southward through grassy marshes from Lake Okeechobee to the Florida Bay. The growers, in the past five months of negotiations, had agreed to take some land out of production but had sought guarantees against losing even more land later.
At Florida's tip lies the Everglades National Park, untouched by development but hardly undamaged by more than 50 years of development around its periphery. The Government is committed to preserving this wilderness.
In an interview on Friday, George Frampton, the Assistant Secretary of Interior who led Federal negotiating, said he would spend the next few weeks coming up with a strategy for the fight ahead. He said he assumed that negotiations would not resume, because in his view the guarantee the growers were demanding was too high a price.
Mr. Frampton said the farmers would have to face the changes that would result from economic and ecological trends in Florida. "That does not mean that agriculture will go out of business, or be less profitable in the future," he said. "But the amount of cane sugar is going to be less. It may be 10 percent, or 20 percent, or 75 percent, or 28 percent less in 20 to 25 years."
 
Going Beyond the Accord

Those figures would go far beyond the agreement in principle, which had contemplated transforming 40,000 acres of farmland into filtration marshes that would have helped remove the phosphorus from the agricultural runoff over 20 years, at an estimated cost of $465 million to growers.
The plan would have provided the farmers with financial incentives to help reduce the pollution, which they could do with new plant varieties, new fertilization techniques and new water pumping practices that the industry is already testing.
Growers also wanted protection from a proposed state tax on sugar to pay for environmental restoration and help with problems with obtaining water permits.
The Government wanted a relatively quick fix to the pollution problem, but over the longer term it wanted a free hand to design a management plan for the whole ecosystem, one that might sacrifice more farmland if necessary.
 
Study Outlines Vision
 The longer-term vision came abruptly into public view this fall when the Government sought public comment on a study that talked about a wholesale reversal of how the state had treated its watery regions for decades.
The study was cited by the growers as a sign that the Interior Department had been bargaining in bad faith over the narrower water cleanup.
The Government scientists contended that on the farmland, drained by thousands of miles of ditches and canals, the mucky topsoil was deteriorating so badly that farming would eventually become virtually impossible.
The study, which raised the possibility of flooding hundreds of thousands of acres of farmland, prompted an outcry in farming communities where the public was invited to comment on it this week.
"I don't think you are willing to die to take my farm," one farmer told Federal officials on Tuesday at a hearing in Clewiston, on the shore of Okeechobee. "But I'm willing to die to keep it."
And J. Nelson Fairbanks, the president of the United States Sugar Corporation, the dominant grower in the negotiations, said the study indicated the Government had acted in bad faith in reaching the accord.
Government officials said the farmers were exaggerating the threat. Environmental groups accused growers of using the negotiations as a stalling tactic and using the report as a monkey wrench in the gears of the negotiations.
"They were looking to walk away from the negotiations, and they found a pretext," said Thomas Martin, director of the Everglades campaign at the National Audubon Society.

In suggesting that any decline could not be predicted precisely, he said, "It might be 10 percent, or 20 percent, or 25 percent, or 28 percent less in 20 to 25 years." He did not use a 75 percent figure.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Selling History on the Lower East Side

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
ORCHARD STREET will never be confused with a suburban shopping mall. Lining it are tenements laced with a spider's web of fire escapes. Levels and levels of coats are displayed above awesomely cluttered sidewalks. Throngs of people, all sworn never even to think of paying retail, paw suspiciously through mountains of merchandise, be it Italian silk sheets or three-for-$10 T-shirts.
In spirit, this marvelously raucous lane, which extends from Canal Street north to Houston, seems to have changed little since the turn of the century, when Yiddish was spoken everywhere and the Lower East Side was home to pushcarts, penny knife grinders and "glimmer men" who fitted eyeglass lenses by the process of elimination. 
 But a second look suggests things may have changed fundamentally. Once almost all the property owners were Jewish; now a third are from other ethnic groups, principally Chinese, and the people who live above the stores these days tend to be of Asian or Hispanic descent.
And for the first time, the traditionally Orthodox neighborhood has strung holiday lights, with a scrupulously correct mix of Jewish and Christian images.
The lights represent one small component of an effort to fight back against economic forces that have combined to pull down one of America's most famous shopping areas.
Some 400 local merchants and property owners have banded together in a business improvement district to advertise and promote the area, as well as to make community improvements. Their strategy is to burnish and market the historic character of this rambunctious bazaar -- to draw tourists and New Yorkers interested in reliving a bit of the city's more colorful history, while prowling sharklike for present-day bargains.
"If we thrive, it's going to have a ripple effect on the entire area," said David Ceci, executive director of the group, the Lower East Side District Management Association.
Two blows have particularly kicked the wind out of Orchard Street over the years. One is the gradual loss of the monopoly on Sunday shopping once enjoyed by a largely Jewish business district that closes on Saturdays; with blue laws now a two-decade old memory, Sunday shopping is ubiquitous. The other is the rise of discounting in all forms of retailing, meaning Orchard Street no longer has a special claim on bargain hunters.
Throw in a long and bitter recession, major repairs on the East River bridges, persistent parking problems, drug selling and other crime, and an exodus of many loyal shoppers to the suburbs. The result is a prolonged business downturn.
There is no body count on the number of businesses that have closed or moved, but the effect is starkly evident on Orchard south of Delancey, where the store vacancy rate is estimated by local realtors to be 15 percent.
Fixtures that have moved or gone out of business in recent years include Ezra Cohen, one of the great linen stores; Eldridge Textile Company, which featured an enormous selection of bedspreads; Penchina Textile Company, Bernstein's kosher deli and the famous Grand dairy restaurant.
"It was very unprofitable to stay where we were," said Jay Rosenfeld, owner of the 80-year-old J. Schachter's, the high-end bed shop that moved to Brooklyn in September. "You can't live on expectations."
The association, which started up in January with a $200,000 budget, acknowledges the need for some urgency. "Our No. 1 goal is to make the cash registers ring," said Mr. Ceci. "There are many stores out there hanging on by their fingernails."
Despite a reality that may be a little shopworn, the new business group is determined to sell the image of a lively, vibrant Orchard Street, not unlike the way South Street Seaport has combined historic ships, cobblestone streets and slick retailing.
"What the South Street Seaport has tried to do, we can do in a grittier, nonantiseptic manner," said Sion Misrahi, the president of the business district.
The thrust has been frankly promotional. One of the group's early actions was to hire a public relations firm, McKeefry & Company, to come up with a catchy new name and logo for the area: "Historic Orchard Street Bargain District."
There are big dreams of luring famous national stores to a place where they have never been. Mr. Ceci speaks of getting a national book chain or a Hallmark greeting card store. More immediately, the plan is to lure tour buses -- perhaps as a package with a visit to the Lower East Side Tenement Museum at 97 Orchard Street and a meal at the legendary Katz's or Ratner's or one of the newer Cuban or Chinese restaurants.
Already, some foreign tour operators include Orchard Street on their itinerary. The Brazilian edition of Vogue just featured the street, producing a stream of South American visitors.
But obstacles abound, and progress is not guaranteed. A voluntary program for stores to remain open late on Thursday evenings flopped. And the group's directors decided it could not afford the big-ticket initiatives, like their own garbage collectors, that other business improvement districts adopt.
"There are no Trumps, Zeckendorfs or Olympia and Yorks down here," Mr. Ceci said. "We have almost exclusively mom-and-pop businesses."
Also, there is the parking headache, a priority for the new business group. Two city-owned lots, on Delancey Street just off the Williamsburg Bridge, had fallen into disrepair and were to be refurbished to accommodate 100 cars with attendant parking. One lot, trumpeted by full-page advertisements, opened on Dec. 10 after a $40,000 investment. But the second is being commandeered by the Sanitation Department for its trucks. The business improvement group has been given 30 days to vacate the property.
"We're fighting to get the business district revitalized and, bingo, the city steps in and takes away the most important part of the revitalization," said Kathryn E. Freed, the City Councilwoman who turned on the holiday lights in a ceremony last month.
But the salvation of Orchard Street will hinge on more than parking and lights. It will depend on the group's ability to rekindle the fires of the past. You can still haggle in some stores, and when the light is just right you might imagine you are in a Jacob Riis photograph. Merchants also point to a commitment to quality and service that they say has long characterized Orchard Street.
"Most of our customers, when they come in, we know them by their first name," said David Gatenio, who with his brother Leon owns Carl & Sons, a men's clothing store at 172 Orchard Street.
Bill Levy, whose grandfather opened Harris Levy, a dry goods store, in 1894, said: "People couldn't get this quality of merchandise anywhere else but Madison Avenue. Nobody is rich enough that they're beyond a bargain."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 26, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about efforts to revive the Orchard Street shopping district referred incorrectly to one store, Eldridge Textile Company. It remains in business, at 277 Grand Street.

HEADLINE: Communities Study Port Chester's Fight Over Topless Bar

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER

 BODY:
EVERY night there are two live shows at the Diamond Club in Port Chester, both sanctioned by the First Amendment of the Constitution. Inside the club, in darkness interrupted by bursts of strobe light, two young women in G-strings, high heels and elbow-length gloves gyrate to music on two small stages. Male customers drinking around the stages push dollar bills between the women's breasts.
Outside the club -- which sits at the end of a shopping strip of three empty storefronts and a chicken-and-ribs restaurant -- a group of protesters picket the strip bar, carrying signs that read, "No Porn in Port Chester" and "Topless Supporters, Leave Town." 
 The owners of the club and the organizers of the pickets have already met in court. The Diamond Club owners say their establishment is legal and that the protesters are hurting business. The picketers insist on their right to protest what they describe as an immoral and degrading "male playground" in their town. In their nightly showdowns, both sides claim harassment by the other.
 
'Completely Caught Off Guard'
 "They are exploiting young girls who are too ignorant to know better, and they are destroying our community," said Goldie Solomon, who has lived in Port Chester for 45 years and is in charge of the evening protests. "There may be a place for this kind of sexually arousing dancing, but it's not in the suburbs, it's not in small towns that have residential properties entwined with commercial, and it's not in a family shopping center."
The bar and its pickets coexist uneasily now after a temporary restraining order was issued prohibiting the protesters from blocking the entrance to the club or harassing the patrons. Meanwhile, the faceoff is being carefully watched by other communities in the county, all of which want to discourage sexually oriented businesses.
Adult entertainment cannot be arbitrarily banned. The Supreme Court of the United States has held that sexually explicit dancing, books and videos -- as long as they do not fall under the legal definition of obscenity -- are protected by the First Amendment as expressions of free speech. But the Court has also permitted municipalities to place restrictions as to where such businesses can operate, as long as officials can demonstrate harmful secondary effects from the presence of the businesses elsewhere and as long as the officials do not unduly reduce access to the businesses.
George O'Hanlon, the Village Attorney for Port Chester, said that the town was "completely caught off guard" by the opening of the Diamond Club last spring.
"It was not in the forefront of anyone's mind as a potential problem," Mr. O'Hanlon said. While the village has since passed a variety of zoning ordinances to try to control the opening of other topless bars, it cannot legally close the Diamond Club, which was operating before the new restrictions.
But several communities that have been following the controversy in Port Chester have taken the position that the best defense against adult entertainment is an offense. The village of Mount Kisco, for example, currently has no topless bars, adult movie theaters, massage parlors or other sexually oriented businesses, but last month it passed a zoning ordinance to regulate the location of such establishments.
 
Two Different Approaches
 "You think of these things happening maybe in the city, but not up here -- but then when you see what's happening in Port Chester you realize it could happen anywhere," said Mayor Richard Roth of Mount Kisco. "The key word here is proactive. Instead of reacting after it happens and lawsuits being filed, you want to see what you can do to control it ahead of time."
Municipalities attempting to regulate adult entertainment through zoning have generally used one of two different approaches: concentration or dispersal. While almost all regulations confine sexually oriented businesses to industrial or commercial zoning, some towns prefer to confine such businesses to one geographic area (such as Boston, which is well known for its Combat Zone) while others prefer to spread sexually oriented establishments throughout a community and avoid creating a strip or red-light district.
In the village of Mount Kisco, the Board of Trustees has taken the dispersal route. The ordinance specifies that adult entertainment establishments must get a special permit to operate in the village. In order to receive that permit, they must conform to certain restrictions, including a requirement that no such business be within 1,000 feet of a residential district, a church, a school bus stop, a public park or a community center. Further, no adult entertainment establishment may be within 1,000 feet of another one.
"This law doesn't stop them from coming to Mount Kisco, but we are telling them if they do come, they have got to play by our rules," Mr. Roth said.
The Village Board passed the ordinance after studying reports about the effects of adult entertainment on several cities around the country. Statistics were presented noting a decline in the market value of real estate surrounding sexually oriented businesses and suggesting a correlation between a concentration of adult-entertainment establishments and an increase in crime, particularly prostitution, drugs and assault. Mayor Roth said many communities -- including Yonkers and Harrison -- had expressed interest in Mount Kisco's law.
 
Doubtful Constitutionality
 Several other municipalities in the county have cabaret laws, which specifically ban topless dancing. The town of North Castle last spring passed a law "to minimize the adverse impacts of such cabarets and yet permit their existence, thus providing for the economic and social welfare, health, peace and morals of the people of the town of North Castle." The law sets up a 23-step licensing procedure and, among other provisions, includes a section on "exposure of persons," which in great detail describes body parts, including breasts, that are not to be exposed.
Greenburgh, too, has a cabaret law, which specifies, "No female person shall be permitted to appear for the purpose of entertainment in any premises licensed hereunder with breasts uncovered or so thinly covered or draped as to permit one to see through same."
Civil liberties lawyers say, however, that such ordinances would probably not withstand a court challenge.
"These places have a right to do business," said Lynn Dewaters, executive director of the Westchester chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. "The community can protest in one shape or another within the law to bring pressure on the owners of such establishments to such a point that they would deem it a disadvantage to keep it open. But whether communities can pass ordinances to keep this from coming depends on the ordinance. Any regulations of this type would have to pass constitutional muster. They are going to have to sit on the books until someone tries to put in this type of establishment."
 
Lawsuits Expected
 Not many people believe that the county is facing an onslaught of topless bars or that such businesses would be profitable in many locations. The owners of the Diamond Club initially operated as an Italian restaurant, but after losing money, they tried to recoup their investment by converting to adult entertainment, said Frank Allegretti, the lawyer for Vincent Sorrano, co-owner of the club. In fact, on a recent Friday evening, a blackboard behind one of the dancers still offered a baked ziti special, though most patrons were sticking with beer and pretzels.
But Mr. Allegretti said that he believes such disputes will play themselves out in other towns and that communities attempting to ban sexually oriented businesses in the guise of simply controlling their locations will face an increasing number of lawsuits.
"It all depends on the layout of the town," he said. "If the so-called limitations of being adjacent to churches, schools, et cetera, in fact excludes the entire area of the town, then it's impermissible and it's going to be overturned by anyone with standing interest. There will definitely be a proliferation of these establishments popping up, and you are going to see more and more court challenges from town efforts to curb them."

HEADLINE: Companies Are Cutting Their Hearts Out

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich is the Secretary of Labor.

 BODY:
There used to be an unwritten contract in America between top managers and workers: If you did your job conscientiously, you could count on having that job as long as the company stayed in business. But that implicit contract is being abandoned, at an ever-faster pace. Even reasonably healthy companies are cutting their payrolls.
For the past four months, American businesses have been slashing jobs by more than 2,000 a day, a 30 percent higher rate than a year ago, when the nation was still in recession. From the standpoint of investors, this trend seems to make sense. Stock prices often spike upward after the announcement of a major cut in payrolls, even among companies that are showing no sign of bottom-line distress. The butcher metaphor of modern management seems apt: It's time to cut the fat, slash the excess, get lean and mean. 
 Enthusiasm for corporate downsizing is particularly strong among large institutional investors like pension funds, which are exerting increasing influence within corporate board rooms. Pension fund managers are quick to defend their new appetite for corporate downsizing, even though they represent the retirement incomes of workers who may lose their jobs as a result of the cutting. Making American companies more productive is in everyone's long-term interest, or so the argument goes.
But I want to sound a cautionary note. Are we in danger of overdoing it?
A recent study of 531 mostly large companies by the Wyatt Company, business management consultants, found that although three-quarters of the companies had cut their payrolls, most reported that the cuts had failed to achieve their expected results. Of the companies surveyed, earnings increased for just 46 percent of them; while 58 percent expected higher productivity, only 34 percent experienced it; while 61 percent sought to improve customer service, only 33 percent concluded that they'd achieved it. Even more tellingly, within a year after making the cuts, more than half of the companies had refilled some of the positions.
The results of the Wyatt survey are corroborated by another recent study, by Kenneth De Meuse, who teaches management at the University of Wisconsin at Eau Claire. De Meuse found no evidence that large layoffs improved, or even stemmed the decline in companies' financial performance. Now, of course, it may have been that these companies were already heading for trouble before they made the cuts, and would have been far worse off had they not made them. But, together with the Wyatt results, De Meuse's conclusion certainly raises the question whether the typical upturn in stock prices immediately upon announcement of a layoff is based more on a collective anticipation by investors that other investors will respond positively to the same news, than it is on any change in the fundamentals.
Perhaps radical surgery needs time to take hold. I know of no reliable studies of the long-term effects of deep cutbacks, but there is cause for concern in the here and now. The first casualties are the morale and loyalty of the employees who remain on the payrolls. Although they do not register directly on balance sheets, high employee morale and loyalty are often among the most important of a firm's assets. Paring the payroll may imperil these assets in ways that escape profit and loss statements but profoundly affect competitive advantage.
Visiting many American workplaces, I have heard the same refrain: "Everybody's scared. . . . I don't know how long they'll keep me. . . ." Employees fearful of getting the ax are hardly likely to pursue labor-saving innovations. Nor are they likely to volunteer that extra time and energy that so often makes a difference in productivity.
Another casualty is the cumulative experience of those whose jobs are eliminated. Knowledge that comes from years of hands-on work with products or technologies, or years of dealing with certain customers, is often the key to discovering needed improvements. But financial officers tend to see only the wages and benefits paid to an employee, narrowly weighing them against the value of that employee's current output.
Several years ago, I was asked by a group of design engineers at a large computer company to help devise a strategy for convincing their financial officers why the company should manufacture rather than purchase a particular component. "They think it's cheaper to buy rather than build," one of the engineers complained, "and it is today. But if we don't make it in-house, we don't gain the experience and knowledge that goes with making it. And then we can't develop a whole range of technologies that are likely to evolve from that component."
Some would argue, of course, that downsizing strategies are still preferable to the alternative of allowing companies to continue their slothful ways. So long as the cuts result in greater output per employee, downsizing would seem to make sense even at the cost of some employee morale, loyalty, knowledge and experience. The test, after all, is profitability.
This argument would be a stronger if the only means of improving productivity was by way of the butcher. But another approach is possible. At the risk of stretching metaphors, let me describe it as the way of the baker. The butcher improves productivity by cutting away whatever seems unnecessary; the baker improves it by enhancing the value of all the ingredients.
The baker strategy is to invest in the skills of employees by providing them with training, both on and off the job. It provides front-line workers with substantial authority, so they can make decisions about how to improve the production process and increase sales. And it gives employees a degree of employment security by tying their wages to profits or to productivity gains. That way, when hard times come, they are shared by everyone rather than only by those who are axed. When profits return, everyone will share in them as well.
Does the baker approach really work? A number of independent studies provide hard-nosed evidence that it does. An extensive review of 27 econometric studies concludes that the introduction of profit-sharing typically yielded 3 to 5 percent higher productivity. Of 29 studies examining employee participation in company decision-making, 14 showed positive effects on productivity, 2 showed negative effects and 13 had ambiguous results.
The implementation of employee training also seems to boost productivity. One study found that companies that introduced a formal training program had at least a 17 percent larger rise in productivity than companies that did not.
Last year M.I.T. researchers compared two groups of automobile factories that were similar in every respect except that in the first set, all three practices -- employee involvement, profit-sharing or productivity gain-sharing, and training -- were followed; in the second, none. The study found that workers in the first set of factories manufactured vehicles 8 hours faster, on average, than workers in the second, and with fewer defects per car.
Higher productivity through baking rather than butchering translates directly into higher profits. In a recent survey of more than 700 companies from all major industries, researchers from Rutgers University found that businesses that used one or more employee-friendly strategies had higher annual shareholder returns, and higher gross return on capital, than companies that did not.
How do these opposing approaches affect the economy as a whole -- a question of critical importance to pension funds and other large institutional investors that have broad holdings across American industry? Consider the effect of widespread downsizing on consumer confidence: workers who have lost their jobs and not yet found new ones tend to consume less than those who are fully employed. Even full-time employees watch their wallets when they're worried that their job may be the next to go. The current recovery would be more buoyant were it not for such anxieties.
Even when a company becomes more productive by trimming its payrolls, America as a whole does not necessarily become more productive. A company's books may show an increase in output for each worker remaining on the payroll after others have been let go; but the output of the nation as a whole must also take into account the fates of the workers who have been forced to leave. If they promptly found new jobs where they could be at least as productive, the nation's total output would be enhanced. But fewer and fewer Americans who lose their jobs are finding new jobs this easily.
The typical duration of unemployment continues to grow. In the 1970's, an average of 11 percent of the nation's unemployed were out of work for six months or longer; in the 1980's, 15 percent were jobless for half a year or more; thus far in the 1990's, 16 percent. Last year, 21 percent of the unemployed had not worked for six months or longer -- the second-highest annual level since the end of World War II.
We all pay the price, not only in lost output and potential tax revenues. Regular unemployment insurance benefits, paid for by payroll taxes, have averaged $22 billion annually (adjusted for inflation) over the past five years. Federal extended benefits for those who have used up their regular six-month insurance have cost an additional $12 billion in each of the last two years.
The Clinton Administration is designing a comprehensive re-employment system to help these Americans get good jobs as quickly as possible after being laid off. Job search assistance, job counseling, job retraining and extra income support during retraining -- all are urgently needed because of changes in technologies and global markets that require Americans to move from job to job at a faster pace than before. The current wave of downsizing makes these re-employment reforms even more necessary.
Downsizing can, of course, be an efficient means of moving the nation's workers to jobs where they can be most productive with their existing skills. But downsizing does not increase the value a worker contributes to the economy, because it does not enhance the worker's skills. It merely reallocates work.
It is difficult to have it both ways. The more we butcher, the less we bake. Other advanced industrial countries face the same choice, but have tended to do more baking. Look behind their current recessions and you see highly competitive work forces. A recent study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development is revealing. In 1991, 27 percent of American workers had been with their current employer for less than one year; 62 percent for less than five years. At the other extreme is Japan, where only 10 percent of workers had been with an employer for less than a year, and 37 percent less than five years. Only 25 percent of American workers had been employed by the same employer longer than 10 years, compared with more than 40 percent in Japan, Germany and France.
Average length of stay in the job is in direct proportion to the amount of training provided on the job to young employees. The correlation is logical. Before a company will invest in training, it must be confident that the worker will be around years from now when the training will fully pay off. In the United States, only about 10 percent of young workers receive any formal company training, compared with more than 50 percent in Japan and Germany.
I do not mean to overstate the case. Many fine companies in the United States are reducing their payrolls while at the same time seeking to enhance the skills and involvement of workers who remain. Moreover, one of the great strengths of the American economy -- in contrast to that of Japan and most of industrialized Europe -- is a highly mobile labor market, and we must do nothing to reduce that flexibility. I simply wish to urge investors -- especially the large institutional investors like pension funds -- to reconsider their assumptions. Rather than pressure firms to cut payrolls, they may do better to insist that companies invest more in their workers.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 19, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An essay by Robert B. Reich on page 54 of The Times Magazine today, about corporate downsizing, includes an outdated statistic about job cuts. In the last four months, American businesses have been eliminating jobs at a rate of 2,600 per business day, not 2,000 per day. The essay also misstated the increase in that rate. It is 5 percent higher than in 1991. The comparison "30 percent higher than a year ago" is erroneous.

HEADLINE: Hartford Firm Tests New Legal Issues

BYLINE: By SUSAN KARLIN

 BODY:
RECENTLY, a husband and wife consulted a Hartford lawyer, Maggie Cassella, about a problem they had. In a few weeks, the man could become a woman. But doctors said they would only perform the sex-change operation if the couple were divorced, because two women could not legally be married.
The couple, still very much in love, wished to continue living together after the operation. They wanted Ms. Cassella to handle the legal work of the divorce and a subsequent property-sharing agreement that would substitute in certain respects for a marriage contract. 
 "This is why my mother doesn't want to talk about my work," said Ms. Cassella, who is 32 years old and has built a practice helping gay and lesbian clients navigate a legal system designed for heterosexuals. Since founding Cathcart & Cassella nearly six years ago with Frank Cathcart, 37, Ms. Cassella has written contracts and probate documents covering property ownership, drafted wills, powers of attorney and bankruptcy documents for AIDS patients as well as handled conventional criminal, personal injury, small business and divorce cases.
 
'She Hangs In' With Clients
 "She's seen a lot of people fall to the ravages of AIDS and resulting financial problems and she hangs in with them far beyond what their families are willing to do," said a law school classmate who now practices family and probate law, Judith C. Benedict.
This month, Ms. Cassella begins the first adoption by lesbian parents in Connecticut. It will be the adoption of a baby by the lesbian partner of the the biological mother who became pregnant by artificial insemination. Given the success of similar adoptions in nine states including New Jersey, New York and Massachusetts, Ms. Cassella and a team that includes Ms. Benedict, Philip Tegeler, a lawyer with the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, and Ruth Harlow, the associate director of the Lesbian and Gay Rights Project of the American Civil Liberties Union, are confident in their clients' case.
"We don't see any reason why it should not be granted given Connecticut's adoption laws, which do not discriminate according to marital status and offer special procedures for adoptions with special circumstances," Ms. Cassella said. "Plus, our clients are economically stable, have a longstanding relationship and are well-educated, which are important criteria in adoption cases."
 
Recognizing Nontraditional Families
 Mr. Tegeler added that if this case is successful, "it will be an important step toward recognizing nontraditional families in Connecticut."
Ms. Cassella's affinity for her legal niche stems from her own life as a lesbian, forced to draft similar agreements with her companion of 13 years and accustomed to living in a gray area of partial legal and social acceptance.
No marital laws protect the rights and property of gay and lesbian couples, because courts regard them as partners rather than spouses, she said, and wills and cohabitation contracts are often contestable. There are no guarantees that a gay or lesbian spouse will be granted a share of the estate or custody rights of the companion's child. "I've even had people fighting over ashes," Ms. Cassella said.
 
Law Open to Interpretation
 With law open to interpretation, Ms. Cassella said she has often found even the best of her legal arguments at the mercy of prejudice, particularly in criminal cases in which clients have been arrested for picking up members of the same sex.
"One prosecutor referred to my client as 'those people,' and when I asked him what he meant by that he refused to answer," Ms. Cassella said. "If someone's breaking the law, arrest them and put them through the system, just like everyone else. The slurs can really be left at home."
She added: "Then there are the lawyers who say, 'I just want to tell you that I don't approve of homosexuality.' When I tell them that I'm a lesbian and that a lot of gays and lesbians using their firm might be interested to know their feelings, they immediately backpedal."
 
Perceptions of Clients
 Her law firm partner, Mr. Cathcart seconded her perceptions. "I'm a straight white guy, so I've never experienced prejudice growing up as a kid, but I get it vicariously through Maggie and how gay clients are perceived," he said. "Laws treat gay couples differently than married couples. Sometimes, other lawyers are weird about their own gay clients. They don't say anything, you can just pick up on it. Maybe I've been sensitized."
Happily, Ms. Cassella said, those kinds of incidents are becoming more the exception than the rule. "If you're out and you're honest with people about who you are right up front, it tends to be a little easier," she said. "I've had attorneys who have been practicing nearly three times as long call me for advice in heterosexual cohabitation breakups and that clearly flatters me."
Ms. Cassella, who grew up in Bethany, began wrestling with the idea that she was gay at 17; the following year three high school classmates spotted her in a gay bar. "It actually made it easier, because then everyone knew and I didn't have to go through the process of trying to cover it up," she said. "Still, two of the people who saw me refused to talk to me afterward."
 
Paralegal and Teacher
 She graduated from the University of Connecticut in 1982 and worked as a paralegal for the Connecticut Women's Educational and Legal Fund in Hartford and taught philosophy at the Loomis Chaffee School in Windsor before returning to her alma mater for law school. After graduating in 1987, Ms. Cassella worked as an associate at Krass, Jacobson & Gussack in Hartford. When she and Mr. Cathcart began their own firm six months later, Ms. Cassella painted houses for two months to support the practice until business picked up, largely from word of mouth and advertisements in publications catering to gays and lesbians.
"We wanted to provide good service at reasonable rates and not have a stuffy attitude that's so stereotypical of lawyers," said Mr. Cathcart, who tends to handle more cases involving landlord-tenant disputes and litigation. "If we're not seeing clients or have to go to court, we wear jeans to the office."
It was around this time that Ms. Cassella began her foray into what has become a thriving avocation -- stand-up comedy -- when she was asked to be a host at the Hartford Gay Pride Rally in 1988. There, she was spotted by a fellow performer, Lea DeLaria, who gained national attention this spring as the first openly gay comic to appear on a late-night talk show. Ms. DeLaria introduced her to the gay and lesbian comedy circuit and Ms. Cassella began performing one weekend a month and wrote for the PBS sketch comedy show, "The World According to Us." Then her performance at the March on Washington for Gay and Lesbian Rights in April landed her steady weekend bookings along the East Coast.
 
Attractive Plus Biting and Sharp
 It was also strong enough to grab the attention of Los Angeles casting directors. "Maggie is an attractive woman and her comedy is biting and sharp, which is what I like in a comedian," said Tammara Billik, who runs a casting company in Los Angeles that has included among its clients the Fox television series "Married With Children." "Pretty and funny is a look we don't see that often and I thought she was inherently castable."
Ms. Billik arranged meetings with colleagues during a trip Ms. Cassella made this fall to Los Angeles, where she also took her first stab at a mainstream audience at the Improvisation in Santa Monica. There, she held court with a sassy romp through gay-themed political, social and relationship issues. "I'm a lesbian and lawyer," she announced to the startled but intrigued audience. "So you don't know whether to hold on to your wife or your wallet. Either way, I win."
Ms. Cassella, whose recent appearances have included performances in a Methodist Church in Brooklyn, N.Y., and in an "All Women, All Comedy" show in Long Beach, Calif., is booked for shows in Michigan in March and at Town Hall in Manhattan in June. Despite her growing success as a comic, "I'm not going anywhere unless someone offers me a series," Ms. Cassella said with a laugh. "Being a lawyer is not always the most fun profession, but I'm not going to give up a job in which I can serve my community and feel am getting better at by the day, for a job that's uncertain."
She added a third professional hat last year, when she and Gary Bechard, a local club owner, opened a lesbian bar in Hartford. Five months later, a third partner, Terry Milling, helped turn the business into a successful jazz club open to everyone called City's Edge. On occasional Sunday nights, the club features gay and lesbian performers, including Ms. Cassella.
For now, the seemingly disparate businesses actually complement each other. "They're all a big schmooze," Ms. Cassella said. "Speaking in front of 750,000 people in Washington makes it easier to speak in front of a judge in court with a couple of people sitting around. It definitely gives you an edge with the oral presentation part of it. Although you never laugh in court -- unless, of course, the judge makes a joke."

HEADLINE: Listen, New York Needs Rail Freight Access

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A Senator Paralyzes Transit Planning" (editorial, Dec. 10):
State Senator Norman J. Levy of Long Island is right. Lack of freight access to New York City and its Eastern suburbs is the major impediment to our economic recovery, particularly in the manufacturing and wholesaling segments of our economy. 
 As the result of the lack of significant rail freight service, more than 96 percent of this region's land freight is handled by truck. According to a March 1993 report by the New York City comptroller the rail share of our area's freight market is about 2.8 percent, compared with 26 percent nationally. The result is economic stagnation, monumental congestion and deteriorating air quality.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its Long Island Rail Road and Metro North subsidiaries see freight service as a nuisance. Requests by the Long Island's freight department for the equipment to provide service through the clearance restrictions that blockade this region, nearly 15 years after a state program to remove these problems was financed and initiated, fall on deaf ears in a state that wishes to devote every available dollar to the M.T.A.'s passenger services.
State Senator Levy, one of the few people in state government who understands the link between rail freight service and jobs, had no choice but to pull rank and block M.T.A. funds to get long-needed attention to this critical economic problem. Fortunately, he has the legislative clout to have some effect.
Logic, reason, economic facts and the catastrophic loss of jobs in this region owed to lack of adequate freight services have not been enough to alter this state's budget priorities. Political will and State Senate seniority leverage are the only answers. Norman Levy is to be applauded in his efforts toward rationalization of freight transportation in this long-ignored region of New York State's economy.
 
JOHN F. MCHUGH
New York, Dec. 10, 1993
 
The writer is a lawyer with railroad clients.

LENGTH: 1940 words

HEADLINE: Japan's Promising New Leader Seems to Lose His Magic Touch

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 16

 BODY:
When he swept into office five months ago as the unlikely leader of a political revolution, Morihiro Hosokawa was hailed as the Prime Minister who could finally change Japan. He reveled in American-style politics -- from teleprompters to polo shirts to brisk tennis games -- and promised to end Japan's political corruption and economic collusion.
But after a blazing start, Mr. Hosokawa seems to be losing his magic touch. The programs on which he staked his leadership, reforming the political system and deregulating a languishing economy, have bogged down. Tokyo's back-room deal-making, which he denounced for years as Governor of a southern prefecture, is beginning to engulf him. Time and again in recent weeks he has struggled to keep ideological rifts between the Socialists and the seven other parties in his fragile coalition Cabinet from splitting the Government apart. So far it has held together, but at great political cost to Mr. Hosokawa.
 
Motivated by Bitterness
 The bureaucrats who ran the country for four decades with the now-deposed Liberal Democratic Party snipe about the new Government's disorganization, whispering over lunch in Kasumigaseki, the Government center, that Mr. Hosokawa is proving himself a small-town politician. He is uninterested in foreign relations, they say, at sea when it comes to handling the economy, unwilling to delve into policy details. Editorialists have begun to complain that his Government is long on symbolism but short on action, too captivated by the example of another former Southern Governor across the Pacific. 
 Much of the criticism is motivated by bitterness: many in Japan have a strong vested interest in seeing Mr. Hosokawa fail. Most of the problems he faces, especially an economic slowdown that is far worse than anyone expected, were inherited from the previous Government. It is far from clear that if the Liberal Democrats had stayed in power the economy would be better off or Japanese would feel more secure in their jobs.
But even American officials say their early hopes that Mr. Hosokawa would move swiftly to address the persistent economic tensions between Japan and America are waning.
"What's going on is no mystery," a senior Clinton Administration official deeply involved in dealing with Japan said the other day. "Everyone's expectations were high, probably far too high. And we're discovering once again that change in Japan is not like change in Washington."
Mr. Hosokawa's closest allies are urging patience, saying that cleaning up a corrupt political system has been such a wrenching battle that the Prime Minister has not been able to turn to anything else.
 
From His Allies, A Plea for Time
 "We need some more time," Masayoshi Takemura, the chief Cabinet Secretary and head of one of the reform parties allied with Mr. Hosokawa, said in an interview. "Some of the criticisms are correct. But I think that soon you will see the outlines of our ideas."
There has been little progress on the issues Washington cares about most. While Japan's worldwide trade surplus has narrowed slightly in the last month, the gap with the United States is continuing to widen and the year-end figure may exceed the record of $57 billion.
After months of restraining their public criticisms for fear of undercutting Mr. Hosokawa's reform efforts, Clinton Administration officials have begun to complain of backsliding in Japan's commitments to buy foreign computer chips, supercomputers and cellular telephones. Once again there are rumblings about trade sanctions. American and a few Japanese officials complain that Mr. Hosokawa has been so focused on domestic political issues that he has not yet focused on the main set of trade negotiations under way with the United States, the broad "framework accord" agreed upon in July between President Clinton and Kiichi Miyazawa, Mr. Hosokawa's predecessor.
 
High in the Polls, But Little Power
 Earlier this month the Administration sent a mission to Tokyo to urge certain politicians to get engaged in the negotiations quickly, overriding the protective tendency of the bureaucrats conducting the day-to-day talks. Few expect Mr. Hosokawa to get involved, though, until just before a meeting with President Clinton in February.
Polls show that Mr. Hosokawa is still enormously popular among Japanese voters, with approval ratings upward of 70 percent until recent missteps pushed them down to the high 50's and low 60's.
Nonetheless, the extraordinary popularity figures have not been enough to enable Mr. Hosokawa to push through his broad political reform legislation, which would change the nature of Japan's electoral districts and impose stricter controls on campaign funds. The Liberal Democrats have dragged their feet, hoping to embarrass the new Government without being blamed for the failure of the bill. The Socialists, the biggest party in the coalition, fear the new system would marginalize them.
While the bill has passed the lower house of Parliament, the chances of getting it through the upper house are 50-50 at best, even with the 45-day extension of the parliamentary session that Mr. Hosokawa obtained this week.
If the bill fails, Mr. Hosokawa may be forced to call a new election. That is his most potent threat, because the leaders of the Liberal Democratic Party, ousted this summer after 38 years in power, are desperately trying to prevent their once-monolithic party from fracturing further. An election would probably result in defections, as younger members of the party jump ship to join the reformers.
"The party is in a chaotic condition," said Takeo Nishioka, one of four legislators who recently quit the Liberal Democratic Party and who has been voting with Mr. Hosokawa. "The party's problem is that there has been no discussion of what went wrong, why we left power and who should be blamed. That condition must change."
The most serious charge leveled against Mr. Hosokawa these days is that he has followed the footsteps of the Liberal Democrats too closely. That was deliberate: to reassure Japan's allies, and an instinctively cautious electorate, the new Prime Minister declared even before taking office that he would follow the main tenets of foreign and economic policy set by the Liberal Democrats.
For a while the strategy worked. "In the L.D.P. there was a feeling of shock, going from the party in power to the one in opposition," said Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, the leader of the largest faction among the Liberal Democrats. "Hosokawa, being smart, did not give us any room to attack him. His popularity has been so high that if we fought him, we would be the ones to get bloody."
In fact Mr. Hosokawa's flair has, until very recently, garnered far more attention than the substance of his actions. The Japanese media marveled at how he pointed directly at questioners with his pen when holding news conferences and spoke in clear, declarative sentences. He went further than any of his predecessors in breaking some major taboos: he went to South Korea and apologized for Japan's 40-year occupation of the country, and talks openly about the need for politicians, not bureaucrats, to set the national course.
 
High on Fashion; Low on Ideology
 Meeting world leaders, he appeared young and vigorous: he showed up at the Asian summit in Seattle wearing an aviator's scarf, even wowing Clinton Administration officials who thought they had mastered the art of classy informality. A few weeks ago a fashion industry group voted him one of Japan's best-dressed men, something that would have been said about few of his aging predecessors.
But over time the apparent absence of a governing ideology has created an intellectual void at the center of the new administration. To hold the Socialists in the coalition and to pass the political reform legislation, Mr. Hosokawa has been fearful of breaking new ground on any of the other major issues affecting Japan: rising unemployment, the need to rethink a defense policy born in the cold war and an industrial policy still focused on spawning new industry rather than restructuring faltering and inefficient sectors of the economy.
Three weeks ago, when Mr. Hosokawa's Defense Minister suggested that the Constitution may have to be revised to make it easier for Japanese troops to take part in a broad range of United Nations peacekeeping activities, he was summarily dismissed. It made no difference that many of the leaders of the new Government -- especially Ichiro Ozawa, who led the defections against the Liberal Democrats and has acted as the shadow power behind Mr. Hosokawa -- have often expressed the same view. Any debate on the issue threatened to tear the Government apart, because the Socialists have long challenged the constitutionality of Japan's Self-Defense Forces, and watered down the legislation that allowed them to go on a first peace mission this year, to Cambodia. Mr. Hosokawa has yet to say what he thinks.
 
A Promise Made But Not Kept
 Days later, when the Japanese stock market plunged, Mr. Hosokawa immediately announced that the Government would step in with a stimulous package -- perhaps, it seemed, even with a long-rumored tax cut to get consumers spending again. But as soon as the market rebounded a bit, he backtracked, saying he was still considering his next economic moves. Now it appears those steps will not be decided until after the new year, and it would take months, or years, for them to take effect.
The behind-the-scenes battles taking place over economic policy -- whether to lower taxes, begin deficit spending or intervene more to prevent workers from being laid off -- became clearer this week with the release of a report on deregulating the Japanese economy and spurring growth through increasing domestic demand rather than exports.
The committee began with ambitious goals, many of them set out by the Prime Minister. But its report was watered down by the powerful bureaucracy. By the time it appeared, it contained few specifics and one member of the commission, Yotaro Kobayashi, the chairman of Fuji Xerox, said its success would "depend very much on how long Hosokawa's Government will last."
Mr. Hosokawa's biggest success so far, but his messiest, has come over the emotional issue of opening the rice market. It was an inevitable step, and leaders of the Liberal Democrats were thankful that after 38 years in power, the moment to make the concession, part of the Uruguay Round of world trade talks, came just a few months after their ouster.
To keep the coalition together, Mr. Hosokawa went through a charade of opposing the move, sending his Foreign Minister, Tsutomu Hata, to Geneva in a mission that was ostensibly to plead for an exception to the market-opening requirements. For days it appeared that the Socialists, who have long opposed any market openings, might bolt from the coalition, bringing the Government down. In the end they decided they enjoyed their first taste of power too much and stayed in.
While Mr. Hosokawa won, he looked weak, because he was unwilling to argue in public, as he has in private, that the rice industry was one of the inefficient, declining industries that Japan had to restructure.
Mr. Mitsuzuka, the Liberal Democratic leader, compares Mr. Hosokawa to one of his famous ancestors, Yusai Hosokawa, a 16th-century feudal leader, and a leading poet of his time. "He was famous for not offending anybody and surviving with good tactics," Mr. Mitsuzuka said. "That way the Hosokawa family survived. Probably, the Prime Minister is like him."

HEADLINE: Inman's Business Record Includes Bankruptcy of Defense Contractor

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 19

 BODY:
At his introduction in the Rose Garden last week as the nation's next Defense Secretary, Bobby Ray Inman promised to apply the experience he had gained in corporate America to the Pentagon, in the hopes of bringing what he called the "best business practices" to the Government and getting "a dollar value for a dollar spent on defense."
But during the 1980's, Mr. Inman presided over a costly business debacle, a leveraged buyout that resulted in the bankruptcy of Tracor Inc., a Fortune 500 military contractor that made submarine and aviation weapons systems. 
 Once the largest commercial employer in Austin, Tracor is now a small part of what it used to be. Although it has emerged from bankruptcy and is now considered financially healthy, the company became a casualty not only of the excesses of Wall Street in the 1980's but also of mismanagement, cost overruns and shrinking Pentagon spending. To bankruptcy experts and technology executives, the fall of Tracor is a case study in how not to run a business.
"Tracor was like a lot of other deals in the mid to late 1980's," said Robert Miller, a bankruptcy lawyer who represented many of the company's creditors during its reorganization. "The management substantially overpaid for the company and tried to expand it, and ultimately it hit the skids."
Frank McBee, Tracor's founder, said in an interview that Mr. Inman was wise to return to Washington, where he "at least knows his way around." He pointedly did not want to discuss anything about Mr. Inman's stewardship.
Nine months after Mr. Inman, a retired admiral, abruptly left as Tracor's chief executive and chairman in December 1989, the company filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. By all accounts, its debt problems were caused by bad management and by the effort to take it private, both of which were led by Mr. Inman.
As Tracor was sinking, Mr. Inman continued to receive a large compensation package, according to documents later filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Inman received nearly $1 million in 1989, including $422,000 in salary, $250,000 in deferred compensation and a $300,000 bonus from the previous year. Two other executives were paid even more money.
The company never disclosed how much Mr. Inman was paid in 1988, his first year at Tracor.
To Mr. Inman's critics, the story of Tracor illustrates his penchant for big spending on high-tech defense, a penchant that will undoubtedly come under considerable scrutiny as he moves on to head the world's largest procurement organization. The Pentagon's $262 billion budget this year will be larger than the budgets of many small nations.
 
Blames Wall Street
 A member of President Clinton's Cabinet who has closely followed Mr. Inman's career over the years expressed some concern about the former Admiral, observing that he seemed to be an expert at spending money but not particularly adept at raising it or saving it or at cutting costs.
Mr. Inman said in an interview today from his home in Austin that the bulk of Tracor's problems had been caused by bankers and lawyers from Wall Street, whose excessive fees had added significantly to the cost of buying the company and had led it down a road of debt that eventually broke Tracor's back.
He also acknowledged that cost overruns and performance problems while he headed the company had reduced its flow of cash, making it even harder to service Tracor's crushing debt load.
"I would say that the lesson I took from Tracor was that you don't do a leveraged transaction at a time of contraction," he said. "Because unless you have the cash flow, you're not going to be in control of your fate."
But he also conceded that the military side of Tracor had stubbornly resisted cutting costs, a mindset that has dominated the defense-contracting industry.
Asked how he would apply this experience to the Pentagon, he said, "We're going to have to change the procurement system." He declined to comment on any future policies before his confirmation proceedings.
Arguing that it would be unfair to focus simply on his two years at Tracor, Mr. Inman said he had also played significant roles in helping to reshape Fluor, Southwestern Bell and Xerox as a member of the boards of those companies. He said it was those experiences he had referred to when touting his business background at the White House ceremony.
Since 1987, Mr. Inman has also served as a director of Dell Computer and until last week was the head of its audit committee. The company is now under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for improper currency speculation. But executives at Dell said there was no evidence Mr. Inman had been involved in the questionable trading or in possible securities violations for failing to disclose losses from the currency speculation.
Mr. Inman said today that when he and the board had learned of the currency transactions, "we were taken by total surprise."
The decision to undertake a leveraged buyout of Tracor was made during the heady days when Wall Street was realizing enormous profits from such transactions, a time when high-yield, high-risk junk bonds were beginning to dominate the world of corporate acquisition.
It was also a time when market illusions were frequently confused with economic realities.
In the typical leveraged buyout, a small group of investors buys a publicly held company by borrowing money and using the acquired company as collateral, much the way a new-home buyer uses a house as collateral. The group then repays the loans with money generated by the company it is buying. If successful in making the company more efficient, the group will turn around a few years after the original deal and sell the company back to the public at an enormous profit.
 
Notable Among Notables
 Two Texas businessmen, Elvis L. Mason and Randy Best, formed a merchant bank, Mason-Best of Dallas, in 1984 that was the main force behind the Tracor purchase. Mr. Mason had a 20-year career in commercial banking, culminating in his elevation in the 1980's to chairman and chief executive of the Interfirst Corporation, one of Texas's largest banking companies. He stepped down from that post in 1983 after the company suffered huge losses from energy loans.
Mr. Mason, who declined through his secretary to comment about Mr. Inman, formed an investment group, Westmark Systems Inc., in 1986 with the intention of taking military contractors private in leveraged buyouts. He recruited an influential board for Westmark that included two former Cabinet members -- Donald M. Rumsfeld, President Gerald R. Ford's Secretary of Defense, and Drew Lewis, President Ronald Reagan's first Transportation Secretary -- and other prominent political and corporate figures, among them Robert S. Strauss, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and David T. Kearns, who had headed Xerox.
Mr. Mason also recruited Mr. Inman as chairman of Westmark, hoping to make use of the retired Admiral's strong ties to the military. Mr. Inman had been a senior Navy official, the Deputy Director of Central Intelligence and had headed the National Security Agency.
In addition, Mr. Mason was impressed with Mr. Inman's experience as the founder and first head of the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, a consortium of computer software and hardware makers created in 1982 to compete with Japan's electronic giants.
In reality, Mr. Inman's four years at the helm of M.C.C., as the consortium is known, was marked by spotty results, analysts and industry executives said. Most notably, he was unable to tame the competing instincts of the member companies. Many withheld their best researchers, and some of the nation's most important technology giants, including I.B.M. and A.T.& T., refused to participate.
 
Paid 23 Times Earnings
 Westmark's first and only purchase was Tracor, which had been founded in 1955 by four engineers from the University of Texas. By 1986, Tracor had 10,000 employees worldwide, and its annual sales had grown to $632 million, making it the 81st largest Pentagon contractor and the 404th largest company on the Fortune 500. Its major products were anti-submarine weapons, decoys for heat-seeking missiles, aviation equipment and fuses.
Westmark bought Tracor for $714 million -- 23 times its earnings -- in a deal that analysts said at the time was highly overpriced. Compounding the company's problems, the stock market crashed a month later, and the value of the comapny's junk bonds headed into a tailspin.
After the stock market's plunge, Westmark's investment bankers, Shearson Lehman Hutton, grew nervous about the deal's financing. They were also worried about a Pentagon investigation into improper pricing that had begun long before Mr. Inman arrived.
A second set of investment bankers had to be brought in from Merrill Lynch to put up money to complete the deal. Ultimately, all the bankers, along with their lawyers, were paid fees and expenses of $70 million -- 10 percent of the purchase price. The costs of the deal rose further as delays in the financing forced Tracor to take out loans at substantially higher interest rates than they had originally planned.
When Mr. Inman was hired to head Westmark and Tracor, his strengths were supposed to include his Washington connections for landing new contracts and his experience running large, complex organizations. But Tracor was plagued by cost overruns, poor production controls and reduced demand for new weapons.
Instead of rising revenues and profits, the company's earnings began to slide, and it became increasingly difficult to pay bank loans. Crucial cash had already been spent to acquire three other companies: Ultron, which made data security products; Elsin, a maker of combat communications; and General Image Engineering Corporation, which specialized in camouflage technologies.
Two years after he arrived, Mr. Inman abruptly resigned in frustration, conceding as he left in December 1989 that Tracor would be better off in the hands of professional managers than with amateurs like him.
"The most disheartening part of this for me was not being able to accelerate the banks' agreeing to allow Tracor to begin to sell assets," he told a reporter at the time. "I felt totally helpless. There was nowhere to go. In the Government I could always speed things up with a letter or phone call."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I would say that the lesson I took from Tracor was that you don't do a leveraged transaction at a time of contraction because unless you have the cash flow, you're not going to be in control of your fate," said Bobby Ray Inman, who was nominated as Defense Secretary to replace Les Aspin. (Zigy Kaluzny for The New York Times, 1984) (pg. D10)

HEADLINE: PREMIER OF HAITI CRITICIZES ARISTIDE

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Three days after formally resigning, the handpicked Prime Minister of Haiti's exiled President lashed out this weekend at the man who appointed him, describing the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide as an erratic figure and questioning his willingness to return to office under internationally negotiated conditions.
The departing Prime Minister, Robert Malval, spoke on Saturday, shortly after returning from a two-week trip abroad during which he tried and failed to organize a national conference in Haiti to break the country's political stalemate. The idea was rejected by Father Aristide, who said that the security of his supporters could not be guaranteed inside Haiti. 
 Mr. Malval described the Haitian President as a man with "a serious ego problem," who along with his advisers in exile is "playing with our lives, playing with the future of Haiti."
 
Caught in a Trap
 It is the first time that Mr. Malval has publicly accused Father Aristide of hampering efforts to settle the crisis. The Prime Minister still blames the military for the collapse of a brokered accord that was to have reinstated Father Aristide by Oct. 30.
In an interview at his house, Mr. Malval described Haiti as caught in a trap between Father Aristide, the country's first democratically elected President, and the man who presided over the President's ouster in September 1991, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras.
He said neither man seemed willing to make the compromises needed to reach a political solution that would halt Haiti's steep economic decline and prevent disaster for its people.
"The country is stuck between a man who refuses to resign and a man who has made a choice to remain abroad as a sort of flag bearer, a mythic symbol," Mr. Malval said of General Cedras and Father Aristide.
"Everything Aristide is doing is meant to preserve his image among Haitians from Miami to Montreal," Mr. Malval said. "But the problem is that this country is going straight to hell and one day the myth is just going to collapse."
To step up pressure on the military, the United Nations imposed an embargo on oil sales to Haiti in October that has aggravated the suffering of the country's poor.
Aides to Father Aristide said he had vetoed the national conference not just out of security concerns but also because he feared that the proposed political gathering would result in new limits on his powers.
"When you go into a conference like this, you know they are going to squeeze you," said Robert E. White, a former American Ambassador to El Salvador who advises Father Aristide. "If the President had accepted the conference and then refused to go along with any new constraints on him, he would have looked all the more intransigent.
"As it is, no serious pressures have ever been brought on the military," Mr. White said. "They have all been applied to Aristide."
Informed about Mr. Malval's criticism by a reporter, Mr. White that said he had conferred with Father Aristide today and that the deposed President had "nothing to add" to his adviser's remarks.
 
Malval Virtually Powerless
 Mr. Malval, a 50-year-old publisher who had not previously been involved in politics, was appointed Prime Minister in August by Father Aristide after playing a crucial role negotiating the July accord with the military providing for the President's return to office.
General Cedras later refused to resign as commander of the armed forces, violating the agreement he had signed. The security forces also organized violent demonstrations in October to deter international monitors and soldiers from paving the way for Father Aristide's return.
Since then Mr. Malval's Government has been virtually powerless. Though he formally resigned on Wednesday, he still technically has authority over the Government's day-to-day affairs. Last week, President Aristide stripped him of his authority to undertake political initiatives.
Mr. Malval said that when he was appointed in August he had expected that the military would try to block Father Aristide's reinstatement. But he said that the president's behavior had surprised him.
Both Mr. Malval and diplomats who were involved in trying to organize the aborted conference said that Father Aristide, apparently distrustful of Mr. Malval, had repeatedly approved steps to resolve the political stalemate during his Prime Minister's trips to Washington, New York, Paris and Rome, only to suddenly withdraw his support.
 
Aristide Distrust of Washington
 Prime Minister Malval said that Father Aristide had abruptly withdrawn his backing for the national conference and the relaunching of an international military mission to Haiti last Tuesday after it had been painstakingly arranged with the White House and leaders in the United States Senate.
The reversal came a day after President Clinton received both Father Aristide and Mr. Malval at the White House to express support for the initiative, he said.
Aides to Father Aristide have said privately that the exiled President had grown distrustful because he suspected that Washington and diplomats at the United Nations were positioning Mr. Malval to somehow supersede him. Relations between United States officials and Father Aristide, a leftist priest, have long been uneasy.
An aide to Mr. Malval, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that even some aides in the Prime Minister's camp had shared that suspicion during their recent stay in Washington.
"Americans did everything they could to build up Malval at the expense of Aristide," the aide said. "His invitations and meetings around Washington had every appearance of a coup d'etat in the making."
A Western diplomat who was involved in those meetings and has played a leading role in organizing diplomacy in Haiti dismissed the suspicion as "ridiculous."
Senior Administration officials in Washington have often privately expressed exasperation, however, with what they assert has been a lack of cooperation from Father Aristide.
Many diplomats concede that efforts to restore Father Aristide are now completely stalled, although the oil embargo remains in place and a delegation of military officers from the United States, France, Canada and Venezuela is due in Port-au-Prince this week to meet with Haitian Army leaders.
The delegation hopes to revive the idea of separating the Haitian police and army and involving them in efforts to rebuild the country's infrastructure under the July accord.
