HEADLINE: Economy Is Humming, But Who Wrote Tune?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Presidencies rise or fall on the strength or weakness of the economy. So it is not surprising that with almost all economic signs looking good nowadays, President Clinton and his advisers have begun to crow.
"Look at the direction we're going in," the President told a group of supporters early this month. "We have unemployment down, investment up, no inflation and low interest rates. We are moving in the right direction." 
 But in economics circles outside the Administration, even some of the President's strongest supporters -- those who believe that the Clinton policies promise significant improvement over the rest of the decade -- say he does not deserve nearly so much credit as he is claiming for what has happened in the economy so far.
 
'Corrective Process'
 "The strength of the economy now is not so much what they have done as it is a natural corrective process that's going on," said Laurence H. Meyer, a leading economic consultant and forecaster in St. Louis.
The country will surely reap benefits from the lower deficit and the international trade agreements the President worked so hard for this year, Mr. Meyer said, but those benefits will not be realized for years.
Benjamin M. Friedman, a professor of political economy at Harvard University, is another prominent economist who favors the Clinton Administration's basic policies but who believes that the improvement in the economy in the last half of this year is largely a result of the normal progression of the business cycle.
"I don't think the Clinton people deserve a lot of credit for what's happening in the economy today," Mr. Friedman said. "It is good that they addressed longer-term concerns by trying to deal with the fiscal imbalances. But that is not what generates a surge of economic activity so soon."
 
Ingredient in the Stew
 Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of Mr. Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, acknowledges that Administration policy is only one ingredient in the economic stew. But she argues that the improvements of the last few months are a direct result of the budget the President managed to force through Congress last summer.
That budget, which the Administration says will cut the Federal deficit by $500 billion over five years, showed the financial markets that the President was dead serious about lowering the deficit and controlling inflation, Ms. Tyson says. As a consequence, she reasons, long-term interest rates have fallen to their lowest level in more than 20 years and the low rates have generated more investment and jobs and growth.
There is no doubt that times have begun to look good in the last few months, after more than three years in which the economy slid gradually into a recession and then crept even more slowly out of it.
The unemployment rate fell four-tenths of a point in November to 6.4 percent, the biggest monthly improvement in 10 years. The rate of inflation from July through September was only 1.8 percent on an annual basis, the slowest pace since oil prices collapsed in 1986. Construction began on more new houses last month than in any previous month in nearly four years. In October, orders and shipments of durable goods set monthly records. Hours worked, family incomes and consumer confidence are all on the rise.
In a newsletter this month to customers of his investment banking company, Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist of Bear, Stearns & Company, wrote, "The economy is now hitting on all cylinders."
As is generally the case with Presidents, Mr. Clinton's standing in public opinion polls has improved in step with the economy. In the latest CBS News Poll, taken early last week, 51 percent of the respondents said they approved of the way the President was doing his job, up from 38 percent in June.
 
Critics See No Correlation
 Mr. Clinton's political opponents give him no credit whatsoever for the way the economy is growing. Michael J. Boskin, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President George Bush and who is now on the economics faculty at Stanford University, said Mr. Clinton was simply lucky in his timing.
"He ran for President when the economy was doing much better than was generally appreciated," Mr. Boskin said, "and now he's riding a normal cyclical recovery."
Jack F. Kemp, who was Secretary of Housing and Urban Development under Mr. Bush, argued that the strong economy now resulted almost entirely from years of inflation-fighting by the Federal Reserve Board.
Victor Canto, an economic consultant from Southern California, said at a conference here on the economy last week that the prospects of further tax increases later in the Clinton Administration had led to increased economic activity this year.
But outside Washington, the view is that these partisans exaggerate their case as much as the advocates in the Clinton Administration overstate theirs.
Even many economists who disapprove of Mr. Clinton's politics find some value in an argument Ms. Tyson made in an interview last week. "Think about what would have happened if we hadn't fought for the budget plan," she said. "The economy was struggling to recover. What concerned the financial markets was that the deficit would continue to grow and strangle off the recovery and the rate of expansion."
In fact, economists from almost every point on the political compass say Mr. Clinton moved at the right time when he tackled the deficit while the economy was strong. They place that in sharp contrast to the mistake they think Mr. Bush made when he disregarded the deficit in 1989, his first year in office, when the economy was healthy, and then sought tax increases and spending cuts in 1990 after the economy had begun to weaken.
 
Deficit and Stimulus
 But the purpose of cutting the deficit is not to give the economy a quick jolt. "You don't want to take the position that deficit reduction is stimulating the economy," said Mr. Meyer, the consultant in St. Louis. "Increasing the deficit would stimulate the economy."
Given the strength of the economy now, most economists say it is fortunate for the Administration that the Senate killed the $16 billion grab bag of public works projects Mr. Clinton proposed at the beginning of his Presidency to stimulate the economy. Even some Administration officials say that in retrospect they believe enactment of the stimulus measure might have sent the wrong signal to the markets.
Economists also agree on the importance of low long-term interest rates play in propelling the economy. Low rates improve the housing market and put new money in the pockets of millions of homeowners who refinance their mortgages. Even more important in terms of the economy, they encourage businesses to borrow, invest and expand, creating more jobs.
Thirty-year Treasury bonds, the standard gauge of long-term rates, are now paying about 6.3 percent interest, a drop of almost a fifth from just a year ago.
The deficit-reduction package was surely one reason those rates fell, though probably not nearly so important a factor as the low level of inflation, the previous cuts in short-term rates by the Federal Reserve or the economic weakness in Europe and Japan.
 
Taking Credit, and Blame
 What is less clear is whether the lower rates are, as the Administration argues, an important element in the condition of the economy today. "I don't think they have yet stimulated investment spending," Mr. Friedman said. "The lag is longer than that. But the more important question is, Will they? The answer is that most likely they will."
At the White House, the dominant view is that Mr. Clinton might as well take credit when the economy is going well, because, as one adviser put it, "He sure as hell will be blamed if it turns sour."
Jimmy Carter bore no responsibility for the surge in oil prices that crippled the economy in 1980. George Bush did not deserve all the blame when the lid blew off the economy during his Administration, after it had overheated so badly in the Reagan years.
"In fairness, no President should be fully credited or fully blamed for the economy at any particular period of time," Ms. Tyson said.
But they are. Just ask Mr. Carter and Mr. Bush.

HEADLINE: John W. Eckman Is Dead at 74; Dean of Pharmaceutical Industry

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
John W. Eckman, former chairman and chief executive of the Rorer Group, the drug and medical products manufacturer, and a director of its successor company, Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, died Friday at Devon Manor Nursing Home in Devon, Pa. He was 74 and lived in Chester County, Pa., and Nantucket, Mass.
He died of cancer of the lymph system, his family said. 
 Mr. Eckman was known as the dean of chief executives of the American pharmaceutical industry at the peak of his career in the mid-1980's, and he remained active as a corporate director and philanthropist until he became ill earlier this year.
Mr. Eckman joined Rorer, based in Fort Washington, Pa., in 1962, when it was a long-established but low-growth company with one well-known product, the antacid Maalox, and annual sales of $15 million. Over the next two decades, analysts said, he built it into a Fortune 500 company and one of the nation's largest makers of pharmaceuticals and medical products.
 
Born in Queens
 John Whiley Eckman was born in Forest Hills, Queens, in 1919, graduated from the Trinity School in New York and attended Yale University before enrolling in the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, where he received a bachelor's degree in economics in 1943.
In World War II, he was as a submarine officer, and in his last tour of duty was the commanding officer of a captured German U-boat, which he piloted on a record 33-day undersea voyage.
After the war, he joined SmithKline and French Laboratories, based in Philadelphia, and in 1952 became vice president of Thomas Leeming & Company, later known as Pfizer. He joined Rorer in 1962 as executive vice president and was president from 1970 to 1980, chairman and chief executive from 1976 to 1985 and chairman of the executive committee from 1986 until a merger formed Rhone-Poulenc Rorer in July 1990.
In expanding Rorer in the 1970's and 1980's, Mr. Eckman used the cash flow from Maalox to acquire 20 subsidiary companies and to develop a broad variety of pharmaceuticals and specialized medical products, including high-technology surgical instruments and diagnostic equipment.
 
Charity and Civic Leader
 One of Philadelphia's best-known charity and civic leaders, Mr. Eckman contributed to and raised money for hospitals, schools, youth centers, homes for the elderly, social service agencies, urban improvement councils, historical societies and performing arts organizations.
He was also chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia from 1977 to 1981, chairman of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association in 1981 and 1982, and a trustee of the University of Pennsylvania and a director of many companies and educational, medical and cultural institutions.
He is survived by his wife, Jane Haussmann Eckman; a daughter, Alison Eckman Beiser of Houston; a son, Stephen Keyler Eckman of Mount Airy, Pa.; two stepdaughters, Jane Darden Ziesing of Nantucket and Heather Whitney Ziesing of Chester County; two sisters, Grace Eckman Gilbert of Sun City West, Ariz., and Alice Eckman Mason of Winnetka, Ill., and a grandson.

HEADLINE: Home Is Where the Recovery Lurks

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 16

 BODY:
If the nation finally has a recovery worthy of the name, it is due in large part to the turnaround executed by home builders like Robert Spies.
Mr. Spies, based in the Dallas suburbs, builds what used to be called starter homes. These days he is keeping busy, and then some. Straight through the weekend, he tours subdivisions where he could start projects and inspects the last of the more than 100 homes he has built this year, the most since 1988. 
 Banks and savings-and-loans are competing to lend him money, and rarely does he get as far as sodding a front lawn without finding a buyer.
That is a far cry from two and a half years ago, when he was on the verge of declaring bankruptcy. The Government took over his major lender and cut off his credit. Potential home buyers were holding back for fear of losing their jobs. His work crews, idled, eventually dispersed.
 
A Painfully Close Call
 "I've gotten 'survivor' written across my chest," he said, drawing himself up with a deep breath. "By the grace of God, I made it."
The boom in home buying and building, in Dallas and much of the rest of the country, has animated the broader economy.
Builders require supplies of materials and labor. Home buyers shop for furnishings and appliances. So today's buyers and construction workers are tomorrow's customers at Sears, Ethan Allen or Circuit City.
[The Commerce Department reported on Friday that home starts were up 3.9 percent in November. Purchases by first-time buyers accounted for much of the gain.]
Visiting a construction site, Mr. Spies, 57, steps nimbly through the skeletal frame of a $100,000 home going up 20 minutes east of downtown Dallas. He prods the carpenters to stay until they use every scrap of lumber delivered that day, lest overnight disappearances cause delays.
For the first time in five years, Mr. Spies is also developing raw land for new neighborhoods, putting in roads, utilities and sewers.
Until recently, Dallas builders could buy all the lots they needed from the Government, which had seized them when the savings and loan institutions capsized. His project in east Dallas, he said, is on some of the last of those lots, its basic facilities and services provided, but then left vacant for years.
Although banks have recently become more willing to lend, their rules are new. "Ten years ago, I could virtually do a land development without putting a nickel into it," Mr. Spies said. "Today, I've got to bring the land to the deal, free and clear." To buy the land without borrowing, Mr. Spies has had to find investment partners, which has cut profits. The banks only finance the improvements.
Even so, by this fall, new single-family houses were going up at the fastest rate nationally since the mid-80's. About a third of the current 4 percent annual growth in the economy can be traced to the building of single-family houses and related spending, said Kenneth T. Rosen, chairman of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Economics at the University of California at Berkeley.
Falling prices and low mortgage rates have brought out the buyers, while banks' renewed willingness to lend has helped builders.
"Housing is the most affordable it's been in two decades," Mr. Rosen said. "It's an affordable-housing boom."
 
Recovery in Name Only
 It's also a boom that has been very slow in coming. New housing, usually the first flower of a recovery, failed to blossom this time until the limp expansion was more than two years old.
The reasons become evident in the story of Mr. Spies's near-collapse and recovery. He is the sort of builder that others in Dallas -- perhaps conscious of their industry's sometimes hucksterish, high-risk tinge -- point to as a good example, his dealings as tidy as a model home.
During the mid-80's boom, Mr. Spies was building 150 to 200 houses a year. His staff of 20 included crews to pour foundations and nail together frames. He remained conservative, borrowing only half the price of his $20,000 building lots. He turned down $10,000 a month from some savings and loan executives to do little more than front for their real estate deals. He still had plenty of money for cruises or European tours and for meals at the Dallas restaurants of the moment.
In mid-1987, regulators demonstrated their trust in Mr. Spies by installing him as a board member at two failed savings and loan institutions in Houston and asked him to liquidate them within about six months. He saw loan portfolios that included land directly under a dam. An appraisal calmly noted that the dam was opened, flooding the land, "only once a year."
Then the regulators told him they had too little money to pay off the depositors. Board members had little choice but to raise interest rates to levels among the highest in the country, in search of new capital. They drew in brokered deposits up to the $100,000 limit of Federal insurance, drawing money away from healthier institutions. His own financing came from a solid Fort Worth bank, Texas American, so he thought he had few worries.
But as more savings and loan institutions failed, the Government was saddled with more and more of the residential building lots those institutions had financed. Efforts to sell those lots only depressed prices.
By January 1989, when the savings and loans were finally liquidated, Mr. Spies was telling his loan officer at Texas American that his sales, and the value of his building lots, were evaporating.
In June, the loan officer made a call that left Mr. Spies dumbfounded. "We have been taken over by the F.D.I.C.," the banker said, attributing the bank's failure to rash real estate lending. "We can no longer make you any loans. I don't know what else to tell you."
Mr. Spies was soon instructed to repay everything he owed or lose his building lots. He and his wife talked with a lawyer about personal and corporate bankruptcy. The lawyer calmed them down somewhat. With other builders in far worse shape, Mr. Spies decided to keep struggling -- in the hope that the regulators would be willing to strike a deal.
He cut his staff from 20 to 8, as his workers left to build houses in Florida or the Carolinas or work in factories. When friends invited him to dine out or take vacations, he politely declined.
When the regulators hired specialists in working out the repayment of soured loans, Mr. Spies offered plans to pay his debts at less than full value, but more than liquidation would bring. They always demanded more information, more justification. There was no use mentioning his own role in salvaging other threatened savings and loans. "They said: 'You're one of the bad guys. You caused the problem. We know what our rights are, and you have none.' "
He eventually noticed that workout officers who struck deals and closed cases worked themselves out of their jobs, while those who lingered had cases that lingered, too.
To redeem his lots from the bank so he could continue building, he had to pay off a $10,000 loan each time, plus $1,000 or $2,000 in accumulated interest. Nearby, the regulators were selling lots for $6,000 or less.
Any profit Mr. Spies made from building went to the bank. "You were working for the Government," he said. "They controlled everything you did. They were bleeding me to death."
By early 1991, the wealth he had built up for decades was gone and the cash to continue building nearly depleted. "I was at the bottom of the barrel," he said.
A banker friend advised him that his chances of remaining a home builder were greater if he filed for bankruptcy, then started afresh.
The bankruptcy lawyer suggested a final gambit. Mr. Spies told his workout officer that he would no longer cooperate, effectively threatening bankruptcy and challenging the bank to begin liquidation.
He hoped that the liquidation department would be a brier patch, a place where deals could somehow be made. Initially, the bank pressed for the sale of his property. Mr. Spies countered with an offer to buy his business from the bank for about 50 cents on the dollar, reducing his debts by transferring them to an investor he had long known.
The bank demanded exhaustive proof that Mr. Spies was, indeed, the best and highest bidder for his own business. His legal and accounting bills mounted to a quarter of a million dollars.
At 8 P.M. on April 19, 1991, he signed an agreement with the bankers, the regulators and his investor. He had his business back, but his relief was fleeting.
"I thought I would come out the conquering hero, but I was exhausted," he said. "Like John Henry, I beat the steam engine and then collapsed."
Usually upbeat and outgoing, Mr. Spies trudged into work. His remaining assistants, aware of his battle to save their jobs, carried the business along. He looked elsewhere for inspiration, to his wife and two children, his Roman Catholic faith, and to motivational seminars and tapes.
Gradually, the local economy picked up, and interest rates worked their way lower -- "a godsend," Mr. Spies said, for his business and his spirit.
 
Lower Overhead Now
 Now, he does business somewhat differently. Instead of rehiring full construction crews, he has stayed with just eight full-time employees, building homes with subcontractors instead. Lower profits in good times also mean lower overhead in bad ones. "It smoothes out the peaks and valleys," he said.
This spring, with three years to go on his investor's five-year financing, Mr. Spies lined up new, cheaper credit from a savings and loan house. Rather than negotiate better terms, his backer was just as happy to be paid off and free himself of home building's perils.
Mr. Spies notes that the lenders who offered him an easy $10,000 a month in the 1980's, as well as another builder who took it, went to jail. The local home builders' association, he said, has only half its previous members.
But even as home building propels an accelerating recovery, Mr. Spies sees some ominous signs. New builders are entering the business, laying the foundations for the next cycle of overbuilding, overlending and bust.
"When it's real bad, you get nervous, and when it's real good, you get nervous," he said. "In two or three years, there will be another correction, and I'm not sure but that building will lead us all back down."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Liberals and Republicans Scrambling for Giuliani Jobs

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
It's hard to keep straight all the interest groups and political leaders who are claiming credit for the narrow victory of Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani. But none are more unabashed than the leader of the state's Liberal Party, who has been introducing himself to Republicans lately as "Ray Margin-of-Difference Harding."
Of course, Mr. Harding, the girthy, occasional Terminator or King Maker of New York politics, is no stranger to that maxim about the victor and the spoils. He has helped promote two allies to deputy mayorships, and if only Mr. Harding didn't have two sons -- Russell and Robert -- New York's hothouse political establishment might not be so confused about which one is going to get the government job. (The answer probably is both.) 
 Let Republicans grumble that the Liberals are beginning to look less like a party than a jobs program. The Republicans want patronage too. For this is transition, and the whole city government as well as the government-in-waiting is caught in a game of telephone, with rumors more plentiful than packing boxes. It's a time to rake in the debts, exploit Who You Know, a time when ally turns against ally and P.C. means personal career.
 
First Chance Since Lindsay
 What makes it especially delicious -- or depressing -- depending on the side you're on, is that Mr. Giuliani's administration offers job-starved Republicans their first crack at City Hall, and the 1,500 positions under the Mayor's control, since John V. Lindsay was elected Mayor in 1965.
"After so many years out in the wilderness, it's almost overwhelming to suddenly play an active role in the selection of our municipal leadership," said City Councilman Andrew S. Eristoff, whose father, Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff was Mr. Lindsay's Transportation Administrator. "I for one was two years old the last time we elected a Republican mayor."
Already, some transition trends are clear. Social workers and labor organizers are out. Lawyers and former assistant United States Attorneys are in. Pictures of Frederick Douglass are coming down from the walls. Small photos of George and Barbara Bush will soon be on their way in.
Of course, even if they fit the profile, job seekers still have to get in the door. And the first trick is to figure out where to send a resume. The 15 job screening committees are an option. But as the selection of William J. Bratton as Police Commissioner showed, the appointee may not actually come through the committee process at all.
Getting to Peter J. Powers, the deceptively mild-mannered transition chairman, is known as the next best thing to reaching Mr. Giuliani himself. But that's not easy. "Trying to get an appointment is like trying to meet with God -- literally." said Frances Werner, the chairwoman of the Queens County Republican organization, who is peddling her own list of candidates, including State Senator Frank Padavan and Bob Bishop, the vice chairman of the Queens party.
Some aspirants in the know have taken to handing resumes to the doorman at the entrance of Mr. Powers's Upper East Side building. Some applicants send in three resumes, even four.
 
'Owed Something'
 After years of alienation, there are Republicans who remember that even with Mr. Lindsay, they didn't have easy pickings. Mr. Lindsay, after all, took fusion to such an extreme that by his second term (after losing a Republican primary) he was running as a Liberal. Soon after that he became a Democrat. And so this time the Republicans are scrambling to make sure that Mr. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal fusion candidate, remembers them just as much as such exotica of his coalition as the Koch Democrats.
"Queens is owed something," said Ms. Werner. "The Republican Party is owed something."
Still, there are matters beyond loyalty. What about disloyalty? Carlos M. Rivera, the Fire Commissioner under Mayor David N. Dinkins who quit unexpectedly in late summer and endorsed Mr. Giuliani, when the Republican-Liberal candidate was seeking Hispanic support, has let it be known that he would like his old job back. No matter that he serves on the committee picking a fire commissioner. He has said he would recuse himself.
 
The Koch Element
 And since this is a fusion adminstration, Democrats too can seek jobs, especially if they once worked for Mayor Edward I. Koch, who endorsed Mr. Giuliani in the crucial waning days of the Mayor's race. Democrats close to Mr. Koch say he has a little list and is lobbying hard for some people, including Felice L. Michetti, the current Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development.
"I'm not lobbying," Mr. Koch protests. Of Ms. Michetti, he says, "I do indeed recommend her, but I'm not lobbying. I have, to anyone who asked me, that they couldn't get a better commissioner of housing."
One former member of Mr. Koch's cabinet, Paul A. Crotty, has already been tapped as Corporation Counsel. Others loom on the horizon. Maria Mitchell, a former health adviser to Mr. Koch, is among the candidates for head of the Health and Hospitals Corporation. Lilliam Barios-Paoli, a former Koch commissioner, is a contender to run the vast Human Resouces Administration.
Both Donald Zucker, a developer who once served as an unpaid adviser to Mr. Koch, and James Stuckey are in contention for the job Mr. Stuckey once had, as head of the Economic Development Corporation. But a Giuliani advirser said Mr. Zucker's chances diminished after news organizations were tipped that the Zucker Organization has an X-rated video store as a tenant.
In some respects, Henry J. Stern, the quotable, eccentric, former Parks Commissioner should be a shoo-in for his old job. He's close to Mr. Koch. He's a Liberal. His longtime aide, Richard Schwartz, was Mr. Giuliani's deputy campaign manager. But in this age of cutbacks, when Parks Commissioner Betsy Gotbaum has turned to private fund-raising for the parks, some contributers have let it be known that they would not be happy about Mr. Stern's return, according to several people familiar with the lobbying.
 
Conflicting Quests?
 But at least the Parks Department, with or without Mr. Stern, will probably still be there. One of Mr. Giuliani's transition committees has been searching for a Commissioner of Mental Health, while another committee has been similtaneously considering whether the Mental Health Department should be merged with the Health Department.
Christopher Lynn, a member of the Civilian Complaint Review Board, is being touted as a candidate for Human Rights Commissioner, even though Mr. Giuliani hasn't committed to keeping the Human Rights Commission.
This kind of thing can put a damper on the job hunt. Who besides the David A. Stockmans of this world (Where is he now? Does he want a job?) would take a post eliminating their own agency?
It may take several months to answer such questions. Last week, with legions of appointments still to be made, Mr. Giuliani -- the one person in all this who knows he definitely has a job come January 1 -- put out a request to Mr. Dinkins's commissioners: to stay in place until he can find replacements.

Mr. Harding, the occasional Terminator or King Maker of New York politics, has helped promote two allies to deputy mayorships. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Challenges of Today Await Giuliani's Administration

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
"Mayors come and go but the life of the city must endure." David N. Dinkins,
 Nov. 3, 1993
IMPLICIT in Mr. Dinkins's message of continuity was the comforting fact that New York City has survived 106 mayors since 1665 and that it would probably outlast the 107th. Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani's challenge, though, will be to resolve boldly a systemic conflict that threatens not only the city but also his ability to make it to a second term. 
 The voters demanded change and Mr. Giuliani embodies it: neither he nor any member of his newly assembled team of four deputy mayors has ever served at City Hall before (Paul Crotty, the new corporation counsel, is a distinguished veteran of the Koch administration, but may find himself too far removed from daily decision-making in the mayoral orbit). The fledgling administration is long on earnestness and independence -- some say arrogance -- and short on experience. Arguably, it owes little, but knows less.
Or, as one seasoned former official said, "You don't populate a whorehouse with virgins."
The incoming administration responded dismissively earlier this month to provocative recommendations of a nonpartisan commission, created by the Dinkins administration to explore solutions to the city's perpetual budget imbalance. That approach may not bode well for an administration that asks to be measured against its stated hopes of ridding street corners of aggressive squeegee wielders and of avoiding tax increases.
"The taxpaying citizens of New York, whether businesses or individuals, are very sensitive to the housekeeping services that make living and working in the city bearable and desirable," says Donald D. Kummerfeld, a former deputy mayor to Abraham D. Beame and chairman of the mayoral commission.
"If we constantly are forced to choose between investing in housekeeping versus the overwhelming human needs of the deprived population of the city that in human and political terms demand attention, then the quality of life functions get starved or deferred, at best," Mr. Kummerfeld warns.
He suggests reserving revenues from certain fees and taxes for those functions "as a defensive measure to make sure we don't have a city that is falling apart" and warns that "otherwise, it will become another Detroit."
"In a political sense I don't think this choice has been confronted," Mr. Kummerfeld said. "I would have thought if we had any mayor in recent years who is well positioned to do that, it's Rudy Giuliani."
Mr. Giuliani's photograph is the final frame of a new exhibit on mayors opening at the Museum of the City of New York. The first depicted is Whitehead Hicks, the last mayor appointed by the British, who prudently announced in 1776 that he was "desirous to retire from the Town" and move to Flushing. Also displayed are memorabilia from the eras of Mayor Richard Varick, who was acquitted of complicity in Benedict Arnold's treason; A. Oakey Hall, who was indicted with the Tweed Ring but became a successful newspaperman; Robert A. Van Wyck, who invested in a company that sought to monopolize the city's ice supply; as well as exhibits associated with more revered mayors and Mr. Giuliani's more recent predecessors (included is a tweed worsted jacket belonging to Edward I. Koch).
The exhibit opens with Mr. Dinkins's post-election aspiration about endurance. It closes with this quotation from Mr. Giuliani, "My administration will be universal in its concerns, sensitive to our diversity, and even-handed in every way possible."
Last month, the Giuliani transition team debriefed Harvey Robins, who was director of operations under Mr. Dinkins, for suggestions to consolidate city government and deliver services more efficiently. Included were proposals to merge a number of mayoral offices into a new Agency for Neighborhood Services, shift responsibility for taxis back to the Police Department and fold the Department of Employment, the Agency for Childhood Development and the Head Start program into the Department of Youth Services.
"There are no new ideas in economics or sex," Felix G. Rohatyn once said (an adage memorialized in "Quotations from Chairman Felix," a compendium of his pithy remarks as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation).
Only new mayors and new New Yorkers facing familiar problems. "A corporate executive cannot evade tomorrow unless he is on the verge of retirement," Mr. Rohatyn also said. "Politicians always hope that tomorrow will never come, or that, if it comes, it comes after the next election."
In less than two weeks, Mr. Giuliani, who proposed to his wife at Disney World, will find himself choosing between Fantasyland and Tomorrowland.
For the Dinkins administration, tomorrow arrives two weeks from yesterday. The inauguration Jan. 2 signals Mr. Giuliani's first official today.

HEADLINE: Voucher Plan To Aid Beggars Is Put in Place On West Side

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
A community group seeking a solution to panhandling on the Upper West Side yesterday announced the city's first program in which residents can give vouchers -- redeemable for food or personal items -- instead of money to beggars.
Following the lead of Berkeley, Calif., which started the nation's first voucher program in 1991, the group, West Side Cares, began its effort this weekend as a way to "stop feeding the drug dealers and start feeding people in need," said Laura Friedman, a coordinator of the group, which includes merchants, charitable organizations and residents. 
 The program, which was met yesterday with praise and criticism from advocates for the homeless, targets 19 blocks of Broadway, between 106th Street and 125th Street. So far, 17 stores have agreed to sell the 25-cent vouchers to customers, who can give them to panhandlers. The vouchers can then be redeemed at face value for food and personal items in seven participating stores, including two Sloan's supermarkets, four smaller markets and a bagel shop.
 
Quality of Life Issues
 Like similar programs set up in a dozen cities, such as New Haven, Seattle and Chicago, West Side Cares' plan is intended to address quality of life issues raised by residents, organizers said.
As the thousands of New York City panhandlers have become more aggressive in their daily hustles, residents have bristled, Ms. Friedman said. "That is the wrong reaction," she said. "I think this will help everyone in the neighborhood -- people who genuinely need to be fed and people who want to give without being worried they are giving to drug dealers."
Christopher Fay, executive director of Broadway Community Incorporated, which offers homeless services, said that the vouchers are a "practical and compassionate response" to the panhandling problem.
And Sam Szurek, a spokesman for the New York City Department of Homeless Services, said that while he could not offer an official response from the city, he considers the voucher plan "a fine program, if it works."
 
Reactions Vary
 But advocates for the homeless and others who study poverty yesterday had mixed reactions to the program. Some said they welcomed a plan that encouraged people to give to the poor. Others, however, said the vouchers would do little more than ease consciences for those who refuse to give or who do so only out of a sense of annoyance, guilt or pity.
They say that the vouchers are simply another sign of a nation frustrated by failed social policies and they point to a report last week by the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty that says cities are increasingly enacting and enforcing anti-vagrancy laws to jail homeless people or remove them from busy areas.
"This is just another way to avoid dealing with the real problems," said Joel Blau, a professor at the School of Social Welfare at the State University of New York, Stony Brook. "It's a substitute for a decent policy for homeless people."
Even when the beggars are not homeless, he said, the vouchers "take away a sense of independence from people giving contributions and it reduces the self-determination of people on the street." Professor Blau said he would not participate in a voucher program but prefers to give change to panhandlers he judges are less likely to use it for drugs or alcohol.
'Let's Not Kid Ourselves'
Mary Brosnahan, executive director of the city's Coalition for the Homeless, said she was ambivalent. "On the one hand, if it allows more people to feel comfortable giving to the poor, then that's great," she said. "But let's not kid ourselves that it's bringing us one step closer to a real solution."
Existing voucher programs in other cities get mixed reviews as well. In Berkeley, residents have purchased nearly 250,000 vouchers over the last two years, 70 percent of which have been redeemed. In New Haven, 40 percent of the 9,000 vouchers sold have been used. But in Portland, only 13 percent of the 8,000 vouchers sold have been traded in.
"It's not really going to change anything," said Randall K. Filer, an economics professor at Hunter College, who studies poverty. Berkeley has been successful, he says, largely because the city has a much more homogenous community with a common liberal bent and large numbers of people have agreed to participate in the program.
 
Street Currency
 "In New York, I can't imagine getting most people to agree on anything," he said. Beggars will continue to get money along with vouchers, he said. And those who do get vouchers but want money instead will simply sell the vouchers to others, turning them, like food stamps, into a form of street currency.
But on the street yesterday, shop owners, panhandlers and customers alike said they were hopeful the program would work.
"I think it will definitely help, especially for people who really need it for food," said Mitchell Moore, store manager at Sloan's grocery store at Broadway at 110th Street.
Outside, Herman Johnson, stood quietly with his back against the grocery store wall, his right hand wrapped around a tattered, empty paper cup. At this post, which he said he had held for eight hours a day for five years, Mr. Johnson, a 39-year-old man who goes by "Hollywood Hall of Fame," said that he has seen passers-by grow more reluctant to give. On a good day, he said, he can make $20, which helps go toward the rent on his mother-in-law's apartment, where he lives. On a drizzly day like yesterday, it may be less than $10.
 
'A Beautiful Idea'
 "I think it's a beautiful idea," he said. "Everyone is not living the right way. And this is sending you to a store to buy what you need for breakfast, lunch or dinner."
Lewis Brown, who said he panhandles in the area from time to time, agreed. "It's a good idea," he said. "But I wonder how many people are going to buy the vouchers?"
As she walked out of the University Food Market at Broadway and 115th Street, Gayle Mitrani, a 22-year-old senior at Barnard College, said she usually refused to give to beggars, who stand with cups outstretched for blocks surrounding Columbia University. But she said she would be willing to try giving out vouchers. "This way I'll know it's going for food," she said.
Ms. Friedman said that so far, things are looking good. As of yesterday afternoon, the second day of the program, 100 or so vouchers had already been redeemed. Though initial expenses came out of volunteers' pockets, the state is providing $3,500 in seed money, and another $1,000 will be provided by seed grant money from the office of Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger.

GRAPHIC: Photo: West Side Cares, a community group in Manhattan, has started a program in which residents can give vouchers, below -- redeemable for food or personal items -- instead of money to beggars. Lewis Brown, center, who said he panhandles sometimes, said, "It's a good idea. But I wonder how many people are going to buy the vouchers?" (Dith Pran/The New York Times) (pg. B9)

HEADLINE: The Marketing of Kwanzaa;
Black American Holiday Earns Dollars, Causing Concern

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
The four attendants at the ice cream stand held hands, as one of the them prayed. "Lord, give everyone who comes a hungry thirst for this ice cream," he said.
So began the Kwanzaa Holiday Expo for the Ben & Jerry's store in Harlem, one of about 300 businesses whose presence at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center over the weekend offered a convincing sign of the commercial potential of the black American holiday. 
 While Ben & Jerry's brought its exquisite sweet potato ice cream, other exhibitors showed dark-complexioned dolls, African art, Jamaican root tonic, Kente cloth neckties, handcrafted African roses and an odd contraption that gives a passable back massage.
But perhaps more telling was the presence of corporate giants like Anheuser-Busch, Pepsi-Cola, Revlon, Chemical Bank, A.T.& T. and Time-Life Books.
 
A Reflective Period
 "If Kwanzaa is what one of your target markets is involved in, it's what you need to be involved in," said Darlene Bryan, director of special markets for the Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company of New York.
Organizers of the annual trade fair, which only last year moved the Manhattan Community College into the spacious confines of the Javits Center, realize the same thing. "We have been working to repackage and remarket Kwanzaa," said Jose Ferrer, chairman of the Expo. "Corporate America seems a lot more comfortable in associating with it."
Kwanzaa, which takes its name from the Swahili word for "first fruits" and is based on African harvest festivals, begins on Dec. 26 and lasts until Jan. 1. A candle is lighted each day, gifts are exchanged and lessons are read in what is usually a family-centered, reflective period.
Maulana Karenga, chairman of the black studies department at California State University at Long Beach, who began the observance in 1966, said Kwanzaa is America's fastest-growing holiday with 18 million celebrants.
Mr. Ferrer and others involved in the marketing of Kwanzaa have stressed the message that the holiday, a cultural rather than a religious observance, is not a substitute for Christmas, not anti-Christ and not an exclusionary gesture.
"People were afraid of it, almost like it was separatist and apart," said Terry Keeling, the Woolworth Corporation's district manager for Upper Manhattan and the Bronx.
This year, Woolworth's began Kwanzaa promotions in 19 New York City stores, offering African-centered books, cards and art objects and holding a contest for children to design Kwanzaa cards. "It's moved more to the mainstream this year than any other," Mr. Keeling said.
Hallmark, for the second year, is selling Kwanzaa cards nationally. After successfully offering one card last year, the company is now selling 12 varieties. All use designs made by the Harlem Textile Works, which teaches students in various crafts.
 
More Commercial Inroads
 "We decided to give people more of what they were happy with last year," said Ronnye Peace, a Hallmark spokeswoman.
Also, Pepsi is promoting supermarket sweepstakes in two area chains, while J. C. Penney is offering for the first time several Kwanzaa products in stores around the country. Anheuser-Busch is sponsoring several events at the Expo for the first time, including a large African-centered fashion show Friday night.
Commercial inroads are also apparent in neighborhood stores outside of predominantly black neighborhoods. At Little Things, a novelty store in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, Kwanzaa is being promoted in a special section for the first time. The merchandise includes black dolls, Kwanzaa books and Kwanzaa bears in colorful African attire, which are now almost sold out.
"We had Hanukkah and Christmas and now we have Kwanzaa," said Edith Brafman, a buyer for the store. Kwanzaa's growing importance to larger merchandisers, makes others nervous, not least because they are threatened by it. Harold Thomas, vice president of Gumbs & Thomas, a New York publisher that has sold Kwanzaa cards for eight years, said, "We have to be careful that in commercializing it, it isn't lost to the black community."
When Dr. Karenga first spelled out his concept for the holiday, one of the explicit principles he cited was Ujamma, which in Swahili means cooperative economics. He said this meant "to build and maintain our own stores, shops and other businesses and to profit from them together."
 
Trying for the Homespun
 In response to numerous queries this year about the growing corporate interest, he issued a statement, saying in part, "The challenge for the African people is to avoid the problems of commercialization that they've learned from other holidays like Christmas."
But the worry among some blacks is precisely that Kwanzaa could become more like Christmas, with its pressures to spend. Lagrane Brooks, who lives in East New York and who works for a film distribution company, said she tried to keep the holiday homespun with only small educational gifts for her 5-year-old son.
The eager exhibitors at the Expo, each of whom had paid $900 for a booth for the four-day event, certainly had no qualms about money-making. Bobbi Humphrey, the pop-jazz flutist who had a booth to sell her compact disks and a poster of one of her photographs, said: "Black people need not be embarrassed about making money. That is what pays the rent and makes America tick."
The expo itself is powerful testimony to the growing importance of Kwanzaa. It began in 1981 as a small celebration in a Harlem school, then moved to successively larger locations as participants grew. Last year, it moved to the Javits Center and drew 250 exhibitors. This year, 300 companies and individuals rented booths from the privately owned company Mr. Ferrer heads.
Mr. Ferrer predicts 50,000 people will visit the show, which closes today. He estimates they will spend $5 million. A smaller show the company staged last week in St. Louis rang up sales of $2.5 million.
For consumers, a clear result of the heightened interest in Kwanzaa is lower prices for products related to the holiday. At one booth, the price of the candleholder, called a Kinara, used for the ritual lighting of a candle, has dropped to $50 from $100 in the last several years, said Malik Ahmed, the proprietor.
Most vendors are small, with their participation perhaps representing a first venture into entrepreneurship. The New York City Housing Authority is using the expo to showcase products developed in an entrepreneurial training program it conducts for project residents. Exhibiting were the fledgling magnates of two T-shirt companies, called Ghetto Gear and Projek Wear. Besides 12 people exhibiting, the authority is taking 1,000 housing project residents in buses to see the grass-roots business activity.
Some exhibitors arrive with high expectations. Harrington Khari came from Los Angeles to sell vests he makes with African designs and messages, which he calls "wearable knowledge." Though he has never been to the Kwanzaa Expo, he said that based on his experience at other African-American bazaars, he expected to sell out $20,000 of his merchandise by today.
The hope of many is that such individual success can be marketed to corporations. In addition to Hallmark's use of the work of Harlem students, J. C. Penney and Woolworth's both bought from black producers. Part of the corporations' interest, suggested Cedric McClester, the expo spokesman, has been the presence of more black executives who have pressed their organizations to get on the Kwanzaa bandwagon.
"There is no problem with commercializing it, but who will be the benefactors of the commercialization?" Mr. McClester said. "It should be people of African descent, not just corporate America."

HEADLINE: A Bar for Wild Ones, and for Domestic Ones

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SYRACUSE

 BODY:
The kitsch-crowned Dinosaur Bar B Que here is where Armani meets heavy leather -- all right, since this is a town that avoids affectation, it's where "off the rack" meets heavy leather.
Just five years after the Dinosaur was opened by Harley-Davidson riders, the blues bar for bikers has emerged as a melting pot where the heirs of the "The Wild One" rub shoulders with people who bought their children the video. 
 "It's the kind of place where middle-age white-collar men talk earnestly about the merits of tattoos and the definition of tattoo art," said Kihm Winship, an advertising copy writer and occasional actor, before hurrying home to read the final two chapters of a Nancy Drew mystery to his young daughter.
The clientele is a melange of bikers and business people, rebels and yuppies -- united by the love of good food at reasonable prices and the unceasing wail of the blues.
 
Champagne and Ribs
 The special on the Day-Glo yellow, plastic-covered menu offers one clue to the bar's dual personality: "Dom Perignon w/rack of ribs." It's $130.
More evidence comes from the bar's Lettermanesque list of reasons why it is the best place for holiday gatherings: "Easy cleanup afterward; the wet-naps are on the table." And, of course, "Absolutely no bad Christmas songs by Pat Boone and Family."
In many ways, the red-and-white diner embodies the evolution of a mining and industrial center known as the Salt City into an academic and education center that bills itself as the Hub of the Empire State and reflexively rejects the mannerisms of larger cities in the state.
"The Dinosaur is the antidote to high-tech," said Lee Conant, the manager of a cafe in the Barnes & Noble bookstore and a caterer who rues what he says is the city's disdain for fine dining. "Instead of the knife-cutting by class, it cuts by attitude. If you can't wear it, drive it or live in it, Syracuse won't spend money on it. Nobody in Syracuse wants to spend money on food."
Just as a ring of factories once encircled this city, the Dinosaur is surrounded in warmer months with a wall of chromed Harleys. Nearby parking lots are filled with luxury sedans whose blinking red alarms turn even summer nights into Christmas. And in winter, the waiting line for tables is a recurrent pattern of plaid flannel and black leather.
 
'Everybody Fits'
 "We've got suits, we've got bikers, we've got young and we've got old," said Cheri Pomatto, a 30-year-old waitress who is expecting her second child. "Every type of life walks through here. And everybody fits. Very seldom is there a problem; very seldom is there any kind of fight."
The Dinosaur goes out of its way to cross-pollinate road warriors with intellectual wanderers, contributing $40 toward employees' first tattoos. A sign on the wall says, "Friends don't let friends eat tofu."
"The waitresses are biker chicks, but you're likely to get one with a British accent," said Rudy Kerven, a customer with a degree in accounting who alternates between being an unemployed roofer and an unemployed pianist.
The bar provokes a continuing conversation between customers by encouraging them to scrawl graffiti on its bathrooms' legal-pad-yellow walls. The Dinosaur takes great pride in these musings and devotes a segment of its monthly newsletter to the staff's favorite sayings. "You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll think!!!" promises the section, "It Came From the Toilet."
Harleys and dinosaurs may have become the latest life-style statements, what conspicuous consumption was to the Me Generation years.
 
Hillbilly Dinosaurs
 The bar grows out of a food stand opened a decade ago at a campground with a primitive theme.
"At the time, the music scene was terrible, we were still listening to the Allman Brothers and I was riding a '57 Panhead," said John Stage, the principal owner. "We were dinosaurs. So we called it Dinosaur Concessions."
His dry-rub barbecue, a Memphis style, was a lip-smacking success. Along with his partner, known universally as Dino, Mr. Stage was soon traveling the East Coast in an old station wagon, towing a pit fashioned from half a 55-gallon oil drum to Harley events.
"We were the Beverly Hillbillies of food," says Mr. Stage, a 33-year-old barbecue maven who says he "reads cookbooks like some people read newspapers."
But he kept returning to Syracuse to have his motorcycle serviced by friends at Andy's Cycle Shop Inc., a dilapidated second-floor Harley-Davidson parts dealership. They pushed him to take over the downstairs restaurant, N & H, a city landmark and traditional shot-and-beer joint whose septuagenarian owners were looking to retire.
"We opened in 1988 and starved for two years," Mr. Stage recalls. "We always said thank God we're in the restaurant business. We thought of closing the doors many times, but we're hardheads."
Three years ago, the Dinosaur installed a bar. Business was soon booming and live blues became a nightly event. Now Mr. Stage is bottling his barbecue sauce and flirting with franchising his restaurant. So far, at least, he's decided against it.
"You lose a little something by expanding," he says. "This is our baby."

HEADLINE: Troubles for Labor;
Legislative Actions in Albany Show Longtime Clout of Unions Is Fading

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 19

 BODY:
By passing one bill and killing off another last week, the New York State Legislature sent renewed notice to organized labor that union influence over statehouse politics continues to wane.
Neither action represented a crushing blow to labor, which remains an important player in the Capitol. But viewed in a line of setbacks this year, they suggest Albany that has become less able, or less willing, to deliver for unions. 
 "It's nothing like 20 years ago when the first question in the Assembly was what does labor think," said Norman Adler, a political consultant who works with several unions representing public employees.
Ending what was perhaps the year's most important labor battle, state lawmakers on Thursday passed legislation intended to control the spiraling cost of workers' compensation insurance by requiring some injured workers to seek treatment from managed-care cooperatives. Unions had lobbied furiously against the bill, arguing that it would place workers in the care of company doctors.
 
'They Took a Hit'
 In what struck some as an attempt to paint victory on a canvas of defeat, labor leaders claimed success in diluting portions of the bill, even though their original goal had been to kill it. But many labor loyalists acknowledged in the end that a major fight had been lost.
"The feeling is, yes, they took a hit," said Assemblyman Joseph Crowley, a Queens Democrat who sits on the Labor Committee.
Also on Thursday, negotiators failed to reach agreement on legislation that would have required payment of union wages on most types of publicly financed construction projects. The bill has been a longstanding goal of construction trade unions and, in failing to reach a compromise, the Legislature squandered an opportunity that may not return for years, many labor supporters say.
 
Other Disappointments
 There were other disappointments for labor this year. In September, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed legislation intended to give New York City school principals more control over custodians -- a law many unions had protested as an unprecedented violation of collective bargaining.
Last July the Legislature rejected a proposal by the Transport Workers Union for improved pension benefits. And in August Mr. Cuomo vetoed a bill that would have prevented conversations between police officers and their union representatives from being used in criminal investigations.
Labor unions continue to be among the most generous campaign contributors to state elected officials, ranking alongside, and sometimes ahead of, banks, lawyers and doctors.
But the weak economy, declining union membership and disunity within the union movement itself have all contributed to labor's loss of clout in Albany. So has the growing importance of television in political campaigns, a trend that has reduced candidates' dependence on union foot soldiers to get out the vote.
 
Fundamental Changes
 Perhaps more than anything else, labor's misfortunes this year say volumes about fundamental changes in the Democratic-controlled Assembly, long considered labor's house.
Last year Democrats won a record number of seats, 101, in the 150-member Assembly, with most of the new members from rural and suburban districts. Unlike their brethren in the cities, where union membership is highest, the new lawmakers have proved less sympathetic, and sometimes hostile, to labor's concerns.
"The upstate Democrats are more centrist than the traditional downstaters," said Denis M. Hughes, executive assistant to the president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. "There's more debate today on labor issues in the Democratic conference than in the 20 years I've been following the Legislature."
"Union people," said Assemblyman Crowley, "have been walking around saying, 'Do we have to go to the Senate now to kill bills?' "
Given the State Senate's traditionally close alliance to business, few think that will happen soon. Less clear is the status of labor's relationship with Mr. Cuomo.
 
A Pivotal Role
 In 1982 the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was one of Mr. Cuomo's earliest supporters and played a pivotal role in his unexpected victory over Edward I. Koch in the Democratic primary for governor.
But in recent years Mr. Cuomo has taken positions that have made some labor leaders uneasy, including criticizing New York City's contracts with its unions as too generous, supporting budget-balancing plans that withheld paychecks from state workers and, this year, strongly supporting the workers' compensation bill.
It would appear, some union leaders say, that Mr. Cuomo wants to counter criticism about his stewardship of the state's economy by winning support from business groups, particularly the Business Council, the state's largest business organization.
The Governor pressed several initiatives sought by the council this year, including the workers' compensation bill, legislation that would restrict lawsuits against corporate boards and a bill that would make it more difficult for consumers to win product liability cases.
"He keeps striving for a balance between both business and labor," said Mr. Hughes of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "And as my father used to say, 'When someone stands in the middle of the road, they usually get run over.' "

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Plotting Fed Rate Move: Yes, but . . . But Then . . .

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
For now it seems that long-term interest rates have seen their lows. But the debate over what the Federal Reserve will do next year, and when it will do it, is picking up.
Most experts think that the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond has reached its lows for now. Should it somehow breach the 5.78 percent level reached on Oct. 15, a 25-year closing low, such an event would happen far enough into next year for analysts to point to a new set of circumstances to explain the drop -- like an unforeseen decrease in inflation or a lowering of inflationary expectations. 
 As for the Fed, the outlook is unclear. The consensus seems to be that the Fed will push short-term interest rates higher by raising its 3 percent target for Federal funds, a level that has held for more than a year. Estimates are that the funds rate will rise one-quarter to one-half a percentage point. (No change in interest-rate policy is expected when the Fed's policy-making body meets tomorrow.)
But that is where agreement ends. Among those who a rate rise, there is no consensus on the timing -- it could be anywhere from early in the new year to sometime after midyear.
 
A Pre-emptive Strike
 There is also disagreement over how forceful the Fed will be, a debate that has led to speculation about a pre-emptive strike against inflation by the nation's central bank, a favorite theme in the bond market.
One measure of a pre-emptive strike would be how quickly the Fed moved and whether the move was made before there was definitive data showing inflation rising above the 3 percent level of the last two years. Another gauge would be how much the bank raised the Federal funds rate, which is the interest on overnight loans between banks. Two increases over time of one-quarter of a percentage point each would not be as tough as a single increase of one-half of a point early on.
And there are some who said they did not think the Fed would raise short-term rates because, they say, both growth and inflation will remain in check.
Though forecasts of growth and inflation play parts in predicting Fed action, analysts' views of the Fed -- its goals and targets -- color the predictions, too. The fact that the Clinton Administration is about to appoint a new governor to the seven-member board to replace Wayne D. Angell, a hawk on inflation, adds to the debate over the Fed's attitude.
 
Late Move Predicted
 Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, is forecasting a very late move by the Fed, even though he said he expected the economy to be surprisingly strong early next year, with first-quarter growth of 4 percent, after adjustment for inflation. Other forecasters would see such growth setting off a move by the Fed.
But Mr. Kudlow said he did not expect the Fed to be so tough on inflation because of political pressure and because it "does not want to risk ending this boomlet."
"The Fed's discipline on the margin is eroding right now," he said, "and the President's nominee will add to that erosion" because the likely candidates to fill the Angell vacancy are expected to be growth advocates.
"The Fed," he continued, "will not tighten until they get two or three consecutive C.P.I.'s above 3 percent." And if rises in the Consumer Price Index early next year are temporarily distorted on the high side by seasonal factors, as they have been for the last several years, the Fed will wait even longer, he said.
But John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said he believed that the Fed and the Clinton Administration had a stronger commitment to controlling inflation. "We think that there are reasons to believe that policy makers will be more serious about inflation," he said of the outlook of Salomon Brothers.
He said the Fed would quickly raise short-term interest rates if the economy was growing at a 3.5 percent pace at the beginning of the year. The Fed, he said, "has to move before the inflation rate has been perceived to have moved up" to maintain its credibility on inflation in the financial markets. This means acting long before the consumer price statistics document a change.
Mr. Lipsky said he did not include inflation, as such, among the factors that would force the Fed to change its policy. Instead, it will be moved by accelerating growth, rising demand for credit and a falling dollar, he said. This means the central bank could raise interest rates even if inflation were still around 3 percent, making this pretty close to a pre-emptive strike, although there was no agreement on the definition.
 
Questions of Pressure
 Mr. Kudlow and Mr. Lipsky also disagreed on how much pressure the Clinton Administration will put on the Fed to keep interest rates from rising. Mr. Kudlow, referring to recent comments by Mr. Clinton, concluded that the Administration did not want the Fed to increase rates, especially with inflation at such a low level.
Mr. Lipsky, noting remarks from other Administration officials, concluded that the President would accept a moderate increase in short-term interest rates if that would help calm worries about inflation and keep long-term rates from rising. Low long-term interest rates are an important source of economic stimulus the Administration has working for it.
Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers, predicted that the Fed would not raise rates any time soon. Commenting on the possibility of a pre-emptive strike and the leanings of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, Mr. Sinai said: "If they did it this time around, it would be the first time in history. I think Greenspan is too traditional." Of the economy, he said, "There is nothing in growth and inflation to get the Fed to move."

HEADLINE: Split Over Rates Ends Clinton-Fed Honeymoon

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
It was sweet for 11 months, but the honeymoon between President Clinton and the Federal Reserve has finally come to an end.
The beginning of the end came with bickering over the President's proposal to have just one agency regulate the nation's banks, a move that would take away some of the Federal Reserve's power. And now it seems President Clinton could sue for divorce if the central bank raises interest rates early next year to fight inflation, as some rumblings from within the Fed suggest. 
 The Clinton Administration is delighted that the economy has finally started to advance, and the last thing it wants is for the Fed to slow it down by raising rates. But Administration officials cannot hide their fears that the Federal Reserve will raise rates to make sure that inflation does not surge.
 
Not If, but When and How Much
 "The real question is not whether interest rates go up, but when and how much," said Frank Newman, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance.
Last week Mr. Clinton was so worried that the Fed might sabotage his promise of stronger growth that he engaged in some unusually outspoken jawboning, saying, "There's no indication that we're facing a return of inflation." He added that until the economy produced "some real threat of inflation it would be inappropriate for us to choke off an economy that has already had a false start or two" since the 1990-91 recession ended.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen joined the jawboning today by saying that with the economy growing at a 3 percent annual rate and inflation low, he saw no need for the Fed to push up interest rates.
"I don't see it in the current quarter or the next quarter," Mr. Bentsen said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
In recent interviews and speeches, Federal Reserve officials indicated that they would not approve an immediate rate increase when the central bank's main policy-making committee met Tuesday.
 
No Alarm Bells Heard
 "I don't see anything at the moment that sends alarm bells ringing about inflation," John P. LaWare, a Fed governor, said in an interview last week.
Even though inflation continues to slide, these officials signaled that they might push to raise rates before long in response to the recent surge in economic growth. The Fed's governors seem to have a predisposition that makes them fear that inflationary pressures will burst forth as soon as economic growth blossoms.
"We seem to have a lot of growth out there, which should make us a bit cautious," the Fed's vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr., said at a conference of the American Enterprise Institute this month. "Once you can see clearly visible signs that inflationary pressures are embedded, it seems awfully late in the game" to act to stop inflation.
He suggested that the central bank's short-term interest rates were so low that they could overstimulate the economy and reignite inflation, although he acknowledged that Pentagon cutbacks and high debt burdens were holding back growth.
Mr. Mullins signaled that he did not support an immediate rate increase, saying, "There is no compelling evidence at this time that inflationary pressures are building."
The Fed is getting contradictory signals from two statistics it watches closely as harbingers of economywide inflation -- unit labor costs, which are declining, and commodity prices, which are inching up.
In an interview, Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Fed governor, read the tea leaves this way: "The inflation genie is in the bottle, but the cork isn't on the bottle." A likely translation: As soon as the genie starts to stir, the Fed will rush to recork the bottle.
The Administration fears that if the Fed raises short-term rates it would weaken the interest-sensitive sectors that are the only engines of growth: housing, business investment and big-ticket durable items, like cars. But the Fed view is that if it increases short-term rates, then the rates it views as key to sustaining growth -- long-term rates -- should stay low because the bond market would see the Fed's commitment to smother inflation.
Several Administration officials said in private that they could accept an increase of one-fourth of a percent in short-term rates once inflationary pressures materialized. But anything more than that would make them uncomfortable, they said.
Economists are divided on how soon and how vigorously the Fed will act.
Predicting that the Fed could raise rates next month, David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York brokerage, said the Fed would aggressively push up its main short-term interest rate, currently 3 percent, to 3.75 percent by April and 4.5 percent by next December. The Federal funds rate is the rate banks charge one another on overnight loans.
"What the Fed wants is a soft takeoff," he said, adding that Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, "believes that if he waits till he sees the whites of the eyes of inflation, it will be too late."
"His case to the White House will be a stitch in time saves nine," Mr. Jones said.
David Munro, a Fed watcher at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm, expects Mr. Greenspan to act far more gingerly because of his cautious personality. Mr. Munro predicted that the Fed would wait until March or April to pull the trigger because it would first want to see how strong first-quarter growth was. His forecast: the Fed will lift the Federal funds rate to 3.5 percent by next December.
"They will act only when there is a fairly strong sign of acceleration in inflationary pressures," he said. "They know Congress will come after them very uncomfortably if there isn't a very solid case.'
Nowadays Mr. Greenspan feels caught in a vise between the two houses of Congress.
 
More Political Control Sought
 Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, wants to assert more political control over the Fed by giving the President, rather than private bankers, the power to name the presidents of its 12 regional banks. Those presidents hold 5 of the 12 seats on the Fed's main policy-making committee and the Federal Reserve Board's 7 governors hold the rest. To Fed officials, the Gonzalez plan is a blatant attempt to cripple their independence.
As for the Senate, Fed officials may be rejoicing about the decision by a veteran Fed basher, Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Senate Banking Committee, not to run for re-election. But they can scarcely be encouraged by the man likely to replace him as committee chairman, Paul Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat who is a more articulate Fed critic than Mr. Riegle.
With an eye to the 1994 elections, Mr. Sarbanes has already warned the Fed that he and other lawmakers are in no mood for higher rates. In a sharply worded letter to Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Sarbanes and Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committee, said it was "incomprehensible" that the central bank would consider tightening monetary policy "despite the absence of inflationary pressures."
They added that "it would be a tragedy to jeopardize the current" economic expansion.
Behind the Fed's marble walls, the big worry is that if the central bankers anger Mr. Clinton, he might support Mr. Gonzalez's proposals. Until now, many economists say, Mr. Clinton has tried to build good will with the Fed by maintaining that he treasures its independence and that, at least for now, he does not back Mr. Gonzalez's proposals.
Fed officials say they are pleased that relations are better with the Clinton Administration than with the Bush Administration. The situation grew so tense over the Fed's failure to cut rates as fast as former Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady wanted that he and Mr. Greenspan broke off their weekly breakfasts.
Clinton Administration officials say a rate rise will not mean an end to Mr. Greenspan's tennis matches or weekly meetings with Mr. Bentsen.
