HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Magazines Create On-Line Salons

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Ever on the lookout for new readers, the magazine industry seems to have hit paydirt. It has discovered electronic publishing.
Almost 100 magazines have signed up with on-line computer services in the last six months and others are joining at the rate of two or three a week. At the same time, a sigh of relief is sweeping the industry because the availability of on-line magazines does not seem to be hurting traditional subscriptions and newsstand sales. 
 "Very few people read text on-line; it's not that much fun," said Jonathan Bulkeley, general manager for media at America Online, one of the leading electronic publishing services. "It's not as compelling as a magazine."
The real popularity of electronic magazines, in fact, has little to do with reading and everything to do with talking. And talking and talking and talking.
 
Opinions Galore
 Subscribers to on-line services are conversing electronically with magazines ranging from Time and Omni to Consumer Reports and Disney Adventures. Many users are offering gripes, praise and advice to editors and writers. Others are scanning electronic bulletin boards for magazine-sponsored discussion sessions, in which they direct questions to everyone from the Rev. Billy Graham to Vice President Al Gore. They are also participating in on-line forums, arguing vehemently about ethics and violence and politics.
"It is like a gold rush," said James Gleick, founder of the Pipeline, a New York-based link to the Internet, a global computer network. "Everybody is suddenly realizing that this world exists and that it is filled with interesting, intelligent, text-oriented people -- and suddenly everyone wants to be there."
All it takes is a computer, a modem and a telephone line. The three major on-line services -- the Prodigy Services Company, with 2 million members; Compuserve, with 1.5 million, and America Online Inc., with 500,000 -- charge less than $15 a month for basic service with some additional fees for extras. America Online, for instance, has a basic monthly fee of $9.95 for the first five hours and $3.50 an hour after that.
The cost to publishers is scant. They are responsible for supplying text, making editors available at specified times for on-line discussions and publishing promotional materials in their magazines encouraging readers to sign up for the services. In return, publishers get a fee every time users call up their magazines electronically or participate in one of their events.
 
Extending a Magazine's Reach
 For a magazine, of course, the biggest benefit may be the potential new audience.
"We're just kind of feeling our way and trying to produce something on-line that is an extension of the magazine," said Kimberly Smith Jensen, senior vice president of The Atlantic Monthly, which signed up with America Online last month. "We are not interested in duplicating what is in the magazine per se. What really drew us is the interactivity."
She said magazine officials were "overwhelmed" by the responses, which have included hundreds of electronic letters and messages.
James Fallows, the Washington editor of The Atlantic Monthly, said he exchanges dozens of letters with readers each day.
"It does help revive what is thought to be a dying art, namely that of letter writing," he said. "But it's much quicker than the usual form of letters to the editor, more participatory."
 
50,000 Responses a Week
 Philip Elmer-DeWitt, an associate editor at Time magazine, said that since Time Online began in September, users have called it up an average of 50,000 to 60,000 times a week. When Kurt Andersen, an editor at large at the magazine, went on-line to talk about his cover article on radio personalities Rush Limbaugh and Howard Stern, 114 users signed up for a lively session. About 300 joined Mr. Graham for an hourlong session after Time's cover article about him.
After U.S. News & World Report made its debut on Compuserve on Nov. 29, users called up the magazine's text, graphics and photographs more than 90,000 times during the next 13 days. Doug Stanglin, the magazine's Moscow bureau chief, even engaged in an electronic discussion in Russian about the new Russian Constitution.
The marketing potential for on-line magazines is still unclear. Mr. Elmer-DeWitt said Time Online was bringing in relatively few new subscribers to the magazine itself. But Jeffrey L. Dearth, president of The New Republic, said that when his magazine went on-line in November 1992, an electronic offer for subscriptions drew about 300 responses.
With that in mind, Mr. Dearth organized the Electronic Newsstand on the Internet in July with 10 magazines, including The New Yorker, The Economist, National Review and Eating Well. More than 60 magazines have signed up, and Internet users worldwide are using the service an average of 20,000 times a day. "We are definitely selling magazines," he said.
The next frontier of on-line services may be advertising. Prodigy, currently the only advertiser-supported network, sometimes runs ads across the bottom of the PC screen; users can call up more information about the products.
 
The Timing of Text
 As electronic publishing expands,publishers are debating the value of putting the full text of their magazines on-line. Time and U.S. News offer full electronic texts before the printed magazines are available on newsstands. Disney Adventures does them one better and puts its text on-line a week ahead of time "to give the kids a feeling that they are part of this special little club," Tommi Lewis, editor in chief, said.
Another approach is taken by Omni, a monthly science magazine, which puts a sampler of its articles on-line the day it hits the newsstands. But it does not make the full text available electronically until the day the magazine comes off the stands.
"Basically we are using the on-line environment to encourage the kind of discussion, explication and investigation of ideas and topics that Omni is most famous for," Keith Ferrell, editorial director, said.
Consumer Reports first went on-line in 1982 and is now available on five services.
"Our mission is to get the information out to the consumers, and we feel that electronic publishing provides us a way to reach the greatest number of them," Thomas Falconer, who is in charge of Consumer Reports' electronic publishing, said. "And it has not affected the sales of the magazine."

HEADLINE: A Smart Move by United

 BODY:
The tentative agreement by United Airlines to sell a majority stake of the carrier to its employees is an attractive solution to a seemingly unsolvable financial problem. Indeed, it could spread to the other major carriers and beyond.
Over the last three years, as the economy has sagged, airline carriers have lost more than $10 billion; United alone has lost more than $1 billion. A major problem is that the large carriers, like United, Delta and American, carry huge debt and other fixed costs that don't go away when business falls off. No matter how few passengers United carries, it still must pay interest to creditors and run its gargantuan hub-and-spoke operations. 
 That makes the major carriers easy prey to strike threats. Management knows that if the pilots walked away from their jobs, the airlines would go bankrupt quickly. Desperate to stay afloat, the airlines have entered labor contracts they can't afford. The situation worsened when upstart carriers, like Southwest, relying on cheap labor and flexible work rules to fly only short-haul routes, began to siphon away United's customers.
The salvation of United lies in cutting its labor costs. That means lower pay. It also means looser work rules so that United can staff planes and airports with fewer workers. But the pilots and machinists, distrusting that they would ever see the benefit, were not about to offer massive wage cuts for nothing. That's why Stephen Wolf, the head of United, entered negotiations for a worker buyout. If it happens, United will become the largest worker-controlled company in the U.S.
Under the tentative agreement, the unions agree to sizable cuts in wages and fringe benefits. The labor savings are expected to exceed $5 billion over six years. In return, the unions will get 53 percent ownership of the airline. Worker control can scare investors who fear that worker-owners would rush to steer revenues into bloated wages rather than dividends or investment. So the unions wisely agreed to appoint only a minority of the board; they would, in effect, retain veto power over many important corporate decisions.
The United deal demonstrates that workers will absorb steep wage cuts only if they are guaranteed benefits down the road. Worker control provides that guarantee. Workers are given an immediate stake in the company's long-term future: wage concessions are immediately translated into stock shares, which stay in an employee stock ownership fund until the worker retires or otherwise leaves the company. And if further wage cuts are needed in the future, worker-owners are unlikely to resort to a bankrupting strike.
Worker-controlled companies have an uneven record of success in the U.S. But many of the failures were preordained, because the companies were at death's door before they were turned over to employees; despite recent losses, United's future isn't bleak. Besides, other worker-controlled companies were not designed to give workers a healthy incentive to watch the company's bank account as closely as their own.
If worker-ownership succeeds at United, it could also solve identical problems at American and Delta. Indeed, other industries forced to meet global competition by restructuring their work forces might gravitate toward the same solution.

HEADLINE: Welfare Recipients Are Victims, Not Criminals;
Abolish the System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The case for a school-to-work program, which is outlined in "America's Job Disaster," Bob Herbert's column of Dec. 1, is persuasive. Certainly, society needs to do much more to help put today's youth into the jobs of the future.
But is in-school training the answer? The best training ground available is the school of employment; yet our inner-city youth shun the entry-level jobs that offer them a step up into the world of work. Why? Because earnings are effectively wiped out by benefit reductions, making crime and welfare the economy of choice for the urban ghetto. 
 A very straightforward solution exists. Abolish welfare and use the money saved to provide a refundable tax credit for all our citizens. Closing down the welfare system would produce enough saving in bureaucracy and misplaced benefits to finance complete antipoverty protection for all of our citizens.
More important, abolishing the welfare-work disincentive would free the poor to become more productive, thus adding to our national wealth and competitivenes. In time, the failed war on poverty would be replaced by economic growth and productivity.
 
LEONARD M. GREENE
President, Institute
for Socioeconomic Studies
White Plains, Dec. 6, 1993

HEADLINE: 'Prevailing Wage' Bill Threatens Public Works

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The innovative housing development proposed for the Hunters Point section of Queens will fail if the "prevailing wage" pending in Albany is passed. It would vastly expand the definition of public works projects subject to extraordinarily high wage rates and unreasonable work practices. The Hunters Point project would fall under this definition and so would most housing and economic development projects in New York.
No one can object to reasonable working wages for our construction trades, but even nonunion workers in New York City earn more than their union counterparts in Jersey City. No wonder New York is losing its competitive edge, encouraging the exodus of jobs and business. 
 Such a law would doom affordable housing production. But more is at stake. If the prevailing wage bill passes the Assembly, most housing and economic development projects will be killed, along with any hope for this city's economic revival.
Mayor David N. Dinkins (along with other elected officials) has an opportunity to leave a lasting legacy of economic revival for New York City by strenuously objecting to the pending legislation.
 
JACK FREUND
New York, Dec. 8, 1993
 
The writer is acting president of the Rent Stabilization Association, an organization of small-property owners.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Picks Dinkins Aide As Housing Commissioner

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday named Deborah C. Wright as Commissioner of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. Ms. Wright, now a board member of the New York City Housing Authority, is the first black to be appointed to a high-level post in the new administration and the first official from the Dinkins administration to join the Giuliani team.
In other appointments, Mr. Giuliani is expected today to name his team to lead the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the city's municipal hospitals. Dr. Bruce Siegel, Health Commissioner under Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, is the Mayor-elect's choice to be the corporation president, according to an adviser to Mr. Giuliani, and Luis Miranda of the Hispanic Federation of New York City is in line to be chairman.
It was not clear last night when Mr. Giuliani hoped to see Dr. Siegel assume his new duties. The current president, Billy E. Jones, has a contract that runs through the spring.
 
Strongly Recommended
 In announcing the housing appointment yesterday, Mr. Giuliani brushed off a question as to whether he has had difficulty attracting black candidates for posts in his administration. 
 "The fact is that it has not been difficult to elicit nominees," said Mr. Giuliani, "and in each case, each selection is a different process. In Deborah's case, she was strongly recommended by the selection committee and if you look at her background and her qualifications, she is clearly the best qualified person to do this job."
Earlier in the day, Mr. Giuliani appeared at a Brooklyn meeting on racial and ethnic relations, where he stressed that he wants to be responsive to all New Yorkers. "I understand that it is my job to reach out to every single community in this city," he said, adding that it was important for people to understand "that we are completely united as New Yorkers."
Mr. Giuliani's new Housing Commissioner is a 35-year-old lawyer and Crown Heights resident who has worked for Mayor David N. Dinkins since 1990. She was a City Planning Commission member from 1990 until August 1992, when she was appointed to the Housing Authority board. In that post, she was responsible for overseeing new construction and major rehabilitation of housing projects.
 
Time to 'Pull Together'
 Ms. Wright said she accepted the Giuliani appointment because she believed "it was a time for the city to pull together" and agreed with many of Mr. Giuliani's housing positions.
Mr. Giuliani has given little indication of what his housing policies will be, except to say he wants to substantially reduce the city's responsiblity for 40,000 apartments in buildings taken for nonpayment of taxes.
Yesterday Ms. Wright said she supported the goal of returning to private owners some of the buildings owned by the city. "Its one thing if you are spending a large amount of money and are providing adequate services," she said. "But if you are spending a large amount of money and services are not adequate, its time to re-evaluate the program."
Francine C. Justa, executive director of Neighborhood Housing Services, a private, nonprofit housing agency that helps to arrange private financing for single and multi-family housing, was among the housing advocates who said the appointment of Ms. Wright was a good one.
"Debbie is a talented and energetic woman," Mrs. Justa said. "But she faces a difficult challenge on the fiscal side. Money is going to be tight."
Ms. Wright will be taking over an agency with a $1 billion annual budget and 3,500 employees. She will replace Felice L. Michetti, who is credited with seeing that the city kept on track with fulfilling a 1986 pledge by former Mayor Edward I. Koch to add at least 47,000 apartments for low-income people before the mid-1990's.
Ms. Wright was born in Bennettsville, S.C. and grew up in Dallas. Her father, the Rev. Harry S. Wright, and her mother, Joan, now live in Brooklyn, where her father used to be pastor of the Cornerstone Baptist Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant. Ms. Wright, who is single, received her B.A. degree from Radcliffe College in 1979. In 1984 she receieved an M.B.A. and law degree from Harvard University.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Adviser Seeks Agencies' Plans for Cuts

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
In a preliminary effort to confront projected city budget shortfalls, Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani's chief fiscal adviser has asked most city agencies to begin preparing scenarios for cutting their budgets by 5 percent and by 10 percent next year.
The request and the response from the agencies, due by Jan. 1, is an exercise and does not indicate that Mr. Giuliani and his designated budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, have made any specific decisions on how they will deal with a budget gap of at least $1.7 billion for the next fiscal year, which begins in July. 
 "The importance of the letter is to send a strong signal that this Mayor expects to deal with the '95 problem almost immediately," Mr. Lackman said in an interview last night. The request, which did not ask for cuts in Medicaid, welfare or city debt service, is just the first step in the planning process, he said.
But the order to begin planning for spending reductions -- in a memo written at Mr. Lackman's request by the current budget director, Carol O'Cleireacain -- may reflect some priorities Mr. Giuliani will bring to fiscal planning after he takes office.
For example, the Board of Education and City University of New York were exempted from having to propose budget cuts, according to the memo, written on Friday and made public yesterday. The Police Department was asked to find ways to cut spending 5 percent for next year; it was not also required to devise a plan for trimming by 10 percent next year.
 
To Offer Different Choices
 The heads of virtually all other city agencies were told to prepare plans for cutting spending by 5 percent and by 10 percent next year. They were also instructed to propose ways to cut 1 percent from their budgets during the last six months of the current fiscal year -- savings that are supposed to translate into an additional 2 percent in spending reductions when applied to the next fiscal year.
Mr. Giuliani said during the campaign that he would try to spare agencies serving children from budget cuts and to protect agencies already hit hard by spending reductions in the last four years. But some of the agencies trimmed most during the Dinkins administration, including the Departments of Parks and Housing Preservation, were not exempted from Mr. Lackman's requests.
 
First Priority
 Ms. O'Cleireacain told agency heads that their first priority should be to cut spending without reducing services. "This means that productivity, doing the same with less, is absolutely crucial," she wrote. She also requested detailed plans to reduce spending on overtime. She asked agency heads to devise ways to collect 10 percent more in revenues than they do now on uncollected fines, fees and rents, and to analyze how spending cuts might affect city services.
In a related development, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said the city's economy appears to have begun a very modest recovery from the recession that began in 1989.
She also suggested ways to close next year's budget gap, which she estimated at $2 billion. Among these, the city could save $366 million a year, she said, by improving how it collects unpaid taxes, fees and fines, and it could save as much as $300 million a year by contracting out for goods and services more efficiently.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
QVC Network said it had raised its bid for Paramount by $100 million in cash. Its offer is worth about $10.4 billion. Viacom's new offer was not known. But QVC asserted that Paramount had said that QVC's bid was higher. [Page D1.]

HEADLINE: Dow Rises On Trendless Trading Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed mixed after an opening selloff yesterday, as trading moved in a trendless fashion familiar to the end of the year.
Traders said the mood of the market included some optimism about inflation, which appeared to be controlled under the Fed's watchful gaze, and greater optimism about corporate profits. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 3.64 points on the day to close at 3,755.21 in moderate trading, as volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 255.9 million shares.
Rao Chalasani, the chief investment strategist for Kemper Securities Group in Chicago, characterized yesterday's trading session as directionless, with low volume compared with a rally on Friday when the trading volume was 363.75 million shares. But he said that rally was related to the "triple witch" expiration of option and index futures.
Mr. Chalasani said bonds, a source from which stocks have often drawn strength, sagged a little yesterday.
 
Defining New Range
 "The bond market, which saw its high in October, is now trying to define a new trading range," he said. "Even though we expect 1994 operational earnings to be up 10 to 12 percent, interest-rate increases do not leave much room for the stock market to perform well."
As the rates climb higher, they offer investors another alternative to equities. For now, Mr. Chalasani said he thought the stock market would mark time with a continued movement sideways.
Yesterday, declining stocks outpaced those showing gains by 1,125 to 990. And the Big Board composite slipped by 0.20 point, to 257.59, while less-than-active trading lifted the Nasdaq composite by 0.92 point to close at 760.15.
Continental Medical Systems, which claims to be the largest provider of medical rehabilitation in the country, fell 1 1/4, to 8, after the company said it anticipated second-quarter earnings to be below analysts' expectations, largely because of the underperformance of its California rehabilitation hospitals and soft demand in the temporary physician-replacement market.
 
Agreement in China
 Qualcomm Inc. rose 1 7/8, to 57 7/8. The maker of digital wire communications technology said it had signed an agreement with China to field-test the company's digital cellular technology.
The stock of TJ International, a building materials company, rose 3/4, to 28 1/8, after Goldman, Sachs upgraded its recommendation to "trading buy" from "moderate outperformer." The brokerage firm gave the stock a target price of $31 a share.
Storage Technology declined 7/8, to 32 1/8. Traders attributed the drop to an article in Barron's in which a money manager who had sold the stock short said he believed the stock would drop to 20.
A report in The Wall Street Journal that the directors of Borden were considering putting the company up for sale drove up the share price of the food and plastics conglomerate by 5/8, to 18 5/8. Analysts said the biggest obstacle to selling Borden outright was that it was a collection of unrelated businesses, and most of them were not doing well.
 
Advice to Buy
 Shares of Wells Fargo rose 3 5/8, to 128 3/4, after Ray Soifer, an analyst for Brown Brothers Harriman, raised his 1994 earnings projections to $14 a share, from $12, with a preliminary 1995 estimate of $15.25 a share. Traders said he had advised clients to buy the stock on weakness.
Talk that Merck & Company was accelerating the work on a promising experimental AIDS treatment made the stock of the drug maker the most actively traded issue on the Big Board. It closed up 1/4, at 33 7/8.
Timberland made a technical rebound yesterday after falling 31 percent last week when investors grew concerned that its fourth-quarter earnings would be lower than expected. Yesterday the stock rose 2 3/8, to 52 1/8, on no news.
Shares of Champion Industries rose 1 1/2, to 18 1/4, after it said its fourth-quarter net income had risen to 19 cents a share, compared with 12 cents a year ago. The printer and supplier of office supplies also declared a 5-for-4 stock split.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against Yen On Talk of Rate Cut in Japan

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday amid speculation about a near-term cut in Japan's official discount rate, but it weakened against some other currencies.
Dealers suspect Japan may announce a rate cut in tandem with its new economic pump-priming package, which could be made public this week. Japanese Government officials have said the plan is unlikely to include details on specific spending and income tax cuts. 
 "The market is pricing in a rate cut immediately," said Christopher Wilson of Union Bank in Los Angeles.
 In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 110.62 yen, from 110.19 on Friday.
 
Rates Already Low
 A Bank of Japan official said early yesterday that interest rates were already low and that the central bank saw no reason for additional monetary measures. But dealers said Japan's short-term money market rates were hovering just above the 1.75 percent official discount rate, suggesting that the official rate would soon be cut by one-quarter point, to 1.5 percent.
Analysts have been expecting Japan's Government to provide monetary stimulus partly to revive the recently battered stock market.
Gold prices also rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most active futures contract, gained $1.90, to $390.80 an ounce.
The German mark was also in demand among yen holders -- helping the mark hold ground against the dollar. Resistance at the key 1.72-mark level also kept a lid on the dollar against the mark, although the dollar managed to squeeze out gains on the mark. It rose to 1.7130 German marks in New York, from 1.7075 late Friday.
The Canadian dollar fell to six-year lows, following up last week's late selling. On Friday, Standard & Poor's said the debt of some Canadian provinces could be downgraded in the future. The Bank of Canada reportedly bought Canadian dollars for American dollars to stem the slide. The American dollar closed at $1.3450 (Canadian) in New York, up from $1.3405 on Friday.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4860, down from $1.4875 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.4580 Swiss francs, down from 1.4590; 5.8370 French francs, up from 5.8360, and 1,675 Italian lire, down from 1,685.

HEADLINE: U.S. IS ABANDONING 'SHOCK THERAPY' FOR THERUSSIANS

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's top Russia specialist said today that the surprisingly large support for foes of reform in Russia's parliamentary elections last week showed that there had been too much emphasis on remaking the economy of Russia and not enough on improving the daily lives of its people.
Strobe Talbott, the State Department's Ambassador at Large for Russia and other countries of the former Soviet Union, also said the United States was looking to other Russian reformers as well as President Boris N. Yeltsin to bring change to the troubled country, even if they were Mr. Yeltsin's political enemies.
 
'Shock Therapy' Has Failed
 While Mr. Talbott was characteristically cautious and noncommittal, his remarks illuminated an important shift in official American thinking: an admission, in effect, that the "shock therapy," the-faster-the-better approach to reform advocated by the West -- and until recently by Mr. Yeltsin -- has not worked. 
 In the first on-the-record admission that Washington is rethinking its strategy on Russia, Mr. Talbott acknowledged that the Administration had begun "intensive deliberations" on "refining, focusing and intensifying our reform support efforts" to take account of the election results.
The goal, Mr. Talbott added, is to find a way for "less shock and more therapy for the Russian people."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher sounded the same theme in a meeting with reporters in New York tonight, The Associated Press reported. Saying the vote should be taken as a "wake-up call" by reformers, Mr. Christopher said he hoped they would "be very conscious of the pain that takes place in the transition" from Communism to capitalism.
 
Speedy Reform Encouraged
 Although the United States and the other Western nations have little direct influence on Russian politics, they have encouraged the speedy pace of reform by tying loans from the International Monetary Fund to the pace of economic change.
Worried about Russia's huge budget deficit and high inflation rate, the I.M.F. has adhered to a strict lending policy, calling for action on those fronts before money would be handed over. As a result, the fund has lent Russia only half of a promised $3 billion, a situation criticized last week in Moscow by Vice President Al Gore, who said the I.M.F.'s board was not sensitive enough to the hardships the Russian people faced.
While Mr. Talbott was careful not to criticize the I.M.F. or call directly for a change in its policy, changing the pace of reform would require some loosening of the fund's standards.
Mr. Talbott also said the Administration was considering the expansion of a strong social "safety net" for the Russian people, but he either was unable or unwilling to say where the money would come from. Other officials were quick to insist that the United States would not go beyond the $2.5 billion it has already set aside for the nations of the former Soviet Union for next year.
Projects that would have a direct effect on ordinary Russians would most likely require an injection of aid from the World Bank, the I.M.F. or the international community.
Other senior officials have said that neither the United States nor the rest of the international community has the money or the desire to bail out Russia, knowing that much of the money would not be repaid. For their part, Russian officials want the money to come in grants, not loans.
"To create a huge social safety net would be very expensive, and we don't have the money," a senior Administration official told reporters after a formal briefing at the White House last week. "There is no collection of countries that can do that."
But one clear implication of Mr. Talbott's remarks was that the United States might be willing to endorse a slower approach to reform if that meant meeting the everyday needs of the Russian people and thus steeringthem away from the far left or far right who offer bread instead of statistics.
 
A Safety Net
 Some officials hope that Russia can push ahead with privatizations and other changes as fast as before if a sizable safety net is stitched together.
The comments by Mr. Talbott reflected the sobering effect last week's vote totals have had on the Administration and particularly on him. Until a few days before the election, he, like many other Russia experts in the Government, dismissed suggestions that the Russian people would choose a Parliament that the United States could not wholehearedly embrace.
By contrast, in analyzing the unexpectedly strong showing by the far-right party of Vladimir Zhirinovsky, Mr. Talbott said today that there was no question the Russian people "were sending a message to their leadership, and their message was that reform, as it has been carried out to date, has been accompanied by a lot of disruption, a lot of disorder and a lot of hardship for the average Russian citizen."
He refrained from repeating past Administration appeals to reform as fast as possible, describing the Administration's current view in different terms. "It might be a mistake to cast it in terms of fast and slow," he said, adding, "Rather than thinking of it in terms of slowing reform down, I would say it's more a concept of broadening the concept of reform."
In explaining what he meant by the "broadening" of reform, Mr. Talbott said, "Rather than focusing just on the economic indicators, which are important and which will remain important -- economic indicators such as inflation rates, levels of credit emissions to large state enterprises and that kind of thing -- they and we also have to factor into our policies the social factors, which you might call the misery index -- unemployment, people's sense of being afraid on the streets, being afraid of the future -- that kind of thing."
Mr. Talbott argued that the Yeltsin Government must adopt measures to ease the effect of the transformation from Communism to capitalism and that advisers of Mr. Clinton were preparing specific recommendations for his summit meeting with Mr. Yeltsin in Moscow in January.
 
Balance Is Needed
 "There is going to have to be a balance between the economic imperatives and also the political imperatives of keeping Russia on the path toward democratization and economic reform," Mr. Talbott said in briefing reporters today after his trip to Russia and other parts of the former Soviet Union with Vice President Gore.
Jeffrey Sachs, an Harvard economist who advises the Yeltsin Government, said in a telephone interview from Switzerland that if $4 billion to $5 billion could be added to a social safety net, it would "go far, but not go all the way." He added, "It's not enough to say, as I fear they'll say, 'Oh, we'll add $1 billion or $2 billion to a safety net.' That will be received with the same zero credibility as much of the aid that has been received so far."
Mr. Sachs said money for a safety net might come from the World Bank, which has already lent $60 million for such social services and is considering an additional $500 million.

Constitution Approved
 MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Russia's new Constitution has been formally approved by a majority of voters after a referendum this month and will go into effect Tuesday, the Central Electoral Commission said today.
An electoral spokesman said final official results showed 54.8 percent of Russia's 106,170,335 eligible voters took part in the referendum. Of those who voted, 58.4 were in favor of the new Constitution and 41.6 against it.

HEADLINE: Kiev Acts Quickly on Pledge To Disarm Nuclear Weapons

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Ukraine's President has told President Clinton that Kiev is prepared to deactivate its nuclear arsenal, including its entire force of modern SS-24 missiles, Clinton Administration officials said today.
The assurance was conveyed last month by President Leonid Kravchuk in a telephone conversation with Mr. Clinton, the officials said. 
 And in a gesture of good faith, Ukrainian officials announced today that they had removed the warheads from 17 of its 46 SS-24 missiles, the most modern weapons in their nuclear arsenal.
"Seventeen missiles have been deactivated," Deputy Prime Minister Valery Shmarov said today, referring to the SS-24's. "There will be 20 by the end of the year. This means lowering the level of military alert. The warheads have been moved away from the launchers."
 
'Crossed a Threshold'
 Some Clinton Administration officials called this move encouraging. "They have crossed a threshold in terms of the declaration of intent," one senior Administration official said.
But other Administration officials were more cautious. Some noted that although Mr. Kravchuk did not specify any conditions when he told Mr. Clinton that he was prepared to deactivate Ukraine's entire nuclear arsenal, Mr. Shmarov told reporters that Ukraine would not deactivate all its SS-24's unless a satisfactory agreement was worked out providing economic compensation and security assurances to Kiev.
"We are prepared to remove all SS-24's from military alert, but only if conditions discussed at these talks are fulfilled," Mr. Shmarov said.
 
Problem for Relations
 The nuclear weapons Ukraine has inherited have been a major stumbling block for arms control and for American relations with the Kiev Government. When the Soviet Union broke up, Ukraine inherited the SS-24's, 130 SS-19 missiles and 564 air-launched cruise missiles, according to the Arms Control Association, a private group.
Neither of the strategic arms reduction treaties concluded during the Bush Administration can formally be put into effect until Kiev agrees to relinquish its nuclear arms. But unlike Belarus and Kazakhstan, which have agreed to give up the nuclear weapons they inherited, Ukraine has been reluctant to part with its arsensal. It is dismantling 20 of the older SS-19 missiles, but it had previously declined to dismantle the SS-24's, which have 10 warheads each.
Kiev's disarmament efforts have brought a tart response from the Clinton Administration, which has declined to schedule meetings between Mr. Kravchuk and President Clinton. Mr. Clinton called Mr. Kravchuk two weeks ago to complain about Ukraine's arms-control policies. At the time it was reported that Mr. Kravchuk said only that he would ask the Ukrainian Parliament to reconsider its refusal to eliminate all of the country's nuclear missiles in accordance with the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty.
The Clinton Administration has been involved in three-way negotiations to encourage the Ukraine not only to deactivate its nuclear arsenal but also to return the warheads to Russia so that they can be dismantled.
Under the arrangement being negotiated, Ukraine would remove its warheads from its missiles and store them temporarily on its territory, perhaps under international supervision. It would then return the warheads to Russia. In return, Kiev would receive low enriched uranium for its nuclear power plants, as well as closer diplomatic and military ties with Washington.
"It is not a done deal yet, but there is reason to be hopeful," an Administration official said.
 
Energy Crisis in Ukraine
 While Ukraine is concerned about the possibility of Russian aggression, it is also under severe economic pressures. Ukraine has a severe energy crisis this winter. Many regions cope with daily electrical brownouts, while in Kiev factories run on a rotation basis to economize.
Kiev has a $2.5 billion debt for the oil and natural gas supplied by Russia. The low enriched uranium Ukraine would receive in compensation for its warheads would reduce Ukraine's reliance on Russian energy imports.
Ukraine is also seeking discounts on gas and oil from Russia for the more than 2,000 tactical nuclear weapons it has already returned to Russia.

HEADLINE: ARISTIDE IS URGED TO BACK PREMIER

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
With their drive to restore President Jean-Betrand Aristide to power at a virtual standstill, diplomats met with the Haitian leader today to urge him to show flexibility in reaching a solution to his country's political crisis.
Diplomats from the United States, France, Canada, Venezuela and the United Nations met with Father Aristide for more than three hours, but participants said later that he did not give them a commitment that he would support a new plan to end Haiti's political crisis. 
 Even as diplomats sought promises from Father Aristide, President Clinton increased the pressure, publicly appealing to him and to others to show some flexibility. "We're going to take another run at it and see if we can do something on it," Mr. Clinton said today. "It's going to require some flexibility on all sides."
 
Words of Frustration
 United States officials and Robert Malval, the Haitian businessman whom Father Aristide appointed Prime Minister, have expressed frustration with Father Aristide for withdrawing his backing for talks aimed at resuscitating the stalled Governors Island accords.
Those accords, named after the island in New York Harbor where they were signed in July, were supposed to lead to Father Aristide's reinstatement on Oct. 30, but they have been ignored by Haiti's military rulers.
Despite the Administration's expressions of frustration, an adviser to Father Aristide said the meeting today was cordial and described it as more of a "strategy session."
 
Military Talks, Too
 The United States, France, Canada and Venezuela, the countries most involved in the dispute, also plan to send a delegation to meet with Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the Haitian military leader, to urge him to accept the Governors Island accords.
The effort to return Father Aristide to power is basically limited to an international oil embargo, which is bringing further havoc to the economy of Haiti, already the poorest country in the hemisphere.
"The message to Aristide is that the military is primarily responsible for the impasse and that we are applying economic pressure," said one Administration official. "But we are not content to do that and sit around and wait. We want also to have an active diplomatic process going."
 
Beyond Sanctions
 Father Aristide was told that "we are resolute about maintaining the sanctions," one of the participants in the meeting said. "But the sanctions are only a means to an end, and the cost in the country is enormous. Therefore there has to be some sort of a political vehicle to address those issues still to be resolved."
Over the weekend Mr. Malval bluntly criticized Father Aristide, saying the President has "a serious ego problem." Referring to General Cedras and to Father Aristide, a plainly irritated Mr. Malval said, "The country is stuck between a man who has refused to resign and a man who has made a choice to remain abroad as a sort of flag-bearer, a mythic symbol."
Mr. Malval resigned last week but has agreed to stay on as a caretaker.
Some of the diplomats involved said they lamented the loss of Mr. Malval, whom they saw as a pragmatic force, contrasting him with other advisers to Father Aristide who, they said, have been giving the President bad advice.
 
A Question of Security
 Advisers to Father Aristide have said that he withdrew his support for Mr. Malval's plan, which entails a conference of a broad cross-section of Haitian society, because of concern about security.
This explanation did not sit well with Administration officials. "Malval has security concerns too," said one Administration official. "He's sitting in Haiti, making efforts to get Aristide back. That involves a certain amount of risk."
The diplomats who met Father Aristide told him that if he is unwilling to back Mr. Malval's initiative, then he must support an alternative being drawn up by the four countries and the United Nations, which one described as "some sort of conference or conclave or some sort of a opportunity for the Haitian parties to work out implementation of Governors Island."

HEADLINE: Health Costs Vary Greatly By Industry, a Survey Finds

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Employers and employees in private industry and state and local governments spent $258.5 billion for workers' health insurance last year, the Labor Department reported today in the first Federal survey of such spending.
Employers accounted for 86 percent of the total. They spent $221.4 billion for employee health benefits, or nearly six times as much as the $37.1 billion spent by workers. 
 The new study found that health care spending varied widely among industries. Manufacturers, on the average, spent much more for each worker than service industries. But the cost of health coverage was higher for transportation and public utilities than for any other industry; it averaged $3,924 for each worker. Retailers had the lowest average spending: $1,044 for each employee.
And in general, the cost of health coverage in state and local government was much higher than in private industry. The cost averaged $3,494 for each government worker, as against $2,267 for each employee in private industry.
"In state and local government, there are more professionals and other people in high-paid occupations who expect health insurance as a benefit," said Wayne M. Shelly, a Labor Department economist who worked on the survey. "Public employers have to offer such benefits to attract these workers. In addition, public employers may provide health insurance to part-time workers, whereas many private employers do not."
The survey is based on data from 5,600 work sites chosen to be representative of the nation as a whole. The data were collected in June by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, a Labor Department agency, at the request of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration. The data were not available to the White House when President Clinton was drawing up his proposal to overhaul the nation's health care system.
One of the most hotly debated features of Mr. Clinton's plan would require employers to buy health insurance for their employees.
 
Complaints From Retailers
 Industries like manufacturing and transportation, which already cover a high proportion of their employees' health costs, would presumably come out winners under Mr. Clinton's plan. They would generally not have to pay more, and some might pay less, than they now pay for employees' health benefits.
Retailers, by contrast, complain that the Clinton plan would require them to pay much more than they now pay, and the new data tend to support their contention.
Benefits of all types account for 29 percent of total employee compensation, with wages and salaries accounting for 71 percent, the Labor Department reported. Health insurance accounts for nearly one-fourth of benefit costs.
 
Benefits Outpace Wages
 But the cost of benefits, led by the cost of health insurance, has been rising much faster than wages. For every $1 increase in wages and salaries over the last five years, benefits increased $1.67, the department said.
Colleen M. O'Neill, a spokeswoman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said money that would otherwise be available for wages was needed just to maintain the health benefits that workers already have.
In 1992, spending on health care of all kinds totaled $839 billion, or 14 percent of gross domestic product, the Commerce Department has estimated. Because the Labor Department study focused on insurance provided by employers, its numbers do not reflect the costs of government programs like Medicare and Medicaid, for the elderly and the poor, or the costs of charity care.
The Administration estimates that health insurance for a two-parent family with children would cost $4,360 a year under Mr. Clinton's plan. The premium, it says, would be $3,893 for a one-parent family and $1,932 for a single person. Consumers would normally pay one-fifth of the premiums, and employers would pay the rest.
The Labor Department found that employers paid 89 percent of the cost of employee health coverage in goods-producing industries like construction and manufacturing. In service industries, the employers' share ranged from 93 percent in transportation and public utilities to 77 percent in retail stores.
Spending for employee health coverage last year totaled $67 billion in the Northeast, $72.5 billion in the South, $63.6 billion in the Middle West and $55.4 billion in the West.
The employee spending figures show only the share of premiums paid by workers for the benefits they got through their jobs. The figures do not include amounts paid for deductibles or for private insurance bought by employees on their own, outside the workplace.

HEADLINE: Haitians Bitterly Accusing Outside World of Desertion

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 20

 BODY:
In the crowded alleyways of a public market here, revived from weeks of inactivity by holiday shopping, Jean-Pierre Paul, a vendor of handmade toys and decorations, had a question for a foreigner that many Haitians are asking these days.
"What are you doing to our country?" the thin 26-year-old inquired with a mixture of anger and frustration. "Either do what is needed to bring our President back, or have the honesty to say that you have failed, and leave us alone." 
 With the approach of the third Christmas since the military coup that ousted the country's first democratically elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Mr. Paul and many other Haitians are expressing increasing bitterness at what they describe as 26 months of dashed hopes, wasted lives and abandonment by the outside world.
Although an international embargo on oil and arms supplies has made life increasingly difficult for the common people, crippling transportation and slowing commerce, few Haitians, from the majority of the population that supported the election of Father Aristide to the mostly wealthy minority that loathes him, express any faith in the world's effort to restore him to the presidency.
 
Wealthy Are Little Affected
 "A sack of rice costs $25 now," said Sauveur Joseph, another market vendor, who joined in the conversation. "If you are lucky enough to have a job, you are still only making $3 a day."
What makes the pain of sanctions even harder for many Haitians to swallow is the widespread perception that their intended target -- the country's wealthy classes and particularly the military -- seems scarcely to have been affected.
Diplomats and Haitians familiar with the workings of the economy here say a porous border with the Dominican Republic and the involvement of some of the Haitian Army's leading officers in the black market for fuel have assured that enough gasoline has remained available for many in the elite to maintain a comfortable life.
Some diplomats here have predicted that the economy will crash as early as next month, forcing the army into new concessions. But many wealthy Haitians place no more stock in international efforts to restore the President to power than do the poor.
"Everyone I know will tell you the date they predict for the lifting of the embargo," said an affluent woman, who like others of her class was confident that neither Washington nor the United Nations would feel comfortable in extending the economic pain here much longer.
With the public squabbling between Father Aristide and his handpicked Prime Minister, Robert Malval, many wealthy Haitians said they were convinced that enforcement of the sanctions would fade within weeks.
 
A History of Failure
 Even diplomats concede there is as much history as cynicism behind such beliefs. Shortly after Father Aristide was overthrown, a general embargo that had shown signs of bringing the military to its knees was suddenly punctured by the unimpeded arrival of a European oil tanker. Since that time there have been many other half measures and false starts to diplomatic initiatives that have strengthened the defiance of the military and its backers and left many other Haitians deeply skeptical of the outside world.
For others, though, nothing the outside world might decide to do, short of an unlikely military intervention, would matter now.
"You are trying to coerce a bunch of people who have no sense of nation and no sense of patriotism," said a well-to-do Haitian who quietly supports Father Aristide, making her a rare exception in her class. "They don't care what happens to the ordinary Haitian. They don't even care what happens to Haiti. If things get too rough for them here, in fact, they'll just hop on the plane and join the family and fortune in the United States."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
An Israeli's Vision, of Both Recent Past and Future

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

The New Middle East
By Shimon Peres with Arye Naor
Illustrated. 224 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $25.
In less than half a century, Israel has produced many remarkable leaders who have been soldiers, diplomats and orators, sometimes all at once. Among those present at the creation were Yitzhak Rabin, now Prime Minister, and Shimon Peres, now Foreign Minister. Both played major roles in the handshake last September between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization on the South Lawn of the White House. 
 Now we learn from "The New Middle East," an edifying and important book by Mr. Peres, that the handshake was the culmination of years of behind-the-scenes diplomacy and daring thinking by both sides about the future of the entire region. Looking beyond his own country's borders, Mr. Peres says he thinks the Middle East nations can be joined in a harmonious entity resembling the European Community, and he sells this bold notion convincingly.
The invisible diplomacy that preceded the accord in September makes the most tantalizing section, particularly the secret negotiations between the P.L.O. and Israel out of sight of the press in Norway. If ever an argument is needed for quiet diplomacy instead of grandstanding for the television cameras, what took place in Norway would be one.
About the talks in Oslo, Mr. Peres writes:
"The setting was ideal. In Norway, no one was looking for scoops. Even on my last trip to Oslo, not one newspaper reporter requested to accompany me. Deja vu was the general opinion among the government-run communications authorities in Israel. Why send a team to cover the visit? What could happen there? Yet because the Oslo negotiations, unlike those in Washington, were far from the eyes and ears of the media, we were able to keep the talks going for months. The two sides could talk directly, person to person, rather than simply spout rhetoric."
Mr. Peres is much too discreet about what occurred in Oslo. It would be interesting to know more about the selfless Norwegians who were the catalysts for the negotiations. And Yair Hirschfeld and Ron Pundik, the two obscure Israeli historians who broke the ice and began the secret talks in Oslo, were not invited by Mr. Peres to the Washington ceremony, as Amos Elon, Israel's keen journalist, reports in The New Yorker of Dec. 20. Mr. Peres doesn't even mention them in his book. Ever the diplomat, he credits two Egyptians, President Hosni Mubarak and Foreign Minister Amr Moussa, with saving the talks and bringing the P.L.O. and the Israelis back together whenever they reached a dead end.
"The New Middle East" is a textbook lesson in how a small nation negotiates in the changed world after the cold war, when even large nations have given up some of their sovereignty. Mr. Peres says that during the negotiations, he touched base with most of the European countries; he was aware that their tacit approval of an agreement and their economic help would be needed. The United States, once the exemplar of shuttle diplomacy in the Middle East, stood more in the wings than at center stage during the negotiations.
At the heart of Mr. Peres's proposals for the next step in the Middle East is economic cooperation: first commerce with open borders, then political understanding. He says that no nation in the Middle East can prosper on its own and that the way to defeat the militant Muslim fundamentalists who oppose the agreement is to attack the roots of poverty and despair. How to do so?
"Some of the basic rules for establishing a modern economy are clear," Mr. Peres writes. "Decrease the war chest; increase investment in education; use available natural reserves wisely and create alternatives as necessary; establish required energy and desalination plants; construct a state-of-the-art infrastructure for communications and transportation; develop industry, agriculture and tourism, making use of all existing advantages; open borders and encourage competition."
Mr. Peres tells why it made historical as well as political sense for Israel to agree to the principle of rule by the Palestinian majority in Gaza. He notes that the city of Gaza is 7,000 troubled years old. What good is control, he wonders, if Israel cannot improve conditions for the people? He answers himself: "Samson, in his time, took a drastic step, bringing down the columns of the shrine in Gaza. There was no point in our repeating it."
In his occasionally repetitious but frequently eloquent book, Mr. Peres often invokes the Bible to drive home his theme of economic unity. Referring to the scarcity of water in the Middle East, Mr. Peres says that Jacob and Esau drank from the same wells, even when their paths separated. But he adds that they were unable to desalinate sea water, computerize irrigation or enjoy the fruits of biotechnology.
Writing of the potential for tourism throughout the Middle East, Mr. Peres says that Jews, Christians and Arabs share an ancestor, Abraham, who was known for his hospitality. "Throughout history," he writes, "Abraham's descendants have recognized the importance of hospitality and have tried to emulate their ancestor." Building on this pleasant thought, he envisions tourism as a great growth industry all over the Middle East.
Word-slinging and stone-throwing may continue, yet Mr. Peres leaves a strong impression in "The New Middle East" that a diplomat may find an advantage in coming from a land of prophets and miracles.

HEADLINE: Gain Seen in High-Temperature Superconductors

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
A TEAM of French scientists has reported that it created a small sample of material that acts like a superconductor of electricity at a temperature of minus 10 degrees Fahrenheit, far warmer than that of previously known superconductors.
The complex material, assembled atom by atom, was capable of transmitting only a minuscule amount of electrical current, much too little to have any practical use. But the scientists involved, Dr. Michel Lagues and his colleagues at the Higher School of Physics and Industrial Chemistry of the City of Paris and the University of Paris, say they believe they have taken an important step toward developing the technology of superconductors. 
 Superconductivity is the ability of a material to transmit a current of electricity with little or no resistance. It was discovered in 1911, but the researchers led by Dr. Lagues say in the current issue of the journal Science that they believe the material they invented is the highest-temperature superconductor yet created.
The French material is a many-layered sandwich in which each repeating sequence has one layer of mixed bismuth, strontium, calcium and oxygen, followed by up to eight consecutive layers of copper oxide, each one only a single atom thick. The all-important copper oxide layers are applied by "sequentially imposed layer epitaxy," in which copper is vaporized in the presence of oxygen and shot at the top of the sandwich, an atom at a time, by an electron gun. Like the electron beam that scans the inside of a video tube to produce a picture, the beam of copper scans back and forth a line at a time.
The cautiously worded French paper does not assert that superconductivity was achieved at high temperature, but merely that measurements were "consistent" with the phenomenon. The French claim has yet to be verified experimentally by others.
Dr. Richard L. Greene, director of the Center for Superconductivity Research at the University of Maryland at College Park, was one of the scientists who assessed the French paper for publication in Science. In an interview, he said that the paper should be treated with some skepticism, and that only a portion of the new substance may be superconductive.
 
Guarded Optimism
 "No one is likely to believe their results until they've been tested by other groups," he said. "There are a lot of funny things about that paper. But lots of things we don't know about are possible, and we need to keep an open mind."
Low-temperature superconductors, which operate at minus 452 degrees (the temperature of liquid helium), have been in use for decades. But in 1987, materials scientists at the University of Houston discovered that a ceramic compound in which yttrium and barium are blended with copper oxide becomes a superconductor at minus 387 degrees. The discovery prompted a wave of excitement among physicists and officials of the Reagan Administration. There were heady predictions that high-temperature superconductors would lead to efficient electric generators, superconducting power lines, magnetically levitated trains requiring very little energy and other marvels.
Laboratories around the world have steadily developed new compounds that superconduct electricity at increasingly higher temperatures, but practical applications have been few and economically modest.

HEADLINE: Bugs Keep Planet Livable Yet Get No Respect

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
HUMANS may think they are evolution's finest product, but the creepies, crawlies and squishies rule the world. Remove people from the face of the earth and the biosphere would perk along just fine, ecologists say. Remove the invertebrates -- creatures like insects, spiders, worms, snails and protozoans -- and the global ecosystem would collapse, humans and other vertebrates would probably last only a few months, and the planet would belong mostly to algae and fungi.
But does invertebrates' indispensable role in supporting human life earn them any understanding, gratitude, respect or even recognition? Precious little, according to a new study that explores both the critical importance of invertebrates and people's attitudes toward them. The study suggests that for the most part people hate the myriad small, spineless creatures on which their very existence depends and would just as soon see them wiped out. 
 People have long been repelled by bugs, worms and the like, of course, but hostility to invertebrates has now become a dangerous attitude, says the author of the study, Dr. Stephen R. Kellert, a professor of social ecology at Yale University, whose findings are reported in the December issue of the journal Conservation Biology.
 
Catastrophic Losses
 Because many people do not know or care much about invertebrates, Dr. Kellert said, they do not worry about conserving them. Yet to the extent that humans are precipitating a mass extinction of species, as many biologists believe, invertebrates are being hit the hardest. The world is experiencing a "catastrophic loss" of invertebrate life as natural areas are destroyed and degraded, he writes. Despite this loss, he continues, "the general public seems largely unaware of its possible impact on human well-being."
Not least because invertebrates are so pervasive, conservationists have lately shifted their focus to the protection of entire ecosystems, with all their multifarious tiny life forms. Rescuing single species of big animals like tigers, whales, pandas, bears, wolves, eagles and condors is not enough, according to the new philosophy; for all their charisma, they are far less important to the maintenance of life than the uncountable armies of the spineless, not to mention vascular plants and bacteria.
"The world is going to go on without golden lemurs and without any one of a number of orchids," but invertebrates "are responsible for all the ecosystem processes," said Melody Allen, the director of the Xerces Society, the country's only conservation organization devoted to invertebrates. The society, based in Portland, Ore., is named after an extinct butterfly.
 
90 to 95 Percent of Animal Species
 Invertebrates -- the group includes mostly insects and spiders but also other soft-bodied and sometimes hard-shelled organisms like crabs, lobsters, clams, squid, sea urchins, jellyfish and sponges -- account for 90 to 95 percent of animal species and total animal weight on earth. In reviewing the scientific literature on the subject, Dr. Kellert found that in the United States, for instance, the combined biomass, or dry weight, of earthworms, insects and spiders is 55 times greater than that of humans.
Partly because of their sheer numbers, invertebrates are the biological foundations of every ecosystem. They are not merely indispensable links in the food chain or key denizens of wild habitats, though they are both of those; to a large extent they are the habitat. They maintain the soil structure and fertility on which plant growth and thus all higher organisms depend. They cycle nutrients by consuming decaying matter, pollinate crops and other plants, disperse seeds, keep populations of potentially harmful organisms under control and eliminate wastes. In the ultimate example, colonies of corals, many of them now endangered, provide habitats for a seemingly infinite variety of sea creatures, including perhaps one-third of all fish species.
While scientists know in general that invertebrates are the key to ecosystem functioning, they know comparatively little about the details and, in fact, scientists say that many of the tiny actors are completely unknown. Consequently, said Ms. Allen, "we can't even recoup our losses" if particular assemblages of invertebrates disappear and their ecosystems consequently fall apart.
On another level, the spineless kingdom directly provides food for innumerable larger organisms, including humans. People may dislike the look of crabs, as Dr. Kellert reports, but they eat them with gusto, along with lobsters, clams, crayfish, oysters, scallops, octopuses and squids. Many non-Western peoples dote on locusts, ants, termites, grasshoppers and beetle grubs.
One example offered by Dr. Kellert speaks volumes about humans' dependence on invertebrates. In the United States, humans produce some 130 million tons of excreta annually, while livestock produces an additional 12 billion tons. "Of this waste," Dr. Kellert writes, "99 percent is thought to be decomposed by invertebrates, leaving one to wonder, if not for our 'little friends,' what humans would be 'up to their eyeballs in.' "
If invertebrates are so valuable, then, why do people so often regard them with anxiety and disgust? That they do so was borne out by a limited survey of attitudes conducted by Dr. Kellert among various economic and social groups in and around New Haven. The survey included 145 members of the general public as well as separate, randomly selected samples of farmers, scientists and members of conservation groups.
"For the most part," said Dr. Kellert, "we found that aversion, anxiety, disdain, fear and loathing were very prevalent," especially regarding insects and spiders. A large majority of the general public, according to the sampling, displayed dislike of ants, bugs, beetles, ticks, cockroaches and crabs. A majority expressed willingness to eliminate whole classes of animals altogether, including mosquitoes, cockroaches, fleas, moths and spiders. Farmers conveyed similar attitudes, and both groups disapproved of major expenditures or economic sacrifices on behalf of endangered invertebrates.
Scientists, and to a lesser extent conservation group members, were far more likely to support such efforts. The best-educated people expressed the greatest conservation concern for invertebrates, as did younger people and men. Biological scientists, as might be expected, knew more about invertebrates and were more interested in and less afraid of them than other scientists. A series of true-false questions indicated that most people had a limited knowledge of invertebrates.
 
Reasons for Human Aversion
 Dr. Kellert's search of the scientific literature turned up a number of possible reasons for humans' aversion, which he offers as speculative explanations. Some are obvious: the ability of some insects to harm people (through stinging and disease transmission) and crops, for instance. Some scientists have suggested that humans have a genetic predisposition toward this fear, forged out of evolutionary necessity millenniums ago, and that it has been generalized to include other invertebrates.
Other speculation holds that the appearance of many invertebrates, their otherworldly monstrosity, plays a role. Some scientists also suggest that their overwhelming numbers and rapid reproduction rates challenge human assumptions about personal identity and individuality, that they are perceived as pitiless and devoid of feelings, and that their willingness and ability to invade human space so ingeniously, insidiously and indifferently to human wishes threatens humans' feelings of control and security. Ignorance undoubtedly plays a big role: "For most people," Dr. Kellert writes, "invertebrates remain largely alien and unfathomable."
Some species are exceptions to the general rule of fear and loathing, of course. The Kellert survey found more positive attitudes toward pretty invertebrates like butterflies, and toward useful ones like shrimp and bees and those with recreational value, like mollusks whose shells are collected at the shore.
In this, Dr. Kellert sees cause for hope among conservationists. Some charismatic butterflies and utilitarian creatures like bees might be enlisted as conservation symbols, just as whales and elephants have been, he says. Likewise, he says, corals might provide an especially effective symbol because "we do have an emotional tendency to recognize order and pattern and harmony, if you will, in nature," and nothing in the world better suggests this than a coral reef. The association of greater education with increased knowledge and concern about biological diversity in general and invertebrates in particular is also encouraging, he wrote.
While it is unlikely that many people will learn to love bugs and slugs, Dr. Kellert wrote, it may be that a greater appreciation of their importance to the ecology and ultimately to human welfare can do much to change human attitudes. Ms. Allen of the Xerces Society says that in her experience, people tend to "get over some of their phobic responses" once they understand invertebrates better. Even so, she said, "the most difficult thing in the conservation world is to get even other conservationists to realize the role of invertebrates."

Diagrams: "The Importance of Being Spineless"
 Invertebrates, animals that lack backbones, are so pervasive that it may be said life depends on them. The most numerous are insects, but there are also spiders, lobsters, corals, worms, etc.
 Some insects prey on invertebrates humans dislike.
 Many insects feed on other invertebrates, sometimes specializing in one species, and many of the prey species are crop pests.
 
"The little guys who run the world"
 Invertebrates build soil into the fertile matrix for plant life, and therefore support life for all mammals, including humans. Some insects act as the matchmakers for much of plant sex life, as many plants rely on insects for pollination. They also do important work in seed dispersal.
 
Invertebrates help explain all of nature.
 Syntomid moth's mimicry of wasp sheds light on adaptation. Study of fruit fly Drosophila has provided major revelations in genetics.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
To Russia in Constancy

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Sometime soon after the anti-Communist revolution, a new mantra entered international life.
The phrases "free-market economy" and "democracy" became chanted together, an inseparable formula. Without one, the other could not exist. In combination they were sung as the only answer to the future of Eastern Europe and Russia. 
 The mantra met the beliefs of many economists and politicians in the West and the dreams of reformers in the new Russia.
I understood the belief and dreams. I had reported from Poland in the cold days of Communism. The system disgusted me. Only a fool, ideologue or apparatchik would not understand that it was totally corrupt, totally brutal, totally inefficient.
And no democracy, however imperfect, came near Communism for distribution of poverty, or stultification. Whenever I left Poland to visit a free city, the mere sight of a stall with fruit or a kiosk with choice made my mouth water and brain tingle.
But democracy within a fully free market is not reachable in Russia any near tomorrow. Three problems will logically slow its arrival. If the West and Russian reformers do not face them, the result may be neither a free market nor a democracy but one more all-controlling despotism -- fascist or Communist.
First: The formula does not always work. Dictatorships by the sewerful have used some form of market economy to strengthen themselves; the Nazis in Germany, the Communists in China, Saddam Hussein in Iraq, the ayatollahs in Iran.
And time and again democracies like India have crept ahead while neighbors like China leapt forward. No mystery: dictatorships can act without the consent of the people. That is a laborious, quarrelsome business. Its only value is that it means the difference between breathing freedom and breathing slavery.
The second problem is that Russians, with no experience in democratic economics, are asked to create a fully free market, quick, snap, while established democracies still move toward it with enormous caution. In Japan, business, government and politicians work together in a largely closed system. In Western Europe, public telephones and telecommunications still are in government hands. In the U.S., administrations are elected and survive by ladling out advantage to selected parts of the society.
Since free markets usually mean unemployment for some to create prosperity for more, Westerners protect themselves with nets of unemployment insurance and social security as they inch toward the risks. For Russians -- no inching, no nets, just the plunge.
The third problem could be the most dangerous. Too many Russian workers feel that the new economic system is being shoved down their throats. Economic hard times become a personal and national humiliation -- a combination that helped Russian fascism get a quarter of the party votes, and a variety of Communists take another large chunk.
Russians created Russia and Russians will have to solve its problems. But the West can help. One way is to draw closer to Russian reformers and other democrats -- not just President Yeltsin but all the others who will have to think things through.
Full speed toward the free market would be fine -- if it could be maintained at acceptable social price. But so far it has meant murderous inflation and more unemployment, without the increased production it is supposed to bring.
For the sake of the civil peace that democracy needs to grow, President Yeltsin may have to listen to reformers who argue for a slower pace -- keeping some subsidies, some controls and some tariffs to buoy drowning industries. Name a Western nation that is not doing that right now.
If the pace has to slow, the West should not denounce or isolate Russia in the name of economic theory. If Russian workers want a little more job security to butter their freedom, and shout that economic theory alone can be too dry to swallow, are they different from Western workers?
We are asking the democrats of Russia to hang together against fascism and Communism. So it would be cruel and self-defeating for the West to choose this moment of crisis to withhold our constancy from those democrats. The revolution against Communism was fought for freedom, not an economics textbook.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Good Year Is Seen for Municipals

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The main reason that the municipal bond market looks so attractive next year is that the flood of new issues that marked 1993 is expected to slow substantially in 1994.
This decline should relieve the downward pressure on prices that analysts contend is the reason the municipal bond market has underperformed the Treasury market this year. 
With next year's new supply expected to fall to the pace of 1991, the increase in Federal tax rates should be able to make tax-exempt municipal bonds attractive enough to give prices a good boost. Under the new top tax rate of 39.6 percent, a municipal bond yield of 5.70 percent has a tax-equivalent yield of 9.44 percent, up from 8.26 percent before this year's tax increase.
According to a forecast by the Public Securities Association, new issues should drop to $178.6 billion next year -- a decline of more than a third -- as stable or even rising interest rates end the rush to pay off older, higher- interest-rate debt.
 
Two Banner Years
 The sharp falloff in new issues will follow two consecutive record-setting years. In 1993, the association projects that new issues will reach $289.5 billion, which would be a 23.4 percent jump from the 1992 record of $234.6 billion. In 1991, new issues totaled $174.1 billion.
The association forecast includes both a decline in new issues used to pay off older high-interest debt and in new issues to raise money for projects. New issues for paying off old debt, which are forecast to rise 57.1 percent, to $192.9 billion this year, are predicted to fall to $68.9 billion in 1994, a decline of 64.3 percent.
The level of issues raising money for new projects is predicted to slip 13.6 percent next year to $96.6 billion, down from an estimated $111.8 billion this year. Most of the decline will be in new issues for projects like roads, bridges and single-family housing.
 
Treasury Market
 There was little going on in the bond market yesterday, with the trading pace beginning to drop off ahead of the holiday weekend. But the subtle nudging of the Federal Reserve continued as Administration officials said they saw no need to raise interest rates now.
The comments came ahead of today's meeting of the Fed policy-making committee to set its interest-rate goals going into next year. Analysts do not expect the Federal Reserve to make any change in policy now, which means its short-term interest-rate target will remain at 3 percent. But many analysts expect that the Fed will have to raise its interest-rate target sometime in the first half of next year to head off a rise in inflation.
In comments at the White House, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said that both the Fed and the Administration wanted sustained growth with low inflation. "That's the objective, I think, of not just this Administration, but, I think it's the objective of the Fed in addition," Mr. Bentsen told reporters.
A rumor early in the day that the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, was thinking of resigning, did not seem to have an impact on the market, as it was quickly squashed.
In late trading in the secondary market, the price of the 30-year bond due in August 2023 was down 11/32as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.30 percent, from 6.27 percent on Friday. Short-term interest rates jumped a little further. The price of the two-year note was down 3/32 as the yield rose to 4.20 percent from 4.15 percent.
 
Results of Auction
 In the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the average discount rate on the three-month bill was 3.06 percent, the same as a week ago, while the average rate on the six-month bill was 3.25 percent, down from 3.26 percent last week.
There are little major economic data scheduled for release this week but traders and investors will have to get by the Treasury auction of two-year notes today and five-year notes Wednesday. After that the week is basically over, with a half-day session scheduled for Thursday and the Treasury market closed on Friday.
In trading in the pre-auction market, the yield on the two-year note was at 4.25 percent, up from 4.21 percent, while the yield on the five-year note was 5.21 percent, up from 5.16 percent.
Following are the results from the Treasury auction yesterday of three-month and six-month bills:
