 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Dec. 21 about the credit markets misstated the periods involved in the Public Securities Association's forecast for the issuing of municipal bonds for new projects. The association forecast of a decline of 13.6 percent, to $96.6 billion, was for 1993, not 1994. The association's estimate of $111.8 billion was for 1992, not 1993. For 1994, the association forecasts an increase of 13.6 percent, to $109.7 billion, in these new issues.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK COUNCIL VOTES TAX BREAKS FOR HUGE TOWERS

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The New York City Council, in a tumultuous meeting that ended its legislative session, voted overwhelmingly yesterday to extend tax breaks to developers who build large apartment towers in Manhattan.
The bill, which is intended to give a stimulus to the city's anemic construction industry, extends to midtown and lower Manhattan a property-tax abatement that has been available to developers since 1975 in most of the city. For developers who qualify for the break, taxes are frozen for 10 years at the amount the owner of the site paid before the new construction. 
 The tax abatement bill was passed on a day of jampacked agendas, fiery oratory, partisan votes and bittersweet farewells. Mayor David N. Dinkins gave a last address to the Council, telling its members that they were the sole guardians of the liberal tradition of the city, now that a Republican had been elected Mayor.
 
Impassioned Debate
 Mr. Dinkins urged the Council to preserve the programs he had started, including the expansion of the Police Department, new health clinics in poor neighborhoods, the all-civilian police review board and the awarding of more city contracts to companies owned by women and minorities.
Besides the tax abatement, the Council, after long and impassioned debate, approved two well-publicized bills Mr. Dinkins has promised to veto: one to regulate vans that provide taxi service and the other relaxing regulations on horse-drawn carriages. Mr. Dinkins's veto of the horse-carriage bill would mean that after Jan. 1 the 19th-century-style carriages now confined mostly to Central Park would be able to range throughout the city, at least until new legislation is adopted. [Page B3.]
Proponents of the tax-incentive bill argued that development had all but come to a standstill in Manhattan, hitting its lowest points since the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's. They said developers needed help to counter the prolonged economic slump. Mayor Dinkins had requested the bill, which was passed, 39 to 8, after little debate.
 
Hope for Recovery
 "I don't see the construction industry falling all over itself to start new jobs in the city of New York," said Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat, a backer of the bill. "The reality is the construction industry is totally flat and dead and these abatements are the engines that fuel economic recovery."
But a handful of opponents charged that the incentives amounted to an unnecessary giveaway to individual developers, among them William Zeckendorf, who is planning a residential project at 56th Street and Broadway that would become eligible under the new law. "It's done for Zeckendorf, and we don't know for who else," Ronnie M. Eldridge, a Manhattan Democrat, said.
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, urged the Council to reject the bill, saying it was spurring development in Manhattan, especially along Broadway in the 50's and below Chambers Street, rather than in other boroughs, where new housing is sorely needed.
"This is encouraging residential development in the wrong place at the wrong time," Ms. Messinger said.
During a real-estate boom in 1985, the city cut midtown and the area south of Chambers Street out of the abatement program, saying incentives were no longer needed. The law passed yesterday reinstates the abatement for the next three years to those zones, which allow towers with 15 times the floor space of the plot.
To qualify, the developer must promise to reserve one in five apartments for low-income families and must build on a vacant or underused property. The city collects no new property taxes for 10 years beyond what the developer paid before the new building went up. Then the new value of the property is gradually added to the old assessment over 10 years, after which the developer begins to shoulder the full tax burden.
It is impossible to say how much tax revenue the city will forgo because no one knows for certain how many buildings would have been built in midtown and lower Manhattan without the incentives, city officials said. But the abatements do have an impact. In 1992, for instance, the city sacrificed $189 million in taxes from hundreds of buildings constructed under the program since 1975.
These were among the other important bills that were approved:
*A measure to let the Department of Buildings contract with a nonprofit organization to do plumbing inspections. Municipal unions opposed the bill, saying it cost more money than paying the plumbing inspectors a higher wage as a way to reduce corruption. But proponents argued that recent arrests of dozens of plumbing inspectors on corruption charges made a radical reform necessary.
*A pilot program aimed at reducing accidents involving speeding tow trucks. It would give certain towing companies a monopoly on business in some neighborhoods to prevent freelance tow trucks from monitoring police radios and rushing to accidents.
*A law to restrict use of car alarms, making it possible for the police or ticket agents to write a ticket when a alarm goes off for more than three minutes. The current law allows them to sound for 10 minutes.
*A measure that allows the city to close a business for illegal activities, including prostitution, drug dealing or gambling, after three violations, rather than the current five.
Dinkins administration officials vehemently denied that the tax-abatement bill was intended to help Mr. Zeckendorf, or any particular developer. They said the measure was an effort to infuse new life in a moribund construction industry that produced fewer apartments this year than at any time since World War II.
"Zeckendorf may have a project, he may not," said Harold Schultz, deputy commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. "No one has approached us with an application at this point."
The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone characterized the measure as "a signal to the people out there that we would like to see some activity."
Some Council members voted for the abatement with reservations, saying the entire method New York uses to dole out abatements needs revamping. Kenneth K. Fisher, a Democrat from Brooklyn, said he believes the city should rethink the philosophy of giving tax incentives automatically to developers. But in the meantime he supported the measure in the hope that it would create jobs. "I'd rather have half of something than all of nothing," he said.
Charles Millard, a Manhattan Republican, said: "The real issue is whether we let the market operate. Developers, just like everyone else, need to be subject to the market."
Warren Wechsler, vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said that for most developers, exclusion of some parts of Manhattan from the abatement never made sense since residential buildings should be encouraged everywhere. He said the measure was needed because only 2,728 units had been built this year, the fewest in decades.
"Based on the figures I have seen," he said, "the last year was one of the lowest for production of privately financed housing since the middle of World War II and the early 1930's."
In other business, the Council approved six nominees from Mr. Dinkins for several city boards -- three to the Environmental Control Board and one each to the Board of Standards and Appeals, Board of Health and Civil Service Commission.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
TAX BREAKS APPROVED FOR HUGE TOWERS
The City Council voted overwhelmingly to extend tax breaks to developers who build large apartment towers in Manhattan. The bill extends to midtown and lower Manhattan a property-tax abatement that has been available to developers since 1975 in most of the city. A1. 
 The Council also passed a bill to expand when and where horse-drawn carriages can operate, but Mayor Dinkins said he would veto the measure. The carriages are now restricted to Central Park for most of the day. B3.
Striving to define and protect his legacy, Mayor Dinkins appealed to the City Council to preserve the liberal programs he initiated from what he called "the very different ideology and philosophy" of Mayor-elect Giuliani. B3.
 
2 SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENTS ARE OUSTED
Two Bronx school superintendents hired to help improve schools and fight graft are being ousted by their local school boards, which have long histories of corruption. The two districts were singled out again last week for censure by the New York City school system's top investigator in a report on voter fraud in the spring school board elections. A1.
 
NEW YORK F.B.I. CHIEF IS SUSPENDED
The New York F.B.I. chief, who supervised the World Trade Center bombing investigation, has been suspended from his duties after Government lawyers complained that he had talked about the bombing case during a television interview. B4.
 
SCHOOL IN BRONX IS REWARDED
The educational philosophy practiced at University Heights High School in the Bronx was richly rewarded when Walter Annenberg, the publishing magnate, donated $50 million to a nationwide network of schools that have reorganized themselves according to principles advocated by Theodore Sizer, a Brown University professor of education. B7.
 
GIULIANI NAMES A HOSPITALS CHIEF
Mr. Giuliani nominated the Health Commissioner of New Jersey, Dr. Bruce Siegel, to head the city's $3.2 billion system of hospitals and clinics, moving to force out the current director before his term expires in May. B3.
 
BOMBING JURY HEARS TRANSCRIPTS
Prosecutors in the World Trade Center case began what promises to be a very long reading of transcripts of conversations. B4.
 
1,000 GIFTS FOR CHILDREN ARE STOLEN
The theft of about 1,000 gifts for homeless children from a shelter at 78 Catherine Street in lower Manhattan was an act that sickened even veteran social workers who thought they had seen it all. B2.
 
REGION
 
DISAPPOINTMENT IN TRADE PACT
Executives in some fields, particularly financial services and entertainment, said that omissions in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade mean that the United States missed a rare opportunity to help the lagging economies of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. B5.

HEADLINE: MORE OF HOMELESS ARE NOW FAMILIES

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
A survey of 26 major cities has found that the proportion of the homeless population consisting of families with children increased by 30 percent this year.
While families made up 33 percent of those seeking food and shelter last year, they account for 43 percent now, according to a report on the status of Hunger and Homelessness in American Cities. The report was released today by the United States Conference of Mayors. 
 Andrew Cuomo, director of policies on homelessness for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, said at a news conference announcing the report that homeless families with children had nothing to do with the more visible homeless adults with mental, drug or alcohol problems.
Mr. Cuomo said that the number of homeless families was growing but that the public was not aware of it because, unlike the mentally ill, the families were "not on the streets, not on park benches, not in doorways."
According to the report, the number of people requesting emergency food assistance increased by 13 percent this year. It said that while resources available for providing food had increased by an average of 7 percent, two out of three cities reported they could not provide adequate food for those requesting it.
 
Unemployment Cited As Factor
 In New York City, for example, where families make up 75 percent of homeless people, 38,000 people a month were turned away from emergency food providers because of a lack of food. At the same time, the report noted that requests for shelter in New York and four other cities had declined slightly.
Freeman Bosley Jr., Mayor of St. Louis and a co-chairman of the Conference of Mayors, said much of the increase in homelessness and hunger could be attributed to underemployment. Thirty percent of adults requesting food assistance this year were employed, he said, adding, "There is a significant number of working poor among the homeless."
The report revealed that the proportion of homeless people who are in families with children varied around the country. Trenton had the highest proportion of families, at 77 per cent. In Nashville and New Orleans, on the other hand, families accounted for only 16 percent and 14 percent of the homeless population respectively.
 
Economic Recovery Could Help
 Portland, Ore., showed the biggest increase in requests for food and shelter -- 88 percent -- followed by Los Angeles with a 50 percent increase.
Mr. Cuomo and other experts on homelessness see the number of families on the street as an economic problem. In the report, New York City officials said they believed the slow recovery from a prolonged recession would make it unlikely that the demand for food and shelter would increase, especially among families.
Recently, Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros made homelessness his top priority, requesting a doubling of the budget for dealing with the problem from $800 million to $1.6 billion, signaling a change in priorities.
"It has been very lonely for us on this issue," Tom Cochran, the executive director of the Conference of Mayors, said at a news conference. He said that for the first time since the task force was set up 10 years ago, an Administration official was present at the news conference.
Advocates have declared today, the first day of winter, Homeless Persons Memorial Day. Across the country memorial services are being held by advocacy groups to commemorate homeless people who died this year.

HEADLINE: As Free Trade Draws Nations Together, Campus Becomes 'Mexico Think Tank'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 21

 BODY:
When President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico needed to better understand the emotional tugs and pulls of United States opinion on illegal immigration, he turned to the Center for U.S.-Mexican Studies at the University of California at San Diego.
When Pedro Aspe, the Mexican Secretary of Finance, wanted perspectives on economic development in the United States, he turned up at the center. 
 And when several hundred businessmen sought ways to enter a Mexican market about to be opened up by the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, they, too, came to the center for help.
As United States and Mexico draw closer economically and culturally with the free trade agreement, which takes effect on Jan. 1, the 15-year-old research center not far from the border has become a clearinghouse for information and analysis.
 
'Main Think Tank'
 "The center is the main Mexico think tank in the United States," said Victor Aviles, Press Minister at the Mexican Embassy in Washington. Mr. Aviles was a fellow at the center's summer program in United States studies for Latin American students. "It was my introduction to the United States."
The center -- the largest in the country devoted to Mexico-United States studies -- trains graduate students and runs special sessions for research fellows and visiting scholars from throughout the United States, Mexico and the rest of Latin America. Researchers there have studied Mexico's political, economic and social cultures and how they interact with the United States. It has become an important source of analysis for journalists covering the border and for elected officials trying to understand migration and other issues.
Over the last five years, the center's researchers have generally been supportive of Mr. Salinas's open-market economic changes and of how he has tamed inflation. Parts of Mexico's new agricultural subsidy program, which includes small farmers who had been excluded from previous efforts, was based in part on work done at the center.
Much of the center's research projected that a free trade agreement with the United States would be beneficial, although the work of Harley Shaiken, a labor economist attached to the center, was critical of the impact a trade agreement would have on workers.
 
Budget Is Problem
 Mr. Salinas is a friend of the center's director, Wayne A. Cornelius. Some analysts say that since the Mexican President took office in late 1988, the tone of the center's work has not been critical enough of social problems in Mexico or of the Salinas Administration's reluctance to make substantive political changes. But the center has published critical studies of parts of Mr. Salinas's policies, including his anti-poverty program, Solidarity. A center report said the Salinas Administration used Solidarity to build a new political base.
With the advent of the free-trade agreement, the need for the center's expertise has increased. But its financial support has become dangerously thin, leaving questions about its future. Although the number of requests from Government officials, journalists and businesses is up, no extra staff members have been hired.
"The total pot of funds we have to allocate to researchers is half what it used to be," Professor Cornelius said.
Thirty-four percent of the center's $1.1 million budget comes from the state university system or from the San Diego campus. The California budget crisis has forced the university to revise its priorities, making the center's financing less certain. More than ever, the center has had to rely on contributions from private foundations and other donors. The Mexican Government provides $50,000 a year.
The money crunch comes at a critical time. The free trade agreement will reduce and eventually eliminate the tariffs on most goods crossing between Mexico and the United States. It also represents a coming together of two nations that have been split by wars and mistrust.
That closeness may require understanding and a sharing of information that does not now exist. "I find it frightening that when Ross Perot claims that all Mexicans live in shacks without plumbing," Professor Cornelius said, "millions of American believe him."
When the center was founded in 1979, the only interest most people in the United States had in Mexico was in Mexican oil. After the Arab oil embargo, "Mexico was viewed as key to long-term energy security in the United States," he said. "Mexico was suddenly on everyone's radar scope."
Other centers have been established at the University of Texas at Austin, the University of Arizona in Tucson and Tulane University in New Orleans, but they do not compare with the scope of San Diego's.
"No other place has the kind of concentrated program that San Diego has," said Richard Sinkin, who was a professor of Mexican history at the University of Texas for 17 years. Mr. Sinkin is now a managing partner at Inter American Holdings, a consulting company, and was involved in organizing a business forum recently sponsored by the San Diego center.
The center enjoys an advantage over other programs because of its closeness to the border, but that location also makes some work more difficult. Professor Cornelius recently wrote an opinion article in The Los Angeles Times in which he criticized as neo-nativist the San Diego residents who complained about the costs of education and social services for Mexican immigrants.
That elicited 100 letters to the newspaper, some of which suggested that one way to start dealing with California's budget problems was to dismiss Professor Cornelius.
 
Ties to President
 Professor Cornelius, who is 48, comes to his understanding about Mexico by way of a small mining town in western Pennsylvania and a high school study-abroad program that took him to Mexico for the first time. He later became a member of the political science faculty at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he taught for eight years before the San Diego campus invited him to establish the center.
While he was teaching at M.I.T., Professor Cornelius had a particularly bright graduate student from Harvard who took advantage of cross-registration privileges between the two institutions. His name was Carlos Salinas de Gortari.
"At that point I couldn't tell how high he could rise," Professor Cornelius said. "He clearly stood out among the foreign students who took classes at M.I.T. during that period as someone with extraordinary drive and intelligence."
The two have remained close. In 1991 the center organized a luncheon with President Salinas in which it raised $87,500 for its endowment. Professor Cornelius is a regular visitor to Los Pinos, the Mexican White House.
Some critics say that the center is too close to the Salinas Administration. A case in point, they say, came this year, when Raul Salinas, the President's brother, was appointed a guest scholar in residence. Described as an engineer and agronomist, he researched land ownership reforms undertaken during his brother's term in office.
Professor Cornelius said that Mr. Salinas came with a legitimate research project and his own financial support. "We have never turned away a qualified researcher with a serious piece of Mexico-related research as long as he had his own financial support," he said.
But he conceded the difficulty of maintaining an image of impartiality, particularly with the increased attention on Mexico. "We're always walking a tightrope," he said. "Namely, are we going to be perceived as advocates or agents of Mexico in the U.S., or as agents for some interests of the United States in Mexico."
 
Reams of Research
 The output of the center's research can be seen in 91 dissertations and more than 115 books, reports and other publications that are used in 120 colleges and universities. Graduates now hold positions in universities all over the continent, as well as in many branches of the Mexican Government.
Reaching agreement on a free trade agreement was only the beginning of a long process of integration for the two nations, Professor Cornelius said. "I view this as a period of both great potential opportunity and great potential conflict," he said. "To the extent that the costs of this trade agreement are going to be spread over the short term, and the benefits realized only over a much longer period of time, there's a potential for recrimination and tension that didn't exist before."

HEADLINE: Comeback City -- A special report.;
Economic Focus in Shanghai: Catching Up

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
If there is a swaggerer in this part of the world, its name is Shanghai.
This Chinese city is racing to recapture the glory of capitalism that flourished here 60 years ago and crumbled under the scorn and persecution of Communism. 
 Recently released private speeches by China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, make it clear for the first time that China's largest industrial city was deliberately excluded from the boom unleashed 15 years ago in a series of experiments that became a revolution.
Back in 1978, fear of failure, and the untested nature of economic reform, left the 13 million residents of Shanghai on the sidelines for more than a decade as "special economic zones" to invent a new Chinese capitalism took off along China's southern coastline.
 
What $40 Billion Buys
 Today Shanghai is racing to catch up, laying the foundations of a new financial capital with a $40 billion public-works binge and a development plan that is putting factories in the rice fields of Pudong, on the east bank of the Huang Pu River, which divides Shanghai.
The economic reformers plan to activate the latent economic power of the Yangtze River delta, bringing Shanghai into competitive play with Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore.
Thus the ailing Mr. Deng, who is 89, and his reform-minded proteges hope to buttress the political bulwark they have been building against ideological and economic retrenchment after his death.
 
First, the Foundations
 To scan Shanghai's horizon is to see the scale of its transformation.
Construction cranes tower over bulldozed neighborhoods as a new merchant class builds office towers, hotels and shopping centers with money from Hong Kong, Macao, Taiwan and the United States.
The largest investor, however, is the Government, which is laying roads and building bridges that will make the new city possible. The first stage is almost complete.
In October the world's longest cable-stayed bridge opened over the Huang Pu. An elevated six-lane ring road, a crosstown expressway and the first line of a subway system are all in progress. New harbor facilities are opening, and water, gas and sewage works. And the first turbines of a new power plant are to begin cranking in 1994.
On the east bank of the river, facing the Bund, old Shanghai's Art Deco waterfront of banks, trading houses and hotels, the skyline is dominated by Asia's tallest television tower, a 1,500-foot-tall architectural Goliath. The tower, which will open next year, has a center spine that pierces two giant "pearls," one of them a geodesic dome housing an elevated shopping mall.
"This tower will be the future symbol of Shanghai," said Yu Guozhuang, an official of the People's Bank of China, which organized $100 million in loans from dozens of Chinese banks for the project.
On thousands of acres around the tower, city officials say, there will be a financial district that they hope will become the Manhattan of the East within 20 years.
"I think we can do it," said Xu Kuangdi, the Executive Deputy Mayor, who spends as much time selling the new Shanghai as he does administering the old one.
 
The Politics
To Modernize, First Apologize
 The scale of Shanghai's program is reminiscent of the post-World War II rebuilding of European and Japanese cities. And the new Shanghai is politically significant because it signals the end of the ideological debate over China's free-market experiments.
"Shanghai's emergence depended upon the success of the earlier stages of reform," Geremie Barme, a China scholar at the Australian National University, said on a recent visit to Shanghai. "Only when that success was assured would they dare tamper with Shanghai."
As Mayor Huang Ju likes to say, 400 million Chinese -- 8 percent of the world's population linked in an expanding Yangtze River economy with Shanghai as "the head of the dragon" -- could be an irresistible political force after Mr. Deng is gone.
"Every act has its political component," Mr. Barme said. "Once they decided to put Shanghai on line as an economic region, it means that they need to do it."
 
'Mea Culpa' From Mr. Deng
 The publication of Mr. Deng's private speeches over the past decade marked the first time that Shanghai residents heard his candid confession of February 1992.
"One of my biggest mistakes," he told a group of Communist cadres, was to exclude Shanghai from the economic zones set up after a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee in December 1978. That was the year of Mr. Deng's comeback after the death of Mao Zedong in 1976.
By leaving Shanghai out of the economic plan, Mr. Deng acknowledged, he consigned a huge population to another generation of poverty. Had he acted earlier, he said, "the situation in the Yangtze delta, the whole Yangtze Valley, indeed in all of China would be quite different."
That one leader's whimsy could spell rags or riches for so many reflects the enormous scale and impact of social and economic engineering under Chinese Communism.
How could anyone have known then what history would prove, shrugged Mr. Xu, the Deputy Mayor. "It would have been impossible," he said, for Mr. Deng to have gambled with an economic experiment in Shanghai only to see it fail. "To lose the experiment would be to lose perhaps 25 percent of China's G.N.P.," Mr. Xu said.
"But after the 1980's, and success in Canton, it was time for Shanghai," he added.
 
Canton Proved the Theory
 In April 1990, after a meeting of the Central Committee, the State Council removed the constraints on trade and investment that had kept Shanghai in an economic backwater.
The key players were Mr. Deng; Jiang Zemin, the new party secretary and former Mayor of Shanghai, and Zhu Rongji, a protege of Mr. Deng. Mr. Zhu took over the Mayor's office and quickly earned the nickname Mr. One Chop, as he began to reduce the number of "chops," or permits, that had been one of the many barriers to foreign investment. His brusque verbal style also "chops" down adversaries.
The special regulations that had enabled the coastal provinces to take off were extended to Shanghai: tax exemptions for enterprises doing business with foreign companies, tax holidays for new factories set up with foreign investment and a bonded zone, the largest in China, for duty-free imports of raw materials. For its part, the central Government said it would help pay for a vast modernization of public works.
That was three years ago, and Mr. Deng was still struggling against party ideologues who opposed reform, especially as China coiled itself in isolation after the Tiananmen Square massacre of pro-democracy campaigners in June 1989.
But because the first economic experiments in Canton, Zhejiang, Fujian and Hainan provinces were wildly successful, Mr. Deng could push ahead.
 
The Problems
Up-Front Costs, Long-Term Saving
 Whether Shanghai can rival its position of old is a much contested question.
Some foreign investors have begun to complain that the city is gouging new arrivals by more than doubling the price of long-term leases in industrial zones and by failing to rein in the bloated bureaucracy.
Though foreign investment still seems to be rushing in, a number of companies have reportedly considered Shanghai and rejected it, citing the tactics of greedy bureaucrats.
Still, the city's vigorous Mayor, Huang Ju, likes to point out that while Shanghai stood by in the 1980's, it attracted only $3.3 billion in foreign investment. But with the establishment of a "special economic zone" here, that same sum arrived in a single year, 1992. And 1993 is headed off the charts, with $6 billion in foreign investment in the first 10 months.
But Shanghai is entering a cutthroat Asian market of cheap labor and tax breaks.
And if one thing is certain, Shanghai is not getting any cheaper. With the stampede of Western and Asian corporations here, the price of prime office space has soared, making Shanghai the fifth most expensive office market in the world. Corporate executives are working out of closet-sized spaces and Western-style, two-bedroom apartments go for $8,000 a month or more.
Though wages in Shanghai are equivalent to turn-of-the-century wages in the United States, they have doubled since 1990 and quadrupled since 1985. That is the city commissars' biggest worry, the Deputy Mayor says.
 
The Topography
From Rickshaws To Subways
 But costs aside, almost nothing could begin without the foundations of a modern city.
Shanghai is a city laid out for rickshaws. "Modernization" under Communism replaced them with seven million bicycles and 300,000 cars, one-tenth the number of cars in New York City, but on Shanghai's antiquated roads, enough to choke the city with near-constant gridlock. An excursion across town can be a three-hour affair.
Now, nearly 24 months ahead of schedule, the city is putting the finishing touches on $14 billion worth of bridges, tunnels, freeways, ports and power plants. In part because inflation added 40 percent to the cost of the first 10 projects, Mr. Xu, the Deputy Mayor, said, "we wanted to speed up and finish them in three years instead of five years."
By next March, he said, the municipal government will be ready to begin the next phase, for $25 billion, to add a subway system, a second international airport, a container port, more tunnels, freeways, railroads, water and sewer facilities.
 
Relocation: Pluses and Minuses
 The 100,000 residents who are losing their homes to make room for new freeways and high-rises spend little time grumbling.
"Shanghainese seem incredibly patient with things that are problematic," said Kate McLean, an Australian business consultant and longtime resident of the city. "I think that on the whole, people are smart enough to know that you can't have certain changes without certain costs."
There is also the promise of better lives.
Wang Yi, a young man from Pudong who works in a cooking-oil factory and who will lose his house in January to road widening, said: "We know we will get apartments with gas and electricity and indoor plumbing, and this is good for our family. We just don't know when or where."
A migrant population of 2.5 million workers from neighboring provinces has surged into the city, where a million people work on construction projects that give the city its insomnolent night glow. Cranes, craters and the skeletal shells of office buildings, department stores, hotels and apartment blocks with names like Gold City and Nightless City are turning the old foreign concession areas on the West Bank of the Huang Pu into a nouveau riche sprawl.
The stock exchange is there, as are Shanghai's new millionaires, conspicuously consuming in the festival of boutiques and department stores along Nanjing Road.
 
Parties, but No Sycamores
 At night the young and the rich converge on J. J.'s, a high-tech disco built by foreign investors. Its nightly throb would scandalize the old Communists who made Shanghai's overindulgence the ideological whipping post for the political purges of the 1960's and 70's.
The Bund has been stripped of the 70-year-old colonnade of sycamores that stood guard over the facades of yesteryear. Now there is a windswept pedestrian esplanade overlooking the dangerously polluted Huang Pu.
The colossal concrete pylons to support the nearly completed ring road linking Shanghai's two new bridges march through densely populated downtown neighborhoods, crushing the traditional lilong houses, the tiny masonry-and-timber quarters, often set above a shop, that are the hallmark of working-class architecture here.
"The foreigners who come back to Shanghai and want to remember the old Shanghai might miss the things that were familiar to them," said Jiang Jianyun, the deputy editor of The Shanghai Star.
She said residents of lilong houses do not find any nostalgia in bundling up each morning to lug their chamber pots down the street to collection points. "Those people who live in those lilong houses are very glad to be moving out because they are so crowded and the living conditions are so poor," she added.
 
The History
Capitalist Flower, Blooming Again
 Shanghai reached the zenith of power and allure in the first three decades of the century, dominating Asian trade when Hong Kong was a sleepy British outpost. More than 165 banks, including 58 branches of foriegn banks, operated on or near the Bund in the 1930's.
The expatriate merchants imported European architecture and society, living in mansions behind high walls in the concession areas they were granted in the declining years of the Qing Dynasty.
The masses of Chinese outside these walls suffered the instability of warlord rule, gang rivalry and political struggle between the underground Communist movement and the corrupt Nationalist Government.
Old Shanghai had opium dens, cabarets imitating Europe's best, pink gin, cigars and the Green Gang. Politics between the wars was sleazy, corrupt and dangerous.
 
Mao's Long Shadow
 The nascent Communist movement, which included young men like Zhou Enlai and Deng Xiaoping, met furtively in safe houses, always fearing detection and massacre by the Nationalists under Chiang Kai-shek.
Shanghai's long decline began with the Japanese occupation in November 1937, followed by World War II and the civil war between the Nationalists and Communists in 1945-49. These conflicts drained the city of its foreign population and investment in a single chaotic exodus.
The Communist takeover in 1949 began four decades of mass social and economic experimentation under Mao; the political purges and mass movements he inspired deflated what capitalist spirit remained, leaving only a totalitarian hulk.
Today the focus of architectural preservation does not extend beyond the Bund, the old City Garden and the elegant villas of the former French concession.
"We will not allow anyone to destroy those buildings," said Mr. Xu, the Deputy Mayor. But, he added, much traditional architecture will come down and modern government-built apartments will go up on the outskirts.
"We will rebuild most of old Shanghai because the people want to improve their living conditions," he said.
 
Skyscrapers in the Paddy Fields
 Pudong, on the east bank, was an agricultural and industrial backwater until three years ago. It is now the future site of Shanghai's "Manhattan" and a huge free-export manufacturing zone.
More than 20 factories are rising behind fences marked with corporate logos like Siemens and Hitachi. Most of the new tenants are banking on tax concessions and duty-free imports of raw materials to assemble finished goods for export using Shanghai's cheap labor. "For all practical purposes," said Peter Topp, the supply manager for the largest joint venture in China, Shanghai Volkswagen, "the cost of labor in China is nothing."
Indeed, an important part of the economic strategy is once again to allow foreign corporations to exploit China's cheap labor market, just as foreign concessionaires did a century ago. But this time Shanghai will get a piece of the action through joint-ventures and the acquisition of technology. And many of the returning foreigners are foreigners only in name. By far the largest investment is coming from Hong Kong and Macao.
"The 50 million overseas Chinese are a little bit like the Jewish people who lost their country," Mr. Xu said. "Even though they are scattered across 100 countries for three or four generations, they are still Chinese people. They want to do something for their hometowns."

HEADLINE: Many Companies in Area Disillusioned by Accord

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Though the New York metropolitan region has the largest concentration of international companies in the United States, it was left relatively untouched by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade signed in Geneva last week. And that's not necessarily good.
Provisions that would have helped industries vital to the region, particularly financial services and entertainment, were left out of the treaty that established new rules for international trade. Executives in those fields said that those omissions mean that the United States missed a rare opportunity to help the lagging economies of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. 
 "We think it is terrific that GATT was concluded, but we are also disappointed," said David Strongin, director of international finance for the Securities Industry Association, which represents stock brokerage and investment banking companies. "Our priority was greater market access, and that was not achieved."
 
Financial Services Must Wait
 The nation's manufacturers are expected to benefit almost immediately from the reduced tariffs on their exports that were agreed to in Geneva. Financial service companies had been hoping to benefit in much the same way -- by an easement in the severe government restrictions they face in opening branches, trading on foreign stock exchanges and acquiring subsidiaries in much of the world.
But when the agreement was reached in Geneva, the concerns of the financial services industry were simply put in abeyance. Although nothing in the accord assures that the restrictions imposed by foreign countries will remain, there is nothing for now that makes it easier for the region's financial service companies to do business abroad. Instead, GATT negotiators gave themselves 18 months to continue debating new rules for financial services.
The United States negotiators "did not succeed on the offense, but they put up a masterful defense," said John R. Price, a managing director and head of government relations at Chemical Bank, who worked with government negotiators in Geneva. When the trade talks neared their conclusion, Mr. Price said, his biggest fear was that the accord would formally sanction current policies, which allow many foreign governments to bar or restrict United States banks while their banks have open access to this country. Now, the negotiators will at least have time to concentrate on lowering these barriers.
The region's financial services companies were not the only businesses with an important stake in the trade talks. Though many manufacturers are happy that the agreement offers tariff reductions, some expressed deep disappointment over other some other results.
One such company is United Technologies Corporation, based in Hartford, a maker of elevators, helicopters and commercial jet engines.
Although United Technologies stands to benefit from increased global demand, a spokesman for the company, James Linse, said the sticking point in the Geneva accord came over questions critical to Pratt and Whitney, the United Technologies division that makes jet engines. Pratt and Whitney had hoped the accord would set strict limits on government subsidies to foreign aircraft makers.
Like the unresolved questions facing the financial services industry, the debate over the aircraft subsidies was put off, and the Geneva negotiators set no deadline to resolve the matter.
 
Entertainment Woes
 Among large companies in the region, the entertainment industry is perhaps the most dissatisfied with the GATT agreement.
"We are profoundly disappointed," said Timothy Boggs, vice president of Time Warner, a diversified producer of movies, television programs, records and publications. While the company's Hollywood subsidiary, Warner Brothers, suffered a harsh blow when the negotiators in Geneva gave in to French demands to continue government assistance to European movie makers, he said the company's television business, based in New York, will also be hurt.
That is because the GATT agreement allows "content quotas" for European television programming. The quotas mean that European TV stations must devote more than half their air time to programs made in Europe, a restriction that Mr. Boggs said will adversely affect United States television companies.
 
I.B.M. Is Upbeat
 Although executives across a wide spectrum of industries in the New York region said they hoped for more from the GATT agreement, few denied that that treaty will ultimately benefit them if it spurs increased economic development around the world, particularly in poor nations.
One company that considers itself a clear winner is the region's largest manufacturer, International Business Machines.
"GATT lays out a whole set of business options for us that were not there before," said Mark A. Holcomb, an I.B.M. spokesman.
But among other manufacturers in the region that rely heavily on their own research and technology, the GATT agreement has left much to be desired.
"Our reaction is mixed, at best," said Lou Clemente, senior vice president at Pfizer, the Brooklyn-based pharmaceutical company, which had hoped for tough new global requirements for patent protection. Like Merck and Company, Johnson & Johnson and a dozen other large New Jersey drug makers, Pfizer looses huge amounts through patent infringement in other countries.
The drug makers' complaints are not that patent protections are ignored by the GATT agreement, but that they are being delayed. Under the agreement, foreign governments, some of which now have no patent laws, are given 10 years to enact them.

HEADLINE: Gay Couples Ruled to Be 'Family Members'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 21

 BODY:
New York State's highest court today upheld a state housing agency's authority to extend the definition of "family members" to include gay couples in matters concerning rent-regulated apartments.
The Court of Appeals, in a 6-to-0 ruling, said the Division of Housing and Community Renewal acted within its authority when it amended rent stabilization regulations to protect the rights of the surviving "life partner" of a deceased tenant. 
 In 1989 the Court of Appeals determined that "family member," when used in rent-control issues, included the roommate of a deceased tenant, provided there existed a long-term emotional and financial commitment, regardless of the sexes of those involved.
That ruling was hailed as a victory for New York City's gay community, which has been devastated by the AIDS epidemic. Many homosexuals whose partners had died of the disease were being evicted from rent-controlled apartments because existing laws didn't allow for them to inherit the property.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New Plan For Phone And Cable

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore outlined a broad plan today to overhaul the nation's telecommunications laws, but provided few details on how the Administration planned to tackle the devilishly divisive details.
As expected, Mr. Gore called for eliminating the legal barriers that now prevent cable television, local telephone and long-distance services from competing with one another. 
 But, in a speech to the National Press Club here, he also left room for continued regulation, expressing concern that the regional Bell telephone companies might still control "bottlenecks" to local telephone customers and could prevent full competition.
 
 
'Public Right of Way'
 Mr. Gore also said the Administration would push for measures to prevent the nation from being divided between "haves" and "have nots" in the information economy, and called for some sort of "public right of way on the information highway."
The Administration plans to issue a detailed legislative package on Jan. 11, at a speech the Vice President is scheduled to give in Los Angeles. Officials from the White House and the Commerce Department have been trying to work in cooperation with key members of Congress, who have introduced several bills that would relax or eliminate many legal barriers and permit greater competition.
But the Administration is still struggling to define its own role in fostering what it calls a "national information infrastructure," a high-speed network or networks to deliver two-way voice, video and data communications into homes and businesses.
It remained unclear today what the Administration intended to do to meet its goal of making advanced communications services available to schools, hospitals and ordinary citizens. Moreover, Mr. Gore offered no details on what kinds of safeguards would prevent a few big companies from dominating the nation's networks. Those issues represent a minefield of bitter disputes that could unhinge any reform effort, industry analysts say.
Thus far, private industry has been racing ahead of Washington on creating the data superhighway as cable, telephone and computer companies have rushed to build the components of advanced new networks. On a policy front, most of the initiatives so far have come from members of Congress, and Mr. Gore deferred to those lawmakers today by noting that they had done "a lot of the heavy lifting and achieved significant breakthroughs."
In the House, a bill co-sponsored by Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat, and Representative Jack Fields, a Texas Republican, would eliminate a law that now bars telephone companies from providing television services over their networks. In the Senate, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, has co-sponsored a similar bill with Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri.
Meanwhile, Representative John D. Dingell, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, has teamed up with a fellow Democratic Representative, Jack Brooks of Texas, on a bill that would loosen prohibitions that currently bar local Bell telephone companies from manufacturing equipment or entering the long-distance business.
 
 
Industry Consensus
 Perhaps because Mr. Gore refused to stray far from what is increasingly a consensus view within the industry about the need for telecommunications reform, today's speech generated little controversy.
The National Cable Television Association praised what it called the plan's "solid, comprehensive principles," a view echoed by the United States Telephone Association, which represents local telephone companies. Both the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and MCI Communications also praised the speech.
The speech also won support from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a nonprofit lobbying group formed to address civil liberties in new electronic media.

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
Japan's Loan Sharks Make Good Money in Bad Times

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Of all the battered sectors of the currently depressed Japanese economy, the business of lending money may be in the worst shape.
Banks are awash in bad debts. The stock market during the last four years has lost more than $3 trillion, equal in value to nearly half the gross national product of the United States. And nonbank finance companies have taken a shellacking on real estate lending. 
 So why does the market here love one of the oldest forms of money-lending -- loan sharks?
While loan sharks appall stuffy commercial banks, occasionally anger the police and even embarrass some customers, investors have found that these specialized consumer-loan companies have a knack for doing something their more prestigious rivals cannot -- make good money even in bad times.
Known here as sarakin, a contraction of the Japanese words for salaryman and cash, these companies provide workers and the downtrodden white-collar masses -- who, beyond family or friends, have traditionally had no place to go for fast cash -- with a range of cash needs, from covering gambling bets to meeting unusual medical expenses.
With improved technology like advanced automated teller machines, some can even offer loan approval on the spot -- a boon to consumers who might be put off by the more formal surroundings of banks, which have always focused on big corporations.
The average loan size at the large sarakin companies now is slightly less than 400,000 yen, or about $3,600. These are high-interest loans that require no collateral.
In the last several months, three of Japan's largest consumer-loan companies -- the ACOM Company, the Promise Company and the Sanyo Shinpan Finance Company -- have sold stock to the public on the over-the-counter market. They have outperformed the market at a time when it has been plunging. They also remain quite profitable.
"These companies are, in fact, quite good at what they do," said Alicia Ogawa, the financial analyst at Salomon Brothers Asia. "They fill a real need. The bigger banks haven't bothered with consumer lending until very, very recently because they always considered dealing with consumers sort of, you know, dirty."
As a result, the rates the sarakin have charged have been usurious. A decade ago they could legally charge 110 percent interest, about 10 times the prime lending rate at banks. Regulators have lowered that to 40 percent, about seven times the banks' prime lending rate. Actual loan rates run about 29 percent. "You can tolerate 2 to 3 percent loan losses if you're charging 29 percent interest," David Snoddy, an analyst here with Jardine Fleming Securities, said.
At one time, the sarakin were relegated to back alleys or the upper floors of out-of-the-way buildings so customers could avoid being seen. Many were affiliated with organized-crime groups and a scandal blew up in the early 1980's because of their unsavory, if effective, collection methods. Intimidation, harassment in the form of tirades outside deadbeats' homes, as well as outright violence, were all tools of the trade.
At least for the large companies, those days are gone. Sanyo Shinpan, for instance, boasts that nearly 90 percent of its 141 loan offices are on the ground floors of buildings.
Sanyo Shinpan also forbids its debt collectors to confront customers in person; contacts are made through the mail and telephone calls. Still, even a call can intimidate a reluctant borrower, since it is considered a humiliation to be known as a deadbeat to a sarakin.
Analysts say the sarakin still do a better job than most banks at managing loan portfolios. They are much faster to write off overdue loans and even better at collecting bad debts.
Sanyo Shinpan is the sixth-largest sarakin company. Shinichiro Maeda, an analyst at Nomura Securities, projected that the company would have a declining rate of bad loan write-offs, and that it would enjoy earnings growth of about 10 percent a year for the next few years, despite the dismal state of the economy.
In the fiscal year ending next March 31, Sanyo Shinpan is expected to post net profits of 8.2 billion yen, or about $74 million. On Tuesday, its stock closed at 14,100 yen, about $127, a share. That's below its offering price in September of 16,000 yen, but the decline has been at a slower rate than the overall market, which has dropped more than 20 percent.
Despite competition in consumer lending with the increased popularity of credit cards here, the sarakin have a strong niche because they are more efficient than banks.
For instance, banks usually close their automatic teller machines at 7 P.M. on weekdays and 5 P.M. on weekends. The sarakin keep their A.T.M.'s open 24 hours in most instances. Promise closes its automated tellers at 10 P.M., but uses the machines as mini-loan centers, where customers can talk to a video image of a company employee and arrange for a credit line on the spot.
In addition, the sarakin work at what is blinding speed by Japanese standards. According to Mr. Snoddy, sarakin can approve a loan in less than an hour. Mr. Snoddy is a fan of ACOM, in large part because it enjoys the highest return on equity, slightly less than 13 percent. Its stock closed at 9,300 yen, or roughly $83.78, a share today, a shade below its offering price last month of 9,500 yen.
Promise, the third sarakin to go public, is trading above its asking price in September of 7,980 yen. Shares closed at 8,300 yen, about $74.77, today.
"These are high-risk, high-reward stocks," Walter Altherr, an analyst at Merrill Lynch Japan, said. "But over the long term one has to believe these stocks will show better growth than the banks."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Customers of the Promise Company, one of Tokyo's most prominent consumer-loan ocmpanies, can turn to electronic machines when they need cash quickly. Many machines even offer on-the-spot loan approval. (Kaku Kurita for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Yen But Dips in Other Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled lower against most European currencies in subdued trading yesterday, but strengthened against the yen amid more talk that the Japanese central bank might cut interest rates early next year to stimulate the economy.
Lower interest rates would further undermine the yen by making yields on yen-denominated securities less attractive to investors. 
 Further, "the market is now really beginning to get nervous over the economic and political situation in Japan," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Paine Webber Inc. "That's keeping the yen weak."
The market largely ignored comments by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who said he did not envision the United States' intervening to support the Japanese currency. Mr. Bentsen also said he was disappointed that so little progress has been made in opening Japanese markets to American goods.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 111.18 yen, from 110.62 yen on Monday.
The dollar was out of the spotlight most of the day. The Swiss franc drew strength as Europe's "safe haven" currency and moved higher. Mr. Flanagan noted that amid Germany's economic problems and growing disputes with labor, investors were inclined to abandon the German mark, and the Swiss franc has been the primary beneficiary.
"For the dollar at this time of year, it's more of a speculative market, and that means dealers are not necessarily trading the dollar," Mr. Flanagan said. Most dealers have settled their accounts and are awaiting the new year.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.4503 Swiss francs, down from 1.4580, and at 1.7103 German marks, down from 1.7125.
The British pound rose to $1.4880 from $1.4860.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 5.8155 French francs, down from 5.8388; 1,669.00 Italian lire, down from 1,673.00, and 1.3449 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3438.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Extends Its Rally To Hit a Three-Month High

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Copper prices, depressed earlier in the year by global recession and an oversupply, extended a recent rally to three-month highs yesterday. But many analysts viewed the 12 percent price rise since late October as a technical recovery in a weak market devoid of strong fundamentals.
"Funds, merchants, producers -- you name it -- everyone was short of copper," one analyst said. "It is the cutting back of those positions ahead of the year-end that has caused this rise." 
 Copper for March delivery gained 0.70 cent, to 82 cents a pound, the highest price since mid-September, at the Commodity Exchange in New York. Since March, prices have fallen from more than $1 a pound to a low of 73 cents.
Early yesterday, the London Metal Exchange, a key trading center and repository for base metals like copper, lead, zinc and nickel, reported that exchange copper inventories had dipped again. The total, 586,175 metric tons, is more than 4 percent below the late-September peak.
 
Far Eastern Demand Improving
 While some worry that there is still an oversupply of the metal, demand has improved in the United States and developing Far East economies, analysts said. But analysts said stocks might start to rise again if supplies from the former Soviet Union, which have been erratic recently because of crowded ports, began moving again.
Other metals prices were stagnant, with February gold down $1.50, to $389.30 an ounce, and March silver 4.5 cents lower at $5.097 an ounce.
On other commodity markets, energy prices eased in trading ahead of a weekly report on domestic inventories. Analysts were also keeping an eye on Arab oil ministers' talks, although there is increasing skepticism that Middle Eastern petroleum producers will cut back output to raise sagging prices.
February crude oil dropped 2 cents, to $14.36 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. January unleaded gasoline edged down 0.17 cent, to 39.38 cents a gallon, and January heating oil sank 0.39 cent, to 43.36 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Playing Politics Over Pork Exports

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
On Monday, the Russian ship Irbenskiy Proliv pulled into the port of Houston to pick up the last of about 24 million pounds of frozen American hog carcasses, cut into thirds and packed in boxes for shipment to Russia as a donation from the United States Government.
The ungainly slabs of raw meat, bones and fat, which cost American taxpayers $25 million, will be sold by the Russian Government to local manufacturers, who will use the meat in sausages to be sold at retail prices to Russian consumers. 
 This is the meager result of the American pork industry's two-year battle to win United States Department of Agriculture support for increased exports -- a top-level fight that ultimately was won when President George Bush, following pleas by a pork-farming friend, overruled his own Cabinet-level trade policy committee and approved the effort.
 
Corruption and Abuses Avoided
 The pork initiative was not afflicted by the corruption and regulatory abuses that have plagued the country's export credit programs in recent years -- violations that have ranged from kickbacks to foreign governments to the export of foreign goods disguised as American products. And the costs to the taxpayers are almost unnoticeable in a program that has already exceeded $40 billion during the last decade.
But if the country's costly export efforts are the sum of hundreds of small initiatives like this one, the American pork industry's bid for support illustrates how political pressures, rather than any thoughtful strategy, can dominate the country's trade programs.
It began in the summer of 1991, as the pork industry fretted that a growing hog population would cause prices to slump unless demand could be increased.
To raise demand, the National Pork Producers Council, an industry promotion group, advertised pork to health-conscious Americans as "the other white meat." And in 1989, it persuaded the Federal Government to donate surplus pork bellies to Poland -- a price-raising project that one Congressional critic compared to "sending ice to Eskimos."
By mid-1991, pork producers were looking to the former Soviet Union as a source of potential demand -- both through American Government subsidies and outright donations. "Russia is going to be a huge pork market for somebody," said Alan Tank, vice president for public policy and trade at the pork council. "It might as well be us."
In addition to encouraging Government donations of pork to Russia, the pork council wanted the meat to be eligible for the Federal export enhancement program, or E.E.P., which pays exporters a cash bonus to allow them to cut prices enough to compete in world markets. The export enhancement program, administered by the United States Department of Agriculture, was established to help protect America's share of world markets against Europe's subsidized farm exports.
 
A Boom in Exports
 In fact, American pork exports had boomed since 1986 without Federal trade subsidies. An industry-sponsored study last April by Abel, Daft & Earley, a consulting firm in Alexandria, Va., showed that American pork exports were already growing much faster than the exports of some heavily subsidized American crops.
Thus, the pork lobby faced an uphill fight to get export enhancement subsidies to sell pork to the Russians.
But on Nov. 8, 1991, the pork producers council announced at a press conference that Prodintorg, described as the "official buying agency" of the Soviet Government, "has formally requested 30,000 metric tons of U.S. pork as part of an additional agricultural credit package." That amount equaled nearly 40 percent of the pork exports in the previous year.
In fact, Prodintorg is just one of several procurement agencies still operating in Russia, and it did not have the power to negotiate trade subsidies. And despite the announcement, the Russian Government had not officially asked to use its existing American export subsidy credits for pork.Mr. Tank of the pork council blamed conflicts within the Russian Government and the Agriculture Department's refusal to force the Russians to use their existing trade credits for specific products for this omission.
Edward R. Madigan, who was the Secretary of Agriculture for President Bush at the time, defended his department's stance. "I couldn't just order them to buy it," Mr. Madigan said. "I couldn't set that precedent, or there'd be no end to it."
Besides the lack of strong evidence that pork exports were suffering in the absence of subsidies, Mr. Madigan said his staff felt the Russians preferred to buy subsidized feed grains for their own livestock -- an argument, Mr. Tank said, that reflected the Agriculture Department's "70-year-old thinking" and the political power of America's corporate feed-grain exporters.
In any case, the department's refusal to grant the subsidies ignited a political brush fire in Iowa and other key pork-producing states. Their Congressional representatives wrote Mr. Madigan almost weekly to protest the decision -- and in 1992, the Presidential campaign increased the heat.
"I had Terry Brandsted telling me that there was a chance the President could carry Iowa, but that this was an explosive issue out there," Mr. Madigan said, referring to the Republican Governor of Iowa. "I had the Iowa Congressional delegation on my back. I just wanted to put out this fire."
Mr. Madigan said he finally agreed to seek Cabinet approval for the subsidies. However, when the issue came before the Cabinet's Trade Policy Review Group, which must review such proposals, Mr. Madigan met opposition from the State Department, the Council of Economic Advisers and the Office of Management and Budget. Those agencies would not comment on the internal debate.
But Mr. Madigan said he recalled that the economists and the budget office had argued that the subsidies were an unwise use of tax revenues, while the State Department had opposed subsidizing products that competed with pork exports from the struggling democracies in Eastern Europe. In March 1992, the committee turned down the American pork industry's request.
Then, the industry pulled out its heaviest artillery: Roy B. Keppy, a third-generation pork farmer from Eldridge, Iowa, and a close friend of President Bush. Mr. Keppy, whose son Glen was an officer of the pork council and President Bush's chief farm fund-raiser in Iowa, said Mr. Bush "has sat in my La-z-Boy chair a couple of times" during visits to the farm. Mr. Keppy agreed in April to personally ask the President for the subsidies.
 
Bush on the Line
 "One day the telephone rang and Mrs. Keppy went to the phone," Mr. Keppy said. "And he said, 'Good morning, this is President Bush.' And I wasn't there! So he called back later."
According to Mr. Keppy, his friend seemed to think that the pork subsidies had already been approved. "How do you tell the Commander in Chief that he's wrong?" Mr. Keppy said. "But I did, and he went to work on it and helped us."
Mr. Madigan confirmed that after the telephone conversation the President called him to discuss the subsidies. "I told him I had been trying to persuade the people on the Trade Policy Review Group," Mr. Madigan recalled. "He said, 'Just go ahead and offer it.' So we did."
Mr. Bush declined to comment. However, Mr. Tank of the pork council said Mr. Keppy was the key to reversing the Cabinet committee's decision. "If anyone understood the importance of pork in Iowa, it was George Bush," he said.
 
Trade Sidetracked
 Pork was made eligible for export enhancement subsidies for one year, starting in August 1992.
But the decision did not lead to a thriving subsidized pork trade with the Russians. The attempted coup in August 1992 threw Moscow into disarray. Then, the Russian Government defaulted on loans granted under other American export credit programs. And, in early 1993 Russian officials raised questions about meat inspection practices in the United States.
According to Mr. Tank, American officials failed to respond promptly to the Russians' meat inspection concerns -- a criticism that department officials have denied. In any case, last April the Russians banned American pork products until the inspection issue was settled.
By the time the ban was lifted, in midsummer, the export subsidies were about to expire, Mr. Tank said. A few transactions were reviewed by the Agriculture Department, he added, but were turned down without explanation.
 
Money for Social Aid
 Although no subsidized transactions took place, the Agriculture Department, in response to the industry pressure, bought the 24 million pounds of pork that are now being donated to the Russian Government through the department's Food for Progress program.
Officials in Moscow said the Government's sale of the pork for processing into sausages would generate money for social aid programs.
Stephen Neel, the director of technical services and research at the United States Meat Export Federation, a trade association, conceded that shipping unprocessed hog carcasses was not the best way to show that America's hams and bacon were superior to European products. But he said the federation would try to insure that Russian consumers knew the sausages contained American pork. "We're trying to make the best of the situation," Mr. Neel said.
Even Mr. Keppy conceded that the Russians "aren't quite prepared for large shipments of pork" because of inadequate refrigeration facilities. "But the pork council is trying to work on that," he said.
Undaunted, Mr. Tank said he was trying to get the export subsidies for pork renewed. But history is repeating itself: The Agriculture Department has approved the renewal, but the Trade Policy Review Group has once again objected that the subsidies cost too much and accomplished too little.

HEADLINE: To Sip, Perchance to Steam

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
LIKE a fragrant gulf breeze, the steamy, seductive aroma of freshly ground coffee beans is caressing New York City.
With names like the Coffee Experience, French Roast Cafe, New World Coffee and Seattle Bean Company, these sleek caffeine canteens are introducing -- some might say addicting -- New Yorkers to potent espresso, ristretto (a short super-intense espresso), cappuccino (half coffee, half steamed milk with foam) latte (espresso with steamed milk and a touch of foam), caffe mocha (espresso with steamed chocolate milk), macchiato (espresso with a dollop of milk foam) and more. 
 For all their snazzy decors, impressive displays of coffee beans and hulking steam machines that pack enough power to propel a Toyota station wagon, coffee quality is widely uneven in the cafes. A recent sampling of 15 establishments revealed that it takes more than good equipment and high-quality beans to make a well-balanced espresso or cappuccino.
Espresso bars were strangely late in coming to New York, this most energizing of cities, where for decades citizens have been content with acrid, watery brews served in cardboard cups adorned with Greek motifs. One might think that hyperkinetic New Yorkers need more caffeine about as much as Arnold Schwarzenegger needs more muscles. Nonetheless, they are taking to the new boutique Java like deer to a salt lick.
"We have people come in two, three or more times a day," said Talitha Whidbee, manager of Philip's Coffee on West 56th Street in Manhattan. "We have one man who comes in six times a day." Customers typically start in the morning with espresso or cappuccino, she said, then later in the day move on to drinks with more milk in them, like latte.
The settings of the new coffee bars vary as much as the quality of the brew. Some, like Philip's Coffee and the nearby Jonathan Morr Espresso Bar, on the Avenue of the Americas near 56th Street, are mere slivers of real estate. They are nooks, done in provocative colors with lots of brushed steel, marble and sharp-looking designer lights. At Jonathan Morr, even the trash can is illuminated in ice-blue neon.
Other bars are bigger, with small seating areas in the back, where customers read newspapers, study or just stare into space to the sound of classical music. Eureka Joe, in the Flatiron district, has a spacious back room with white fabric-covered armchairs and sofas; New World Coffee, a much smaller establishment, in Greenwich Village, plays sleepy Gregorian chant -- perhaps in an attempt to counteract the caffeine.
Many of the espresso bars are in the lobbies of office buildings, where they set up aromatic trawlnets to snag arriving workers before they reach the elevator. Usually offered are scones, beignets, muffins, pastries and sandwiches. But don't look for bagels and cream cheese: they don't make it with marble counters and Vivaldi.
With more than two dozen new coffee bars in the city and many more on the way, the European-style coffee house is almost surely more than just a passing fad. Seattle-based Starbucks Coffee, the General Motors of espresso, has 270 coffee bars across the country, with plans to open 125 more next year. The first New York Starbucks is planned for the spring.
All this coffee excitement has energized the once-dominant Chock Full o'Nuts to get back into the act, too. The company, which once had 110 coffee shops and restaurants, mostly in the New York metropolitan area, closed its last outlet in 1983. Its memory is kept alive as a brand of coffee on supermarket shelves. Chock Full o'Nuts plans to open at least five coffee bars in New York City next year, and foresees up to 70 in the future.
"This is a major commitment," said Marvin Haas, the company's vice chairman and chief executive. Mr. Haas attributes the coffee-bar explosion in part to the bad economy. "Espresso, cappuccino and latte are inexpensive treats," he reasoned, things people historically turn to when bigger treats are unattainable.
Lavazza (pronounced la-VAHT-sa), a major coffee brand in Italy, has just opened coffee training centers in New York, Boston and Seattle. Meant both for consumers and for people in the business, they offer classes on coffee beans and the proper use of espresso machines.
For making good coffee, fresh beans are critical, as is the type of grind. Rancid beans yield sour coffee. If the coffee is exceedingly bitter -- a mild bitterness is desirable -- chances are coffee was overextracted, that is, exposed to forced hot water for too long. Other causes could be too fine a grind or a dirty machine.
In hot, humid weather coffee beans sweat oil; in dry weather they contract. The changing conditions require periodic adjustments to the grind. Ms. Whidbee at Philip's Coffee said that on humid summer days she adjusts the grind 10 times or more.
Another variable is the tamp, or the pressure with which coffee is packed into the filter. One quick way to assess the quality of a coffee bar is to observe the workers. A wham-bam, careless attitude is a signal to turn and walk out.
A well-made cappuccino should have equal parts espresso and steamed milk with foam. The foam should be creamy and dense, not full of evanescent bubbles. If the foam is fragile and airy, chances are skim milk was used.
The recent tour of cafes showed that there was not always a correlation between price and quality. The price of a small espresso ranged from $1.25 to $2. The better cafes serve coffee in porcelain cups, which makes a difference; inexplicably, some of the most stylish places -- those that have spent lavishly on decor and equipment -- serve their coffee in cardboard cups.
Many factors enter into the prices charged by coffee bars around town. Aside from overhead, there is the cost of the beans themselves, which can range from about $1.20 to $5 a pound wholesale. So far, at least, New Yorkers aren't balking at paying up to $3 for a trendy new treat.

HEADLINE: A Safety Net for Russian Reform

 BODY:
Russians voted their fears, pain and anger 10 days ago when they turned toward anti-reform demagogues in surprising numbers. The West cannot cure Russia's distemper with the promise that better days are sure to follow if only Moscow will move quickly to a market economy. It must provide aid, and soon, so that Boris Yeltsin's reformers can protect Russia's most vulnerable citizens from the wrenching dislocation of economic reform.
Economic recovery in Russia means shutting down mammoth military, steel and other factories that produce little of value. In time, investment can be redirected into housing and consumer products that Russians crave. But the unemployed, the displaced military and pensioners cannot wait. Only when they are taken care of can President Yeltsin's reform Government survive. 
 The value of this aid cannot be oversold in the way the West originally sold the virtues of rapid reform. This means being honest with ordinary Russians -- as well as American taxpayers, who will be asked to foot the bill -- about the fact that Russia inevitably faces at least several more years of tough times as the price of seven decades wasted under a command economy.
That said, Western aid must flow far faster than it has. So far, the International Monetary Fund has failed to get the job done. President Clinton and other leaders of the industrialized nations must take over from I.M.F. technocrats and prepare a package of aid for delivery when Mr. Clinton meets Mr. Yeltsin next month. In return, Mr. Yeltsin must provide a credible program of economic reform. Binding commitments at the top are needed to help the desperate people on Russia's streets.
The leading industrialized powers had the I.M.F. oversee half of a $28 billion aid package conditioned on Russia's undertaking market reforms. Befitting its traditions, the I.M.F. insisted that reform precede the release of most aid. As a result, the I.M.F. has provided only $1.5 billion. This did little to nourish Russia's pro-Western reformers. The I.M.F. now says it might loosen its preconditions. But that will not be enough.
Mr. Clinton must round up support for a different imperative: Russia's reformers can't win over a fearful population unless they have money before they undertake reform. Reform requires closing down unneeded factories. But in Russia, the factory means more than a job for life. It is a source of housing, food and pensions. That's why fear of failing factories drives Russians to despair -- and reaction.
So Russia's leaders are trying to keep those factories going by printing rubles instead of moving ahead with reform. But that has driven the economy to the brink of hyperinflation. It is this reckless money creation, not the barely begun reforms, that has pummeled Russia's economy. Western aid would help finance a safety net for the unemployed and pensioners with hard currency, eliminating the argument for printing rubles.
In return, Mr. Yeltsin would have to pledge that a credible economic plan would follow. The West need not care how Russia reforms except to insist it move toward markets on a financially feasible path. That means the budget deficit must be closed fast enough to keep inflation in check.
But as Mr. Yeltsin's slowdown of reform shows, the pledge is politically risky since shrinking the deficit means cutting subsidies to factories. The two-way pledge is also risky for Mr. Clinton. He would commit U.S. money on little more than Mr. Yeltsin's promise. But the parliamentary elections make clear that the risk is worth taking. No society has transformed itself without outside help. If the West forces Russia to try, the likely outcome is social turmoil and political reaction.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
