HEADLINE: Wanted: A Cabinet of Taxpayers

 BODY:
Of course, the White House knew it was asking the public and Congress to accept a double standard in nominating Bobby Ray Inman as Secretary of Defense. That's why the public was kept in the dark for four days about what President Clinton has known for weeks.
For seven years Mr. Inman has failed to pay Social Security taxes on his housekeeper's wages. His failure continued throughout a year in which thousands of Americans, alerted by Zoe Baird's experience, voluntarily began payments. 
 Ms. Baird, whose problem was complicated by the fact that she employed an illegal alien and broke a law she would have to enforce, withdrew as the nominee for Attorney General. The issue of taxes for domestic workers also helped derail the nomination of Federal Judge Kimba Wood for the Attorney General's post, even though Ms. Wood broke no law. But the White House thinks it can save its male nominee from being judged as sternly as the two women.
So they have resorted to some transparent tricks. First, in the initial announcement, Mr. Clinton was portrayed as almost desperately needy of a seasoned national security expert who could keep the generals in line. Moreover, by announcing the appointment last Thursday -- without the full facts -- the White House counted on a long weekend of stories aggrandizing Mr. Inman and underscoring the President's yearning for a strong hand at the Pentagon.
Then, once the country had gotten used to the reassuring prospect of Secretary Inman, came the disclosure that Mr. Inman had a small "Baird problem." But this time it's not supposed to be fatal because he told on himself early enough and hired no illegal aliens. The entire production, with its lack of candor and cunning play of the news cycles, bears the stamp of David Gergen, a skilled perfumer of rank public-relations problems.
But the public should not let Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gergen keep slip-sliding along. This is a big country full of talented people. The Cabinet can and ought to be filled with that category of talented people who pay taxes. If it was right to dump Ms. Baird -- and it was -- how can it be right to look the other way for Admiral Inman?
The Zoe Baird affair gave Mr. Inman plenty of time to put his books in order. The White House's explanation for his delay is disingenuous. It says Mr. Inman did not pay his back taxes because he was waiting to see if legislation pending in Congress would relax the $50 per quarter standard, substantially raising the threshold for taxable earnings.
In other words, Mr. Inman was selectively ignoring the law until it changed in his favor. It may be an economical way to do business, but it is not an example of Cabinet-level civic leadership.

HEADLINE: How Tenure Safeguards Academic Freedom

 BODY:
To the Editor:
What you neglect in "Amid Joblessness, the Joys of Tenure" (The Week in Review, Dec. 12) is that abolition of tenure would radically change the character and qualifications of college and university faculties. Young people now typically spend five or six years earning a doctorate in the subject to be taught. Why would they do so if their training could be rendered useless by some administrator who decided that they, having reached age 40, were "dead wood"? 
 Accountants or lawyers who are fired in their 40's or 50's have a decent chance of continuing their professions elsewhere. There are hundreds of thousands of jobs for those occupations. But in the entire New York metropolitan area, there may not be a dozen jobs for a specialist in 18th-century French literature or Aristotelian philosophy. To fire such a person would be like disbarring a lawyer or denying a physician the right to practice medicine.
No one would advise a young person to make such an investment of time and effort without the security of tenure; college faculties would therefore come to be made up of generalists with bachelor's or perhaps master's degrees, people who could move easily back and forth between higher education and business without serious financial loss.
You also imply that academic freedom no longer needs the protection of tenure. You neglect the very real pressures that ethnic, religious and other groups can apply.
My own courses on the history of Christianity have been criticized by the religious right; and were it not for tenure, my university might be tempted to tell me to modify them. And I, a 60-year-old historian who is paid, after 30 years of teaching, about what many beginning lawyers are paid, would probably be frightened enough to do so. The prospect of being unemployed at this stage in my life would make me exceedingly eager to please everyone.
 
JOHN C. MOORE
Prof. of History, Hofstra U.
Hempstead, L.I., Dec. 12, 1993

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Doubtful on Serbian Sanctions

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
In a new assessment, the Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that the economic embargo imposed on Serbia 18 months ago is likely to deteriorate and that the West will probably have to accept the ethnic partitioning of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
In the analysis, the C.I.A. also says that there appears to be "no good and politically viable alternative" to the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, who has been accused in the West of starting the ethnic violence that followed the breakup of the old Yugoslav federation. 
 He is "probably the only Serb leader the West can deal with and the only one capable of delivering a comprehensive solution" to the Bosnian crisis and Serbia's conflict with Croatia, the agency said.
The analysis was completed early this month, before the elections on Sunday in which Mr. Milosevic's party gained seats in the Serbian Parliament.
 
Division of Bosnia
 The Bush and Clinton Administrations have supported an integral Bosnia and Herzegovina, and have backed United Nations economic sanctions against Serbia to punish it for its role in the war in Bosnia. The Serbian Government has supplied the Serbian forces that have taken control of about two-thirds of Bosnia. Croatia, which has seized about 20 percent of the country, has avoided international economic sanctions.
A document drawn from the assessment, called a National Intelligence Estimate, says it will be "difficult or impossible to undo" the large population shifts that resulted when hundreds of thousands of Muslims, Serbs and Croats were driven from their homes in the fighting.
Last week, David Kanin, the C.I.A.'s chief analyst for Yugoslavia, alluded to plans by Serbian and Croatian leaders to annex portions of Bosnia and Herzegovina and to the prospect that Kosovo, an ethnically Albanian province of Serbia, will one day become part of Albania.
"I believe we are moving toward a greater Serbia, a greater Croatia and a greater Albania as result of this war," Mr. Kanin said during a roundtable discussion at the Woodrow Wilson Center, an arm of the Smithsonian Institution here. "The issue is whether to manage it or ignore it."
"We are not trying to manage it," Mr. Kanin said. "We're just ignoring it."
 
Not View of Agency
 Apprised of Mr. Kanin's public remarks, Kent Harrington, the C.I.A. director of public affairs, said: "We encourage our analysts to participate in academic discussions, but when they do they speak as individuals and do not represent intelligence views. Mr. Kanin's remarks were no exception."
Mr. Kanin's view is also contained in the written intelligence estimate, which sees Croatia absorbing parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina and recovering some of Krajina, the area in Croatia that it lost to Serbs in 1991. It sees Serbia acquiring parts of Bosnia now held by Bosnian Serbs and part of Krajina. In addition, it forecasts that Albania might ultimately gain Kosovo and perhaps even some areas of Western Macedonia inhabited by ethnic Albanians.
The intelligence estimate appears to have prompted no reconsideration of United States policy on Bosnia.
"There is no debate on these issues," said a top-ranking State Department official who has read the C.I.A. assessment and who is involved in policymaking on the former Yugoslavia. "Sanctions are not a major policy issue. We don't question the boundaries of Kosovo. We are not in the business of redrawing borders."
 
Breakup of Yugoslavia
 The new assessment is not the first time the Central Intelligence Agency has confronted a gulf between its assessment of the Yugoslav situation and the attitude of Government policy makers. In November 1990, the agency completed an analysis predicting -- accurately -- that the Yugoslav federation would collapse as early as the summer of 1991 and that civil war could ensue. But Bush Administration policymakers chose not to act upon this assessment.
Yugoslavia began to fall apart in June 1991 when Slovenia and Croatia seceded from the federation, and fighting broke out immediately.
In its assessment, the C.I.A. says the sanctions are likely to deteriorate in coming months because Serbia's neighbors are no longer willing to bear the economic sacrifices entailed in enforcing them: severe restrictions on Danube River traffic and the closure of vital rail and road connections between the Middle East and Northern Europe.
Romania, Bulgaria, Greece, Hungary, Macedonia and Ukraine have complained bitterly in recent months to the United Nations that the sanctions are costing them billions of dollars' worth of trade and industrial production. The European Union has proposed easing the sanctions in exchange for territorial concessions by the Bosnian Serbs to the Muslim-led Bosnian Government.
But Administration policymakers remain uniformly in favor of maintaining sanctions on Serbia and Montenegro, its small partner in the truncated Yugoslav federation. Some even wish to tighten the embargo still further, according to officials involved in the policy process.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 22, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
 An article yesterday about intelligence assessments of the military and political situation in Bosnia reported that the C.I.A. had concluded that the economic embargo imposed on Serbia 18 months ago was likely to deteriorate, and that the West would probably have to accept the ethnic partition of Bosnia. It cited several passages from what it described as a formal C.I.A. National Intelligence Estimate to support those generalizations.
After the article appeared, a C.I.A. spokesman said the excerpts obtained by The Times were not from a National Intelligence Estimate, but from a C.I.A. memorandum about a symposium at which divergent views on Bosnia's future were expressed. The Times should have tried to verify that the document represented a C.I.A. conclusion.
A corrective article appears on page A6.

HEADLINE: Times and New York City Reach Final Accord on New Plant

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
The New York Times reached final agreement yesterday with New York City to build a $280 million printing plant in Queens, clearing the way for construction to begin as early as next summer on what would be one of the largest manufacturing centers in the city.
The Times, which opened a major printing plant in Edison, N.J., early in 1992 and had considered moving all of its printing operations out of New York City, will build the Queens printing and distribution plant on 31 acres in the city-owned College Point industrial park just west of the Whitestone Expressway. 
 The city and the state agreed to grant The Times a package of tax incentives, low-cost energy and other benefits worth a total of $29 million over 25 years.
The incentives offered by the city and the state to The Times are larger, in proportion to the number of jobs involved, than comparable incentive packages given recently to other major New York corporations, like Morgan Stanley, Prudential Securities and CBS Inc., city officials said.
 
Capital Investment
 Several recent academic studies have criticized the city and the state for relying excessively on incentives aimed at large companies as a central component of their economic development strategies.
But city officials said they believed that such incentives were necessary to help stem the loss of jobs and companies from New York. They also argued that the higher cost of the agreement with The Times was justified because of the substantial capital investment it plans to make in the new plant and because skilled factory jobs are particularly hard to retain in New York.
"The city places a tremendous value on our manufacturing jobs," said Karen Backus, a senior vice president at the New York City Economic Development Corporation. "The site is extremely tough to build on and these incentives were absolutely critical."
The decision by The Times to build its new printing plant in Queens will provide as much as $115 million in benefits to the city and the state, Ms. Backus said. These benefits include the rent that The Times is to pay for the land, direct and indirect taxes to be paid by the company and its production employees, and other related gains.
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive officer of The New York Times Company, said, "We are particularly pleased to keep New York's largest newspaper manufacturing operation right here where it belongs -- in New York City."
Construction will start only after The Times board of directors gives its approval to the project.
 
Variety of Tax Benefits
 The agreement calls for The Times to receive a variety of tax benefits, including stabilized real-estate taxes valued at $5 million over 25 years, a 12-year tax credit for each relocated job, worth $1.1 million, and a $4.8 million exemption from sales taxes on construction materials. A preliminary agreement was first announced in November 1992.
Lower power costs and money to prepare the site, which is now used as a police evidence lot for automobiles, are also included.
The Times employs about 1,000 people in press and delivery operations for the daily newspaper at its corporate headquarters, at 229 West 43d Street in Manhattan. The printing and distribution operations there will be shifted to College Point, where The Times plans to install advanced high-speed color printing presses. Company officials said they did not know how many people would work at the new plant.
The business and news operations of The Times, which employ about 2,000 people, will remain at the 43d Street headquarters, just west of Times Square.

The Paramount Deal
Paramount Communications' board agreed to merge with QVC Network. The board's acceptance of the $10 billion offer is bitter for Paramount's chairman, Martin S. Davis, who had led his board in rejecting QVC in favor of Viacom. [Page A1.]
The Hollywood buddies of QVC Network's chairman, Barry Diller, said his apparent winning bid for Paramount was further proof that what Barry wants, Barry gets. [D5.] 
 QVC's bid for Paramount is a bet that the big money in TV's 500-channel future will be made the old-fashioned way -- by creating the programming that people want to watch. [D5.]
The start of the siege of Paramount was the April evening that Martin S. Davis dined with Sumner Redstone, Viacom's chief. [D5.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Gives Haiti's Military Rulers a New Deadline

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The United States warned Haiti's military rulers today that it would expand an embargo against the country unless they stepped aside by Jan. 15 and allowed the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to return to power.
The current embargo applies only to oil and arms. American officials said it could be widened to include restrictions on flights to and from Haiti, as well as other commerce that is not considered vital to sustaining the country's population. 
 The Clinton Administration threatened to tighten the sanctions after the leader of Haiti's armed forces, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, refused to meet with military officials from the United States, Canada, France and Venezuela who had flown to Haiti to talk with him today.
"We regret that General Cedras did not take advantage of this opportunity," said David Johnson, a State Department spokesman.
 
Urge Military Urged to Step Down
 The representatives from the four nations had planned to urge General Cedras to step down and to agree to a retraining program for Haiti's security forces so that the country's police and army would not stand in the way of a return to democracy.
After General Cedras failed to meet with them, they distributed the warning to reporters.
In a statement issued jointly with the governments of Canada, France and Venezuela, the United States called on General Cedras to honor an agreement that he signed in July to give up power and allow the return of Father Aristide, who was ousted in a coup in September 1991.
The four nations suggested that the embargo be tightened so that it would be observed not only by members of the Organization of American States but by all members of the United Nations as well.
 
Advice for Aristide
 The four countries, working closely with the United Nations Secretary General, also had some recommendations for Father Aristide, who has been living in exile in Washington since he was deposed. They urged him to step up efforts to build a broad coalition with Haitian lawmakers to open the way for a return to democratic rule.
The four nations also pressed Father Aristide to support a conference that Robert Malval, who is serving as a caretaker Prime Minister after he resigned as Father Aristide's hand-picked head of government, had tried to assemble to foster political reconciliation in Haiti.
Mr. Malval, who was appointed by Father Aristide in August, has criticized the exiled President for refusing to support the conference. Mr. Malval insists that such a meeting is needed so that a broader coalition can be formed to stand up to military pressure.
The four nations said that such a coalition was especially important because no political party has a majority in either chamber of Haiti's Parliament.
 
Aristide Plans Statement
 A public relations firm representing Father Aristide said that it planned to issue a statement on his behalf on Thursday.
The statement from the United States and the other nations warned General Cedras that he was not only violating the accord he signed in July calling for a restoration of democratic rule but was largely to blame for the growing economic deterioration.
The embargo imposed upon Haiti has created immense privation for the population. Clinton Administration officials say they hope that the fuel shortage created by the embargo will squeeze the military rulers so severely that it will force General Cedras and his supporters to relinquish power within a few weeks.
The statement said the military was responsible for arming hostile civilian groups and for preventing the docking of a military mission, which included American soldiers, that the Haitian military had officially accepted to help retrain its forces.
The four nations said the military should do far more to prevent individuals who are not in the police or military from carrying weapons. Armed sympathizers of the military known as attaches have terrorized supporters of Father Aristide.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From an Interview With President Clinton Reviewing the Year

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a year-end interview with President Clinton today by reporters from four news services:
Q. How about all the stories from Little Rock, the state troopers, their allegations? How do you feel about it, and are they true? What can you say? 
 A. Well, obviously it hasn't been a pleasant thing, especially coming here at the holiday season. But we put out a very strong statement about it, and I don't really have anything to add to what has been said in our written statement or what Hillary said yesterday.
Q. Mr. President, there's something new now in the allegations. Now there are allegations that public funds might have been used, public employees to do something that was improper. Are you ready to deny that that happened?
A. The statement covers that. There was an allegation about offering a job, too, and that's the only thing I think I should specifically say because it affects my role as President. We've already put out a statement about it. But I want to reaffirm that, that that absolutely did not happen.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
On Removal of Files
 Q. How about the Whitewater files that were taken from Vince Foster's office? If the investigators want to see those files, will you let them look at them? There's some reason to believe that they want to see them.
A. Of course we'll do what we can to cooperate on that. Now, let me say I don't know what's in that file. But I asked about that when I saw the news stories, and let me say what I understand the circumstances to be just to make sure. (Addresses aides in the room) And if I make a mistake you guys can correct me. But literally I don't know what's in the file and haven't looked at it. But when -- after Vince committed suicide and the authorities, the people came in to investigate, as they should have done, all the files were still in the office. There were no files, it's my understanding, removed or anything like that. But they were broken into three categories. The bulk of them were the files that he was working on which were then obviously distributed to others in the office.
Then he had some personal files which were turned over to his family, his personal lawyer.
Then he had this one, and I don't know that there are any more. But there was this file which related to work he had done before he came to work at the White House on our behalf, which was given to our counselor after the investigation. There was never any indication that anyone wanted to see it.
Obviously if anybody feels that there's some relevance to any ongoing investigation, we'll do what we can to cooperate.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Do you feel there was any wrongdoing?
A. Let me just say this: we have no reason to believe at this time -- I read one of the stories today right before you came in -- I have no reason to believe at this time that anybody thinks there's anything in there relevant to any ongoing Federal matter. But if they do . . .
Q. So you've had the request?
A. No, we've had no request. To the best of my knowledge we haven't. But if anybody wants, thinks that we have some relevant information, then obviously we'll do what we can to cooperate.
I just want to emphasize this: I don't exactly know how this happened. But this Whitewater thing has -- we tried to deal with this back in the campaign. And when I got into this investment, Hillary and I did, it was a time when land values were going up and Arkansas retirees were flooding down there. It looked like a pretty good deal.
What happened was we had a big recession starting in 1980, land values went down, retirees didn't buy so much. And so I never thought much about it when we were clearly losing money and never knew until obviously the accountant closed the books out exactly how much we had lost.
In an attempt to sort of reassure people about this in the campaign we commissioned this independent accounting firm with whom I have never had any contacts or any dealings before or since to try to look at all these, what records we had, to at least ascertain how much money it cost us. Which is about all I thought we were in position to know since we hadn't been involved in running the company, didn't have access to all the records.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
On Highs and Lows
 Q. What have been the highs and lows of your year?
There have been an awful lot of highs this year.
Q. All at the tail end?
A. No, no, not at the . . .
Q, Except for the inauguration.
A: No, no, there were some in the beginning. Appointing Ruth Ginsberg to the Supreme Court happened fairly early. The passage of the budget plan happened early -- happened in August, but happened early by historic standards.
Yes, family medical leave. Yes, that was pretty quick. So there were a lot of highs, you know: the Middle East peace signing, the Nafta victory, the economic plan. There are a lot of highs. The national service day was a big high for me. So there were a lot of things that happened that were highs.
I think the low for me as President, obviously, was when the young men lost their lives in Somalia. That was the low point of the year.
Q. Mrs. Clinton said yesterday that no matter how much you talk to people about it, no matter how much you prepare for the job, that you can never truly be aware of everything that awaits you when you come into the White House. What has been your biggest surprise, what was your biggest surprise in your first year in office?
A. I think my biggest surprise, in a negative sense was -- I shouldn't have been surprised by it -- that coming here from another place and another way of doing things, there really is a Washington culture here that, on the one hand, needs to be changed, but on the other hand, has to be dealt with if you want to get anything done.

HEADLINE: Post Office Considers a 32 Stamp for '95, to Break Even

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Even as Americans jam post offices to finish their holiday mailing, the Postal Service is working on a rate proposal that could raise the cost of a first-class stamp to 32 cents in 1995.
Postal Service officials said today that they needed to raise rates in 1995 for the service to break even, as it is required to do over a period of years. And because of the cumbersome process any increase entails, the service must make its request early in 1994, officials said. 
 Among the plans they are considering is an innovative across-the-board increase of 10.3 percent, which would add three cents to the cost of a first-class letter, the officials said. The idea is supported by businesses that make heaviest use of the mail.
The Postal Board of Governors will discuss the rate increase at a Jan. 3-4 meeting here.
 
No Higher Than Inflation
 "There are several options they are considering, but there is no final decision at this point," said Robert Hoobing, a spokesman for the Postal Service.
Whatever form the rate change takes, Postmaster General Marvin T. Runyon has said that he wanted to keep any rise under 14 percent, a cap that would put maximum first-class postage at 33 cents. The 14 percent figure, Mr. Hoobing said, is the estimated rate of inflation for the four-year period beginning in February 1991, when rates last went up. That increase was four cents, to 29 cents.
It would be the first increase of the first-class rate under Mr. Runyon, who took office in July 1992 with a pledge to break the service's tradition of raising that rate every three years. That tradition began in 1971, when the service was made a quasi-independent agency subject to Congressional oversight.
"There has to be an increase because we haven't had one in four years," said Norma Pace, an economist and a governor on the board of governors. "We have to have a rate increase for 1995 to help us break even."
The Postal Service, which generates revenues of $43 billion a year, is expecting a loss exceeding $1 billion for the fiscal year ending in September, Ms. Pace said.
According to the bureaucratic process that governs rate increases, the board of governors makes a recommendation for an increase, then gives an independent body, the Postal Rate Commission, 10 months to evaluate it.
Traditionally, the service has set different rates for various classes of mail, based on costs and overhead. The uniform 10.3 percent increase is favored by the largest users who think it would level off the impact of the rise and give Postal Service managers a chance to study a restructuring of the various classes of mail.
"It's an option that we especially like," said Arthur B. Sackler, managing director of the Mailers Council, a group of the nation's biggest mailers.
Officials said they were also considering smaller, more frequent increases.
Ms. Pace said the Postal Service still offered the best mail service in the world for its cost. First-class postage, for example, is as much as 25 cents higher in countries like Japan and Germany.
"From the tip of Florida to the uppermost tip of Alaska, it still cost the same 29 cents to send a first class letter," she said. "We're committed to maintaining that universal cost at the same time we've got to be extremely efficient."

HEADLINE: Palace of Toys Finds Profits Elusive

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Neither rain, nor sleet, nor snow nor the depths of recession seems to shorten the queue of people shivering outside the F.A.O. Schwarz flagship store in Manhattan during the holiday season, awaiting a chance to wander through the closest thing to Santa's workshop south of the North Pole.
The "toy" soldier standing at the main entrance salutes to more than 50,000 people each day at this time of year. Many are tourists who include the Schwarz store at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street on their itinerary in the same way they do the Empire State Building or the World Trade Center. 
 But despite its ability to delight and inspire with talking teddy bears, a Barbie boutique and $8,200 miniature gas-powered Mercedes cars, the world's most renowned toy store chain has trouble turning a profit. Sales at the 25 stores have marched steadily forward, more than tripling in the last decade and growing by 40 percent in the last two years alone. But when there were any profits in the last decade, they were small, and materialized only briefly between 1987 and 1989 before giving way again to red ink.
A succession of four owners between the early 1960's and 1986 threw up their hands at ever making money off of Schwarz, which was founded in 1862. The fifth, an investment group that backed Schwarz management in a buyout in 1986, and then sold the company in 1990, said the company turned a profit of as much as 5 percent of sales during its ownership, a figure the few analysts who follow the company question.
The analysts say the company's higher costs of business, including expensive real estate, and its singular quality make it difficult not only to make a profit but also to expand its operations. And in an era when low prices excite shoppers far more than interesting displays and wonderful ambiance, Schwarz must contend with competitors who can and often do undersell it.
"It's the classic problem of how can you have something unique on a mass scale," said Sean McGowan, a toy industry analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company. "There's a certain amount of cachet to having an F.A.O. Schwarz shopping bag draped over your arm, but you destroy that if the enterprise gets too big."
It's a problem many other distinctive retailers have faced, including Barneys New York and Bergdorf Goodman. And Schwarz's sixth owner, the Dutch retailing conglomerate Koninlijke Bijenkorf Beheer, has so far had little better luck than its predecessors in solving the riddle. K.B.B. bought the company for more than $50 million in mid-1990.
A report on K.B.B. issued by Bank Van Haften LaBouchere earlier this year takes the Dutch retailer to task for losses at Schwarz, "which with hindsight should never have been bought, at least not at that time."
Nonetheless, an executive at K.B.B. told analysts last spring that the chain would turn an operating profit this year. And John Eyler, the president and chief executive of Schwarz, said in a recent interview that if the company manages to generate comparable-store sale gains of 10 percent this holiday season, it may eke out a small profit.
The Christmas season makes or breaks the year financially for Schwarz, as it does for almost all toy sellers. But holiday sales for retailers nationwide this year have come in wide swings -- one day strong, the next day weak -- making it difficult to predict how well the chain will do.
"I'll know on Christmas Eve," Mr. Eyler said last week.
Despite his cautious assessment of the holiday season, he was cheery enough to dance a jig that played "Chopsticks" on a Dance-On Piano in the waiting room at the corporate offices. The Dance-On keyboard, played with the feet, was made famous by Tom Hanks in the movie "Big." While the steel-framed version costs a cool $9,500, Schwarz now offers a $42 model that will not exceed the credit limit on most customers' charge cards.
 
A Three-Pronged Attack
 The cheaper Dance-On illustrates one of the strategies that Mr. Eyler and K.B.B. are pursuing to broaden the chain's appeal without damaging its franchise. A veteran of the specialty store business who joined the chain a year and a half ago, Mr. Eyler has started a three-pronged strategy that includes replacing the chain's small stores in shopping malls with larger "mini-flagships," increasing the amount of exclusive and less expensive merchandise, and trying to increase the amount of business Schwarz does outside the holiday season.
He is so confident of the chain's long-term prospects that he predicts that sales, which were about $67 million in 1992, will double by 1996, and says it may open at least six more United States stores and one abroad during that period. "We're in a period of growth and rejuvenation and success that may be a first for the company in a long time," he said.
To produce that kind of growth, he will have to find a way to leap the hurdles Schwarz has faced over the last two decades, say the few analysts and retail consultants who watch the company. While its flagship locations in New York, Chicago, Boston and San Francisco have been successful, Schwarz's other branch stores must begin to contribute to sales and profits. The chain must also counter Toys "R" Us and other toy sellers by offering one-of-a-kind merchandise. And Schwarz must try to build its business over the entire year to alleviate the pressure to produce in the fourth quarter.
Mr. Eyler and analysts agree that the biggest challenge is to find a store format, in addition to its 30,000- to 40,000-square-foot flagship stores, that will generate a profit. The 18 mall-based stores, some as small as 3,000 square feet, have not proved profitable, and more than one previous owner sold Schwarz after deciding that American shoppers would sustain three or four flagship stores but not a chain of smaller locations.
"We really foundered on the issue of format," said one former owner who spoke on condition of anonymity. "People were used to F.A.O. Schwarz in Manhattan, and that was what they expected in Atlanta and St. Louis and Chicago -- not some dinky mall store with pricey toys."
Mr. Eyler agrees: "We always tend to disappoint people who expect to find F.A.O. Schwarz on Fifth Avenue in their local mall."
His antidote? An 11,000-square-foot branch store that duplicates the flagship stores in the classes of merchandise it carries and in the mechanized toys and props used for display. The first mini-flagship opened in Seattle in July, complete with the mechanized clock that sings "Welcome to our world of toys" every seven and a half minutes.
Since then, Schwarz has opened other smaller flagship stores and plans to replace five or six mall stores with the new format in the coming year, he said. The new stores, Mr. Eyler contends, can produce a 15 percent return on investment on the same sales per square foot that it takes to break even in one of the smaller mall stores.
Mr. Eyler said he believed there was room for about 40 Schwarz locations in this country. Some might be smaller kiosk stores in airports, which would sell gift items and increase the company's year-round business. The company also plans to make its debut next year on a television shopping network.
Another hurdle for Schwarz is its costs. Its salaries and benefits alone eat up 18 percent of its revenues, according to Mr. McGowan, the Gerard Klauer Mattison analyst. In contrast, total expenses at Toys "R" Us -- including salaries, utility bills, advertising and rent -- cost 19 percent of its revenues.
The difference in costs means Toys "R" Us can easily undersell Schwarz. Video games that are sold at promotional prices by most toy retailers are always sold at the manufacturer's recommended price at Schwarz, Mr. McGowan said.
But Schwarz also suffers from the perception that it usually charges more for toys. In fact, in its Manhattan store, Schwarz was selling T.V. Teddy, the interactive teddy bear that is popular this holiday season, for $69.99, while the Toys "R" Us Manhattan store was selling the bear for $76.99. Both stores were selling Toby the Terrier, another interactive toy, for $49.99.
Mr. Eyler insists that Schwarz does not really compete with Toys "R" Us, the country's largest toy seller, and his buyers are working to put distance and difference between the two companies by commissioning exclusive merchandise. About one-third of the items carried in its stores today are exclusive to Schwarz, or double the amount when Mr. Eyler arrived.
The company is using its longstanding ties with manufacturers to develop unique merchandise. In the last year, for instance, a buyer fell in love with a puppy dog-shaped sleeping bag made by a small Portuguese manufacturer, who could not afford to buy the cloth to fill such a big order. So Schwarz financed the purchase, and the sleeping bag, which appeared in itscatalogue, sold out.
A $140 yacht for Barbie is available only at Schwarz stores. Steiff, a German maker of stuffed toys, has made a musical bear especially for the company. And Schwarz also boasts the world's biggest box of crayons, 144 different shades compared with Crayola's 128.
Schwarz is using some of those exclusive items to give itself a tier of lower-priced merchandise. "About 75 percent of our merchandise is under $50, but no one wants to talk about that," Mr. Eyler said. "Everyone wants to talk about the $8,200 Mercedes."
The company is also using its ties to Gund Inc., a maker of plush stuffed toys, to increase its year-round business. The two have teamed up in "Bearmail," a gift business featuring stuffed bears ordered through a toll-free number.
Schwarz is also trying to develop other business that is less dependent on the Christmas season, like books and toys for infants. Mr. Eyler said the company's book sales tripled in the last year.

Despite his caution about the results of the Christmas season, he was upbeat about the toy store chain's long-term prospects. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A 'New' Russia: Yeltsin Needs Consensus and Cash

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 22

 BODY:
After the strong vote for the far right and far left, President Boris N. Yeltsin had a serious choice to make about the pace and kind of economic reform. But today, in his first post-election news conference, there was no indication he has made that choice.
His decision to keep Yegor T. Gaidar, a current First Deputy Prime Minister and leader of the reformers, means the probable continuation of a Government so divided that it has been unable to pursue a consistent economic strategy. 
 After two years of on-again, off-again policy that can scarcely be called coherent, many Russian voters rebelled against the instability of this uncharted transition to a market economy.
In response, Mr. Yeltsin spoke of the need to balance the fight against inflation, which is over 15 percent a month and sure to increase, with the need to help the poor.
He also said he would like to provide more social benefits to ease the pain of those who are suffering from the slow transition to a market economy, thus echoing a wish expressed by the Clinton Administration.
 
Who Pays?
 But Mr. Yeltsin did not speak at all about where such money might come from, or about the consistent plea of the reformers and the International Monetary Fund that Russia spend less money on subsidizing otherwise bankrupt and inefficient industries.
In essence, Mr. Yeltsin has followed the usual pattern of the past two years, which is to try to please everyone. And after the harsh message of unhappiness expressed in the elections, the number of constituencies he has to please has increased.
It appears inevitable, from what he said and did not say, that the pace of economic stabilization and structural change, especially for Russia's industrial behemoths, will be significantly slower. The emphasis is likely to be less on stabilization than on production, investment and social welfare.
But the West and the Clinton Administration also have a choice to make, going beyond statements in Washington about finding "less shock and more therapy for the Russian people."
The Administration's talk about the success of its Russia policy has turned quiet, raising doubts about its assumption that the new Russia will be friendly and Western-oriented, and patient with the chaos of economic transformation.
 
Nervous Neighbors
 Now, countries in Central and Eastern Europe are likely to want more than platitudes about security and "Partnerships for Peace," the phrase used by the Administration to bring those nations into NATO without making them full members.
As for Russia itself, Washington may be under pressure to consider a more active engagement -- and an even larger commitment of funds.
For two years, the West has claimed that the success of the Russian transition toward democracy and free markets is the most important task of foreign policy. But the contrast between those stakes and the way support has been provided "has been so sharp," a prominent banker from a multilateral institution said, "as to appear almost contradictory."
Using the International Monetary Fund as their financial agent, the major industrialized nations of the West have set economic criteria for aid that have been very difficult to meet. Russia's failure to control bank credits and subsidies has led the I.M.F. and the West to provide very little aid at all.
And by making the fund the primary vehicle for aid, the industrial nations have washed their hands of serious bilateral commitments and avoided a political commitment to reform.
 
Without a Map
 A senior official of one multilateral agency added: "Nor, in a large sense, has the West given Russia any coherent road map for reform, with specific promises of real aid in steps along the way. It has basically let the I.M.F. do all the talking, junior minister to junior minister."
Western economists also ask whether the I.M.F. is an appropriate agent for the tasks required, which include social welfare, the development of small businesses and investment to convert and strengthen newly privatized enterprises.
Briefing reporters in Washington on Monday, Strobe Talbott, Ambassador at Large for the republics of the former Soviet Union, talked of Washington's new desire for "refining, focusing and intensifying our reform-support efforts," without ever defining what "reform" is.
Is any sort of Russian "reform," short of a reversal to the command economy, good enough for Washington? Is Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin's idea of aggressive investment to protect decaying businesses and empty jobs -- never mind the inflation -- "reform" enough?
But in Washington there have been few officials publicly asking certain questions.
What, for example, is the West's responsibility in Russia? Is the West helping its friends or simply hoping that all will turn out for the best -- in a world of tight domestic budgets where politicians fear being seen to support another country's unemployed?
The problem, one senior banker said, is that the White House seems to think that the Dec. 12 vote means Russians want slower reform, when what they probably want is more stability, less corruption and a tougher fight against crime.
The White House "also seems to buy a tradeoff between economic reform and hardship, which is not clear at all," he said, adding that the hardship from a transition to a market economy is inevitable and that a slower transition may only extend the pain.
If the West wants to pay to assuage the pain, it is likely to cost money. And if the West is going to pay, it might make sense to urge faster reform, not slower.
And if the West is not going to pay to help reform, some in Russia have an answer. Vitaly Tretyakov, editor of Nezavisimayl Gazeta, says the West should stop giving Russians so much advice because, "We've got fools enough of our own."

HEADLINE: Correction: C.I.A. Says Paper On Bosnia Policy Was a Draft

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency said today that a document described in a New York Times article today as embodying the agency's conclusions on the crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina reflected ongoing discussions among analysts and not the settled judgment of the agency.
A C.I.A. spokesman described the document as an unclassified memorandum summarizing various arguments made at a symposium this month by Government intelligence specialists and academic experts on the Balkans. 
 On a copy of the document given to a Times reporter on Monday, the heading and a footnote are obscured and a final page is missing.
A copy of the same document supplied today by Kent Harrington, the C.I.A.'s director of public affairs, bears the heading "National Intelligence Council -- Symposium Notes, 3 December 1993" and a footnote that says in part, "The views expressed in this memorandum do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Intelligence Council or the intelligence community."
 
Suggestions of a Rift
 The Times article said the C.I.A. had concluded that the economic embargo imposed on Serbia 18 months ago was likely to deteriorate and that the West would probably have to accept the ethnic partition of Bosnia. It cited several passages from the symposium notes to support those generalizations.
Both the Bush and the Clinton Administrations have backed United Nations sanctions against Serbia to punish it for its role in the Balkan war and have backed an integral Bosnia. A C.I.A. conclusion to the contrary would therefore open a significant gulf between the agency and the White House, but Mr. Harrington insisted that no such judgment had been reached.
Mr. Harrington said that the National Intelligence Council was currently focusing on Bosnia and that the Dec. 3 symposium was part of that process.
 
The Panel of Analysts
 He said the symposium had been attended by five experts from foundations and universities, a C.I.A. employee, two employees of the Defense Intelligence Agency, a State Department official and three officials of the National Intelligence Council, only one of whom works for the C.I.A.
Government officials said the council had prepared a draft of a new National Intelligence Estimate, based in part on points reflected in the memorandum. Such drafts, the officials cautioned, are subject to revision before final adoption -- sometimes quite substantial revision.
Mr. Harrington noted that at several points, the symposium summary presents conflicting hypotheses and opinions, attributing them to "the majority," "one participant," "some experts" and so on.
The heading on the sixth page of the document, which is missing from the copy originally obtained by The Times, makes the disagreements among the analysts explicit. It reads: "What Kind of Serbia Would Emerge: A Kaleidoscope of Views."

HEADLINE: '95 Budget Projects Drop In Deficit to $190 Billion

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration in February will propose a Federal budget for the next fiscal year that has a deficit "in the vicinity of $190 billion," the White House budget director said today.
The budget chief, Leon E. Panetta, said the Administration had been able to bring the deficit figure down to that level by making "a number of very tough decisions involving cuts across the board," in keeping with a discretionary-spending freeze voted by Congress last summer. 
 Speaking at a news conference, Mr. Panetta said severe cuts, including an Administration plan to phase out operating subsidies for mass transit, had been necessary to pay for increases in programs that President Clinton classifies as "investment." These include spending for the broad anticrime bill that is expected to win final Congressional approval early next year, health research, child immunization, job training, clean-water enforcement, Head Start, national service and education.
 
Pentagon Dispute Settled
 The deficit projection that Mr. Panetta offered today for the next fiscal year, which will begin Oct. 1, is about $60 billion below the White House's estimate for the current year. It is also below the $200.4 billion that was projected only three months ago as next year's deficit. An Administration official said today that the difference was attributable to improved economic assumptions.
Mr. Panetta also reported that the White House's dispute with the Defense Department over the Pentagon's budget had been resolved. He said the military had been allocated an additional $8 billion to $9 billion to cover the cost of pay increases voted by Congress last year.
But, he said, the remainder of the "shortfall" that the military had complained about will not be provided. That sum, $21 billion to $22 billion, would have covered the costs of inflation over five years. When Congress voted to freeze discretionary spending at $540 billion in the budget reconciliation bill last summer, it did not provide for increases due to inflation.
 
Furor on Mass Transit
 After the White House submits the new budget to Congress, the lawmakers will be able to increase the Administration's spending on some programs by imposing equivalent cuts in others. Members of the House from the New York metropolitan area were already at their fax machines today, sending out attacks on the Administration's plan to phase out $800 million in annual mass transit operating subsidies, of which the New York area now receives about $100 million.
Representatives Charles E. Schumer, Jerrold Nadler, Nita M. Lowey and Jose E. Serrano all contended that the phaseout could lead to higher fares. Although it was not clear how quickly the subsidies would be eliminated under the Administration's proposal, Mr. Schumer and Mr. Nadler estimated that the provision would ultimately mean an increase of 10 cents for a ride on the subway or a city bus.
In an interview with radio reporters today, the President, in a more general way, made the same points that Mr. Panetta did.
"This budget will first of all reduce the deficit in fiscal year '95 to below $200 billion," Mr. Clinton said.
"When I became President, it was estimated that the budget deficit would be $300 billion in fiscal year '95," he said. "This is, I think, quite an important achievement. We will do it by reducing funding in 9 of 14 major agencies below the fiscal year '94 levels. We will meet our 100,000-employee personnel reduction by the end of fiscal year '95."
 
Few Figures From Panetta
 Except for the deficit figure, Mr. Panetta declined to give any numbers related to the new budget, including its total size. The reason, he said, is that the basic decisions made by the President now have to be translated "into what are literally hundreds of thousands of numbers that feed into our budget."
But he said hundreds of programs would be cut below their current levels and that spending on hundreds of others would be frozen.
Mr. Panetta said Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, had succeeded in getting more money for projects to aid the homeless. Mr. Cisneros had sought a doubling of the current $800 million, but Mr. Panetta said, "It will not be as much as the Secretary wanted."
Mr. Panetta said the Administration's ability to hold the deficit as low as $190 billion was a result of "the strong deficit-reduction policies that have been enacted, plus the economic progress that's obviously been made in 1993."
"We feel that the President is, in fact, staying on track with the economic plan that we set in place last year," the budget chief said . "We are continuing our commitments to fiscal discipline and to deficit reduction, as well as to the initiatives that the President feels are most important to the future."

HEADLINE: New Governor Named For the Bank of Canada

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 22

 BODY:
John Crow, whose Draconian anti-inflation policies have made him a political target in a period of double-digit Canadian unemployment, is stepping down as the governor of Canada's central bank, the Government announced today.
But he is to be replaced by his deputy, Gordon Thiessen, a longtime Bank of Canada employee, who is expected to keep the same emphasis on price stability. 
 The announcement by Finance Minister Paul Martin ended one of the biggest guessing games here since the election of the Liberal Government nearly two months ago.
Mr. Crow's policies had been attacked by many Liberals, including the new Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, whose campaign slogan was "jobs, jobs, jobs." But until now the Government had ducked the issue of whether he would be reappointed when his seven-year term expired next month.
 
Policy Called 'Misguided'
 Bankers had argued that Mr. Crow was essential to maintain the country's financial credibility abroad and prevent a collapse of the Canadian dollar. Yet many on the left wanted to dump him. A recently formed "Crow To Go" coalition called the policy of fighting inflation with high interest rates "misguided and destructive."
Jeff Rubin, the chief economist at Wood Gundy Inc., a leading brokerage firm, said Mr. Crow "became a sacrificial lamb."
The change in the guard did not fluster the markets. The Canadian dollar, after touching a six-year low, rebounded immediately after the announcement and closed against the American dollar at 74.82 cents, up 0.43 cent.
"The market is taking it as a very positive sign that the new governor is someone so closely identified with the present policies," said Katherine Beattie, an economist at MMS International, a financial information service.
Edward Neufeld, executive vice president and chief economist at the Royal Bank, said he expected a "smooth transition" and little political trouble for Mr. Thiessen.
 
Inflation Less Than 2 Percent
 "The new governor is in the fortunate position of not having to drive the inflation rate down any further," he said.
At less than 2 percent, Canada's inflation is about a point lower than that of the United States. But its unemployment, at more than 11 percent, is almost double that of the United States.
Mr. Crow's tenure recalled a period of the early 1980's when the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, throttled inflation in the United States. Yet Mr. Volcker's efforts did not rouse the same political passions as Mr. Crow's did in Canada, possibly because the austerity in the United States was followed by a strong expanson that created millions of jobs. Canada's growth has not made a dent in the jobless rate.
Like the man he is succeeding, Mr. Thiessen started at the Bank of Canada on the research staff. Although the two men are roughly the same age -- Mr. Thiessen is 55, and Mr. Crow, 56 -- Mr. Thiessen joined the bank 10 years earler, in 1963. In the 60's Mr. Crow held senior staff positions with the International Monetary Fund in Washington.
Mr. Thiessen, whose appointment is effective Feb. 1, becomes the sixth governor and will earn an initial salary of $224,000 Canadian ($168,000).

HEADLINE: Company Reimbursing Excess Fees For Water

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
A private water company on Long Island that has been the target of consumer protests and government lawsuits agreed yesterday to make $11.7 million in payments to settle pending litigation and state penalties.
Of that amount, $7.1 million will go to customers in Nassau County in the form of credits averaging $260 per household over three years. The other $4.6 million will go to the City of New York, partly to pay back sewer taxes. 
 The company, the Jamaica Water Supply Company, has customers in Queens and western Nassau. As part of the settlement, it also agreed to freeze its rates at their current level for three years and to submit to a tough system of official oversight and financial penalties if its performance and service do not continue to improve.
While customers and government officials hailed the agreement, workers for the company objected. A union representing about half the company's 500 employees said it would meet today to consider calling a strike.
 
Agreement Called Historic
 Danny Frank, a spokesman for the union, Local 374 of the Utility Workers of America, said the agreement is "balanced on the backs of company workers."
Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board, called the agreement historic.
"After years of controversy and poor service quality, Jamaica Water customers finally have a fair deal," he said. "Up to now, they have been forced to pay twice or three times what customers of municipal water utilities pay."
The agreement was signed by the company and a number of public agencies, including the State Public Service Commission, the State Consumer Protection Board, the State Attorney General, the Nassau County Executive, the New York City Department of Environmental Protection, and Waterbill Watchdogs, an organization of Nassau County homeowners who have been protesting their water bills for years.
Raymond Howell, the president of Waterbill Watchdogs, said his group welcomed the agreement. "We are pleased with the new management team at Jamaica Water and how they have been responsive to the needs of their customers."
 
Higher Water Bills
 The Watchdogs organization says Jamaica Water Supply charges some of its customers in Nassau about $900 a year, or about three times what other consumers pay for water supplied by municipal utilities in the county. In contrast, the organization said the average bill for Queens homeowners was about $200 a year.
Jamaica's president, Hampton D. Graham, disputed the Watchdog's $900 figure, saying the company's average water bill in Nassau, based on using about 100,000 gallons a year, was $450.
Mr. Graham said the wide discrepancies between Jamaica's bills in Nassau and those of municipal utilities in Nassau and its customers in Queens resulted from the fact that the company was taxed by Nassau County on its property in the county, while municipal utilities and the company's property in New York City is not taxed.
All told, the company said it served 650,000 people in 30,000 homes in southwestern Nassau and 90,000 homes in areas of Queens, including Hollis, Jamaica and Jamaica Estates, Kew Gardens, Laurelton, Queens Village, Richmond, Rosedale and St. Albans.
While Nassau customers will get credits toward their bills, Queens customers will not receive any direct benefit, officials said, because their lower bills are already effectively subsidized by New York City because it does not tax the company.
 
Racketeering Suit Ends
 In 1989, the city filed a petition in State Supreme Court to acquire the company's property in Queens by eminent domain. But the petition was dismissed this year.
A joint statement by the company, the State Consumer Protection Board and the Public Service Commission said the agreement provides for a tentative settlement of $10.6 million in economic penalties recommended at a commission proceeding in 1992.

HEADLINE: 3d-Quarter Output Revised Upward to 2.9%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Vigorous consumer spending and booming new-car business quickened the pace of economic recovery this fall, the Commerce Department said today, adding momentum for a strong final quarter bolstered by rising Christmas sales.
In its final estimate of national output during the three months from July through September, the department said gross domestic product expanded at a 2.9 percent annual rate instead of 2.7 percent as previously estimated. 
 It also said inflation was restrained in the third quarter, with the implicit price deflator rising at a 1.6 percent rate, the same as previously estimated, and the G.D.P. fixed-weight index up only 2.1 percent instead of 2.2 percent.
 
Good for Holding Rates
 The steady inflation rate may allay concern over a pre-emptive Federal Reserve move early in 1994 to quash any inflation risk by pushing interest rates up. The Clinton Administration is arguing against any such move, contending there is no evidence that prices or wages are rising sharply.
With consumer spending continuing strong, many economists are forecasting fourth-quarter growth exceeding 4 percent before tapering to a slower rate in 1994.
"Right now consumers are in a buying mood and they've been willing to open their wallets to do it," said an economist, Sung Won Sohn of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, warning that rising debt loads might soon put a brake on spending.
"It's quite possible that in the first quarter of 1994, we'll see consumers start holding back on purchases of big-ticket items," said Mr. Sohn, who foresees G.D.P. growing at a 2.5 percent to 3 percent rate in the first half.
But 1993 will end on a strong note. Factories cranked up car assemblies in response to strong sales of new cars and light trucks. A Johnson Redbook Survey of retail shopping on Tuesday showed sales up 7.1 percent in the first three weeks of December from last year's level.
 
Farm Output Rebound
In addition, Commerce officials predicted an increase of four-tenths of a percent in fourth-quarter growth from a rebound in agricultural output. Devastating Midwest floods and drought in the Southeast had slashed third-quarter growth by about six-tenths of a percent by destroying crops.
The economy gained power steadily in 1993, advancing from anemic annual increases of eight-tenths of a percent in the first quarter and 1.9 percent in the second quarter as momentum built.
The key reason for the slight upward increase to 2.9 percent in third-quarter growth was that businesses added about $2.7 billion more goods to inventories than previously estimated. Even though the goods were unsold, they count as more production that pushes up quarterly G.D.P.
The Commerce Department also said today that corporate profits after taxes grew by only seven-tenths of a percent in the third quarter to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $274.3 billion after a much stronger 5.2 percent increase in the second quarter.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Rallies on Output News; Soybeans Up, Cattle Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Crude oil futures prices rallied strongly from five-year lows on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on news that six Persian Gulf states were willing to cut production if non-OPEC producers would do the same.
Analysts said that while an effective effort to cut output was unlikely, even the remote possibility was enough to set off buying in the depressed crude market. 
 On other commodity markets, soybean futures rose sharply, leading most grain futures higher, and livestock futures were mixed.
Light sweet crude oil for February delivery rose 41 cents, to $14.77 a barrel; January home-heating oil surged 0.66 cent, to 44.02 cents a gallon; January unleaded gasoline rose 0.03 cent, to 39.41 cents a gallon; January natural gas rose 2 cents, to $2.022 for 1,000 cubic feet.
It was the strongest advance since Sept. 10 for crude oil, which had slid to a five-year low following the refusal on Nov. 24 by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut production.
The Gulf Cooperation Council, an OPEC subgroup composed of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Bahrain and Oman, said yesterday that it would reduce production if other producers around the world pledged to do the same.
 
Analyst Skeptical
 But one analyst, Tom Bentz, director of the energy division for Quantum Financial Services in New York, noted that two major non-OPEC producers, Norway and Britain, had already said that they would not cut production.
"I'm not sure they are saying anything that is any different from what's out there right now anyway," he said of the gulf group.
Oil prices also drew support from a weekly American Petroleum Institute report on Tuesday that showed a drop in domestic crude stocks, and from reports this week of oil rig problems in the North Sea.
Soybean futures surged to a four-and-a-half-month high on the Chicago Board of Trade after a Government report showed stronger demand for soy products than traders expected.
The soybean rally helped push near-term corn deliveries briefly above $3 a bushel for the first time since July 2, 1990.
Cattle futures ended mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange but hog futures fell on ideas that cash hog prices will remain weak for the rest of the week.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in Steep Drop Linked To Comments by Bentsen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended sharply lower against most currencies in slow trading yesterday, under pressure from lower domestic interest rates and comments by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen.
Gold prices also declined worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for February delivery, the most active futures contract, settled at $387.20 an ounce, off $2.10 from Tuesday. 
 The dollar had climbed to a seven-month high against the Japanese yen in overnight trading in Tokyo after comments Tuesday by Mr. Bentsen indicating he did not see a need for the United States to intervene in currency markets to support the yen. Traders interpreted his comments as a sign that they could buy dollars.
But as the dollar climbed, Mr. Bentsen released a statement yesterday expressing concern that Japan had not met its commitment in reducing its trade surplus and stimulating its economy. That sent the dollar plummeting on the notion that the Federal Reserve might be willing to buy yen to support it.
"It's not necessarily true, but that's the market's knee-jerk reaction," said Andrew Busch, a trader with the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 111.30 yen, up 0.55 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 110.50 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 110.40 yen, down from 111.18 on Tuesday.
Dealers also said lower interest rates were putting pressure on the dollar. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond fell to 6.21 percent, from 6.31 percent Tuesday.
Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable, thereby lessening investors' need for the American currency.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4946, from $1.4880 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.4968 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.4880.
Separately, there were rumors that the Bank of Canada had entered the market to buy Canadian dollars at the expense of the American dollar. "The Canadian dollar was down sharply, but it ended up closing sharply" off those lows, said Michael Malepede, an analyst with Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
If scalpers can get so much, why aren't tickets costlier?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
BARNEY, idol of the Oshkosh B'Gosh set, is coming to Radio City Music Hall in March. But unless you are prescient -- or very rich or very indulgent -- the tike in your life is going to miss the chance to see the purple dinosaur in the polyester.
Tickets for all 11 shows sold out in two hours. The only way to get them now is through brokers who are selling $30-list seats for as much as $200 -- a fact that has raised the dander of New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs, which will be trying to collect fines under New York State's anti-scalping law. 
 No doubt the slowly unfolding Barney affair will keep grandparents at high dudgeon for weeks. But Richard Thaler, an economist at Cornell University, thinks the furor over ticket scalping obscures a far more interesting quirk in capitalism: If the seats could have been sold for more than $30, why didn't Radio City charge more than $30? More generally, why are legitimate sellers -- everyone from the producers of hit Broadway plays to the owners of this month's chic restaurant -- so often reluctant to use prices to ration scarce supply?
A cynic might look to the darker side of human nature for the answer: Keeping prices below the figure that matches demand with supply creates opportunities for box office employees, headwaiters and the like to make a dishonest living by marking up the scarce space on their own. But Gary Becker, the Nobel Prize-winning economist from the University of Chicago, points out that this hardly explains why their bosses put up with it, or why rationing by price is traditional practice in some industries (steel, airline tickets, soybeans) and almost unheard of in others.
Mr. Becker thinks that success begets success -- and that good entrepreneurs recognize it. Steel is steel and airline seats are airline seats; you generally know what you are getting from the price or the description in the catalogue. But the quality of a book, movie or Caribbean resort is a matter of judgment, he notes, and one way to judge it is by its popularity with others. Thus the line outside a new restaurant or a two-month delay for tickets to "Angels in America" may certify the product as worth buying.
Put it another way: If the restaurant moves swiftly to eliminate the line by doubling the price of the entrees, the absence of a wait may reduce profits along with the demand for reservations. Indeed, its popularity may prove to be very sensitive to menu prices over time, as empty tables beget more empty tables. Mr. Becker thinks this helps to explain why the demand for entertainment in general is apparently so fickle, and so hard to forecast.
But Mr. Thaler is unconvinced. Year in, year out, he notes, the Super Bowl is a sellout. Yet there is surely no risk that higher ticket prices would prevent the stadium from being filled, or reduce the value of television ad time to makers of beer, socket wrenches and other guy things. Far from it: reports of the $1,000 prices charged by Super Bowl ticket scalpers have become a routine part of the hype.
Why, then, the relatively low prices for Super Bowl tickets, or for that matter, third row-center orchestra seats for hit shows on Broadway? Gerald Schoenfeld, the head of the Shubert Organization, which owns a dozen theaters and produces plays, offers a clue: "There's a strong public relations argument" against raising prices when costs remain unchanged, he laments. "We are often told that Broadway ticket prices are too high," and are loath "to add fuel to the fire."
Mr. Thaler agrees, though he puts it somewhat differently. Those with businesses cannot afford the "perception of unfairness," he argues. Hence Broadway producers hold the line on ticket prices even when they have a blockbuster on their hands, and ski resorts charge only a modest premium in high season. "If you gouge skiers at Christmas," he says, "they won't come back in March."
By contrast, Mr. Thaler suggests, a championship boxing match is a one-time event that generates no good or bad will to help or haunt the promoter. Thus ringside seats can and are priced at astronomical sums.
All this may explain why some prices aren't raised rapidly in the face of scarcity. But it doesn't entirely explain why, say, theater owners would care enough about scalping to press the government to make it illegal, and then lobby for tough enforcement.
One possibility is that the objection to scalping is itself a public relations ritual, used to make clear to potential buyers that the initial sellers are not callous profiteers and are not benefiting from the higher prices in the resale market. Or it may be that they simply share the outrage of the public.
Americans, it seems, may be happy to argue in the abstract that free markets are better than the alternatives. But their enthusiasm for the real thing turns on a far more complex calculus of right and wrong.
