HEADLINE: The Crafts of America Find Recognition at the Top

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TWENTY years ago, Leon and Sharon Niehues were part of a back-to-the-land movement. After they left Kansas for the Ozarks of Arkansas, he worked all day, splitting trees at local sawmills, and at nights and on weekends they taught themselves from a book to make baskets. Not just ordinary baskets, but lacy, double-walled, two-toned, witty affairs that have been exhibited in museums and galleries from Portland, Me., to Tokyo, and command prices sometimes in the four figures.
The Niehues are among the many crafts artisans now giving ancient technology some modern twists and developing new methods to produce crafts with heightened appeal to the eye and the touch. 
 "The field has grown from a handful of well-known individuals to large numbers of practicing craftsmen, many with a great sense of sophistication and commitment," said Michael Monroe, the curator of 20th century crafts at the Renwick Gallery of the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of American Art. "Twenty years ago there was one magazine, Craft Horizons, serving all the media. Today there are 10 or more, specializing in glass, ceramics, metal, fiber and wood."
This expansion has also been seen in the growth of crafts collections at museums, the proliferation of craft fairs, from a handful to hundreds each year, and since 1973, the tripling of the number of art galleries that show crafts.
"And the boom has not weakened but strengthened the vision of craftsmen," Mr. Monroe said. "They are increasingly adventurous in exploring technology and everything about crafts."
Perhaps nothing has brought as much attention to the field as the first exhibition of contemporary crafts at the White House, which showcases some of the best and brightest objects made today by Americans, with dazzling displays that have transformed tabletops, mantels and window sills.
Hailed by professionals and viewed by many as an unofficial endorsement of the field, the show includes works of glass, wood, fiber, ceramic and metal by studio-trained and self-educated artists.
Several hundred thousand artisans in America now make a full-time living at their crafts, signaling a flourishing of the field, which was unimaginable 30 years ago. The objects shown at the White House reflect most of the major trends in the crafts of the 1990's: the lavish gilding, hand forming even of glass vessels, layered constructions, exotic surfaces and technological innovations that are helping to distinguish and popularize crafts across the country.
The White House show came just in time to catch the end of the Year of American Craft, which was proclaimed a year ago today, when President George Bush signed a bill passed by Congress.
While the observance spurred scores of fairs and symposiums for craft artists, the general public remained largely unaware of the celebration until the Christmas decorations were completed at the White House on Dec. 6, and the doors were flung wide for public viewing. Tickets are available daily at the East Gate, beginning at 8 A.M. By Jan. 1, the day crafts displays are dismantled, about 150,000 visitors will have filed through the 12 hallways and rooms.
"Some trees are hung four deep in angels," said Hillary Rodham Clinton. She added that she was astonished at the ornaments produced by 3,000 artisans across the country. Even more important are the objects of 65 craftsmen, both prominent professionals and less-known artisans, who were invited to contribute bowls, baskets and other table-top-size items to the White House collection.
"This is the icing on the cake rather than the cake," said Harvey Littleton, the dean of American glass craftsmen. "It implies recognition. I hope we can circulate these crafts so that there will be a wider public acceptance and a firmer footing nationally for crafts."
Mrs. Clinton said she chose crafts as the theme of the White House Christmas decor "partly because of my own personal interest in American crafts -- we have a very small collection of mostly pottery." Mr. Littleton said that the traveling exhibition that Mrs. Clinton envisions would have been as unthinkable 30 years ago as the exhibition of crafts at the White House. In fact, in the 1960's when he began producing art glass, very few of his colleagues made a living at crafts.
Three decades ago, glass makers, weavers and ceramists took it for granted that they would supplement their incomes with other work -- mostly by teaching. And they became full-time craftsmen only in the 1970's or 1980's, said Mr. Monroe, who was the adviser to the White House on its exhibition.
While the public became aware of the Year of American Craft only after the White House show, Anne (Susie) Gray, the originator of the concept, who helped lobby the bill through Congress, is not displeased. Mrs. Gray, a New Hampshire craftsman who founded the Smithsonian Crafts Fair in Washington, said: "We purposely aimed our thrust of activities at the grass-roots level. That's where there is a strong creative energy. Without the input of regional crafts, artists become so involved in esthetics, they begin to lose all connection in their work to people."
Suffice it to say that most of the master craftsmen are represented, including Wendell Castle, who sent a laminated wood clock, and Joel Philip Myers, whose round glass vase depicting red and purple poppies glows in the morning light on a window sill. Joan Mondale, who filled the Vice-Presidential mansion with crafts in the late 1970's, sent one of her small pots embellished with calligraphy.
The most enterprising artisans today prove how far crafts have come from the days when it meant only rudimentary wind chimes and macrame. Toots Zynsky, an American now living in Paris, creates bowls with fused glass fibers that imitate fabric -- and you can feel the threads.
Laney K. Oxman, a Virginia potter, combines decals, paint and 24-carat gold to achieve the images of nostalgia she devises on her multi-fired pedestal bowls.
Craft skills and the taste for the same media are inherited in some families, judging by the works of three fathers and sons whose work is represented at the White House.
Mr. Littleton sent to the White House three trumpet-like blue orchids from his North Carolina studio. his son John and his wife, Kate Vogel, also of North Carolina, produced the show's most amusing tromp l'oeil sculpture -- a stack of blown-glass sacks, satiny in texture, with colors to match: blue, green, purple and red. The craftsmen in the two other families -- Melvin and Mark Lindquist of Florida and Edward and Philip Moulthrop of Georgia -- are wood-turners.
While innovative glass dominates the White House displays, as it does museum shows and craft fairs, some of the most decorative crafts today are ceramics. And among the masters is Bennett Bean, a potter for 30 years who began in the late 1980's to add gesso and gold leaf to his vessels. And he didn't stop there, emblazoning the one at the White House with gilding, an American flag and lots of patterning.
"I don't see that the White House exhibition will change the world," Mr. Bean said. "But I'd love it if what the Clintons have started will do for crafts what Jackie Kennedy did for an awareness of decor."
Mrs. Clinton agreed. "I'd love it, too," she said. "As we find ourselves buffeted about in today's world, handicraft takes on more meaning. Besides, I view crafts as an essential economic activity. There may be thousands of people making a living at crafts today. It's a real growth industry."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Crime and Black Images in TV News

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"Viewpoint," the useful ABC program that gives critics of television news a chance to confront its perpetrators, recently devoted 90 minutes to "Crime, Violence and TV News." Although more was bitten off than could be chewed, troubling questions were raised about the evening's hottest issue, the coverage of crimes committed by young black men.
Jeff Greenfield's scene-setting and Ted Koppel's questions were well aimed, and the criticism by the black panelists -- among them the writer Ishmael Reed; the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, a prominent New York City minister; Fred Thomas, the Washington chief of police; Representative Walter R. Tucker 3d, a Democrat from Los Angeles, and several journalists -- was unsparing. 
Here, in sum, is the charge:
*Crime stories, staples of local-news programs, lack context. In the competition to be first with live reports on death and other carnage, these programs often deliver pictures of the consequences of violence before many of the facts are in. Mr. Greenfield quoted the news producer's adage: "If it bleeds, it leads."
*As a reflection of a skewed justice system, white criminals are treated more gently on the tube than black criminals, and not enough attention is paid to ordinary, law-abiding black families. There is a paucity of positive stories about black life to counter the steady stream of blood and bullets.
*Too few black programmers hold decision-making jobs in television.
The problem is more serious than some of the complaints. Whatever the deficiencies of the police and the courts, for television purposes white crime is just as welcome as black crime. Amy Fisher, Joel Rifkin, Leona Helmsley, the Los Angeles police officers who beat Rodney G. King and many others have received hours of unflattering tube time. Local television news, after all, is an offspring of tabloid newspapers, and they have always doted on villains, race no object.
Still, the suspects seen on television being arrested in muggings and shootings are almost always black men in their teens and 20's, and they figure hugely in the prevailing anxiety, among blacks as well as whites, over personal safety. Nobody is afraid of Leona Helmsley. Mr. Reed's call for more stories about cocaine use in white, middle-class suburbs is simply a distraction.
The rules of journalism require that violent crimes be covered, but it is the rules of the tabloids that require them to be covered prominently, frequently and graphically. The crime of the local-news shows is not that they treat whites better or don't report enough positive stories about blacks. (There are plenty of those, although the doings of hard-working, honest citizens, of whatever shade, have never sold newspapers). It is that their thirst for blood is unslak able. If a fresh murder is not available, a nasty accident will serve. You don't have to be black to be distressed by the result or concerned about its impact.
Some nights, the attention given to crimes of violence turns reality into the surreal. No positive stories can compete with the recurrent images of shackled black youths. Add to this the near-hysterical language of the television reporters, whose vocabularies are not by and large extensive (what would they do without the words "tragic" and "shocking" and "brutal"?), and daily life becomes a theater of horror. (Network news, too, has been focusing more on crime lately, but in a less Gothic mood.)
Such has always been the stuff of the tabloids, on the principle that the higher the anxiety level, the better for business. Mr. Greenfield's call for more reporting about the suffering and pain caused by inner-city violence to complement or replace the pictures of corpses is just an invitation to another, softer sort of tabloid ism, which in fact is by no means neglected by local-news shows. Unfortunately, that may be as much as one can hope for, but it only reinforces the identification of blacks with crime, whether as victims or criminals.
If, Mr. Butts desires, there were more blacks running news departments, there would presumably be more sensitivity to the messages being sent forth. But black executives, too, would be under the pressure of ratings, and in that competition, instant crime in the form of punchy pictures that tell strong, simple stories is premium merchandise.
Surveys reported on "Viewpoint" indicate that most Americans think there is too much violence on the tube. That may be what they tell survey takers, and they can also tell it to the marines. The men and women who run local stations know better. The success of the bloody-minded so-called reality-based shows and the proliferating news magazines, whose stock in trade is crime, is a more convincing measure.
My impression as a constant viewer is that the reporters, news directors and even executives at most local stations, at least in New York City, have been making an effort to present positive stories about black families and to give more time to other aspects of city life than bloodshed. The black anchors and reporters themselves are admirable role models. So the programs seem to be improving, at least around the edges, but the content is still chronically tilted toward mayhem.
Exactly what effects this grisly diet (which is peculiarly garnished with lighthearted chitchat like watercress on raw hamburger) has on its audiences remains unclear, but even its practitioners do not contend it can be wholesome. Yet how much can even the best-intentioned of them do about it, tempted as they must be by the technical wonders of the medium and constrained by its economic imperatives?
Their line of work, which features fast, easy, cheap, on-the-spot grabbers, does not allow for much background or interpretation, and the competition to keep viewers tuned to their channels works strongly against anything that strains the mind. News directors feed their audience sweetened sensationalism because nutritious fare can be risky.
That observation is not offered as an excuse for surrender, just as a fact of existence in commercial television. More power, then, to programs like "Viewpoint" for at least drawing attention to the ailment and compelling some of the professionals to explain what they think they are up to. The success of Mr. Koppel's "Nightline" indicates that there is an audience for something different. Things do change, and disgusted viewers must take what hope they can from the change in public taste since crowds were drawn to reality-based entertainment in the form of hangings and beheadings.

HEADLINE: ON THE WAY HOME WITH: Diane Von Furstenberg;
Always Room For Old Beaus

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
THE dark green Jaguar was on its weekend run from Fifth Avenue in Manhattan to the hills of Litchfield County. Behind the wheel, a woman with major cheekbones and a quirky European accent was talking about "Christmas in Connecticut."
Not the 1940's movie in which a magazine writer (Barbara Stanwyck) and a war hero (Dennis Morgan) find love under the mistletoe -- not that celluloid chestnut. 
 No, this was a real-life "Christmas in Connecticut" for the 90's, in which a fashion designer who used to be a princess (Diane Von Furstenberg) becomes the queen of the QVC home-shopping channel. She celebrates the holiday by decking the halls of her country estate with evergreen swags and old beaus. "If you've loved somebody," she said, "they always remain part of your life."
The ranking old beau (Barry Diller) is an entertainment mogul. (As the chairman of QVC, he's trying to take over Paramount Communications, and she has a piece of the action. But that's another movie.)
Also spending Christmas on the designer's 100-acre spread, Cloudwalk Farm, will be her former husband, the prince (Egon Von Furstenberg). She refers to him as "my first husband," though she has been married only once. She describes their children (Alexandre, 23, and Tatiana, 22) as "my best patterns."
Alex, as he is known, works for Allen & Company, a financial-services firm; his sister is an editorial intern at The Daily News. The paper's publisher (Mortimer Zuckerman) is another old beau.
"Before I go on, I want to ask you something," Diane Von Furstenberg said, barely touching the wheel of the Jaguar. "Do you like Mexican fast food?"
"Love it."
"You're sure? You see, I usually stop where they have the best burritos, but . . ."
"Take me there."
Ms. Von Furstenberg seemed a bit overdressed for burritos. She was done up in beige and black with several strips of silky cashmere looped around her throat. "It's called pashmina," she said. "Spell it? I don't spell it, I wear it. Pashmina. It's from those few little hairs under the animal's chin, but only goats in certain regions and only on certain mountains."
She looked splendid. On New Year's Eve, she will turn 47. She has certainly had a long run, as these things go, probably because of this itch she gets every few years to reinvent herself.
Right now, the thing is selling her silk sportswear on QVC and posing on the sofa with Mr. Diller in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria as the photographer Annie Leibovitz snaps them for Vanity Fair's "1993 Hall of Fame." (Ms. Von Furstenberg is a contributing editor of the magazine.)
In its December issue, Vanity Fair calls the Diller-Von Furstenberg team "a power couple that have doubled their power," noting that "together they stroll hand in hand down the information superhighway."
At the moment, it was just the Hutchinson River Parkway and just the Jaguar, a gift from Mr. Diller. Mind you, this was hardly the first time that she had talked about her professional and private lives, which are pretty much the same thing, but it was worth going along for the ride.
Remember the wrap dress? Surely no woman over 40 has forgotten. A Belgian-born designer who studied economics at the University of Geneva, Ms. Von Furstenberg was just 25 in 1972 when she created a little jersey dress not unlike those worn by European women. She just knew it would lure American women out of pants suits. Four years later, she had sold 30 million of the dresses -- to women of all ages, shapes and incomes -- and she was on Newsweek magazine's cover.
The strategy behind the dresses, as Ms. Von Furstenberg once put it, was simply this: "You can wear them with serious heels, serious pearls, walk into a serious restaurant, and still show your bottom."
The wrap dress lives -- and not just in costume collections and thrift shops. Sometimes when Ms. Von Furstenberg is giving a talk out of town, a woman in the audience will walk up, throw open her coat -- and smile. "I love seeing those old dresses, those old friends," she said in the car.
But she added, "I don't want to be somebody who did something when she was 25."
Her idea of not living in the past is doing a "Midnight Special" on QVC, moving 12,000 of her silk shirts, at $59.95 each, in less than 20 minutes. "Sitting in the green room and watching all the numbers come up on the computer screen is like being at a horse race," she said.
From time to time, her story was interrupted by phone calls in several languages. (She speaks four.) And once, during a chat with her housekeeper on decorating plans for "Christmas in Connecticut," there was a momentary sense that Martha Stewart had somehow commandeered the wheel.
The moment soon passed, however, as Ms. Von Furstenberg went on to talk about her strange and enchanted existence in the 80's. "I was four and a half years with Paolo and four and a half years with Alain," she said at one point. "That's my quota."
Paolo was a Brazilian art dealer with whom she shared a bamboo hut by the beach on the island of Bali. The interlude inspired her to create a perfume, Volcan d'Amour, and to decorate her Fifth Avenue offices with Balinese artifacts, including a flock of wooden geese. The geese remain, but Paolo has flown. "He's the only one I'm not still close to," she said.
After Bali came Paris, where she set up a literary salon and founded a publishing house, Salvy. "Writing is the one art I am most sensitive to," she said. "I have a weakness for writers." In particular, there was the novelist Alain Elkann, with whom she shared an apartment on the Left Bank. He's an old beau.
"Alain came three Christmases ago with his children," she recalled with a light laugh. "Funny, his children and my children are cousins, because his first wife and my first husband are cousins. There were too many around the table that day."
In the 80's, the DVF signature sold more than $1 billion worth of licensed products -- everything from eyeglasses to luggage. The royalties were rolling in, she said, but her label was being ruined by the manufacturers.
"They were doing junk," she said. "I tried to talk to them, but they wouldn't listen. I could tell they thought: 'She's a has-been. What does she know?' "
Her voice grew edgy as she described how she did what few designers have managed to do. "I decided to bite the bullet and take back my name," she said. "In some cases, I had to buy it back; in some cases, beg it back, all kind of ways. My accountant was not happy, but it was worth it to be back in fashion and beauty."
She sighed. "Those years from '89 to '92 were very difficult. I ate a lot of humble pies."
It was time for a burrito break. The Jaguar pulled into Texas Taco, a roadside spot in Patterson, N.Y., permanently decorated for Christmas -- twinkling colored lights, walls spray-painted gold, gnomes, kewpie dolls. The owner, Rosemary Jamison, had bright green hair, and "Silent Night" was playing in the bathroom.
After polishing off a burrito, some guacamole and a glass of cider, Ms. Von Furstenberg daintily pressed a napkin to her lips. "I ate like a pig in front of you," she said with a half smile. She is not an extravagant smiler. Her look, even during a "Midnight Special," is one of languor.
The final leg of the journey was marked by a near-collision with a squirrel and more talk of Mr. Diller. "We met 18 years ago and fell in love -- no question," she said. "Barry and I were together five years, from '75 to '80. He loved me unconditionally and still does.
"But our relationship is different now because it just is. He's a little bit like my husband except that we are not married. He's definitely family."
The Jaguar was almost home. Flashing by the windows were rolling hills, open fields, old stone fences. Another half smile.
"In my house you'll see where each man leaves something behind, eh?" she said. "Barry left the movie projector. Paolo left Balinese textiles, and Alain left a lot of books. A house is very much a home."
Cloudwalk Farm, at last. And leaping about on the raked gravel drive, a welcoming committee of dogs. There was her cocker spaniel, Tatiana's Dalmatian, a German shepherd that used to belong to Paolo, a couple of mutts and a Rottweiler whose mate, Alex's Rottweiler, was penned up.
She bought the farm 20 years ago with part of her wrap-dress fortune. It has an apple orchard, gardens, a stream with a waterfall and, dotted around the landscape, five 18th-century buildings. Serving as her studio is a converted tobacco barn with soaring ceilings, Warhol portraits of D.V.F., plantation chairs and a twig bed.
Always, she said, this has been "a private place," a family retreat. But that may be changing.
The stream with the waterfall was in the September issue of Vanity Fair, and so was Ms. Von Furstenberg, afloat in a cast-iron bathtub full of soap bubbles, to promote her new book, "The Bath" (Random House, $37.50). The tobacco barn was recently shown on QVC, along with the designer perched barefoot on the edge of another tub to promote her new line of home and body fragrances, Surroundings.
"Welcome to my bathroom," she said into the cameras.
Now there was to be another revelation as she set off across the lawn, dark hair flying, dogs barking. She paused before a small wooden bridge leading to the other side of the stream and a stand of red birches.
"Come," she said. "I'll show you where I'm going to be buried."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rise Sharply In Late Rally

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury market rallied sharply yesterday as strong demand at the auction for five-year notes and sudden buying interest from investors gave prices a lift on the last full day of trading before Christmas. The price of the 30-year bond jumped more than a point as the yield dropped to 6.21 percent.
"I think there was some pent-up demand waiting to get past the auctions," said John Costas, head of government trading and sales at CS First Boston. 
 Traders and investors often worry that a Treasury auction will be disappointing, so they wait until the auctions finish before they jump in.
And Mr. Costas said many traders had been selling Treasury securities recently, expecting to pick up two-year and five-year notes in the auctions Tuesday and yesterday.
 
 
Dealers Caught Short
 But when the demand at the auction turned out a lot stronger than expected, the dealers were caught without the notes they needed and had to buy in the open market.
With the light recent trading -- including a remarkably slow morning yesterday -- the sudden move carried more weight than usual, and was able to lift prices on Treasury securities across the board.
In late trading in the secondary market at 5 P.M., the price of the 30-year bond due in August 2023 was up 1 7/32 points as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.21 percent, down from 6.31 percent Tuesday. This is the lowest the yield has been since Dec. 10. The yield on the bond hit a 25-year low of 5.78 percent on Oct. 15. But since early November, the yield has been in a trading range between 6.10 and 6.38 percent and was near the top of that range yesterday.
But yesterday's rally did not change the tone or direction of the market or the outlook of traders and investors. The 30-year bond and other Treasury securities are still locked in a trading range that tends to produce selling at the top and buying at the bottom, where market prices were in early trading yesterday.
 
 
'A Christmas Present'
 "The market likes to give itself a Christmas present," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities. "But I would be surprised if it goes outside of the trading range before the end of the year."
Once the new year has arrived, though, the market is likely to be tested. While traders and investors have apparently accepted the strong 4 to 5 percent growth now assumed for the fourth quarter of this year, they are counting on the pace of growth to slow at the beginning of 1994. If it does not, then some strong selling may emerge.
Investors are also waiting on the Federal Reserve, which many analysts predict must raise short-term interest rates early in 1994 to prove its determination to keep inflation from breaking out of a two-year lull in which it has stayed under 3 percent. That expectation has already pushed short-term market rates higher.
 
 
Two-Year Note's Yield Drops
 The yield on the new two-year note, which was auctioned Tuesday, also fell sharply yesterday, ending at 4.18 percent. It was auctioned at a yield of 4.28 percent, which slipped to 4.25 percent Tuesday. But that was still the higher yield since June and the top of the recent trading range.
In the $11 billion, five-year note auction, the high yield, which all the securities are sold at, was 5.19 percent, down from the 5.20 percent of last month.
The expectation ahead of the 1 P.M. auction deadline was that the yield would be as high as 5.23 percent, so the results were quite a surprise, reflecting strong demand because dealers and their customers were willing to pay more than expected to get the new notes.
At the same time, the dealers who thought the yield would be higher and the price lower did not get any notes. Since many had already sold some to customers ahead of the auction, they had to buy the notes quickly, which helped add momentum to the rally.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 3; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Daughter of Castro Leaves Cuba And Is Given Asylum in the U.S.

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Fidel Castro's daughter has fled Cuba and has been granted political asylum in the United States, State Department officials said today.
The woman, Alina Fernandez Revuelta, arrived in Atlanta on Tuesday on a flight from Spain after her asylum request was granted by the United States Embassy in Madrid, said David Johnson, a State Department spokesman. 
 Mrs. Fernandez, who is 37, is personally and politically estranged from her father, who conceived her out of wedlock when he was a young revolutionary. She has sought to leave Cuba for years, denouncing her father as "a tyrant" and describing Cuban Communism as "a dead-end street." She fled alone, leaving her 15-year-old daughter in Havana.
Her flight is a small but significant political statement against Mr. Castro and his increasingly bedraggled 35-year-old Government.
 
Economy in Steep Decline
 Since the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe in 1989, Cuba's economy, which relied heavily on subsidies from the Soviet Union, has been in a steep decline, contracting by more than 40 percent. This year's sugar harvest was the smallest in 30 years. Annual export revenues have fallen from more than $5 billion to $1.6 billion.
The Central Intelligence Agency reported this summer that "the impact of the economic crisis on the populace has been devastating." Food shortages have caused malnutrition and disease, public transportation has collapsed and half the labor force is looking for work, the agency reported.
Political resistance to Mr. Castro is becoming louder and freer. On Friday, witnesses said, thousands of demonstrators shouting "Freedom! Freedom! Freedom!" marched 12 miles from Havana to a shrine devoted to Lazarus, the biblical figure who rose from the dead.
"This is not just an economic crisis," said Jose Cardenas, a spokesman for the Cuban American National Foundation, a Washington research group opposed to Mr. Castro. "It's something more profound. There is a political, spiritual, social crisis on the island. And that is why Alina Fernandez is important. She needed something more and that was freedom."
Mr. Castro has neither acknowledged nor denied fathering Mrs. Fernandez, who never took his surname or had a real relationship with him, according to biographers of the Cuban leader.
 
A Clandestine Courier
 Her mother, Natalia Revuelta, a wealthy, socially prominent and well-educated woman still living in Cuba, met Mr. Castro in November 1952, according to Tad Szulc's biography, "Fidel: A Critical Portrait" (William Morrow and Company, 1986).
Though married to a prominent surgeon, a heart specialist, Mrs. Revuelta fell in love with the young revolutionary as well as with his revolution. She became a clandestine courier of texts and proclamations supporting Mr. Castro in the 1950's. Their relationship took root not long after the first major uprising of Mr. Castro's revolution, the attack on the Moncada Barracks in Santiago de Cuba on July 26, 1953, celebrated annually under Mr. Castro's Government.
Their daughter, Mrs. Fernandez, was conceived in revolution but came of age in its less than glorious aftermath.
Married at least three times, thin and asthmatic, she lived with her daughter, an aspiring dancer, in a down-at-the-heels two-bedroom apartment in Havana adorned with photographs of her mother as a secretly subversive socialite in the 1950's and of herself as a fashion model in the 1980's. Her mother, Mrs. Revuelta, lived nearby and gave support both to the father of the Cuban revolution and to the child he fathered.
 
Visa Requests Denied
 Before her flight, Mrs. Fernandez had left Cuba only once, at age 8, with her mother on a trip to Paris in 1964. She was denied permission to accompany her husband, a Mexican, to Mexico City in 1986. Her requests for visas were denied as recently as last year, Mr. Cardenas said.
State Department officials and Mr. Cardenas said Mrs. Fernandez was deeply upset that word of her flight had become public, that she wanted to keep her silence for the time being and wanted most of all to be reunited with her daughter.
In Havana, the Government said it had no details on Mrs. Fernandez's case. Reuters quoted the Cuban Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina, as saying that he never commented on "those who defect," and then adding, "I think that at times like this many people have defected because the situation of the country is difficult -- and these are times in which people prove themselves."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 24, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday about the defection of Fidel Castro's daughter misstated the site of the defection in some copies. It was Madrid, not Washington.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alina Fernandez Revuelta, Fidel Castro's daughter, looking out from her apartment in Havana in 1991. The door had been decorated by her daughter, Alina. The young girl remained in Havana yesterday while her mother was granted political asylum by the United States. (Cox Newspapers)
